column2: MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., March 6.--A strike occurred at the Columbia Iron Works at Hamesport, Burlington County, yesterday, in consequence of an order being issued that all the employes should wear boots.

SYDNEY, March 6.--The Ministry of New South Wales has been defeated on the question of protection and has resigned. Sir Henry Parker will form a free trade Cabinet. He was the Prime Minister of the last Cabinet.

John A. Blair, Past Commander of Edward H. Wade Post, No. 520, G.A.R., said yesterday that he had retained counsel to recover certain household effects which were recently, without his knowledge or consent, transferred from 3 St. Luke's-place, this city, where he and his wife occupied two rooms, to Sharon, Conn.
WASHINGTON, March 6.--The Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon accepted $277,500 registered 4 percent, bonds at 108.
LEXINGTON, Ky., March 6.--William C. Baldwin of Washington, Penn., has bought of William T. Withers of Lexington, Algernon, bay colt, 3 years old, by Alecto, dam by Happy Medium, for $1,000.
ALBANY, N.Y., March 6.--Five times the case of Edgar T. Brackett, Administrator, against Chester Griswold and others has been tried and yesterday the Court of Appeals sent it back for a new trial.

ALBANY, March 6.--Three months ago John Snaith was considered one of the most honored contrastors in New-York State. To-day he is occupying the position of a fugitive from justice. The disposition which he betrayed to bring his books before Mr. Ainsworth's appropriations committee is only equaled by his indisposition ...

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 6.--The Mahoning National Life Association, doing an insurance business on the mutual assessment plan, failed to-day and asked as order of court for dissolution. D.E. Stevens the President, was appointed ...
A circular was yesterday sent out from the headquarters of the American Federation of Labor to the national and international unions affiliated with it.

Two clubs, which have had their headquarters in West Twenty-fourth-street for six or seven years, have outgrown the accommodations that sufficed hitherto, and appointed committees to scour the city for better quarters.

The big room in Commissioner Fink's office was occupied from noon until 5:30 yesterday afternoon by representatives of the Central Traffic Association, the Executive Committee of the Trunk Lines Association, and the General Passenger Agents of the trunk lines, and of ...
WASHINGTON, March 6.--A meeting of the Department of Superintendence of the National Educational Association was held at the Hall of the National Museum to-day.
The following special dispatch was received yesterday from St. Paul:

LONDON, March 6.--The abdication of King Milan will create considerable uneasiness on the Continent, chiefly because M. Ristics, who is left in charge, has no majority back of him, either in the Skuptsohina or the country, and has intrigued equally with Russia and Austria.

Mss. Emily O. Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seth R. Johnson, was married last evening at the home of her parents, 1,069 Bergen-street, Brooklyn, to Thomas J. Esterbrook, the well-known baseball player.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 6.--The fates seem to be against Harvard in athletics, for she has now suffered a loss that materially lessens what chance she had for success on the baseball field this year. Luce, the most promising candidate for pitcher, has gone out of practice.

HAVANA, March 6.--The third and last game in the new chess contest was opened with the Evans gambit. There were 33 moves made. Steinitz and Gavilan played against Tschigorin and Ponce and won the game.

Edwin E. Littlefield, aged 18 years, a clerk employed by Owens Co., coal dealers, left his house, 70 East One Hundred and Sixteenth-street, on Sunday last with the intention of going to a museum, and since then no trace of him can be found.
Capt. Walter G. Schuvler of the NewYork Athletic Club returned to this city yesterday from Washington, where, with his regiment, the Seventh, he took part in the inaugural ceremonies.

At the annual meeting of the Texas Pacific Railroad Company in this city yesterday Jay Gould and his party resumed control of the property. President Roberts of the Pennsylvania Railroad and the other independent Directors were dropped from the board and Gould men given their places.

Speculation in copper in this city waits on London and Paris at present. Therefore the dealers and brokers on the Metal Exchange who, until lately, have been putting up margins on the ups and downs of the French syndicate, contented themselves yesterday with looking wise, but keeping quiet. No man dared to open his mouth to make a bid and not a single transaction in this commodity market the day.

UTICA, N.Y., March 6.--In the town of NewHartford, Where there was a tie on the vote for Supervisor, the Town Board has appointed a Republican. The new Oneida County Board of Supervisors therefore stands; Republicans, 23; Democrats, 20, a Republican gain of two.

A sadder man--one more completely filled with disgust at deception practiced on him-- than Controller Myers cannot be found in NewYork. He is at last convinced that there was rascality committed by men to whom he intrusted the details of distributting stands in the new West Washington Market.

TRENTON, N.J., March 6.--The Democrats in the Senate to-day could not pass the Werts local option repealer because Senator Adrain was absent from the morning session, and Senators Piraffer and Smith were not present in the afternoon.

At All Saints' Episcopal Church, in Henry-street, special religious services were held last night in celebration of the thirtieth anniversary of the ordination of the Rector, the Rev. William N. Dunnell, to the diaconate. Mr. ...
The Central Railroad of New Jersey will on Sunday next open its new line from NewYork through to Baltimore and Washington.

CAMPBELLFORD, Ontario, March 6.--The Orange Grand Lodge of Eastern Ontario to-day passed a resolution condemning the action of the Quebec and Dominion Governments in the Jesuit estates matter, indorsing Col. O'Brien's intention of asking the Dominion Parliament to disallow the bill, and resolving that they themselves petition, and that they request the 400 lodges in their jurisdiction to petition, the Governor-General to disallow the bill.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 6.--To-day the Supreme Court of Louisianna reversed the judgment of the Criminal Court and remanded the celebrated case of the State against Louis Claire, John Gibson, and William Feehan for a new trial.
The owner of the midget horse Baby Bunting, which is making the rounds of the city dime museums, and his manager, L.W. Hoffman, are at odds.
CHICAGO, March 6.--Newton Watt, who was convicted of the murder of Express Messenger Kellogg Nichols, and died in the penitentiary, was buried here to-day.

WASHINGTON, March 6.--The Union League of America to-day unanimously elected officers, as follows: President-Gen. Charles H. Grosvenor of Ohio; Vice-Presidents--William E. Chandler of New-Hampshire, Thomas R. Rich of Maryland, John F. Bryant of Georgia, Nathan Goff of ...

MONTREAL, March 6.--J.B. Hegue of Peoria, Ill., a capitalist, who is in the habit of floating companies and bringing out new inventions, obtained the patent on a new gas-burner, and engaged Austin D. Cable as agent here. He canvassed the cities thoroughly, and at times received orders for 300 dozen burners.

BOSTON, March 6.--The Hon. Sidney Bartlett, a leader of the Boston Bar and a Director of the Chicago Burlington and Quincy Railroad, is dying, Mr. Bartlets celebrated his ninetieth birthday in February.
MARTINSVILLE, West Va., March 6.--Notwithstanding the fact that from 200 to 300 dogs suspected of being mad or infected to some degree with rabies have been killed in this (Wetzel) ...

An attendant at the New-York City Asylum for the Insane on Ward's Island, while making his rounds through the corridors early yesterday morning discovered Joseph Phrym, a Bohemian cigarmaker who had been confined in the institution for melancholia since 1882, hanging dead in his cell.

CHICAGO, March 6.--The American Trotting Association spent the forenoon to-day in an informal discussion of certain proposed changes in the rules. These changes are extensive enough to cover 15 closely type-written pages, and are designed to remedy defects in the existink rules and to cover a large number of individual

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 6.--Herbort Hance, the proprietor of a country store at Point Pleasant City, the seaside resort at the head of Barnegat Bay, is dying from the results of an attack upon him a few nights ago by unknown persons.

ST. AUGUSTINE. Fla., March 6.--Among those who have recently arrived are Mr. and Mrs. William H. Lefferts, Master Lefferts, Miss Elsie A. Crane, Dr. and Mrs. F.M. Hossmer, Mr. and Mrs. James M. Hartshorne, Miss Hartshorne ...

Mr. JOHN WANAMAKER was duly installed in the office of Postmaster-General yesterday. Though he is from the Quaker City, he is not a member of the Society of Friends, and it is fair to assume that he waived the constitutional privilege of ...

PARIS, March 6.--It is again asserted that M. Deufert Rochereau, a Director of the Comptoir d'Escompte, whose death was announced yesterday, committed suicide. The weapon with which he is said to have killed himself was a revolver.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 6.--Grand Army men here are much interested over two things, one being the refusal of the Alinshouse Board to appoint David Hitchcock, an honorably ...
BOSTON, March 6.--Everybody anticipated a tumble in copper stock to-day, and under the influence of the morning news from abroad the feeling at the opening was one of gloom indeed.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 6.--A rather authentic report leaked out here to-day to the effect that tha Iron Steamboat Company will not run boats to and from this place the coming season.
On the 10th inst. the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad will formally open its trunk line from New-York, and run solid trains to Washington and the West without change of cars, as hitherto.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 6.--The gold excitement in Lower California, near Ensenada, is increasing, and many people are flocking from San Diego to the gold fields.
BOSTON, March 6.--For some time past the question of the consolidation of the branch lines of the Union Pacific system centring in Ogden has been under consideration.
BISMARCK, Dakota, March 6.--Yesterday was a red-letter day in both houses. The Swanston Railroad bill, passed by the House, is a heartless measure, and leaves capital and industrial interests on top.

The Juniors of the School of Mines, Columbia College, have a bonanza scheme on hand. They have leased the entire seven floors of the Pottier Stymus Manufacturing Company Building, at Fifth-avenue and Forty-second-street, for March 21,22, and 23, and are ...
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 6.--The Northwestern Miller to-day says:

Judge Ingraham of the Supreme Court has dismissed the complaint in the suit of George B. Ellery against Henry R. Cassel, and made an allowance of $500 to the defendant. This was the second trial of the suit, in the first the jury having disagreed.
Samuel A. Green, a countryman from Schoharie County, was at Castle Garden yesterday looking for a wife. He is a widower 55 years of age.
LONDON, March 6.--Queen Victoria sailed from Portsmouth to-day for Cherbourg, on her way to Blarritz.

Robert Garrett, ex-President of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, who since last Summer has been living is seclusion at Ringwood, N.J., attended by private physicians, has so far recovered from his mental malady that he was able to depart upon a railway trip to Mexico yesterday.
Mrs. Langtry will appear as Pauline in "The Lady of Lyons" at the Harlem Theatre Comique to-night.
The following was sent to the Mayor this afternoon:
WASHINGTON, March 6.--Commissioner Stockslagen of the General Land Office has rendered a decision in the Tumacacori and Calabazas private land claim in Arizona.

DETROIT, March 6.--The annual meeting of the Grand Rapids and Indiana Railroad Company was held in Grand Rapids to-day. The total earnings for 1888 were $2,842,363 16, a decrease of $111,593 99 from 1887, and the net ...

The Special Committee of the Board of Education has prepared a report in favor of abolishing the present marking system in the public schools. It recommends, also, the abolition of the system of examinations for promotion except in cases of ...

While the United States, after an experience of nearly a century with immigrants from Europe, is endeavoring to hit upon some just and proper plan for restricting immigration and confining it to those who promise to make good and valuable citizens, the nations of South America, ...

When President Harrison turns his attention to Kings County's Federal offices he will find a lot of very hungry and very thirsty politicians waiting for him. Instead of being appeased by Gen. Tracy's appointment as Secretary of the Navy the appetites of these gentlemen have been vastly increased.

Frank Perry, the Superintendent of Henderson Morris's brass works, at Bedford-avenue and North Eleventh-street. Williamsburg, has been missing for several days. He is 40 years old, and lived with his wife and family at 374 South Second-street.

Mrs. Mary Martin, the young wife of Michael Martin, a hack driver who lived in a furnished room on the third floor of the house of N.H. Duggan, 997 Third-avenue, was assaulted with a smoothing iron last night by Louis Beauchamp, a hack driver, and was fatally injured.
The Atlas Line steamship Andes arrived at this port yesterday from Port Limon, bringing reports of the Haytian war. She left Portau-Prince on Feb. 4.

BERLIN, March 6.--The National Gazette, commenting on President Harrison's inaugural address, says: "There is no reason to doubt the President's pacific principles or the siucerity of his opinion regarding the peaceful adjustment of international difficulties, although he recommends the strengthening of the navy.

Judas Iscariot and five other street vendors, were fined $5 each by Judge Gorman yesterday for loitering over 10 minutes in one spot. They went to jail, not being possessed of the money to pay the fine.

In the House of Representatives at Austin, Texas, Representative Hamblen, on behalf of the citizens of Houston, yesterday presented a gold medal, set with diamonds, to Miss Annie E. Dowling only child of Dick Dowling, who, on Sept. 8, 1863, in command of only 42 men held at bay and drove off from the Sabine Pass Union forces of more than a thousand men.

PATERSON, N.J., March 6.--A man giving his name as James Godwin, who says he is a Scotchman, was arrested here to-day on suspicion of being the murderer of Mrs. Wilson, who was killed at Braintree, Mass., in December last.
Patrolman John A. Logan of the Fourteenth Precinct, Brooklyn, was to have been married yesterday to Miss Josie Vossig of 588 Wythe-avenue, but he disappeared on Monday, and has not since been seen.

The two prisoners whom Lieut. Arthur Dillingham, United States Navy, brought home recently from the Pacific are now under trial before a general court-martial at the Boston Navy Yard. They are William J. Healy, able seamen, and William Ogg, Ordinary seaman.

ITHACA, March 6.--By its first election under a city charter John Barden (Dem.) was elected Mayor by five votes more than Warren Hunt (Rep.) received in a total poll of 2,227. As the Mayor's term of office is two years and he has autocratic powers of appointment, the Republicans publicans are greatly chagrined at the loss of ...
Many complaints have been made lately to Chief Inspector Byrnes about the swindling operations of a young man who calls himself Albert Morris, but whose real name is believed to be Albert Meyerheins.
LOUISVILLE, March 6.--The work of laying pipes to bring natural gas to this city has been in progress some time.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 6.--Kansas City has furnished Secretary Blaine with probably his first official business with a foreign country. The facts of an interesting occurrence which led to a telegram being sent from here by the Humane Society to the State Department this afternoon are as follows:
CHICAGO, March 6.--As expected, the Wabash Railway is preparing to kick over the traces on account of the action of the Kansas City lines in resuming the fast train service.
TEMPLE, Texas, March 6.--An awful tragedy was enacted on the streets of Temple yesterday. Alfred and Herbert Rother engaged in a gun fight with Tom and Hugh Mattock.
ROME, March 6.--The Riforma says it learns that ex-Gov. Porter of Indiana will succeed Judge Stallo as American Minister at Rome.

BOSTON, March 6.--A cablegram received here by the agent states that Capt. Anderson and crew of the schooner Electric Light. Portland for Buenos Ayres, before reported passed at sea on fire and abandoned, arrived to-day at St. Vincent, Cape Verde Islands. All well.

There was a lively little discussion in the Aqueduct Board yesterday. Mayor Grant started it by refusing to vote for the payment of bills for the transportation of engineers and inspectors along the line of the aqueduct.

ALBANY, March 6.--The first order for the big celebration in April was issued from the Adjutant General's office to-day by Gen. Porter. It announces that the National Guard will take part in the centennial celebration of the inauguration of the first President of the United States, at the city of New-York, the 30th of April next.

NYACK, March 6.--The Rockland County Historical and Forestry Society, including in its membership the most prominent citizens of the county, is making an effort to have a building of its own in which to store historic relies and other property of the society.
At the twenty-eighth sale of paintings in aid of the Artists' Fund Society at 366 Fifthavenue last night $7,910 was realized, without including the prices set on the frames.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 6.--At a mass meeting of college students to-day F.S. Miller, '90, of New-York, and A.D. Wilson, '91, of Pennsylvania were respectively elected President and Treasurer of the Football Association for the ensuing year.
LONDON, March 6.--Viscount Mandeville, eldest son of the Duke of Manchester, has been declared a bankrupt. His liabilities are officially placed at $600,000.
The body of an unknown man was found in the East Dale Shelter, at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. He had shot himself in the head.

The Executive Committee of the National Association of Amateur Athletes held a short meeting last night of the Windsor Hotel to consider the protests made at the last meeting of the association in the Madison-Square Garden. There were present G.L.M. Sacks of the Manhattan Club, D.J. Cox of the Brightons, Mr. Ware of the Crescents, C.J. Harvey, and J.D. Douglas.
NORWICH, Conn., March 6.--For nearly a quarter of a century Charles Noyes, the veteran keeper of the Latimer light, opposite the historic and antiquated borough of Stonington, ...

ST. PAUL, March 6.--The movement of wheat from farmers' granaries in Minnesota and Dakota is materially less than a few days ago. During the first half of February there was very little moving, but in the last half the movement was the largest of the Winter.
The first regular monthly shoot of the Fountain Gun Club at Woodlawn Park yesterday was not so well attended as the members expected. Owing to the high wind the scores ...

ALBANY, March 6.--The Central Cross-town Railroad Compans shows excellent results from its operations the last quarter of 1888. Its net income was a fourth of the gross earnings. The comparisons with the same quarter last year show:
The funeral services of Col. William W. Stephenson took place from the Simpson Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon.

James Doyle, aged 60, of 322 West Fiftythird-street was convicted of grand larceny in the first degree before Judge Gildersleeve yesterday for misappropriating trust funds left by his brother, William Doyle. William, who was a prosperous builder, died suddenly Feb. 2, 1887. Two years before this he had called his relatives about him and, by word of month, distributed his ...

Ex-Alderman Arthur J. McQuade, who may be tried in Saratoga, in June, for his connection with the Broad way surface road's franchise, called at the District Attorney's office yesterday to renew his twenty-thousand-dollar bail bond. On the old bond Thomas J. Dunn of 321 East Sixty-eighthstreet, Anthony Gorman, and Julius Goodby were the sureties. On the new one Dunn, a relative of McQuade, shoulders the whole responsibility.

CHARLESTON, West Va., March 6.--Mr. R.R. Carr, President of the State Senate, to-day moved on Gov. E.W. Wilson with a writ of quo warran to compel him to show by what right he continues to hold the Gubernatorial chair.

LONDON, March 7.--In the event of the Parnell Commission presenting no interim report on the forged letters, the Opposition contemplate a motion to adjourn in order to call attention to the action of the Government in aiding the prosecution to collect evidence, or an address to the Crown ragarding the expenses of the commission.
WORCESTER, Mass., March 6.--A verb peculiar accident happened at the works of the Richardson Manufacturing Company in this city this afternoon, when a section of the floor of their ...

Manager Aronson yesterday refused to sell the entire orchestra for the performance of 'Nadjy" on the evenings of April 29 and 30, although the person making the offer claimed to do it on behalf of the Centennial Committee. Mr. Aronson thought it would be unfair to the public to give it no choice of seats on these two ...
At the annual meeting of the German Society of the City of New-York yesterday the following officers were re-elected: President-- Charles Hauselt; First Vice-President-G. ...

Twenty clerks of a leading fire insurance company have formed a close corporation for the purpose of investing their savings in the reinsurance of risks which are not considered first-class by the company which accepted them.

At yesterday's meeting of the Board of Education the special committee of eight submitted its report in reply to the memorial of the Public Education Society. The committee divided the memorial into three separate heads, dealing with accommodations provided, courses and methods of instructions, and administration.

"Nothing like it has been seen here since the time of the old Ellsworth Zouaves," said an enthusiastic veteran who watched the splendid exhibition drill given by the Toledo (Ohio) cadets, Capt. William V. McMaken, at the ...

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 6.--Reports from up the river to-night show that all the ice in the Hudson, from Germantown south, is on the move, and it is believed a boat will be able to reach Albany by Saturday without much difficulty.
NEWARK, N.J., March 6.--The New-Jersey Trades Assembly, at a meeting here to-night, adopted an amendment to their by-laws prohibiting the Knights of Labor from representation.

WASHINGTON, March 6.--At to-day's session of the conference of State Railroad Commissions Commissioner Crocker of Massachusetts introduced a resolution recommending persistent efforts toward the bringing about of a more uniform classification of freights as a benefit to shippers and railroads.

The work of formally presenting evidence at the second trial of Thomas B. Kerr, the Treasurer of the Broadway Surface Railway Company, indicted for bribing the Board of Aldermen of 1884, was begun yesterday morning. It was the eighteenth day of the Extraordinary Term of the Court of Oyer and Terminer, convened for the case, but Judge Daniels was seated on the bench promptly, as usual.
WICHITA, Kan., March 6.--Yesterday Ira Campbell of this city moved to a farm 14 miles northwest of here, and at 10 o'olock last night he was visited by White Caps.

P. Rockwell, who owns the bakery at Third-avenue and Ninth-street, is angry and yearning for the scalps of some thieves who have been stealing his horse blankets. Yesterday he published an advertisement offering $100 reward for information that would lead to their arrest and conviction.

United States Commissioner Shields listened to a great quantity of testimony yesterday in the case of Meyer Sollaway, or Soloman, who was arrested for perjury in the procurance of naturalization papers when he had not been long enough in the country to be entitled to them.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 6.--The Custom House officers made an important seizure of opium on the steam collier Empire this morning from Departure Bay. About 700 boxes, valued at $4,200 were captured. Edward Jansen and John Gaven, sailors, were arrested for the smuggling.

The annual meeting of the Bee Line stockholders was held yesterday. The total earnings of the road for 1888 were $7,611,000, a decrease of almost a half million from the year previous. George S. Russell was elected Treasurer, and J.T. Wann Secretary of the company.
TROY, N.Y., March 6.--Catherine Taylor, a widow, aged about 50 years, was murdered in her bed at her home, 330 Third-avenue, West Troy, about 9:30 o'clock last night.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 6.--After a spirited debate the State Senate this morning passed a bill completely changing the election laws of this State. There were 21 affirmative votes, 7 Democrats and 2 Republicans voting in the negative.
ALBANY, N.Y., March 6.--The State Civil Service Board makes the following announcement:
MIDDLETOWN, N.J., March 6.--Early yesterday morning the house of Andrew Winter, near Chapel Hill, caught fire.

After choir practice on Saturday night Deacon Tibb climbed into the left over the choir gallery, on his way to the belfry, carrying a lantern and a can of oil. He intended to lubricate the machinery of the bell, because its squeaking on the previous Sabbath had excited unfavorable comment in the village.

The opinion of Judge Benedict in the case of the Conserva, the libel on which was dismissed on Saturday, was filed yesterday in the United States Court, Brooklyn. Judge Benedict finds that the evidence failed to show that this Government was under any obligations of ...

Police Sergeants of the regular line, as well as the Detective Sergeants, will be paid at the rate of $2,000 a year, beginning April 1, There age 200 of them altogether.
William Hildreth Field was yesterday appointed the third Commissioner of the Supervisory Board of the municipal service by Mayor Grant.
That much--heralded "inauguration boom" is done and forgotten, poor thing! Yesterday's stock market was weak. Only one or two stocks on the whole list showed strength; not one displayed buoyancy.

Inspector Byrnes received dispatched yesterday from his officers, who are en route for this city, having in custody Mrs. Olive E. Friend, W.E. Howard and his wife Emily, and Augustus and George Heistead, who were indicted here for the Electric Sugar swindle, stating that they will arrive here to-day. The officers in charge of the prisoners are Detective Sergeant Ruland, Creed, McKought, and Heard, and Deputy Sheriff Dwyer of Washtesan County, Mich.

ST. PAUL, March 6.--Officials of the Minneapolis and St. Louis Road have taken the bull by the horns, so to speak, and brought the members of the Western Freght Association to a sense of the state of affairs in this section by reducing lumber rates from Minneapolis

The Willets Manufacturing Company, which carried on the Excelsior Pottery at Trenton, N.J., with a capital stock of $30,000, was reportod in difficulties yesterday. The stock of the company is all in the hands of Messrs. Edmund R. Joseph, and Daniel Willets. The company's agent in this city, at 50 Barclay-street, says the embarrassment is only temporary and that the aasets far exceed all liabilities.

WASHINGTON, March 6.--The army of paraders has gone, but the legion of office seekers has taken its place. The place hunters swarm in all the hotels in sufficient numbers to insure a good business from that class of people alone for some time to come.

The thieves who have robbed the State under pretext of building a new ceiling for the Assembly Chamber seem to take the same light and jocose view of their crime that is customary in this country when the crime is connected with "politics." The ...

A crowd of curious people stood all yesterday afternoon in the bleak station of the New-Jersey Central Railroad in Jersey City awaiting the arrival of Mr. and Mrs. Grover Cleveland, who were on their way from Washington to New-York on a special train over the Baltimore and Ohio Road.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 6.--Gov. Seay filled the new Supreme Court Judgeship recently created by act of the Legislature by appointing the Hon. Thomas N. McClellan, for the past five years Attorney-General of the State, to the place. Mr. McClellan is only 36 years old, and is the youngest man who ever filled a place on the Supreme Court Bench of Alabama.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 6.--The South Boston Iron Works Company made three preliminary test shots to-day, at the naval proving grounds, with the pneumatic gun carriage.

BELGRADE, March 6.--King Milan issued a decree this afternoon adbicating the throne of Servia in favor of his son Alexander, who will reign under the title of Alexander I. The decree appoints M. IOVAR Ristitch and Gens. Protiteh and Beilmarkovic Regents during the minority of Alexander, who is 13 years old.

MONTREAL, March 6.--The colony of American citizens making a temporary stay in Canada is stirred to its depths, and dismay is spread through its ranks. For a long time the tendency has been toward a stricter dealing with boodlers who were making Canada their place ...
RED BANK, N.J., March 6.--The Eintracht gave their first annual ball last evening in Bergen's Hall. Delegations from German societies at Long Branch and Keyport were present.

MIDDLETOWN, N.J., March 6.--The Republicans of Middletown Township have nominated the following ticket: Assessor--Rutsen S. Snyder; Town Clerk--George Brannin; Collector-- Capt. Benjamin Griggs; Overseer of the Poor-- William T. Franklin; Township Committee-- Dr. J.H. Van Mater; Commissioners of Appeal ...

READING, Penn., March 6.--The failure of the Reading Iron Works has caused a great flurry among iron men throughout this section. Last night the rolling mills at Naomi and Gibraltar, Berks county, the greater portion of whose products were received by the Reading from Works, closed down for want of orders, and this ...

NEW-ORLEANS, March 6.--The Rev. Max Heller, rabbi of the Temple Sinai, and Miss Ida Marks, a young leader in Jewish social circles, were married to-day in the presence of a large congregation in the temple.

The Irish National League is threatened with a civil warfare which may prove at least a great stumbling block to the success of the organization, if it does not end in an open rupture between some of the most important councils. Already there is much bad feeling, and this is increasing almost daily.

The annual auction sale of seats in the callroom of the Produce Exchange was held yesterday afternoon and the result very clearly indicated that the importance of the call has sunk very low in the general estimation of traders. In 1887 the premiums paid for seats amounted to nearly $3,000; last year they ...
The police were not able yesterday to find William D. Sproal, the manner of the fruit department in the wholesale grocery of Austin, Nichols Co., at Hudson and Jay streets, who is missing.

The trial of Mrs. Harriet L. Lane's suit against her father-in-law, Maltby G. Lane, to have set aside two mortgages of $2,500 each on Bay Ridge property and her dower interest in the property, took place yesterday before ...

NEWARK, N.J., March 6.--Capt. Richard Petter, who commands the steamship Santiago of the Wilson Line, came here a day or two ago to visit F.J. Griffith, Assistant Superintendent of the Morris and Essex Railroad.

At the meeting of citizens held in Union Hill Tuesday night to consider the question of splitting Hudson County and organizing Hoboken and the North townships into the new county of Hamilton, Mr. Hamilton V. Meeks, ...
The entries for five events of the Maryland Jockey Club meeting, which closed March 1, exceed those of last year in the aggregate by three.
WASHINGTON, March 6.--At the expiration of each Congress the gavel used by the Speaker of the House in preserving order is always presented to him as a memento of his services in the chair.

A somewhat romantic story is brought to light by the suicide of Dr. Charles A. Hopf, a German druggist, who lived on the third floor of 74 Second-avenue. Dr. Hopf visited Hahn's saloon at, 21 Tompkins-avenue, Brooklyn, on Tuesday, and, after taking a drink, sat at a

WATERBURY, Conn., March 6.--When it was stated yesterday that Silas B. Terry had resigned his position as Deacon in the First Congregational Church, having previously given up the office of Sunday School Superintendent, gossip went to work, and it did not have to go far, ...
The Russian papers are publishing various statements according to which the Russian branch of the English family Lesley has recently inherited in England a legacy of some 10,000,000.

ALBANY, March 7.--It is plain from the developments in the ceiling scandal since the Fish committee began to angle for facts that the public must expect a tall amount of lying before the thing is finished. The matter has reached such a pass that the people who are involved ...

LONDON, March 7.--The British man-of-war Sultan has been wrecked on the Island of Comino, in the Mediterranean. The Captain and crew were saved. The Sultan was an iron armor-plated vessel of 9,290 tons. She was temporarily attached to the Mediterranean squadron.

PITTSBURG, March 7.--The sewer-pipe men, who have held several meetings in this city, will hold another meeting next week, when a schedule of prices will be arranged to govern the Spring trade. Nearly all of the manufacturers in the country are now in the association, and it ...

An act of Congress says that "on the admission of a new State into the Union, one star shall be added to the union of the flag, and such addition shall take effect on the fourth day of July then next succeeding such admission."

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 7.--In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Weldon asked what instructions, if any, had been given to the Shipping Master in St. John, New-Brunswick, as to the shipping of seamen in United States vessels.

Mrs. Fannie A. Loewenstein made application to Surrogate Ransom yesterday to be released from the bond of Emily J. Earl as Administratrix of William H. Sibley, who died in 1848. She had gone on the bond with J.P. Johnson Howard, who is now in Sing Sing for his great activity as a straw bondsman. William C.B. Thornton opposed the motion.

George H. Baldwin, a prominent lawyer of White Plains, and Miss Kate D. Wilson, daughter of Mrs. H. Wilson of Lord-avenue, Bergen Point, N.J., were married at the residence of the bride's mother on Wednesday evening. Miss Ada Low of Bayonne, N.J., was maid of honor and Farrington M. Thompson of White Plains best man.

Mrs. Olive E. Friend, William E. Howard and his wife, and George and Augustus Halstead, the five persons who were arrested in Michigan for the famous electric sugar fraud, arrived in town yesterday morning with a guard of detectives and went to Police Headquarters.

The young man who committed suicide by shooting himself in the head on Wednesday in Prospect Park was identified yesterday as David F. Moody, 24 years old, who had lived with his father and sister at 86 Sterling-place.
Judge Lawrence of the Supreme Court yesterday granted a writ of habeas corpus, retunable Monday morning, against Superintendent Macdonald of the insane asylum on Ward's Island.
ALBANY, March 7.--The New-York Life Insurance Company is the last of the big companies to make its report to the Superintendent of Insurance for the year 1888.
Gen. O.O. Howard, commander of the Division of the Atlantic of the United States Army, was installed a member of U.S. Grant Post, G.A.R., in the Johnson Building, Brooklyn, last night.

CHARLESTON, West Va., March 7.--The initial step was taken in the Supreme Court to-day by Gen. Goff's attorneys suing out a writ of mandamus against Gov. Wilson to compel him to surrender the office fo Governor to Gen. Goff.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 7.--Mayor Grier of this city issued a proclamation to-day calling upon all the citizens to lend their active aid in making the demonstration on April 29 in honor of President Harrison's passage through the city a memorable event.
A White Star Line steamship, bound west, was passed March 7 in lat. 40 49, lon. 67 87. A Rotterdam steamship, bound west was passed ...

Chief of Police Murphy of Jersey City was notified by the New-Brunswick Police yesterday that a gang of pickpockets had passed through that place on their way from Washington, where they had been attending the inaugural.

CHICAGO, March 7.--A dispatch from Oklahoma, Indian Territory, says: "The situation in Oklahoma is growing critical. Between 200 and 300 men have taken up claims in the immediate vicinity of this place.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 7.--There is another virulent outbreak of pleuro-pneumonia among cattle of the town of Monroe, this county.

Miles O'Brien, Assignee of the dry goods firm of J. C. Johnston, Broadway and Twenty-second-street, has sold the entire stock of the Assignors to Jordan, Marsh Co., a retail dry goods firm of Boston, for about $112,000.
Another gala performance will occur at the Casino to-night on the occasion of the two hundredth representation of Chassaigne's sparkling operetta, "Nadjy."

ATLANTA, Ga., March 7.--The Farmers' Alliance has swept everything before it in this State, and now virtually dictates the movements of the politicians. The county merchants have been pushed to the wall in many instances, and county warehouses have been established by the alliance men. The work for a State Exchange has been completed.
ST. LOUIS, March 7.--Information comes from Padueah, Ky., that Mitchell Peebles and his wife and two children were found murdered in bed in their home on Duck Creek this morning.

Little of interest was developed yesterday in the course of the inquiry by the Commissioners of Accounts into the distribution of stands in the new West Washington Market. No more testimony respecting the procurement of "presents" by Clerk Henry Woltman for helping persons to get stands was given.
TROY, N.Y., March 7.--William Taylor was araigned before Justice Grogan, at West Troy, to-day, on suspicion of murdering his mother, Mrs. Catherine Taylor.

It was reported yesterday that Corporation Counsel Beekman had drawn up for submission to the Legislature a bill intended to provide for the appointment by the Mayor of a commission to consider the rapidtransit matter in its entirety.
WASHINGTON, March 7.--The third and last day's session of the conference of State Railroad Commissioners with the Inter-State Commerce Commission was held in the office of the commission to-day.

NORWALK, Conn., March 7.--The condensing factory at Hawleyville is to be closed April 1. The Orange County Milk Association, which leased the property for five years, expecting to buy it if profitable, has not been able to ...

PORTLAND, Oregon, March 7.--A Port Townsend special says: Chief Officer Smith of the British bark Port Gordon arrived from Quinault Reservation last night on the tug Sea Lion with 12 of the crew. He reports that the vessel was lost at 5 o'clock on the morning of Feb. ...

Ex-President Grover Cleveland and Mrs. Cleveland, ex-Postmaster-General Don M. Dickinson and wife, and Danial Lamont and wife occupied a box at the Broadway Theatre last evening, and applauded little ...

ST. LOUIS, March 7.--Advices from East Tennessee say a party of mountain desperadoes, headed by the notorious "Clabe" Watson, Lee Watson, "Bill" Turner, and Judson Bell, attacked the camps of Hay Rivenac, railroad contractors, at work near Cumberland Gap.

Additional reports concerning the Haytian difficulty were received in this city yesterday in a letter to Mr. Frank Frazier of 290 Broadway, from W.G. Marsh, an English-American in Legitime's army at Mont Rouis. Marsh was Master-at-arms on board the United States corvette Bear during the Greely relief expedition ...

OTTAWA, March 7.--The incandescent electric lighting patent held by the Edison Electric Light Company has been declared null and void in Canada on the ground of failure to comply with the patent regulations which provide that the article thus patented must be manufactured in Canada within one year from the issue of the patent, and the imposition of the same patent from the United States must cease within two years.

Rembrandt's famous picture, "The Gilder," recently purchased by Mr. H.O. Havemeyer from Mr. William Sohaus, has been loaned by Mr. Havemeyer to the Metropolitan Museum of Art for exhibition for an indefinite period. The picture will be hung on Monday next in the Marquand Gallery, where Mr. Havemeyer already has two other paintings by the same great master on exhibition.

HARTFORD, March 7.--Mr. Charles J. Hoadly, the State Librarian in the Capitol here, is the only person in the United States, so far as known, who owns copies of the Weekly Journal issued by the Continental Congress in 1779. A few copies, some of them duplicating Mr. Hoadly's, are preserved in the New-York State Library.

The newly-organized "Mets" will soon meet at 21 Park-row to proceed further with the organization. Every man of the old team, with the exception of Esterbrook and Hankinson, can be had for the club. "Jack" Lynch will do nearly all of the pitching.

A suit won by losing it is that of John G. Maier against the city, decided yesterday by the Supreme Court. Maier owned land through which Volkmar-street was ordered to be opened in 1880, but this was never done.

Detective Sergeant Rogers of Police Headquarters arrested a man at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre last night, said to be a conductor on the New-York and New-England Railroad. The prisoner was charged with stealing a pair of the theatre's opera classes.

A brave but fruitless struggle against a death from drowning was made by Thomas Lawsen, a Norwegian seaman, who fell overboard last Sunday night from the steamer State of Texas, when just off Cape Hatteras.
The projected railroad from the West shore station at Weehawken to Englewood, N. J., has been abandoned. The line carried the road through the Meeks estate, and the owners strongly opposed it.

HARTFORD, March 7.--The hearing on the Secret Ballot bill was begun this afternoon. The legislative committee from the State labor organizations was represented by Ira F. Balch of Manchester, Thomas H. Kehoe of New-Britain, George W. Hewitt of Groton, and Charles B. Leonard of this city.

The cable announcement of yesterday that the Pope was about to write an encyclical on the necessity of maintaining peace has created curiosity in many quarters as to the probable scope of the letter. Well-informed clergymen whom a TIMES reporter interviewed ...
PARIS, March 7.--The officers of the Comptoir d'Escompte were crowded to-day with persons awaiting to withdraw their deposits. The Bourse was agitated. Societe des Metaux shares fell ...
LONDON, March 7.--The Inman Line steamship City of New-York, Capt. Watkins, sld. from Queenstown for New-York to-day.
Mr. George Inness, the artist, writes to THE TIMES from Montclair, N.J., under date of March 6, as follows:
CHICAGO, March 7.--Joseph A. Moore, the Indianapolis insurance agent who embezzled $500,000 and fled to Canada, is reported to have spent to-day in Chicago.

They have so many peach stones in Vaca Valley, California, that they have had to invent some way to get rid of them. It occurred to some wiser mind than the average that peach pits will burn, so he tried it, and sure enough they made a warm fibre.

The interesting address of Mr. POST, President of the Department of Docks, delivered yesterday to the Chamber of Commerce, gives an instructive account of the commercial necessities of this port.
Robert Sigel, chief clerk in the Pension Bureau in this city, was indicted yesterday on two charges of forgery by the United States Grand Jury.

Three men intent on robbery were thwarted early yesterday morning in attempts to break into two Chinese laundries near Police Headquarters. They first went to the basement of 79 East Houston-street and were trying to force the door when the proprietor, Kum Wah, ...
An ice inspector who has made the tour of the Hudson River icehouses reports that the crop harvested this season is only from onehalf to three-fifths as large as the average.
PITTSBURG, March 7.--In an interview at Youngstown, Ohio, to-day, Dr. M.S. Clark, one of the Trustees of the Mahoning National Life Association, which collapsed yesterday, said ...
NEW-ORLEANS, March 7.--Early the morning Farantas Theatre, at Orleans and Bourbon streets, was burned.

LONDON, March 7.--Lord George Hamilton, First Lord of the Admiralty, stated in the House of Commons to-day that the delay in supplying the navy with guns was due to the failure of the system of lining. All the ships, he said, would be supplied by the end of the present year.

M. Coquelin will bid farewell to America at the Star Theatre in this city, where he will appear with his French company during the week of March 25, giving six evening performances and a Saturday matinee of French comedy.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, March 7.--W.F. Becker, student at Wittenberg College, after a two weeks' career of glory, has been found guilty of plagiarism. Becker, two weeks ago, carried off second honors at the State oratorial contest held at Akron.

While the lighter AEtna, belonging to the New-York Lighter and Transportation Company, was lying at Pier 28 East River yesterday afternoon, fire was discovered among cotton bales with which she was loaded.

The paintings and studies by the late R. W. Hubbard and the paintings contributed by the Artiste' Mutual Aid Society for the benefit of his estate were sold at auction last evening in the salesrooms of Ortgies Co., at 366 Fifthavenue.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7.--Donald Frazer, a watchmaker 40 years of age, residing at Bryn Mawr, Penn., fired two shots at his wife to-day and then shot and killed himself.
BERLIN, March 7.--The Boersen Zeitung says that the United States has proposed to refer that portion of the Samoan question concerning Germany and the United States alone to arbitration.

William Harris, the young man who was arrested some days ago for a series of burglaries in up-town residences, visited the home of Judge Gildersleeve of the Court of General Sessions a few nights before his arrest.

NORWICH, Conn., March 7.--The oldest man in the employ of the Consolidated Railroad is John O'Brien, night foreman on the Connecticut River drawbridge at Saybrook. He is a patriarch in appearance, which has gained for him the nickname of "Old Johnnie."

TRENTON, N.J., March 7.--Harrison is a city of Hudson County, opposite Newark, on the Passaic River. Kearny is a township, also lying along the same river. Mr. Farrell, who represents these municipalities in the Assembly, has introduced a bill which provides for ...

A jury in Part IV, of the Supreme Court, Circuit, yesterday gave George W. Morrison a verdict of $5,000 for injuries received by being thrown down and dragged through the carelessness of one of the Broadway Railroad drivers.

Judge Van Brunt of the Supreme Court yesterday handed down a decision refusing the application of New-York and Long Island Bridge Company for the appointment of Commissioners for the acquirement of land on Blackwell's Island for piers of the proposed bridge.

The sale of what is termed the finest collection of Oriental porcelains ever put up at auction in America was begun yesterday afternoon by Thomas E. Kirby, auctioneer, at the rooms of the American Art Association, 6 East Twenty-third-street.
BOSTON, March 7.--The stockholders of the Pacific Guano Company at a meeting to-day listened to a report of the committee, showing $3,500,000 liabilities and $900,000 quick assets.

NEWBURG, N.Y., March 7.--The propeller Newburg of the Ramsdeil Line opened navigation for the season, arriving here from NewYork at a late hour last night. No ice was met with, the only spot where it was seen floating being at Cold Spring.

Gunther Wechsung, drug clerk for Otto Doepfner, was so injured in the prescription room of his employer's shop, 937 Third-avenue, at 7 o'clock yesterday morning, by some one who hacked his skull with a wood hatchet that he died at 5 o'clock in Bellevue Hospital.
CITY OF MEXICO, March 7, via Galveston.-- The postal treaty arranged between Great Britain and Mexico has been officially published.

The death sentence of Godas, the Indian half breed who was to be hanged at Helena, Montana, to-day, was yesterday commuted to life imprisonment by Gov. Leslie. Godas killed a frontier settler last year.

CHICAGO, March 7.--Charles P. McAvoy admitted to-day that his brewery has been sold, but the owners of the Wackel Kirk and the Michael breweries--also reported sold to English parties--while admitting that negotiations are pending for the purchase of these plants, assert that the sale has not been consummated.

LONDON, March 7.--Queen Victoria arrived at Biarritz to-day. Her Majesty was welcomed by the Mayor of the city and other prominent persons. The Queen was enthusiastically cheered by the people along the route from the railway station to her villa. President Carnot sent a telegraphic message of welcome to her and has placed a military band at her disposal during her stay at Biarritz.
CHICAGO, March 7.--C.J. Beattie, a lawyer who makes a specialty of divorces, was arrested to-night charged with furnishing a bogus decree and introducing perjured evidence.
CHICAGO, March 7.--Cornelius Vanderbilt, Chauncey M. Depew, and their party arrived in Chicago to-night. They had traveled over the Big Four Road from Cincinnati and taken a look at its condition.

NORWICH, Conn., March 7.--Judge Levi E. Coe of Meriden has prepared some interesting statistics showing the extent of farming in Connecticut.

By the payment of $6,200 to Thomas T. Waller, Collis F. Mackenzie, formerly head of the firm of C.F. Mackenzie Co., stock brokers of 30 Broad-street, and a member of the New-York Stock Exchange, vacated an order of arrest which had been obtained against him by Charles A. Jackson, Mr. Waller's attorney.

AUGUSTA, Me., March 7.--The House to-day passed the bill which provides that a person who sells his vote at elections shall be fined a sum not more than $100 and imprisoned for not over one year and disenfranchised for ten years.
The Western Union Telegraph Company showed some respect for the Board of Electrical Control by reporting at its meeting yesterday that the company has taken down 135 poles ...

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 6.--Nelson W. Runyon of Plainfield was to-day appointed by Judge McCormick of the Union County Orphans' Court as Administrator pendente lite on the estate of Sarah M. Latimer, who died recently at Plainfield worth $1,000,000, of which $50,000 is cash in bank, and the balance is real estate.

The second day in the trial of Thomas B. Kerr, since a jury was obtained, was not enlivening to the audience. Assistant District Attorneys Semple and Dos Passos passed eight hours of the hearing yesterday in reading extracts ...

A great crowd of spectators saw the revival of "The Taming of the Shrew" at Daly's Theatre last evening. The comedy had the same cast as it had during its long run two years ago, except that Miss Chalmers took the part of Bianca in place of Miss Drener.

The joint meeting of representatives of the trunk lines and Central Traffic Association roads at the office of Commissioner Fink was finished yesterday, when a long series of resolutions on the subject of commissions on passenger tickets was made public. After reciting the fact that illegal commissions are still paid the resolutions go on as follows:

RALEIGH, N.C., March 7.--The Legislature to-day passed a bill providing for an election law much similar to the famous South Carolina law in that it requires educational qualification. The bill provides that all boxes shall be labeled, and that voters shall approach the polls one at a time, and place their several ballots in proper boxes.

Old-time dullness seems to have fastened itself upon Wall-street again, and recent hopes are languishing. Fluctuations are few; speculators are not to be found in brokerage offices; what activity the Stock Exchange has it gets almost wholly from the operations of its own "room traders."

Mayor Gleason of Long Island City created another sensation yesterday morning. Accompanied by Commissioner of Public Works Patrick Jerome Harrigan, a gang of laborers, and 20 police, he marched to the lumber yard ...

The Brooklyn City Railroad Company is preparing to build a cable road from Fulton Ferry to Fort Hamilton. The route is to be along Fulton-street and Third-avenue to the city line and thence over the dummy road.

A letter was received by Mayor Grant several days ago from Mr. W.R. Jenkins asking him to visit Public School No. 9, at the northeast corner of West End-avenue and Eighty-second-street, and determine for himself whether the school building was suited to the accommodation of 1,100 children.

WASHINGTON, March 7.--Mrs. Harrison received a number of callers this afternoon from 3 to 4 o'clock, in the Red Parlor of the White House, where Mrs. McKee and Mrs. Russell Harrison assisted in receiving, Mrs. Harrison's gown was of a light shade of green broadcloth, braided in fine black silk braid.
It is reported around the Court House, on Jersey City Heights, that there are serious differences between District Attorney Winfield and the Grand Jury.

ZANZIBAR, March 7.--An Arab dhow which has arrived here reports that she was boarded by an officer of a German gunboat, who granted her a pass. Afterward she was fired upon by other German gunboats, and her Captain was killed. This news created great excitement among the people of Zanzibar, and crowds surrounded ...

The parlors of the Fellowcraft Club were filled last night as they have rarely been filled since the club's organization. It has grown to be a pleasant custom for its members to have a monthly reunion and a dinner, to which gentlemen distinguished in various walks of life are invited, and last night was such an occasion.

The sale of the modern paintings belonging to the collections of Elmer H. Capen of Boston and the late Wilmot L. Warren of Springfield was begun last evening in Chickering Hall under the management of the American Art Association, with Thomas E. Kirby as auctioneer.
ST. LOUIS, March 7.--For the last three days the millers of the Winter wheat States have been holding a secret meeting here for the purpose of forming a combine to control the flour output.

One of the keenest things ever said on the Bench is attributed to Judge Walton of Georgia. While holding a term of the Supreme Court at Augusta he sentenced a man to seven years in prison for a grave crime.

The Brooklyn real estate belonging to the estate of A.S. Barnes, and supposed to be worth at least $500,000, was sold at auction yesterday by John F. James Son. The prices obtained were only fair, and in some cases were very low.

CHICAGO, March 7.--It appears that the ticket scalpers are not having so hard a time as is generally supposed. The discovery has been made that some of them are well supplied with Colorado tourist tickets, which they offer for sale at $1 less than the tariff rates.

Ex-President Cleveland was made an honorary member of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday, his name being proposed by Mr. Alexander E. Orr, the President of the Produce Exchange, representing the Executive Committee of the Chamber.

WASHINGTON, March 7.--President Harrison has continued to-day to devote a large part of his time to demonstrating to several thousand of his curious countrymen and countrywomen that he is actually President, and that he has hands that can be shaken without coming off.

ST. LOUIS, March 7.--As a shifting engine was hauling the De Sota accommodation train of the Iron Mountain Railroad from Main and Convent streets to the Union Station today it jumped the track and turned over on its side carrying Engineer Mahoney and Fireman George Ebel with it.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 7.--At the Quarantine conference to-day an interesting paper was read by Dr. D.M. Burgess of the hospital service stationed at Havana. He urged greater efforts to prevent yellow fever from being brought to this country by steamships and in smuggled goods.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 7.--George Stiger, aged 25, of Houston-street, Newark, was struck by a train this morning while walking on the New-Jersey Central Railroad bridge across Newark Bay at Elizabethport.

HARTFORD, March 7.--Speaker John H. Perry of Fairfield was nominated this afternoon by the Fairfield County caucus for the Court of Common Pleas Judgeship in that county, succeeding Joel B. Hall of Stratford, who has been advanced to the Superior Court Bench. Howard B. Scott of the law firm of Brewster, Tweedy Scott of Danbury, was Mr. Perry's only competitor.

PATERSON, N.J., March 7.--David Tredo, a well-known baseball player, who kept a saloon at the corner of Market and Prince streets, being aroused by a fire on the next block this morning, started to run down stairs.

The graduation yesterday of more than fifty young plumbers, coming from every part of the country, in Col. AUCHMUTY'S Trade Schools (East Sixty-seventh-street) will call attention anew to one of the most practical and useful enterprises ever initiated ...

The will of Francis W. Lasak is to be contested. He died in his ninetieth year at Dobbs Ferry last month, leaving an estate estimated to be worth $5,000,000. He accumulated his large fortune through early association with ...

Some excitement seems to have stirred up the residents of West Fiftieth and West Fiftyfirst streets on account of several attempts, mostly unsuccessful, of so-called burglars to effect entrances into houses in that neighborhood. Nearly all of the thefts have been trivial, but the consecutiveness of the attempts at burglary has put the residents on the alert.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7.--A meeting of the creditors of the Reading Iron Works was held at the office of the company in this city this afternoon. Fully four-fifths of the total number of creditors wore either present or represented by counsel, Mr. George F. Baer, a Director of the company and also its counsel, read ...
SAN FRANCISCO, March 7.--Drafts, sight, 15, telegraphic Co.

The Ninth Ward Pioneer Corps at its annual meeting last evening elected the following officers for the evening year: Robert B. Miller, President; M.S. Vanderbilt, First Vice-President; R.H. Ross, Second Vice-President; L.J. Robbage, Secretary, and Dr. W.T. Breakell, Treasurer.

David Rea, dealer in fancy leather at Montreal, has assigned, with liabilities of $57,388. The principal creditors are the Merchants' Bank, in $19,000; the Toronto Bank, $11,000, and the Union Bank, $5,000.
Not long ago there was a case of malignant diphtheria in the family of W.F. Walton, a broker living at 72 West Forty-sixth-street.
There was beautiful weather in NewOrleans yesterday, and the attendance at the races was large. The track was in fair condition. Following were the winners:
CHICAGO, March 7.--The Cincinnati express which came in on the Louisville, New-Albany and Chicago Road last evening brought a badlyscared lot of passengers.

Commissioner Daniels has received a letter from Inter-State Commissioner T.M. Cooley, in which the latter said he understood that the Chicago roads had begun to pay commissions again, and that if that course were persisted in it would be necessary to take the question up at a public hearing at Chicago, where the question would be of the reduction ...

NORWICH, Conn., March 7.--The School Fund Commissioner, who has been devoting his time to enumerating the total number of children of school age in the State, has finished his work and made a per capita apportionment of 75 cents.
The Franklin-square associates of the late Mary L. Booth, editor of Harper's Bazar, have prepared and adopted the following resolutions as a tribute to her memory:

BOSTON, March 7.--The authors' readings given in the Boston Museum this afternoon in aid of the International Copyright Association proved a notable entertainment. Officers of the association with invited guests occupied ...

The fair wind from seaward yesterday brought up New-York Harbor a fleet of vessels which surpassed in numbers any arrival of the year. Every vessel reports extremely bad weather outside, and the accounts furnished by those coming from the southward indicate heavy gales and storms in a region far below Hatteras.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 7.--The prize debating contest in Clio Hall last evening resulted in the awarding of prizes as follows; First, D.R. Todd of Kansas; second, Samuel Semple of Pennsylvania.

Mme. Diss Debar had a box at Dockstader's last night. With her was Douglas Stewart. Out in the parquet sat Luther R. Marsh. People who watched them said that there were no signs of recognition between them.

The corn palace special train from Sioux City, Iowa, which left that place about two weeks ago to carry a delegation of Sioux City's citizens to Washington to attend the inaugural ceremonies of President Harrison, is now at the station of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey in Jersey City.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., March 7.--The twenty-sixth annual session of the Washington Conference, Methodist Episcopal Church, (colored,) is being held here. The attendance is the largest in the history of the body.
I hear that the Emperor William is about to send a marble bust of himself to the Czar, another to the Emperor of Austria, and a third to the King of Italy. They are the work of Prof. Begas.

NEWARK, N.J., March 7.--A man giving his name as James Jordan was captured early this morning by Policemen Dolan and Steckler of the Orange Police, after a struggle, in which Jordan tried to shoot the officers. He tried all the cartridges in his revolver, but they missed fire. He is also wanted on a charge of burglary.
AUBURN, N.Y., March 7.--The adjourned meeting of the Central New-York Baseball League was held this afternoon, but no organization was effected.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7.--A special to the Press from Oxford says: "The separator in the milk-receiving station at Hickery Hill, in Elk Township, a branch of Big Elk Dairy, bursted with great violence while running this morning. George W. Smith, the manager, and Owen Springer were in the room at the time.

LONDON, March 7.--At the sitting of the Parnell Commission to-day, an ex-American Fenian named Coleman, now residing in Ontario, and employed by the Canadian Pacific Railroad, detailed the outrages in which he took part while he was in Ireland. He stated that Macauley told him the League had paid him (Macauley) 200 for shooting Burke.

Although President Harrison would not have ex-Senator Platt in his Cabinet, he is not willing that Mr. Platt should stand aside and give his Administration no assistance. He has, therefore, requested Mr. Platt to visit him and talk over matters.

The Very Rev. James Bartley, Provincial of the Carmelite Fathers of Dublin, Ireland, who came to this country to make arrangements with Archbishop Corrigan for members of his order taking charge of the new parish to be formed from that of St. Stephen's, in Twenty-ninth-street, has returned to his monastery. He will immediately send several Fathers to this city, and next month they will begin the work of erecting a church.

UTICA, N.Y., March 7.--A large meeting of capitalists interested in the project of building a railroad from Saratoga to Utica, through Johnstown, Gloversville, Dolgeville, and Northern Herkimer County, was held this afternoon in the Gloversville Opera House.

Auctioneer H.C. Merry yesterday sold at Leavitt Co.'s salesrooms, at 787 Broadway, a lot of bric-a-brac, oil paintings, and other articles for account of Louis Windmuller, Chairman of the Art Committee of the German Hospital Fair. The prices for some of the pictures and etchings were very low, although there were few objects of art that had much intrinsic value.

What has proved to be the greatest sale of trotting-bred horses ever held in this country was begun at the American Institute Building in this city yesterday morning under the management of Peter C. Kellogg Co. The horses sold yesterday consisted chiefly of a consignment from the stock farm of L.J. Rose at Los ...

Col. John M. Wilson of the Engineer Corps has been placed in charge of the work on the Washington aqueduct extension, relieving Major G.J. Lydecker, who will be tried by court-martial on the 25th inst. for neglect of duty in connection with this improvement.
OTTAWA, Ontari., March 7.--The Hon. C.H. Tupper, Minister of Fisheries, resumed the debate on the budget in the House of Commons this afternoon.

ROCKLAND, Me., March 7.--St. David's Catholic Church, a wooden structure erected in 1858, was burned early this morning. The steeple fell upon and crushed a store adjoining. The parsonage was badly damaged. Loss, $6,000; insurance, $4,000.
OTTAWA, Ontario, March 7.--In the Senate today Mr. McDonald or Toronto called the attention of the Government to the state of the export and import trade of the country.
PARIS, March 7.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day the election of Gen. Boulanger to the Chamber for the Department of the Seine was verified.

PAW PAW, Ill., March 7.--The elopement which threw this community into excitement last Monday morning has ended in a tragedy. It was regarded as an abduction rather than an elopement, owing to the extremely tender age of the girl and the unenviable reputation of the man with whom she fled.

DUBLIN, March 7.--Dr. Tanner, member of Parliament for Cork, who was arrested for violating the Crimes act, was tried at Tipperary to-day. He was convicted and sentenced to three months' imprisonment without hard labor. He has appealed from the sentence.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 7.--The positive announcement of Gov. Hovey that there will not be an extra session of the General Assembly has induced the Democrats to begin pushing the Appropriation bills toward final passage. The Deficiency bill passed the Senate this morning, and that body will pass the General Appropriation bill.

Since the Manhattan Railway Company was created it has been trying to evade by every manner and means payment of the damages to owners of property abutting on its lines. It has tried various devices with gratifying success. It now has a new scheme, which came to light yesterday.

A private letter from Thomas H. Hall, owner of the schooner yacht Republic, which is now carrying the Atlantic Yacht Club flag in West Indian waters, demonstrates that that veteran yachtsman and his family party are having a fine trip.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 7.--The City Council to-night, on the urgent recommendation of Mayor Grier, passed an ordinance for the purchase of a new steam fire engine for Elizabethport and for repairs to the fire alarm at a cost for both of $10,000. A resolution to pay City Councilmen $500 salary was beaton.

Mayor Grant was informed yesterday that the Brush Electric Light Company erected on Wednesday a tall support pole at 390 Thirdavenue and a similar pole on the opposite of the street. As the company had no authority to erect the poles, the Mayor requested Electrician Wheeler of the Board of Electrical Control to notify it to remove them at once.

The Clifton track was in fair shape yesterday and some good racing was witnessed. Thirtysix bookmakers started business, but on the fourth event one of them came to grief, and investors on the winner of the race were the sufferers.

The sale of California trotting and pacing bred stock at the American Institute Building was concluded yesterday, a total of 59 animals being disposed of during the day for a total of 74,375.

Frank Faila, a saloon keeper at 1,357 Avenue A, was attacked yesterday by a big Newfoundland dog and badly bitten. He drove the animal off and then attacked Charles Makofsky, an undertaker, of 176 East Thirdstreet, whom he charged with setting the dog upon him. Makofsky had him arrested, but then it was found he was so badly bitten that he was sent to Bellevue Hospital.

Rumors prevail in Jersey City that Justice Jonathan Dixon of the New-Jersey Supreme Court may be appointed to succeed Justice Bradley in the United States Supreme Court.

BUTLER, Penn., March 8.--Senator Greer, Inspector of the Soldiers' Orphan Schools, has completed his report regarding the crazy boys at the McAllisterville school. The report will be one of the most singular and interesting ever filed in that department at Harrisburg.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 8.--The general belief among the loggers is that the crop will, when the final figures are all in, show a shortage of 25 per cent. from the calculations made at the beginning of the season. This will not be detri mental to the lumber market. It will have a tendency to stiffen prices, which will not be un pleasant to those having stocks to sell.

Mr. Burr McIntosh, a heavy-weight actor, is now the champion pool player of the theatrical profession. He won that proud distinction at 2 o'clock yesterday morning, when he defeated Mr. Robert Hilliard, middle-weight actor, in George Slosson's Columbia Billiard Rooms. The game was at 150 points, continuous pool, and the only stake was the honor of winning.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 9.--Edwin Harris, whose summary removal from the office of Deputy Collector of Customs is announced today, is a brother-in-law of Collector Benjamin F. Jonas, who was President Harrison's colleague in the United States Senate several years ago. Harris was formerly State Senator, and has been for years a power in Democratic politics. All parties are extremely reticent as to the charges upon which the department acted.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., March 9.--About 8 o'clock to-night fire destroyed the Crandall Block on Commercial-avenue. The building was occupied by John Franey as a flour and feed store, Wanton Harrown as a paper box factory, and Guy's gun shop. The firemen did noble work and succeeded in confining the flames to the building where it originated. The loss is placed at about $12,000, with but little insurance.

RALEIGH, N.C., March 9.--The negro exodus has a serious aspect in this section, and is creating a sensation. The whole of the eastern portion of the State threatens to be depopulated of negro laborers, and the situation is growing alarming for farmers. Large numbers are leaving daily, and the number transported westward during the past two months will run up in the thousands.

LONDON, March 9.--Floods prevail in the west of England. Railway traffic has been stopped, and passengers on some of the trains were compelled to sleep in the coaches last night. The windstorm that burst upon NewYork yesterday brought with it the fear that another blizzard was coming this way. It is nearly time for one, taking last year as a criterion, and many persons will expect, when they wake up this morning, to find the streets covered with snow and the air filled with flying flakes, driven by a breeze with a velocity of 50 or more miles an hour.

Winants, the donor of the new dormitory to be erected at Rutgers College, has been elected a member of the Board of Trustees to fill a recent vacancy caused by death. Jefferson Howe, who was released from the Elmira Reformatory about a year ago, was before Justice Patterson at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday charged with beating his mother, who lives at 19 Horatio-street. CALCUTTA, March 10.--A sensation has been caused here by the discovery of a plot in Cashmere against the life of the British Resident. The discovery was made through letters left by the late Premier of Cashmere. --G.P. Putnam's Sons announce a limited edition in handsome form of Irving's "Life of Washington," to be published at the coming anniversary of the first inauguration of Washington. It will consist of five volumes of quarto size, and will contain 200 illustrations, 130 of them on steel. Only 300 sets will be printed and these from type. The price of the set has been fixed at $50.

The net of circumstantial evidence is being drawn very close about William Krulisch, the supposed murderer of Gunther Wechsung, the drug clerk who was chopped to death last Thursday morning. Five resolutions or declarations, prepared by the Committee of Arrangements, will be considered. Green's old plan to have a large amount of the territory lying about New-York City incorporated within the city limits and to have the immense area involved known as the city of New-York, has been revived by that gentleman, who now thinks he has some hope of seeing the scheme which he has cherished for 15 years carried to a successful conclusion.

Malone, and Alfred De Oro is to be played off at Daly's rooms, in Brooklyn, and the first game took place there last night. ALBANY, March 12.--The Assembly has passed the bill appropriating $400,000 to complete the addition and construction of the American Museum of Natural History. Mr. Martin offered, and the House accepted, an amendment that the Museum be opened on Sunday whenever the Board of Estimate and Apportionment made the request of the Board of Trustees. The bill passed, 73 to 6.

HUNTINGTON, Long Island, March 12.--Many acres of valuable timber on the farms of Shaw Brothers and John Buffet have been destroyed by a fire which broke out last night and was still burning at latest reports. The loss will reach thousands of dollars.

The Gas Commission yesterday approved the new form of contracts for lighting the streets during the year beginning May 1, and ordered its clerk to advertise for proposals for gas and electricity.

The Rev. Lysander Dickerman of Boston lectured last evening before a large audience at Chickering Hall on "The Discovery of a Forgotten Nation," the Hittites, whose history and writings are now receiving the careful attention of archaeologists and other students of antiquity.
CHICAGO, March 12.--The loan of the deed to a burial plot in Calvary Cemetery took Mrs. Evan T. Rees into court to-day in an effort to recover that property.
Albert M. Frey and James L. Malone played the second game of the pool tourney tie series in Brooklyn last night. Frey won by a score of 158 to 127 in 19 frames.
The Board of Aldermen yesterday accepted invitations to review the procession of Irish societies next Monday and to join in the Parnell fund festival at Jones's Wood that evening.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 12.--M.K. Barber died here last month leaving an estate of about a quarter of a million to his second wife.

NEWBURG, N.Y., March 12.--The distillery of Daniel Shaefer, at Pine Bush, this county, has been seized for violation of the revenue laws by the Deputy Collector, M.S. Durkin. Shaefer conducts a hotel at Montgomery, and it was there Mr. Durkin found the unstamped whisky from the distillery. The value of the property seized is about $3,000.

John A. Campbell, ex-Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States and Assistant Confederate Secretary of War died at his home in Baltimore yesterday afternoon, aged nearly 78. His death was the end of a long illness resulting from old age. He was born near Washington, Wilkes County, Ga., and was graduated from the University of the State at the age of 15 with first honors, and afterward went to West Point.

Last night was the first opportunity the Republicans of Kings County have had to meet since the party took hold of the Federal offices, and they improved the chance to fight over local patronage. This wrangle took place at the meeting of the General Committee in a hall at Bridge and Willoughby streets. Franklin Woodruff presided.

Reminiscences of last year's blizzard were vividly recalled to the eye last evening by the Brooklyn Academy of Photography at its fifteenth exhibition reunion at the Hoagland Laboratory, on the corner of Henry and Pacific streets, Brooklyn.

The stock market was pretty firmly anchored yesterday. It stood still, and there wasn't a drift even fractionally profitable in any direction. A few room traders pecked away at the quotations, but they had only their labor for their pains. The bull got no opportunity for exultation; the bear had to forego the pleasures of self-satisfied growling.

SALEM, N.J., March 12.--The fifty-third session of the New-Jersey Methodist Episcopal conference closed to-day. W.S. Mayen, W.E. Snyder, A.L. Iszard, J.L. Howard, and George F. Illman were admitted to the ministry. Addresses were made by the Rev. Dr. Hareburk of New-York and the Rev. F. Ives of Utah. Reports of various societies were read and accepted, and the Conference adjourned, to meet in Brooklyn next year.

The Grand Jury of the March term yesterday showed its appreciation of the Manhattan Railway Company's scheme to frighten the lawyers of New-York by declining to find any indictments against the gentlemen who have managed suits against Jay Gould's corporation. Incidentally, the District Attorney's office was given a lesson.
INDEPENDENCE, Wis., March 12.--A party from Ashland has been here this week in the interest of Mr. Foster, who is backing the Ashland, Eau Claire and Independence Railroad scheme.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., March 12.--The employes are at work removing ice from the locks. It is found that the ice is about 28 inches thick in the canal, the same as it was last year. The ice in Mud Lake is three feet thick, and unless there is favorable weather from this time on there is not much chance that navigation will open up before May 1.
ALBANY, March 12.--A lease to continue during the existence of the companies was filed here to-day by the South Ferry and Broadway and Seventh-Avenue Railroad Companies.

The annual dinner of the College of Pharmacy of the City of New-York was given last evening at Delmonico's, the occasion being the fifty-ninth anniversary of the institution. About 150 persons were present, and it was conceded to be one of the pleasantest gatherings the college has held.

The will of Capt. John Ericsson was filed yesterday at the Surrogate's office. It is a business-like document, wasting no words, and giving little idea of the extent of his fortune, except that it was doubtless more than $200,000.
Baroness Louise von Schiller, nee Locher, relict of the poet's eldest son Carl, chief forester at Lorch, died in Stuttgart on Thursday of last week at the age of 85 years.

April 24 has been designated as a day of special thanksgiving for the liquidation of the Masonic debt in this State. It will be an occasion of great joy for the hundred thousand Masons, particularly Grand Master Lawrence.

It is now understood by the members of the Republican Down-Town Business Men's Association that Mr. John F. Plummer will not press for the acceptance of his resignation of the Presidency of that body, but will, in a few days, announce that he will retain the position, and begin to do in it almost as good work for the great Republican cause as he promised to do in the ranks when he hysterically resigned.
The County Democracy held a meeting in the big hall of the Cooper Union last night. The hall was filled and the gathering was enthusiastic.
County Auditor Lake of Brooklyn yesterday ended his investigation of ex-County Clerk Ranken's bill for $18,500 for copying records.
