The rumor that the Nipsic has been blown out of the water by a German gunboat is treated far from lightly by the great mass of navy officers, for they agree that if the Olga succeeded in planting an Schwartz-Kopff torpedo fair and square below the water line the little Nipsic must have gone down like a shot.

CHICAGO, March 12.--The Rev. Daniel M.J. Dowling, Rector of St. Bridget's Parish, was to-day appointed Vicar-General of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago, a position which has been vacant since the death of Vicar-General Conway last Summer.
Speedwell, the speedy racer who went to the Winter tracks at the close of the racing season in this State, has been taken to the Brooklyn track, where she will get a couple of months' rest.

BOSTON, March 12.--Only partial returns from the New-Hampshire elections are received, but there seems little doubt that the Constitutional prohibition amendment has been defeated by nearly 3,000 votes.

OTTAWA, March 12.--The Dominion Government announced its steamship policy to-day in reply to unreasonable demands from the St. Jonn (New-Brunswick) Board of Trade. Sir John Macdonald spoke at considerable length.
ST. LOUIS, March 12.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Missouri Pacific Railway Company was held this morning.
ELIZABETH, N.J., March 12.--Daniel J. Leddy, residing at 125 Pine-street, this city, died last night at the supper table. Mr. Leddy was 21 years of age and a brother of Councilman Michael Leddy.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 12.--This city promises to take a prominent place among the iron ore receiving ports this season. Buffalo's trade in this product has been of a very small character until within two years.

MAUCH CHUNK, Penn., March 12.--Ottoman Schmidt of Wilkesbarre, while walking on the track this morning, was struck and instantly killed at Mud Run Station by a Lehigh Valley passenger train bearing the witnesses and several of the defendants in the Mud Run disaster trials which are in progress in this city. Schmidt's body was mangled almost beyond recognition.

ST. LOUIS, March 12.--The annual meeting of the Wabash Western was held to-day, 299,999 shares of stock out of 300,000 being represented. The Directors elected are O.D. Ashley, T.H. Hubbard, E.T. Wells, Cyrus J. Lawrence, H.K. McHarg, Peter B. Wyckoff, Effingham H. Nichols, James F. Howe, and Charles M. Hays.

MADRID, March 12.--The Government has received dispatches announcing the loss of the steamer Remus, which had a Spanish military expedition on board. The vessel was wrecked off the Philippine Islands. Forty-two persons were drowned and 127 were saved.

A patriot is Alderman "Sojer" Flynn. Alderman Carlin supported the resolution.

Ex-President Grover Cleveland was last evening elected a member of the Bar Association at its regular meeting. With him were elected Robert Hunter McGrath, Jr., Jared G. Baldwin, Jr., Ruford Franklin, James L. Skillin, Edward P. Lyon, John J. Lenehan, John N. Beckley, and Howard R. Bayne.
BERLIN, March 12.--Count Von Berehem, Under Secretary of State, will represent Germany at the coming conference concerning Samoa.

ST. PAUL, March 13.--There is a little wheat coming from farm granaries in the Northwest, particularly in the north of Minnesota. Many of the elevators are closed for want of business.

PATERSON, N.J., March 13.--Paterson is the first city in New-Jersey to profit by the law of last Winter providing for the purchase of sites for armories in cities having none. Yesterday a site of 22 city lots, bounded by Market-street, Pennington-street, Armory-place, and Graham-avenue, which was selected some weeks ago by the State Military Board, was conveyed to the State, the county paying $19,000 for it.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 13.--The Inland Revenue Department has issued a bulletin relative to the adulteration of lard. The American product comes in for general condemnation. Nearly every sample examined was found to be adulterated. It is recommended that the duty be increased in order to practically exclude the article from Canada.

Acting District Attorney Bedford said yesterday that after reading all the newspaper reports of the acquittal of Policeman Lavin by Coroner Schultze and a jury yesterday he made up his mind that the case had not been properly conducted. He then sent to the Coroners' office for all the papers bearing on the death of Casper Pfost, and an investigation of all the circumstances surrounding the clubbing will be made.
A portly, well-dressed man of fine appearance and good manners was brought into the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday and quietly arraigned before Justice O'Reilly.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13.--The first official test by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company of a new system of heating passenger cars by steam was made on a special train which ran from this city to Jersey City this afternoon. The trial was most satisfactory in every detail, and the system will probably be adopted by the company for use on its passenger trains.

Yesterday's stock market was one more of the sort which has precious little satisfaction in it for either bull or hear. There was no fluctuation that got beyond a fractional limit and the aggregate of the day's transactions was very small.

WASHINGTON, March 13.--It was a day full of disappointment for the scores of would-be officeholders who hung around the corridors in the Senate wing of the Capitol waiting to see who would be nominated by the President today.

WASHINGTON, March 13.--Mrs. Harrison received a number of callers from 3 to 4 o'clock this afternoon, assisted by Mrs. McKee and Mrs. Russell Harrison. MINNEAPOLIS, March 13.--Slowly but surely the Binding Twine Trust is tightening the coil about the farmers, and the effect of it is seen in Minneapolis, where most of the twine in stock has been bought up for the trust and now lies in a Minneapolis warehouse, and where the price has already advanced materially.

Hoary old Winter has had a first-rate time resting in the lap of Spring, but the gentle creature has deposed him apparently for good and all and asserted herself most delightfully. Yesterday was a perfect day. Spring overcoats were upon most of those people who were over coats, and Spring fever affected all.
LONDON, March 13.--The steamship Lake Huron, (Br.,) Capt. Tranmer, from New-York March 2 for Liverpool, passed Brow Head to-day.

Two trappers named Finlayson left Canot River settlement, 40 miles from Prince Albert, North west Territory, last August for Dell Lake, intending to remain all Winter trading in that region. Their dead bodies have been found 200 miles further north, near the Hudson's Bay Company's post. Fears are entertained for the safety of Lord Lonsdale.

ST. PAUL, March 13.--Quite a heavy snowstorm is prevailing all over the Northwest today. The railroad weather reports show it to be snowing between Glasgow and Great Falls on the Manitoba Road and in the same locality on the Northern Pacific. Two inches of snow is reported to have fallen. At Neche, Grand Forks, and Pembina it is much colder, the mercury ranging from 2 to 10 below zero.

Messrs. Kiliaen Van Rensselaer and E.E. Sterns, representing the West Side Improvement Association and the Torrey Botanical Club, called on the Park Commissioners yesterday and protested against the cutting down of trees in Central Park.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 13.--After a discussion of less than half an hour the Senate, by a vote of 22 to 15, has passed the resolution resubmitting the prohibitory amendment to the Constitution. The resolution must now pass the next Legislature before it can be submitted to the people.
After the mists of the legal storm that wrecked the Arcade Railway scheme had partially cleared away yesterday there was a general overhauling of rapid-transit projects.

Few meetings of the Nineteenth Century Club have been as well attended as that held last evening in the Assembly Rooms of the Metropolitan Opera House, at which Mr. W.J. Henderson delivered an address on "Wagner and the Opera of the Future."
ST. PAUL, March 13.--The fight on flour rates opened this morning in deadly earnest and promises to make things lively for the next few days.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 13.--James Payne shot himself in the head last night at his residence, 258 Livingston-street, this city. He was employed in the Singer Sewing Machine Works for about 30 years at good wages.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 13.--The funeral of Capt. Dawson took place this afternoon. The weather was wretched. Last night a heavy wind and rain storm set in. This continued all day. The funeral was held at the Cathedral Chapel. Notwithstanding the severe storm the church was crowded to its utmost capacity.
The Anchor Line of steamers has purchased the Kelsey property in Brooklyn, comprising nearly three blocks, and including the water front, wharves, stores, and elevators.

Malone and De Oro played the third game of the tie in the recent pool tournament last night at Daly's billiard rooms in Brooklyn. Malone won by a score of 151 to 148. The game was very close and exciting from the start. Twenty-three frames were played. Frey and De Oro will play to-night.

The constitutional amendment prohibiting the manufacture and sale of intoxicating liquors, "except cider," has just been defeated in the State of New-Hampshire by a majority larger than has been secured by any political party in that State for many years.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 13.--At Shelby, Miss., this morning, G.T. Nelson shot and killed William Avant. The two men quareled over a game of cards in Nelson's saloon last night, and Avant threatened to kill Nelson at sight. This morning Nelson armed himself and laid in wait for his enemy.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., March 14.--Reports from Newfoundland say that the issue of licenses to American vessels for the purchase of bait and other necessary outfit will be refused this season, and that the home Government will coincide with the Dominion Government in its policy.
There was no cessation yesterday in the warfare of the factions into which the members of the Mutual Benefit Life Association of America are divided.

PURCELL, Indian Territory, March 14.--Okla homa Hill is here urging an invasion of the country. He leaves to-morrow for Oklahoma. His life was today threatened by cattle men. The Freshmen of Stevens Institute dined last night at Clark's, in West Twenty-thirdstreet, and had a merry evening. Nelson Macy, President of the class, was toastmaster. The committee in charge of the dinner was composed of Messrs. Martin, Jeukins, Bill, and Gardner.

Directors Field and Fitch, the insanity experts at Bellevue Hospital, had a heavy day's work yesterday. They passed judgement in 13 cases, in 8 of which the patients were sent to the insane asylums on the Island.

MACON, Ga., March 14.--John L. Adams, the faster, died last night in his sleep. He had been sleeping peacefully, when the watchers by his bedside noticed a cessation of breathing, and on examination Adams was found to be dead. He had been conscious all day, but spoke but little, and then in a whisper so faint that it could scarcely be heard.

The Eight-Hour Labor Conference met in Clarendon Hall last evening. Twenty-three trades and labor organizations were represented, and an Eight-Hour Leage was organized. Chairman Gompers suggested that the eighthour demonstration on July 4 be in the form of a picnic. Some of the delegates said that there were hardly any union parks in the city where such a picnic could be held.

There were two novelties on the programme of Theodore Thomas's fifth orchestral matinee at Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon.
SPRINGFIELD, ILL, March 14.--The colored people of this city had a meeting last night, and decided upon the erection of a monument in this city to the memory of Abraham Lincoln, William H. Seward.
Joseffy and Rosenthal are announced to play compositions for two pianos by Reinecke and Saint-Saens at the public rehearsal of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Society this afternoon.
The work on the machinery for the cruisers Concord and Bennington is getting along at a rapid rate and its quality is certainly very satisfactory.

PATERSON, March 14.--Under a system adopted in Passaic County, some years ago, the Board of Chosen Freeholders of the county spends about $30,000 every year in macadamizing the principal roads leading into the city of Paterson. Last week the board resolved that in macadamizing the roads hereafter the preference would be given to those townships which appropriated the most money for the same purpose.
Edward Trowbridge of 95 Harrisonstreet, Brooklyn, who, as related, in THE TIMES, was arrested on a charge of swindling, would not talk about his case at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday.

The Jersey City Board of Finance was last night notified that County Collector Dugan intends to demand an immediate settlement of arrears of taxes due the county from the city. According to a statement made to the board the arrears now amount to $586,595. The board referred the subject to a committee, and will probably seek legislative aid to settle the difficulty.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., March 14.--Miss Emma Althouse, the Warsaw sleeper, is awake again after a sleep of 11 days. The home of Bennington Hill is a scene of unusual bustle.
HAVANA, March 14.--M. Tachigorin, the Russian chess champion, who has been engaged in the tournament here with M. Steinitz and other well-known players, sailed to-day for New-York.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 14.--Mr. Wood of Westmoreland resumed the budget debate in the House of Commons this afternoon. He gave voluminous statistics to show that the prosperity of the American Union was unevenly distributed between the various States.

Robert Sigel, the Pension Office clerk, withdrew his plea of not guilty yesterday in the United States Circuit Court and pleaded guilty to four counts, on two indictments, for forgery. He will be sentenced next Thursday.
The monthly exhibition at the Union League Club is again fortunate in bringing together some very remarkable porcelains and a few oil paintings belonging to members of the club.

TRENTON, N.J., March 14.--The annual dinner of the Princeton Alumni Association of NewJersey was held at the Trenton House to-night Gov. Green of the Class of '50 is the President of the association.

Mrs. BURNETT, the novelist, has been making a very just complaint about the denial to people who attain any kind of celebrity of the ordinary immunitics of private life. Men or women who happen to write successful books or plays become by that achievement objects of curiosity among those who have been interested by the books or the plays.

Mrs. Langtry was unable to fill her engagement at the People's Theatre in the Bowery last evening on account of illnees. The remainder of her engagement of one week has been canceled in consequence of her physician's orders, but she hopes to be able to act in Philadelphia Monday.
Burglars got into the rectory of the Little Church Around the Corner between 1 and 6 A. M. yesterday, and carried away about all of the Rev Dr. Houghton's silverware.

There were no exciting disclosures in the West Washington Market inquiry yesterday. A number of witnesses were examined, but they had little of interest to tell.
At a meeting of the Harlem Regatta Association last evening in the rooms of the Atalanta Boat club, 574 Fifth-avenue, it was decided to hold the Harlem River Spring Regatta on May 30.
LONDON, March 15.--The Hamburg-American Line steamer Bohemia, Capt. Kopff, which left Havre March 13 for New-York, has been in collision with the steamer Paris. Both vessels were slightly damaged.
At the Broadway offices of the International Company of Mexico yesterday many inquiries were made for the condition of affairs in Lower California.

The Republican Senators to-day received the committee of five appointed last night by the Assembly Republican caucas to ask for a joint caucus. The interview was brief and pointless.
NEW-ORLEANS, March 14.--The new Police Com-- mission recently organized under the law at the last Legislature last night elected David Hennessey, the present incumbent, Chief of Police.

On Saturday evening, March 23, at Chickering Hall, a concert will be given in aid of the Riverside Rest, a temporary home for friendless women, espesially for such as are discharged from the city institutions.
The Academy of Medicine, through Bellamy P. Winans, have purchased three lots on Forty-third-street, just west of Fifth-avenue, for $90,000.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14.--The will of Emlin Cresson, who died on the 2d inst., was probated to-day. The value of the estate left by the testator is not given in the petition filed with the writing, but it is said to be a large one.

A bill, whose sponsors profess to believe will solve the question of rapid transit in this city, was sent to Albany last night to be introduced in the Legislature. Corporation Counsel Beekman. who drew it at the request of Mayor Grant, took it to the capital.

WINNIPEG, March 14.--Word has been received here that Lord Lonsdale has arrived at a point in the arctic circle known as the Ramparts, which is the last outpost of the Hudson's Bay Company. He and his party are well and in good spirits. He will remain there a few weeks and then push in north. He does not expect to get back to civilization for nearly a year and a half.

William Krulisch, who is suspected of having killed Drug Clerk Wechsung with a hatchet, was indicted yesterday by the Grand Jury for murder in the first degree.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 14.--The inquest in the case of Capt. Dawson was held to-day. A drenching rain and heavy wind storm, which has prevailed since the night of the murder, prevented the gathering of a crowd and probably saved the murderer from lynching. McDow was brought out of the jail about 11 o'clock this morning and placed in a police patrol wagon.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 14.--In the Union Station Hotel at 6 o'clock this morning Adolph Mafay, son of an exiled Hungarian noble and father of the Teller of a bank in New-York City.

AUBURN, N.Y., March 14.--At to-day's meeting in this city of the New-York State League of Baseball Clubs the following places were represented: Auburn--G. Frederick Gregory, A.D. Hammond, C.B. Kosters; Utica--H.E. Devendorf.

Aldermen Walker, Carlin, and Oakley came from New-York this morning with the lists of 72,000 property holders who are said to be in favor of the cable road. These petitions were called for by resolution of Senator Pierce adopted some time ago.

This year's International Convention of the Young Men's Christian Associations of North America will take place in Philadelphia, May 8 to 12 inclusive. The meeting for organization will begin on May 8 at 11 o'clock.

The Committee on Sites of the Armory Board reported to that board yesterday that there are now as many militia regiments quartered or having quarters prepared for them above Fifty-ninth-street as ought to be sent up to that part of the city.

The Western Union Telegraph Company has stirred up many of its patrons lately by defects in its local service. They complain that not only are important telegrams delayed, but that it is impossible to get satisfactory explanations at the executive offices of the company.

An interesting meeting of the Society of Medical Jurisprudence and State Medicine was held last night in the Buckingham Hotel. It was the sixty-first regular meeting of the society, and the rooms were filled with gentlemen belonging to both the medical and legal professions.

Gen. and Mrs. Daniel Butterfield entertained the Austrian Minister, the Chevalier de Severa, at a handsome dinner party last evening in their residence, 60 Fifth-avenue. This was one of the most elaborate home dinners given this season.

Gen. B.F. Tracy has concluded that his duties as Secretary of the Navy will prevent him from properly caring for the interests of his breeding farm for trotters at Apalachin, Tioga County, this State, and known as Marshland.

ALBANY, March 14.--The Senate Committee on General Laws gave a hearing this afternoon to the Pierce bill, the general purpose of which is to discontinue the practice which has prevailed in this State since 1864 of confining insane persons charged with crime at the Auburn State Asylum for Insane Criminals.

PARIS, March 14.--M. de Freycinet, Minister of War, has assumed the duties of the office of Minister of Marine made vacant by the death of Admiral Jaurez. M. de Freycinet will retain the position until a new Minister is appointed.
Louis Fried, a Russian 28 years old, who keeps a meat shop at 197 Broome-street, attempted to commit suicide yesterday by taking paris green.
The bill which has been drawn by Corporation Counsel BEEKMAN to embody Mayor GRANT'S plan for securing rapid transit for this city is to be introduced in the Legislature to-day.

WASHINGTON, March 14.--The President and Mrs. Harrison received the diplomatic corps at noon to-day in the Blue Parlor of the White House, where the introductions were made by Secretary Blaine.

ALBANY, March 14.--Gov. Hill has made one of the greatest efforts of his life. He has presented to the Legislature his so-called Ballot Reform bill. Mr. Linson was its sponsor in the Senate. Mr. Sheehan in the House.

FRESH POND, Long Island, March 14.--The body of Dr. Theodore T. Franklin, editor of the Long Island Central Zeitung, and a leader, with Carl Schurz and others, in the German revolution of 1848, was incinerated at the Mount Oilvet Crematory this afternoon. The ashes will be sent to Germany.

Miss. Isabel Dutcher, daughter of John T. Dutcher, and Wiliam Alonzo Simpson were married yesterday at high noon in Zion Church, Madison-avenue and Thirty-eighth-street, by the Rector, the Rev. Dr. C.C. Tiffany.

One member of the scurvy-stricken crew of the bark Fannie Skolfield, which arrived from Calcutta after a 149 day's trip on Wednesday, died yesterday, and it is believed that four more will die. The bark is at the Hoboken docks and some excitement has been caused by the fact that three of the crew of the stricken vessel have escaped to the shore. The county Health Officers have been warned to look for them.

Evans and the Woodlands Cemetery Company over the custody of the dead body of Mrs. Evans's husband, Lieut. John G. Evans, which is now lying in a vault at Woodlands Cemetery.

CITY OF MEXICO, March 15, via Galveston.-- Lower California is entirely quiet now. Gov. Torres has sufficient troops to preserve order. Conservative papers insist that Mexico will lose Lower California, and the inference is that the United-States will absorb it.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 15.--During the last year the Rev. Thomas Elnig of this city, the missionary who travels over the canals of NewJersey, has, he reports, preached 610 times, made 272 hopeful conversions, and held 106 open-air meetings, besides those in churches. He made special visits to 793 canalboats. The missionary has been engaged in the work 20 years without pay.

WHEELING, West Va., March 15.--Near Industry, Jefferson Country, Ohio, about 30 miles north of this city, Samuel Gordon and George Kelley, who have been paying attention to Miss Ella Duck, happened to meet at her house Tuesday night.
CHICAGO, March 15.--The General Managers of the lines in the territory of the Inter-State Railway Association completed to-day the task of organizing auxiliary associations.

JACKSON, Miss, March 15.--Testimony is still being taken in the Kernaghan-Hooker contest for Representative in the Fifty-first Congress. Volumes have already been submitted, and as far as ascertained there is nothing in the testimony here to sustain any of the grounds alleged in notice of contest.
MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., March 15.--Five of the six entombed miners at Black Diamond Colliery were rescued to-day.

WASHINGTON, March 15.--Chief Bell of the Secret Service received information to-night of the arrest of a gang of counterfeiters in NewYork City, who for several weeks past have been successfully putting spurious silver dollars in circulation.

NEWTON, N.J., March 15.--William E. Barber, a prominent citizen of Andover, committed suicide this morning by shooting himself. While his wife was preparing breakfast he sat up in bed, and, placing the muzzle of a shotgun to his left ear, touched the trigger with a cane. Financial troubles are given as the cause of the suicide. Barbor leaves a widow and two daughters.

ALBANY, March 15.--A dinner was given tonight at the Kenmore Hotel in honor of Mr. George F. Spinney, managing editor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES. The dinner was given as an evidence of the esteem in which Mr. Spinney was held by his colaborers during his eight years' service as the legislative reporter of THE NEW-YORK TIMES. Covers were laid fer 40.
FRANKLIN, Mass, March 15.--A train on the Franklin and Milford Branch of the New-York and New-England Railroad narrowly escaped being wrecked this morning.

RED BANK, N. J., March 15.--The monthly live pigeon shoot of the Riverside Gun and Rifle Club took place this afternoon. Considering the heavy wind good scores were made.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 15.--A special encampment of National Delegates of the Sons of Veterans is summoned for this city on April 10 to consider a proposition to merge the camp and post systems.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 15.--Hattle Schensk of Middlesex Country, the colored woman who was pardoned this week by the New-Jersey Court of Pardons, had served only three weeks of a two years' sentence. The case is one of the quickest on record. Papers asking a pardon were drawn the day the woman reached the prison.
NEW-ORLEANS March 15.--Argument in the case of the State against the Cotton-Oil Trust was concluded this afternoon by Attorney-General Rogers. The case was submitted and taken under advisement.
GREENVILLE, Ga., March 15.--A spark from a passing engine at noon to-day set fire to the cotton on the warehouse platform and 1,300 bales were destroyed. The loss is $55,000.

ERIE, Penn., March 15.--The revenue cutter Commodore Perry, which was torn from her moorings in a gale last December and thrown high and dry on a pier, has been released.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15.--Capt. Evans of the British steamship North Gwalia, at this port from Perman, reports a perilous voyage. When a few days out the wind, which was southeast, turned suddenly to northeast.

LOCKPORT, N. Y., March 15.--Another chapter in the lighting question of this city was enacted here to-night.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, March 15.--W.J. McGarigle, the Chicago boodler, who has been recruiting in this country for a long time, will leave for Toronto in a few days, where he expects to meet many of his old Chicago friends. NECHE, Dakota, March 15.--Gabriel Dumont crossed the border on his way to Winnipeg this morning. He fears not his enemies, he says.

Miss Emma Karnes of Charleston, Ind., has brought suit against Charles Boyer, a Pullman conductor on the Air Line Road, for $10,000 damages for breach of promise. The couple were engaged since June, 1886, but Mr. Boyer went off and married another woman.

CHICAGO, March 15.--William H. Davis, the real estate man, who is charged with swindling so many people in selling them property not his, was arrested this morning. He declares Tolman's accusation that he swindled a large number of people to be false, and says he had no intention of running away.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 15.--Michael Bobe, 60 years of age, a resident of Beavertown, was buried alive in a stone quarry to-day by one of the banks giving way. He was buried completely our of sight but six men with crowbars and shovels hastily came to his rescue and finally got him out.

Superintendent Olsen of the New-York Yacht Club has received a model of the schooner yacht Coquette, built in 1845 by Winde Clinkard for J.H. Perkins. The Coquette beat the sloop in a match race of 25 miles to windward and return for $1,000 on Oct. 10. 1846.

Emil Nagelstein, who designedly shot himself in the breast at 382 Grand-street, the office of his employer, Saturday evening, is dying in Gouverneur Hospital from the effects of the wound. Many friends called to inquire about him yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 17.--President Harrison will have to send to the Senate to-morrow a very long list of nominations if he desires the good wishes of the crowds of place hunters who still remain in Washington.
Notwithstanding the abundant harvest in South Russia last year, in the interior whole provinces are suffering from a state bordering on famine.

PROVIDENCE, R.L., March 17.--The resignation of United States Senator Jonathan Chace, which is a brief and formal letter, reached Gov. Taft yesterday, was nothing of a surprise and only caused a ripple of excitement because of the state of things in the Republican Party that the appointment of his successor may bring about.

The Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix continued yesterday his series of Lenten sermons which he introduced a few Sundays ago with a discourse on the "Trinity of the Churches."
Funeral services of Edward Daly, the eminent Brooklyn lawyer, who died last Friday at his residence, 358 State-street, Brooklyn, were held yesterday afternoon.
ASHLAND, Wis., March 17.--Work will begin in a few days on the Lake Shore Road's main connecting link from Rhinelander to Hurley, known as the Rhinelander "cut-off."

The new hall of St. Francis Xavier, in West Sixteenth-street, was formally opened and dedicated last night in the presence of an immense crowd. On the stage sat many prominent Catholic clergymen, all the college Faculty, and friends of the institution. Gilmore's Band occupied the front of the stage.

The British military authorities have made a through inspection of the samples of small arms recently issued to the troops in the Soudan. It will be remembered that many swords and revolvers in use by the forces operating in Africa were said to have become useless at the most critical moments.

In recent letters from Liberia the Rev. Dr. George W. Samson, Presidens of Rutgers Female College, has received some facts as to that republic and the American College there, for the support of which institution about $120,000 is held in trust in this city and Boston.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 17.--Over 50 converts were baptized at the First Baptist Church to-day.

NORWICH, Conn., March 17--Next Tuesday will be an important day for the Knights Templar of Connecticut when the thirty-third annual conclave of the order in this State will be held at the asylum of Palestine Commandery, N. 6, K.T., of New-London.
The show of equipages in Seventh and Jerome avenues was unusually small yesterday, although the roads were in very fair condition.

ALBANY, March 17.--Dr. John Swinburne is critically ill, and but slight hopes of his recovery are entertained. He is under the care of two physicians. Yesterday he suffered a bad hemorrhage. The cause of his sickness is overwork and a general breaking down of the system.

Ex-President Cleveland will leave this City this morning in a special Pullman car for St. Augustine, Fla., on his trip to Cuba. He will be accompanied by ex-Sacretaries Bayard, Fairchild, and Vilas. The party leave Washington at 3:40 P.M. by way of the "Atlantic Coast Line."

Dr. McGlynn addressed the usual Antipoverty Society audience last evening in Cooper Union. He had been advertised to speak upon the "Horrors of Landlordism in Ireland," but said at the outset that he did not think St. Patrick's Day an appropriate day "to speak upon the horrors of anything."

It is not often that Irish enthusiasts have a chance to hurrah for the green flag and St. Patrick for two whole consecutive days, but it happens so this year. Sunday prevented much organized celebration and waving of flags on the real St. Patrick's day, but it was no damper to the exultant bursts of patriotic hearts.

There was a meeting at Chickering Hall last night for the purpose of setting forth the claim of Mrs. Sophia Adelaide Kent, who says that she is the eldest daughter of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert and the real Princess Royal of England.
ALBANY, March 17.--The State Board of Health is making a sincere effort to improve the sanitary condition of the most unhealthy public building in the United States, the State Capitol.

Surrogate Ransom has decided that the will of Augusta Y. Cranston, the first wife of the late Hiram Cranston, for many years proprietor of the New-York Hotel, must be admitted to probate. Mrs. Cranston died in May, 1888. Her will was executed Feb. 27, 1885.

Judge Cowing held court in General Sessions yesterday for about an hour. The cases set for trial had to be postponed for one reason or another, and the court adjourned before noon.

Ex-President Grover Cleveland was last night made an honorary member of the Young Men's Democratic Club, and the club adopted resolutions in praise of his administration of the affairs of the Nation.

LONDON, March 18.--The Rev. Mr. Tanning to-day applied to the authorities of the prison at Chatham for permission to visit Dr. Gallagher, but his application was refused on the ground that Dr. Gallagher was undergoing punishment for a breach of the prison rules.

Frederick H. Stevens, 59 years of age, a native of Pennsylvania, who had been employed in Overin's whip factory, 659 Sixth-avenue, was found dead yesterday morning in bed at the Columbus House, a cheap lodging house.

The inquiry yesterday by the Commissioners of Accounts into the West Washington Market scandal developed some matters suggestive of trickery by more persons employed in the Finance Department. George H. Switzer, a bookkeeper for Bartholomew Gray, a livery stable keeper, is the claimant of two stands in the market.

In spite of an utter lack of moisture in the atmosphere the parade held yesterday in honor of St. Patrick was just as fine as if a rainstorm of the first class had deluged the city. Until the paraders began trooping toward Washington-square there was nothing about the day to remind one of St. Patrick, except in the vicinity of the City Hall, over which waved the green flag with the golden harp.

The Deputy United States Marshals who were employed during the last election in the First and Second Assembly Districts will be paid to-day by United States Marshal McMahon at his offices in the Federal Building. Then for nearly three weeks the work will go forward until all such claims against the Government are liquidated.

ELMIRA, N.Y., March 18.--The strife for the Hammondsport Post Office, which had created considerable feeling among the candidates and their friends, has been settled amicably, and L.W. Brown, editor of the Hammondsport Herald, will be the next Postmaster.

The contract to build the machinery for the new armored cruiser Maine will, it is believed, be given to the Quintard Iron Works of this city. About 2,000 men were in the St. Patrick's Day parade in Jersey City yesterday. They were under the lead of Owen Carroll as Grand Marshal, and a corps of lieutenants aided him in moving the line.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 18.--A new phase has been developed in the case of the Barrett boys, who are to be hanged in Minneapolis Friday for the murder of John Tollefson, the street car driver, unless Gov. Merriam exercises his prerogative.

The Philanthropic Sons of the St. David's Benevolent Society, the Welsh organization of this city and Brooklyn, held their annual election last evening in the rooms of the society, University-place and Ninth-street.

The intention of the Government to give the dynamite cruiser Vesuvius another speed trial is looked upon by naval officers as outrageous. It is regarded as savoring strongly of "politics." The Cramps naturally consider this action as reflecting somewhat on their vessel's record.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 18.--In the tennis tournament at St. Augustine to-day Campbell beat Trevor, the present tropical champion, and won the City Gates trophy. The weather was perfect and the attendance large.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 18.--The changes that have taken place in the transport trade of Canada since the construction and completion of the Intercolonial and Canadian Pacific Railways form the material for an important Blue Book.

WASHINGTON, March 18.--The Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon accepted the following bonds: Four and one-half per cents, registered, $50,000, at 108; $15,000, at 108.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 18.--At a meeting of the Southern Baseball League held here to-day New-Orleans, Mobile, Birmingham, Memphis, Charleston, Nashville, and Chattanooga were represented. Chattanooga's ultimatum was accepted, and she enters the league. At to-morrow's convention the schedule of games will be arranged.

A meeting of the commandants of the Veterans' Associations of the National Guard regiments in this city and Brooklyn was held last night at the Hotel Hungaria to consider the refusal of a place for them in the centennial parade of April 30.

Wheather this latest movement will be successful time alone will show.

A CHANGE IN SATURN'S SYSTEM. GENEVA, N.Y., March 19.--Prof. Brooke, Director of Smith Observatory, has obtained several observations of the new white region on Saturn's ring, and announces his discovery that the light is Variable and that pulsations of the light at irregular intervals have been detected by him.This evidence of a change in Staturn's system is of the highest scientific interest.

BALDWINSVILLE, Mass., March 19.--A house situated neat Day's Mills, about on mile from this village, owned by J.M. Perley, was burned aboht 4 o'clock this afternoon. Mrs. Russell, aged 79, and two daughters of a neighbor named Truehart, aged 5 and 15 respectively, perished in the flames.

TRENTON, N.J., March 19.--The liquor men of the State triumphed in the Assembly today, and after many delays and dozens of caucuses, the Werts Local Option Repeal bill has practically become a law. Its passage by the Assembly to-day completed its round of the houses, and the Governor will sign it as soon as it reaches him.

The Board of Pilot Commissioners yesterday found occasion to discipline two of the pilots employed in bringing ocean steamers into port. In one case Capt. Mann of the steamship State of Pennsylvania was the complainant.

WATERLOO, Iowa, March 19.--Mayor Hoot, the shoemaker who was elected at the late city election by the labor vote and feeling of dissatisfaction with the regular nominee, assumed his office last night. There was a large crowd at the Council meeting when the new Mayor read his address.
The entire outfit of the Palette Club, at 21 West Twenty-fourth-street, was sold at public auction yesterday morning.

The report spread yesterday afternoon that ex-President Cleveland had been elected a member of the Tammany Society and would parade with it at the coming Centennial celebration is untrue. Mr. Cleveland has not even been proposed for membership in the society.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 20.--Positive assurances were resolved here to-night that President Harrison would come to this city and embark from Elizabethport for New-York April 29. The Board of Trade to-night received a dispatch from Congreesman Kean to that effect.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 20.--The prisoners in the jail at Jeffersonville made an attempt to escape last evening. E. Powell, a river pirate, had sawed out several bars of the cage which surrounded the cells, and a dozen of the prisoners soon made their way to the roof by means of an open skylight, and thence they intended to climb down to the ground by an iron pipe.
The Committee on Finance and Audit of the Aqueduct Board yesterday made a report that the supplies and transportation furnished to employes by the board were properly furnished.

A very common provision in laws, both State and National, for the creation of commissions to take charge of duties of especial importance, is that not more than a stated number of the members shall belong to the same political party, in order to prevent the control of such a commission falling absolutely into the hands of one party.

The Tammany Hall Executive Committee and representatives of the regiment that Tammany Hall raised and equipped for the war of the rebellion yesterday decided to erect on the field of Gettysburg, as a memorial of the regiment, a bronze monument, representing an Indian teepee with a brave in war attire in front of it. The memorial will be mounted on a granite pedestal, and will cost $7,500.

The soot in a chimney at the residence of Mrs. Hicks-Lord, 32 West Washington-square, took fire last evening, causing some excitement among the residents or the neighborhood. The burning soot was extinguished by throwing a quantity of salt down the chimney and no dam age resulted.

The New-York Electrical Society last night met in Clinton Hall and elected these officers for the ensuing year: President--F.B. Crocker; Vice-Presidents--Joseph Wetzler, Francis Forbes, and Dr. O.A. Moses; Secretary--G.H. Guy; Treasurer--H.A. Sinclair.
Dudley Buck's cantata, "The Light of Asia," was produced in London on Tuesday evening by the Novello Choir. A cable dispatch says that it met with great success.

There was a good deal of enthusiasm at the recent Delmonico banquet of New-York's Southern Society over a toast to "The South in Wall-street." The story of how enterprising representatives of the new South have gathered in the dollars at the North's financial centre sounded much like a fairy tale. Ex-Confederates who came here with patches on their trousers--often more patches than trousers-- can write out checks for millions now.

The woman who was found dead in a hotel in Pitt-street, Boston, last Monday, was identified yesterday as Mary Tynan who, in 1874, was nearly murdered by Thomas Piper, sexton of the WarrenAvenue Baptist Church, who was afterward hanged for the murder of little Mabel Young.

Private dispatches received in this country disclose the fact that the British gunboat Spider made a complete failure on her Government trial trip last week off Plymonth. The Spider is the first of her class of gunboats so far to be tried, and though she showed high speed on the run over the measured mile, she was wholly unable to develop the horse power required by the specifications.

Wall-street life smacked somewhat more of pleasure yesterday than has been usual lately. Nearly every stock on the list was strong, some were buoyant even; but still there were no such bull fluctuations as make men rich with any special alacrity.

ALBANY, March 20.--Controller Myers of the city of New-York received a snug little sum as his perquisites for collecting $563,728 from collateral inheritances the past six months. NEWARK, N.J., March 21.--The New-Jersey Sons of the Revolution organized in Newark yesterday with Adjt.-Gen. Stryker as President. Among the well-known persons present were Julian Hawthorne, Gen. E. Burd Grubb, and Major G.B. Halsted. The object of the society is to perpetuate the memories of the Revolution. Letters from the Governors of 17 States were received signifying their sympathy with the movement.

PESTH, March 21.--The efforts of friends to effect a reconciliation between Deputies Polonyi and Kraitsik, who had an altereation in the chamber yesterday, were unsuccessful. The two Deputies fought a duel to-day. Neither was injured.

NEWARK, N.J., March 21.--A free fight in Frank Dean's saloon at 320 Market-street, Newark, resulted to-night in Harry Cole being stabbed in the neck. In the encounter were John Martin, a pugilist; James Fox, a wellknown man about town, and Joseph Noonan, alias "The Bat." Noonan is in custody on suspicion of having done the stabbing. He is the man who some months ago shot a man on Market-street.

SEATTLE, Washington Territory, March 21.--G.R. Carlton, bookkeeper for Smith Brothers Co., sent a note to the firm on Monday. He also sent the safe keys. He said he was ill and would not be down that day. Inquiry was made at Carlton's lodgings, and it was learned that he had left the city. An examination of the books shows that Carlton is an embezzler to the amount of $20,000.

The grand tournament of the Sixth American Chess Congress will begin on Monday afternoon at 1 o'clock, at 8 Union-square. PARIS, March 21.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. Laur, in the discussion of an interpellation on the copper crisis, demanded that the Penal Code provision against monopolies be enforced. CHICAGO, March 22.--The big Wabash Railway case did not come to a close to-day, as the agreement entered into yesterday over the plan for selling the different branches was not entirely satisfactory to all of the parties in interest.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 22.--News of the death of Justice Stanley Matthews was received here with expressions of regret on all sides. Judge Thurman was called upon to-night, and, after expressing his deep regret at the death of Mr. Matthews, paid a high tribute to his memory.

OYSTER BAY, Long Island, March 22.--John Barrett, second mate of the schooner Myra W. Spear of Bath, Me.,was fatally injured at Oyster Bay yesterday. He was unloading ice when a heavy piece fell from the slide striking him on the head. His skull was fractured.

A fervent and full meeting of the General Committee of Tammany Hall was held in the great wigwam last evening. It was called to do a number of things, and it did them all in the most approved Tammany manner.
Assistant United States Treasurer McCue, who was stricken by apoplexy on Wednesday, was greatly improved yesterday.

ROME, March 22.--Signor Corveto, Under Secretary of the War Department, has challenged Deputy Cavalotti to a duel. The challenge is the result of a personal dispute.

CINCINNATI, March 22.--A singular case developed to-day in the efforts of George Duffy and George Draers to convict each other of having drowned a man in the canal last Monday night. LONG BRANCH. N.J., March 22.--A report that one of Mrs. Christian Herter's cottages at Monmouth Beach had toppled over into the sea drew a number of curious people to the spot today, but the journey proved a fool's errand. Mrs. Herter's cottages are not damaged, and, except for the destruction of one of the bulkheads, her property is unharmed.

A larger number of looms were running yesterday at Fall River, Mass., than at any time since the strike began. As yet there is no sign of a settle ment between the millowners and the weavers. ELIZABETH, N.J., March 22.--William Venn, a boilermaker, had both legs cut off this evening at Elizabethport. He was standing in an empty coal car, which was in motion, when the bottom of the car broke and he fell through. He was removed to the City Hospital. The physicians say he cannot recover.

Flint, late of Boston, contains the following public bequests to the town of Middleton, Essex County: Fifteen thousand dollars for a public library; to the Institute of Technology, $10,000; the New-England Genealogical Society and the Boston Natural Historical Society, $5,000 each; the Massachusetts Intemperate Women's Home, $1,000: to Phillips Academy, Andover, $5,000 to found a scholarship.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 22.--The Hewitt and Cooper party passed through the city on their way home. They are all in good health and spirits. Mr. Hewitt reiterated his belief that Chattanooga is to be the great city of the new South.

LIVERPOOL March 23.--A game of ball was played to-day between the American players and Liverpool team. Under rounders rules the English players won by a score of 16 to 14, but under baseball rules the Americans won by 17 to 0. In each caso there was an inning to spare.

WASHINGTON,March 23.--The Justices of the Supreme Court met today and made arrangements for their attendance upon the funeral of Justice Matthews. ALBANY, March 24.--To watch the veracious Republicans of Albany County would impress a disinterested person with the idea that they had been out of the Federal offices for 20 years instead of less than four. It appears as though every Republican who has been active in city or ward politics is looking for a place under the new Administration.

BERLIN, March 24.--The Cologne Gazette says that neither criminal nor civil procedure is applicable to the case of Klein in America. It only remains for Germany to bring evidence against him before the tribunal at Apia, including the American Consul. It may be assumed that when Herr Steubel, the newly-appointed German Consul, arrives in Apia, satisfaction will be demanded from Mataafa.

The queer old hermit who has been known throughout this State for some years as the "Leather Man," from his unique apparel. Which was made of skins, was found dead in his cave on the George Dell farm in Mount Pleasant, near Sing Sing, yesterday.

Werren Keifer, ex-speaker of the House of Representatives, in this city and Washington, are making vigorous efforts to have him appointed Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, vice Stanley Matthews deceased. CHICAGO, March 24.--The first sail vessels of the season left Chicago to-day. The schooner Lillie Pratt set sail at 3 P.M., Capt. Thomas Fay taking the credit of being the "early bird" for 1889. At 4 o'clock the schooner Ida left the harbor. Both go to Michigan for cargoes for Chicago. Several tugs tired up to-day, and there will be 10 of them under steam to-morrow.

Ex-Assistant District Attorney Ambrose H. Purdy made an ingenious defense of his client, "Kid" Miller, who was brought before Judge Lawrence in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, on a writ of habeas corpus. Miller, he said, had been called a "steerer." Persons acquainted with European usages would at once recognize that he was what is known in Europe as a "courier." The commitment and all the proceedings in the case, Mr. Purdy urged, were faulty.

East-bound shipments from Chicago of flour grain, and provisions last week by the railroads in the Central Traffic Association aggregated 29,137 tons, against 33,340 for the week previous, a decrease of 4,203 tons, as against 48,636 for the corresponding week last year, a decrease of 19,499 tons. So poor a showing at this season of the year is unusual and is supposed to be due to the manipulation of rates by the roundabout routes.

SARATOGA, N.Y., March 25.--The Rev. Mr. Brown of North River, Warren County, took a sail to-day on the upper Hudson River at that place with his wife and her mother, Mrs. MaoClelian. Mr. Brown having lost control of the boar, It was whirled through the rapids and capsized. Mr. and Mrs. Brown saved themselves, but Mrs. MacClellan was drowned.

As Alvis Turner and Jeff King were going toward the Cumberland Gap road yesterday, two miles from Pineville, Ky., they met James Burch going into town. Turner shot at Burch, the ball striking Burch's gun. Burch returned the fire, killing Turner, and then King fired and killed Burch. The shooting grew out of the arrest of Gen. Sowder by King last week.

The steamers of the People's Line to Albany have resumed their tripe for the season, and the floating palaces Drew and Dean Richmond are again plying the waters of the American Rhine. RED BANK, N.J., March 25.--The body of the man washed ashore on the beach near Atlantic Highlands one day last week has been identified as that of Frederick Shuckmann, who lived at 1,240 Third-avenue, New-York. Schuckmann was a collector for a wholesale house in NewYork. He leaves a widow and several children. He had been missing since Jan. 4.

Haight, one of the most enthusiastic yachtsmen of this city, owner of the crack sloop Domino, and an active member of both the New-York and Brooklyn YachtClubs, suffered a stroke of paralysis at his apartments in the Everett House on Sunday last. Yesterday his physicians reported that the stroke was not of a particularly serious nature and that Mr. Haight was rapidly recovering.
PARIS, March 25.--At 1 P.M. Comptoir d'Escompte shares were quoted at 117f. 50c., Societe des Meteux shares at 30f., and Rio Tinto Shares at 291f. 25c.

The Baptist Pastors began their usual Monday morning conference yesterday with a lengthy discussion on moving their place of meeting from the present quarters at 9 Murray-street to some more commodious place.

The annual Winter games of the Orange Athletic Club were held last evening in the tennis court building of the club adjoining the clubhouse at Brick Church, N.J. About 350 persons, many of them being ladies, from this city and the vicinity of Orange, witnessed the contests, which were very interesting.

There was a labor strike yesterday in the Union-Square Theatre, the carpenters, varnishere, framers, and house smiths quitting work because their complaint that non-union men were employed in the place was not heeded.

Mrs. Mary De Hart Simonson, who died on Saturday at Port Richmond, Staten Island, was 90 years of age. she was married when but 16 years of age, and from that time on lived in the same house in Jewett-avenue. Her husband died 18 years ago. Mrs. Simonson was the mother of three children, had nine grandchildren, and twenty-one great graudchildren.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 25.--Joseph Battin, a millionaire land owner of this city and President of the Elizabeth Water Company, to-night made a donation to the city, presenting it with the famous Dimock mansion. Mr. Battin desires that it shall hereafter be used as a high school for the advanced pupils of the public schools.

WASHINGTON, March 25.--Funeral services over the body of Associate Justice Stanley Matthews were held this afternoon at the family residence, Connecticut-avenue and N-street.

HARTFORD, March 25.--At the meeting of the Hartford Board of Trade this afternoon the proposed issue of $2,000,000 bonds by the new management of the Hartford and Connecticut Western Road caused a lively discussion.

Ladies on Spring shopping bent crowded Sixth-avenue all day yesterday. One of the great centres of attraction to them was Macy's, and the shoppers never saw there a prettier array of seasonable novelties.

The steamship Colorado, which arrived from Galveston Sunday, brought news which was the general theme of conversation in shipping circles yesterday. On Saturday a damaged life raft was sighted, and on examination it was found to have lashed to it the dead bodies of two seamen.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 25.--A young German giving his name as Franz Schuberg, called at the police headquarters this morning and said he was ill and wanted to be cared for.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25.--Mrs. Langtry made her reappearance on the stage in this city to-night in Macbeth. Beyond a slight weakness she showed no signs of her recent illness, which has kept her in retirement for nearly two weeks.

The sixth American Chess Congress was formally opened yesterday afternoon at 8 Union square by the President, J. Spencer Turner, in a brief address, in which he reviewed the history of the game from early times in the far East and of its development in Europe and later in this country.

All the local members of the Legislature and some of the "hayseed" delegation called on Mayor Grant yesterday. They were told by the Mayor that they should go slow in the work of increasing the debt of this city, and he suggested that they should ask the advice of the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund respecting the bills now before the Legislature providing for the issuance of bonds.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 25.--Levi Lewis, one of the oldest engineers on the New-York Central Railroad, dropped dead on his engine near Chile to-night. The remains were brought to this city. It is supposed heart disease caused death Lewis lived in Buffalo.

Representatives of the Eden Musee and Koster Bial's called on Superintendent Murray yesterday to discuss an order given to Capt. Reilly to see that these places are closed on Sunday, because they have both a concert or theatrical license and an excise license.

Considerable interest in art subjects has been recently aroused among the people who read the books of the New-York Free Circulating Library by a gift of pictures and casts to that institution. This donation is from a lady, who stipulated that her name should not be mentioned, and was made about a month ago.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 25.--Navigation opened for the season on the Delaware and Hudson Canal to-day, more than two weeks earlier than last year, when the opening was delayed until April 9. The company has accumulated at Honesdale during the Winter about 300,000 tons of coal, now available for shipment.

The Directors of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company will hold an important meeting to-morrow. They are to vote upon a project, supported by Henry Villard, by which the Northern Pacific Company can practically come to operate a continuous line of railroad from the Atlantic to the Pacific Ocean.

M. Coquelin began his farewell engagement at the Star Theatre last evening with the famous comedy of Pierre Beaumarchais, "Le Mariage de Figaro," a work that is better known nowadays to students of French literature than to the ordinary playgoers.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 25.--Charges were recently made to the Board of Managers of the Hudson River State Asylum that much of the work on Rutzler Blake's contract was not of the character provided for in the specifications.
The trial of Miss Clara M. Totten's suit to recover $100,000 damages from Cassius H. Read of the Hoffman House was begun yesterday in the Court of Common Pleas before Judge Daly and a jury.

In the will of Jane E. Kelemen, filed for probate with Probate Clerk Tinney yesterday, the New-York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, the New-York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, and the Methodist Episcopal Church Home were named as beneficiaries for $5,000 each.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 25.--Col. John R. Fellows, District Attorney of New-York, arrived here this morning on a visit to his brother-in-law, Col. Rob. ert Garrett of the Queen and Crescent Railroad. Col. Fellows celled informally on several old-time friends and messmates whom he had not seen since the war, when he served in an Arkansas regiment and was captured at Port Hudson. He remains here until Saturday, and will then leave for Cincinnati.

ST. PAUL, March 25.--A morning paper attempted to spring a sensation to-day over the treatment that convicts receive at Stillwater. Twelfth Infantry, at Fort Lincoln, Neb. ...
Visions of a new Hollywood at Norton's Point, Coney Island, began to fade yesterday. So far as can be learned the property is likely for some time to belong to the town of Gravesend.

WASHINGTON, March 25.--The President has granted a pardon in the case of Frederick F. Bickell, convicted in Minnesota of abstracting funds of a national bank while acting as its messenger and seatenced June 6, 1888, to five years' imprisonment. He has also pardoned John R. Brown, convicted in September, 1888, in Washington Territory, of selling liquor to an Indian and sentenced to one year's imprisonment at hard labor.

Daly's Theatre was packed to the doors yesterday morning by an audience composed largely of ladies, which had gathered to greet John L. Stoddard and listen to the first of his lectures which are to form the entertainment at the Lenten matinees at Daly's this season.

CAMDEN, N.J., March 25.--An interesting question is raised in a contest begun to-day over the election of School Trustees in the borough of Chiselhurst, Camden County, last Tuesday night. The election was held under the new school law allowing women to vote in New-Jersey. Of the 54 votes cast, 14 were de posited by women, and the election officers ...

Judge Barrett is very sick man. Yesterday he was taken to Holly wood, Long Branch, to see whether the air and quiet would not tend to his recuperation. A week ago Judge Barrett first yielded to his illness. On Sunday he ventured out, but too soon, and after returning to his home his symptoms became unfavorable.

TRENTON, N.J., March 25.--Ex-Congressman James W. Pidcock of the present Fourth Congressional District has held the partisan Congressional redistricting scheme from getting out of the Judiciary Committee because it put his county of Hunterdon in a district that has but a nominal majority of 300.

At last the inquiry into the West Washington Market matter has been postponed indefinitely. If George Hanley, the missing witness who was called for repeatedly yesterday, should appear, it will be reopened. The Commissioners of Accounts would like to hear from Mr. Hanley ...

Ella Hammond and Addie Stanton, who were implicated in the attempt at robbery on Phil Daly for which George Meredith and Henry Hermann are now serving terms in State prison, pleaded guilty to grand larceny in the second degree in Judge Martine's court yesterday. They were both indicted for attempt at robbery and assault in the first degree.

The complaints of bribery of voters in the Eighth Assembly District, which the City Reform Club brought to the attention of the District Attorney, are at last being acted upon in a manner which indicates a possibility that some of the offenders will ultimately meet punishment.

Another manhole explosion occurred in this city just before noon yesterday, and, considering the time, locality, and the surroundings, the wonder is that no person was seriously injured and that more damage was not caused.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 25.--The British steamship Jamaica, Capt. Edwards, from Liverpool via West Indies, arrived Saturday. Capt. Edwards reports that his vessel, while at Colon. was chartered by the Jamaican Government to take 1,485 destitute Jamaicans from Celon to Kingston, Jamaica.

WICHITA, Kan., March 25.--One of the leading boomers in the vicinity of Oklahoma City received a dispatch this afternoon from Congressman Springer stating the proclamation would succeed in getting through the State Department to-morrow.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 25.--Miss Julia Marlowe, who was announced to appear at Wieting Opera House to-night as Viola in "Twelfth Night," was taken ill at the Leland Hotel today and was unable to appear. Her illness was a great disappointment to the public, as a large audience was assured. Miss Marlowe and her company, which includes Mr. Charles Barron ...

Daniel Spellman, alias Daniel Nevins, a noted thief, and Charles Barrett, both of NewYork, were arrested at St. George, Staten Island, late on Sunday night, charged with stealing a diamond scarf pin, valued at $700, and a pocketbook from Mr. Frederick Guhrange of 20 Broadway. The prisoners will be tried to-day.

The dry goods store of Schedler McWatters, corner of Pearl and Bridge streets, Cleveland, Ohio, was closed yesterday by the Sheriff on judgments aggregating $60,000. The creditors all live in Cleveland, with the exception of George Borgfeldt of this city, who has a claim for $8,967. The liabilities of the firm are placed by the bookkeeper at $90,000, and the assets are about the same.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 25.--Congressman John R. Neal of the Third Tennessee District is dying at his home in Rhea Springs. He has become a member of the Methodist Episcopal Church, (South,) and, though kept alive only by stimulants, he is perfectly rational. He cannot last through the night.

There was no subject of legislation more urgently demanding immediate attention when the present session of the Legislature began than that of providing for the employment of the convicts confined in the State prisons.

According to one of our dispatches yesterday morning there is on foot in the State of Alabama a definite effort to give form and effect to the movement suggested by the President in his inaugural address for the extension of the protectionist party in the South.

PARIS, March 25.--It is stated that the Cabinet will soon be remodeled in order to avert a threatened Ministerial crisis.

On a snow-white pedestal, surrounded by a bank of beautifully-tinted sea mosses, reposed in Fulton Market yesterday an annual and everwelcome Spring visitor to New-York. A giltedged card imbedded in the moss read:
WASHINGTON, March 25.--The Secretary of the Treasury to-day accepted 4 per cent. bonds to the amount of $412,00 at 108.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 25.--Hezekiah Smith, an Old Bridge farmer, was attacked by an enraged boar on Saturday, and barely escaped with his life. His left leg was torn open to the hone from the hip to the knee.
Many of the pupils and all of the teachers of Public School No. 54 attended the funeral of Miss Rebecca Gibbs at the Harlem Presbyterian Church last night.

HAVANA, March 25.--Ex-President Cleveland and party have been visited by both the Intendent of the Treasury and Director-General of Marine. The tourists started yesterday for the Santa Rosa estate belonging to Sener Mier. They are expected to return to this city to-day. Ex-Postmaster-General Dickinson remained at the Pasaje Hotel, being slightly indisposed. He is entirely well again, however.

NEWARK, N.J., March 25.--For some time Mrs. Catherine Schreder, a comely widow of Bergen-street, Newark, has been annoyed by the attentions of an old man named Edward Merty.

BALTIMORE, March 25.--The second annual reunion and banquet of the Baltimore Light Artillery, C.S.A., was held here to-night. Gen. B.T. Johnson and Capt. George W. Booth, who were present as invited guests, made addresses abounding in reminiscences of the war. During his speech Gen. Johnson said:
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 26.--The first annual Conference of the Delaware and Chenango Societies of Christian Endeavor has just closed a two days' session at Norwich.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 26.--When the O'Brien resolutions were called up in the House of Commons this afternoon Col. O'Brien moved an amendment declaring that the Jesuit Order is a secret organization, and is fraught with danger to Canada.

Mrs. Potter's vaulting ambition took another leap last night and landed with crushing effect upon "Camille," that hapless victim of cruel novices and heartless amateurs. The result was pitiable in the extreme, for the lachrymose heroine of the Camellias was put to such torture that the audience suffered fully as much in witnesing the spectable as she did in undergoing Mrs. Potter's treatment.

If the present plans of the Brooklyn Park Commissioners are carried out 60 acres of the east side lands adjoining Prospect Park will be converted into a park and afford sites for a museum, a free library, and institutions or an educational character.
The Conserva was an iron-screw steamer, registering 861 tons. She was 225 feet in length and drew, when light, about 15 feet of water.
Business in the Real Estate Exchange yesterday was more active than on any day this year, more than 2,000 persons entering the auction room and a lively interest being sustained throughout the sales.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 26.--About 4 o'clook this afternoon an engine and a number of cars of a freight train west-bound of the Central Hudson Railroad jumped the track at Rectors or Five-mile Crossing, west of this city.
CHEYENNE, Wyoming, March 26.--Fifteen months ago James Grant arrived at Fort Laramie as one of a batch of recruits.

SARATOGA, March 26.--The forward weather prevailing in all sections of the country has not overlooked this important village. FINDLAY, Ohio, March 26.--A peculiar suit in replevin and for damages was begun here to-day by Beebe Bartow, a gambling firm, whose place was raided by the police on Saturday night and their tools confiscated by the city.
TORONTO, Ontario, March 26.--It is understood that the Mail Printing Company is making preparations to contest its libel suit with the Jesuits wholly regardless of expense.
LONDON, March 27.--The Anchor Line steamship Anchoria, Capt. Campbell, from New-York March 16 for Glasgow, arr. at Moville yesterday.

The statement of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad Company for February gives: Gross earnings, $1,711,176.90, a decrease of $337,102.69 from 1888; working expeuses, $1,128,701,40; net earnings, $382,475.50; net earnings, less earnings of leased lines, $422,794.20, or $18,700.73 less than for the same month in 1888.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 26.--Thomas Quinn, aged 19, in the employ of the New-Jersey Southern Railroad Company, was killed last night at Monmouth Park Junction while trying to board a moving train. The body was brought here, and an inquest was held to-day by Coroner Van Derveet. The young man lived with his parents near Red Bank.

BOSTON, March 26.--The schooner M.B. Steadson of Provincetown arrived here to-day in distress, having been in collision. Capt. Bowman says the schooner left George's Banks yesterday with a good breeze and a large catch of fish.

Beautiful flowers, gayly-decorated booths, and pretty girls filled one of the parlors of the Hotel Brunswick yesterday from noon until 11 o'clock at night. The occasion of this display was a bazaar given by the H.O.P. Sewing Society for the endowment of a bed at St. Mary's Free Hospital for Children.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 26.--Fannie Stammers of Mount Vernon, Westchester County, has sued Gilbert Van Vlack of East Fishkill, Dutchess County, for breach of promise of marriage, fixing her damage at $25,000.

Allie M. Weill, who is trying to establish the fact of her marriage to Leon M. Weill by a suit for separation, which is now on trial before Judge Beach and a jury in the Supreme Court, fell in a faint when she left the witness stand at the close of her examination yesterday.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 26.--Milton J. Cunningham, Jr., 21 years old, son of ex-AttorneyGeneral Cunningham of Natchitoches, in this State, was arrested to-night by Deputy United States Marshal W.B. Logan.

Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, on application of George H. McAdam, granted an order to show cause why the warrant of attachment issued by Judge Ingraham against Graham McAdam should not be vacated. It is claimed that the warrant was unusual and that the ordinary order committing him for contempt should have been entered. The matter will be argued in Chambers to-morrow morning.
The trial of Vincenzo Quartararo, the handsome young Italian who is accused of the murder of Antonio Flaccomio was begun in the Court of General Sessions yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 26.--Judge Allen G. Thurman, accompanied by Judge Patten of Defiance, visited the House of Representatives to-day and were most cordially received. They made brief speeches of acknowledgment. Judge Patten is 80 years old, and was Territorial Judge under Andrew Jackson.

None of the Harlem River clubs have yet made up their crews for the season, but all clubs intend to enter singles, doubles, fours, eights, or all in the Decoration Day regatta. Entries will close May 20 with A.E. Colfax, 420 Broadway. In a month they will know just who their best men are and will regularly form their representative crews.

A lively discussion was started in the Board of Aldermen by Alderman Shea yesterday. He moved to dischage the Committee on Streets from the consideration of the list of streets which the Commissioner of Public Works thinks should be repaved.
There was a good deal of noise on the Exchange yesterday, and for a while the bears roared so valorously that it seemed as if the whole market was finally bound straight for the bow-wows.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 26.--To-day Milwaukee, for the first time in her history, has been the scene of the consecration of a Bishop of the Episcopal Church.

ALBANY, March 26.--Gen. Husted made a motion in the House this morning that a special session be held to-morrow afternoon from 5 to 6 o'clock. He explained, but made his explanation no part of his motion, that the House would then consider the Saxton Ballot Reform and Crosby Excise Commission bills.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 26.--The two branches of the General Assembly cast their respective votes for United States Senator today to succeed Jonathan Chace, resigned.

BERLIN, March 26.--The Emperor to-day attended a parliamentary dinner at the residence of Prince Bismarck. There were 40 Deputies present. The Emperor sat between Princess Bismarck and Baron Levetzow.

What might have been a very serious accident occurred on the Long Island Railroad yesterday. The Patchogue express train, consisting of a combination car and six passenger coaches, with Conductor Ringhouse in charge, jumped the track at Ridgewood.

The 'Varsity and Freshmen crews of Columbia College have begun their work on the Harlem and the class crews will start their river work at once. ATLANTA, Ga., March 26.--An East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia south-bound passenger train moving at a speed of 40 miles an hour collided with a freight train 20 miles south of Atlanta this afternoon. Engineer Gillon of the passanger train was killed.

The dinner of the Cornell Alumni will take place at Delmonico's to-morrow evening at 6:30 0'clock. A business meeting for the election of officers will be held preceding the dinner.

The annual Spring opening at Stern Brothers' mammoth store at 36 West Twentythird-street is an event which always fills the feminine heart with joy. For there is always so much that is beautiful and so many things that are calculated to delight the feminine eye that the place is hardly large enough to hold the crowds which come to see them.

CHICAGO, March 26.--Chairman Blanchard has called a meeting of the managers of all roads in the territory of the Central Traffic Association for April 3 to receive and act upon the final report of the committee on revision of the contract governing the association.

LONDON, March 26.--The news this afternoon of John Bright's dying condition diverted attention from all other subjects. Bulletins were posted in the House of Commons and outside the newspaper buildings in Fleet-street. His long illness has caused the most voluminous series of bulletins ever known by the English press.
In the opinion of the members of the Tammany Central Association of the Eighteenth Assembly District there is no man like Fire Commissioner Richard Croker.
WASHINGTON, March 26.--The President sent the following nominations to the Senate to-day: First Lieutenant (Army)--Second Lieut. WILL- IAM A. MERCER, Eighth Infantry.
Ex-Gov. John Lee Carroll of Maryland is at the Victoria Hotel.
ATLANTA, Ga., March 26.--The Jewish Orphan Asylum erected by the Hebrews of the South Atlantic States is now finished and will be dedicated Thursday.

LONDON, March 26.--Mr. John Bright has suffered another relapse and is very weak. He has not taken food for 36 hours, except from a spoon. Dr. Hoyle, Mr. Bright's physician, said he was gradually sinking. At 10 o'clock to-night he was unconscious, and his condition was regarded as hopeless. At midnight he was still unconscious. The Queen and the Prince and Princess of Wales have sent messages of sympathy to the family.

Southern-trained horses are beginning to journey North for the Eastern racing season which begins next month at Washington. Word was received here yesterday that Green B. Morris had arrived at the Ivy City track with his string of horses that have been wintering at Charleston, S.C. On Friday W.P. Burch will reach the track with his horses.
WASHINGTON, March 26.--There is considerable talk in the west end of a duel which is expected to take place Thursday on the famous old dueling grounds at Hyattsville.
PARIS, March 26.--The Boulangist Committee has decided to give a grand banquet in the Salle Wagram, and to invite all the members of the Revisionist Committees of the Department of the Seine.
A letter was received at the Mercantile Exchange a few days ago from Senator Rhodes, asking the members for an expression of opinion as to the bill making Saturday a full holiday.

An alarm of fire was sent from the Catholic Protectory, at West Farms, just above the Bronx River, in Westchester County, at 1:30 o'clock this morning. Efforts were at once made by the Fire Department authorities to establish telephonic communication with the Protectory.

Stepping lightly into one of the elevators in the Tribune Building the reporter was lifted quickly up to the top floor. Turning to his right he observed a little window like unto that used by the ticket sellers of the elevated railroads. A young man's head was behind the window.

The officers attached to the Navy Department are highly gratified at the information which has reached them of the participation of the British authorities and forces in the funeral ceremonies of Rear-Admiral Chandler, who died in Hong-Kong Feb. 10.
It is gratifying to foreigners to know that Frenchmen themselves have difficulty in explaining to their own satisfaction the popularity of Gen. BOULANGER.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 26.--Inquiry at the railroad offices regarding seeding develops the fact that work is being begun much earlier than usual.

CITY OF MEXICO, March 26, via Galveston.-- The steamer Ocotian foundered on Lake Chapala, near Guadalajara. A large excursion party was on board at the time. Fifty bodies have been recovered. Many more are known to be still in the wreck.
WASHINGTON, March 26.--Under date of Aspinwall, 15th inst., Capt. Howell of the Atlanta informs the Navy Department that there is no longer any danger of rioting or insurrection on the isthmus.

The suspicious actions of two well-dressed women of apparent respectability who were wandering about, McCreery's big dry goods store at Broadway and Eleventh-street yesterday afternoon attracted the attention of the superintendent of the place, and he watched them closely.
Ex-Senator Daly was sworn in by Mayor Grant yesterday as Collector of City Revenue and Superintendent of Markets, to which position he was appointed by Controller Myers on Monday.
