That it has not obtained a greater amount of publicity is solely due to the fact that heretofore its meetings have been attended only by the ...

NEW-HAVEN, March 26.--The Yale crew is now in diligent training, and the prospects are exceedingly bright. Gill and Corbin have finally consented to row, and Gill has begun to train. The latter rowed last Saturday for the first time this season, and pulled the car in his usual lusty style. This makes six veteran oarsmen already in the boat, and Carter is still in the university.
CINCINNATI, March 26.--The burial of Stanley Matthews, late Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, was a simple, beautiful ceremony.
Mr. Nat C. Goodwin and his company will present the successful comedy "A Gold Mine" at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre to-morrow afternoon for the benefit of the New-York Press Club building fund.

The decision of Mr. Henry Buermeyer, the referee at the Amateur Athletic Union's championship contests on Saturday, giving the light-weight boxing championship to E.T. Walker of the Schuylkill Navy Athletic Club, is severely criticised by many who saw the contest between Walker and J.J. Sampson of the Pastime Athletic Club.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 26.--Louis Perrine, aged 23, an employe of the New-Jersey Southern Raliroad at Long Branch, shot himself in the right temple late last night, inflicting what is suppose to be a mortal wound.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 26.--Miss Mary Knendsen of Perth Amboy-was taken to the insane asylum to-day. She is 17 years of age and, it is said, was made insane partly by hard study.

Four suits for slander have been begun against Edward Corrigan, the Chicago race horse man. The plaintiffs are Henry P. Townsley, James T.Winter, Archibald R. Wilson, and Mary J. Wilson. The suits grow out of alleged slanderous words attered by Corrigan at a meeting of the Directors of the Chicago Fair and Trotting Breeders' Association Monday.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 26.--Many of the residents of the lower part of the city were out seal hunting yesterday. Every Winter a number of seals come up the Raritan as far as the canal outlet at New-Brunswick, and then turn back. That was the situation yesterday when the first seal of the season appeared. The seal escaped all his pursuers.

NEWBURG, N.Y., March 26.--The remains of Capt. George A. Price, United States Army, who died at Fort Elliott, Texas, in June last, are expected to arrive here for burial on Saturday, having left the fort this morning. A delegation of officers from West Point will attend the funeral, and the arrangements will be in charge of the Grand Army posts of this city. The interment will be in Woodlawn Cemetery.

PITTSBURG, March 26.--Two families prominent in the Presbyterian Church of Emsworth have become involved in a quarrel which has demanded the action of the church session and threatens to divide the church and the community into hostile factions.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.Y., March 26.--The sporting men of New-Brunswick are greatly excited over a foot race which came off last night in Recreation Hall by which they lost thousands of dollars.

CHICAGO, March 26.--The Central warehouse, at the corner of Rush and North Water streets, took fire at about 4 o'clock this morning and, with its valuable store of teas and coffees, was burned to the ground, entailing an estimated loss of $1,250,000.
WHITE PLAINS, March 26.--The annual elections took place in the 22 towns of Westchester County to-day for the election of town officers.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 26.--The week ending to-night has been the most prosperous and brilliant one of the present season. The demonstration that Mr. Flagler caused to be made in honor of ex-President Cleveland and party, who were his guests While here, was something indescribable.

NEWBURG, N.Y., March 26.--The probabilities are that the art collection tendered the city by the nephew of the late Henry K. Brown, the sculptor, consisting of all his models, pictures, drawings, and sketches, wiil not be accepted, owing to certain restrictions imposed.
Col. Stephen Van Rensselaer Cruger returned from Washington yesterday, but he has little to say to the general inquirer about the reason or rasults of his visit.
According to the announcement made by him some time ago, P.T. Barnum, the famous showman, has presented the tusks and the stuffed skin of the elephant Jumbo to Tuffts College.
WASHINGTON, March 26.--The Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon accepted 4 per cent. registered bonds to the amount of $16,500 at 108. The amount offered was $1,105,000 at the same price.

CHICAGO, March 26.--The resent active operations of the Union Pacific guillatine, and the sudden and unexpected shifting about of various officers of the road have attracted a good deal of attention and comment.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 26.--Prof. J.V. Brower, who has been commissioned by the Minnesota Historical Society to make a scientific survey of the Mississippi River, to further establish the truth or falsity of Capt. Willard Glazier's claims, returned to the city to-day, ...
Mayor Grant informed the Board of Aldermen yesterday that he had signed the ordinance directing the Chambers-Street and Grand-Street Railroad Company to employ conductors on its cars.

Experienced sportsmen believe that English snipe may confidently be looked for earlier than usual this season, owing to the open Winter. Immediately after a northeast storm, when the weather is warm, is the time of all times when it is best to go out in quest of this highly-prized game bird.

Love-sick Ora W. Wallace was taken before Justice Weed in Jersey City yesterday on a charge of having unduly importuned Mrs. Wade, a pretty widow, to marry him. Two months ago he went into Mrs. Wade's house, at 24d York-street, to board.

President Bayles of the Board of Health sent to the Mayor yesterday a letter, asking him to request the Board of Education to take some action respecting the condition of the public school in West One Hundred and Fourthstreet, where Miss Rebecea W. Gibbs contracted the fever of which she died last week.
One of the first acts of the new Administration in connection with the minor service was the replacement of the notorious AQUILA JONES as Postmaster at Indianapolis by Mr. WILLIAM WALLACE.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., March 26.--The madstone was yesterday applied to another of the four children of the Rush County (Ind.) farmer who were bitten two weeks ago.

The New-York Academy of Anthropology met at Cooper Union yesterday afternoon and listened to a lecture by Henry G. Hanchett, M. D., on "The Unconscious Man." There was a very large attendance, and Dr. Hanchett's paper was given undivided attention.

WICHITA, Kan., March 26.--The Oklahoma boomers here are highly indignant to-night over the slowness manifested by the Administration in issuing the proclamation.

A more studious assembly of men could not be found yesterday than the celebrated chess players who are competing for prizes in the sixth American Chess Congress at 8 Unionsquare. Cups of coffee were placed next to the chess boards and, occasionally, a pony of brandy was deemed necessary for proper exhiliaration of the mind. The cigars the players smoked are strong, and two or three of them affect well-burned pipes.
There was another important sale of dress fabrics yesterday at Field, Chapman Fenner's auction rooms, 364 Broadway.

Suit was entered yesterday in the United States Circuit Court, with the Government as plaintiff, and Adam Badeau, Horace Porter, and Frederick D. Grant, "Administrators of the goods, chattels, and credits of Ulysses S. Grant, deceased, as defendants."

The case of Mrs. Jessie Reynolds, wife of Dr. William M. Reynolds of Flushing, Long Island, who was charged jointly with her husband with falsifying insurance returns, came up before Recorder Smyth yesterday.

Alfred E. Owers, proprietor of a shoe factory in Williamsburg, had occasion to handle a can of oil in his office yesterday afternoon. It was about 1 o'clock when a boy of 15 years came down stairs from the shop with a fivegallon measure.

STILLWATER, Minn., March 28.--Warden Stordock was seen to-day with reference to the charges made against tue prison management by ex-Convict Wallace Brigham in a St. Paul morning paper.

In a country where government depends upon the will of the people and political questions must be decided by a majority vote the bribing of voters ought to be regarded as one of the most infamous and detestable of crimes.

The fourth concert of the New-York Philharmonic Club was given at Chickering Hall last evening. It cannot be said with justice that the concert was especially interesting, though it had one or two moments of relief.

There was an industrious scene all day yesterday in the examination room of the Civil Service Commission at Cooper Union, where competition was in progress for two classes of position within the jurisdiction of the State board. At the head of the room sat Prof. Melvil Dewey,

Judge Van Hoesen, in the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday rendered a decision for the plaintiff in the case of Mary J. Odell against the Manhattan Elevated Railroad. The suit was for damage to premises at the northeast corner of Ninth-avenue and Fifty-ninth-street, Sackett and Bennett appearing for the plaintiff. Judge Van Hoesen allowed $4,000 for damages to the building and $1,200 for loss of rental.

BALTIMORE, March 26.--Sister Benedicta, Superior of the new City Hospital being erected at Calvert and Saratoga streets, to-day received a cheek for $150, forwarded by Emperor William of Germany for the benefit of the institution.

The new Union-Square Theatre, spick and span and glittering, was shown to the public for the first time last night. Manager Hill got out of a sick bed to come and look at it and thought the effort well repaid him. So did his friends, who crowded around to congratulate him on having so beautiful a house.

"Le Juif Polonais" was performed at the Star Theatre last evening, with Coquelin as Mathis, the Alsatian peasant who murders a wandering polish Jew to secure a large sum of money the victim carries in a belt, hides the body in a limekiln, prospers thereafter, with ...

WASHINGTON, March 26.--The United States delegates to the approaching Maritime Conference met at the Depertment of State to-day for the purpose of consultation and arranging a programme for the conduct of the conference.
The contracts by means of which the jute-bagging combination of last year was made expired by limitation at the end of the year.

The thief who stole Charles A. Burger's overcoat Saturday night from the drug store at the corner of Broome and Ludlow streets made a better haul than he knew. Mr. Burger not only keeps the drug store, but he is a dealer in rare stamps.
The Centennial Celebration Committee have received from Mrs. Martha J. Lamb a suggestion as to a feature for the celebration which seems well worth carrying out.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 26.--The Occidental and Oriental steamer Arabic arrived late last night, bringing Hong-Kong news to Feb. 28, and Yokohama advices to March 11.

The Distributing Committee of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Collection fund met yesterday afternoon in the Mayor's office. There were present Mayor Grant, Chairman, and Messrs. Charles S. Smith, Edward Cooper, Jesse Seligman, and Cornelius Vanderbilt.

A New-York Steam Company pipe, that twin peril to pedestrians and property, of the explosive manhole, sprung a big leak in Liberty street near Nassau early yesterday morning and started the pavement for a space of ...
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 26.--Ex-Gov. Thomas H. Watts, who was a Whig leader before the war and has been a stalwart figure in the Democratic Party of Alabama for 25 years, ...

Mayor Chapin was not a witness in this city's great tax suit yesterday. He came to the hearing, but he had so many other engagements that Judge Countryman, the Referee, and all the counsel excused him. He will give his testimony in this city some time in April.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 26.--Three or the instructors in the preparatory school of Rutgers College, including the head master, the Rev. George F. Jewett, have resigned, and their places are to be filled, as well as that of a fourth, by the Trustees. Mr. Jawett resigns to take more congenial work in a public school. Mr. E.D. Merriman resigns for a year's rest, and Mr. H.B. Niver goes to Johns Hopkins University.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 26.--The Rev. Dr. Theodore L. Cuyler, at the request of Dr. McCosh and others, lectured on temperance before a large audience here to-night. The town elections take place next week. Dr. Curyler's lectture last year contributed much toward carrying the town for "no license."
HAVANA, March 26.--Ex-President Cleveland and party returned today from Santa Rosa, to which place they went yesterday.
PARIS, March 26.--M. Kuehn, formerly Police Inspector at Avricourt, has been sent to prison for two years as a German spy.

Abbey, Schoeffel Grau will not manage the tour of Mrs. Potter next season. Their contract with her expires in June, and it will not be renewed, both parties being perfectly satisfied with this arrangement.

Hermine Schwenk, a pretty young woman, aged 20, residing with her parents at Tompkinsville, Staten Island, yesterday caused the arrest of John Larkin, a well-known young man of Clifton, who, she says, is her husband, on a ...
SAN FRANCISCO, March 26.--Drafts--Sight, 17 ; telegraphic 22 .

TRENTON, N.J., March 26.--The Democrats of the House to-day showed an utter disregard for all decorum. For some reason Messrs. Patterson of Monmouth, Keys of Passaic, and Schmelz of Essex were absent, and, as soon as the Democrats had 29 members present, they moved a call of the House.
Deputy Sheriff Kaufman yesterday sold out the effects of the Manhattan Clock Company of No. 58 Warren-street on execution for $4,301, in favor of M.S. Frost, the President, for money advanced.
PARIS, March 26.--Several papers state that a judicial inquiry into the formation of the copper syndicate has been begun.

Superintendent Murray yesterday informed the Police Commissioners that at the request of the Counsel to the Corporation he had obtained and forwarded to that official evidence of the character of the entertainments given at Poole's Theatre. Third-Avenue Theatre,

Probate Clerk Tinney was surprised yesterday when he was presented with a small paper-covered book, bearing a wonderful picture of Indians on horseback, game, and white hunters in various positions, on the cover.

The Jute Bagging Trust people are evidently intending to run things with a high hand this year. Last year they controlled the product pretty well, but they had neglected to secure all the jute butts in the market, and the result was that prices did not go higher than about 12 cents a yard.

PATERSON, N.J., March 26.--The will of Samuel Pope of Paterson was made public today. By it he bequeathes $10,000 to the Paterson General Hospital for the endowment fund and $10,000 to the Paterson Orphan Asylum. To his widow he leaves property which will secure her an annual income of $17,000 or $18,000 a year. The remainder of his estate, which is valued at $400,000, goes to the children of an adopted daughter.
The old fight between the property owners of the Twenty-third Ward, in the annexed district, and the New-York Central Railroad Company has broken out anew.

EXETER, N.H., March 26.--The members-elect of the New-Hampshire Legislature of 1889 are in a state of terrible uncertainty as to whether there will he a railroad war this year or not. At least one-half of those who are to sit in the Legislature this Summer are hoping as hard as they can that there will be such a war.

BELVIDERE, N.J., March 26.--James Martin, a well-to-do farmer living at Ballietville, Penn., died a few days ago, leaving a will by which he disinherited his only daughter, the result of a disagreement 50 years age.

THE HAGUE, March 26.--Upon the assembling of the lower house of Parliament to-day the Prime Minister announced that the Cabinet had decided that the King was incapacitated for carrying on the Government and had communicated this decision to the State Council. The declaration of the Council in the matter is now awaited.

The proposed extension of the New-York, Ontario and Western Railroad into the Pennsylvania coal fields elicits earnest approbation from the towns on the route, which see commercial advantages in the new outlet for their trade.

Gen. McNulta, Receiver of the Wabash, held a conference with Chairman Abbott of the Western States Passenger Association yesterday at Chicago in regard to the arrangement for reduced fares to the national encampment of the Grand Army at Milwaukee next August.

The new Wagner stateroom car Lorraine was opened for inspection yesterday, and the verdict of the hundred or more railroad men who visited it was that it is the neatest piece of car construction ever put on wheels. With a luxury of this kind at command, they agreed that it will be more comfortable hereafter to travel than to stay at home.

British naval officers have been given a chance to test their guns on armor and have learned some interesting lessons. The attack on the Resistance took place a week ago. The old iron-clad had her sides and deck heavily armored for the experiment. Her deck was made in the form of a turtle-back. The shells used were filled with powder, gun cotton, and lyddite.

The annual dinner of the Princeton Alumni of New-York and vicinity will be given to-night at the Hotel Brunswick, beginning at 6:30 o'clock. President Patton will be present, and in his address will make important announcements as to gifts to the college and additions to the college courses. Other speakers will be F. Hopkinson Smith, Ethelbert P. Warfield, Ph.D., President of Miami University; Francis Ormond French, Frederick W. Hinrichs, and Chauncey M. Depew.
AMHERST, Mass., March 27.--The heavy gymnastic exhibition occurred to-day at the Pratt Gymnasium. Four college records were broken.

ALBANY, March 27.--New-York City's muchtalked-of new Music Hall Company was incorporated to-day by the Secretary of State, with a capital of $300,000. Andrew Carnegie, Walter Damrosch, Stephen M. Kneval, Morris Reno, and William B. Tuthill are Trustees.

The rumor committees seemed to be somewhat exhausted yesterday. No new railway Receiverships were created. No more banking houses were wound up. The day was dull. Yet more people were in good humor, and the market, so much as there was of it, showed a firmness almost like strength.
A complete service of fast express trains is now in operation between New-York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, and Washington via Bound Brook route and Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.

The new Union-Square Theatre is handsome and comfortable. The aisles and vestibules are broad and spacious, the rows of seats are not too close together. The decorations are bright and cheerful and the auditorium is probably the most brilliantly lighted in the city.

A large crowd of people visited the ruins of Albert E. Ower's shoe factory at 389, 391, and 393 Kent-avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday, in the expectation of seeing many bodies taken from them, but a careful search failed to dis cover a single victim of the fire.

ALBANY, March 27.--Senator Murphy introduced a bill which is likely to create something of an excitemnt within the ranks of the committee having in charge the preparations for the Washington centennial celebration.

The town officials of Jamaica, Long Island, have submitted their annual reports. Supervisor Brinckerhoff reports his receipts from all sources $27,173 98; expenditures, $19,431 46. Overseer of the Poor Pearsall reports: Receipts, $9,808 07; disbursements, $7,560 10. Other reports of minor importance were reported correct.
Emmons Blaine of Chicago is at the Everett House.
The annual election of the Staten Island Athletic Club was held at the clubhouse at West New-Brighton, Staten Island, last night.
SCRANTON, Penn., March 27.--The large dry goods establishment of Cleland, Simpson Taylor, with its enormous stock of goods, valued at $200,000, was destroyed by fire this evening.
PHILADELPHIA, March 27.--Albert Frey, the world's champion pool player, and Alfred De Oro played an exciting game of pool to-night at the Union League Annex.

Capt. Axel Severin Aslaksen of the Norwegian steamer Amieitia will hereafter carry a heavy gold watch and chain of American make, which was presented to him on Tuesday after noon in recognition of his humanity and bravery. The watch bears the following inscription:

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 27.--Charles Rupert, a wholesale dealer in country produce at Newark, N.J., was ejected from a train on the Pennsylvania Railroad in this city to-day and strongly resisted the officer, who had to carry him out of his seat, while the conductor lugged out his sachel and other articles.

PITTSBURG, March 27.--At Wilmerding, on the Pennsylvania Railroad near Pittsburg, the Westinghouse Air-brake Company is creating a town modeled after Pullman of Illinois. The air-brake works in Allegheny have long been cramped for room, and Mr. George Westinghouse, Jr., determined to extend them.

While the Kerr case was on trial talesmen complained that they had been followed in the streets and even into their homes by men who questioned them respecting their views on the "boodle" matters, and that their families had been pestered by the same officious persons.

For nearly forty years JOHN BRIGHT has divided with Mr. GLADSTONE the fame of the first orator in England. Mr. GLADSTONE'S power of oratory was acquired in the House of Commons, to which he had passed by the regular grades of Eton and Oxford.

Manager A.M. Palmer made arrangements yesterday under which Miss Minnie Maddern will produce "Featherbrain" for a run at the Madison-Square Theatre, beginning May 6, or at the close of the regular season at that house.
WASHINGTON, March 27.--Senator Palmer, who has accepted the Spanish mission, said today:

The Patchogue way train from Long Island City ran off the track at Belmont Junction yesterday afternoon. No one was injured, but the passengers were all well shaken up. After a short delay the passengers were transferred to another train and carried to destination. The track was reported clear at midnight.

COLUMBIA, S.C., March 27.--The first case ever tried in the courts of this State under the statute of 1859 allowing damages to be recovered by the widow and children or other beneficiaries of a man who had been unlawfully slain came up in the Greenville Court of Common Pleas Monday.

No doubt there were many curiosity seekers at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening. These saw a wiry little man, with a strikingly-intellectual head and a picturesquely-nervous manner, conduct an orchestra with a marvelously-expressive variety of gestures.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 27.--To-day an officer of the War Department at Washington came here to take charge of Capt. Craft of the United States Army, who has been in confinement here since Monday evening.

SCRANTON, Penn., March 27.--The political guillotine is working smoothly in Pennsylvania under the Harrison regime. A few days ago Congressman Scranten, who represents the Lackawanna district, sent for Postmaster Connolly of this city, and politely demanded his resignation.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 27.--A big party of Frenchmen is about starting from Chicago for Western Wyoming and Northern Colorado, where they will spend the next few months in a search for specimens of the game of North America, which they propose to capture alive and transport to the museums and public gardens of Paris.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 27.--Drafts--Sight, 17 ; telegraphic, 22 1/8.

The Park Commissioners decided yesterday to put a new cover of asphalt over the present pavement foundation of the esplanade in front of the City Hall and to repair the main paths of Tompkins-square and as many of the minor paths as can be covered by an expenditure of $15,000.
PATERSON, N.J., March 27.--Last Fall the Republican Street Superintendent of Paterson, N.J., swung all the influence of his office to elect Alderman John Mallon, Democrat, to the State Senate.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., March 27.--The fruit growers and farmers of Western New-York are not feeling over and above good. The causes are the low prices in the apple market and the swindling operations of Chicago commission men.

The steamer Horrox, Capt. Rendle, from Rio Janiero, arrived at this port yesterday. Capt. Rendle reports that when they went into port at Santos on Feb. 25 he found the town pest-ridden with yellow fever.

LONDON, March 27.--This was the third day of the Lincoln Spring meeting. The race for the Lincolnshire Handicap of 1,000 sovereigns, for 3-year-olds and upward, at one mile, was won by half a length by Wise Man. Acme was second and The Baron third. There were 26 starters. The last betting was 8 to 1 against Wise Man, 10 to 1 against Acme, 17 to 1 against The Baron.

WASHINGTON, March 27.--The trouble between George A. Armes, a retired officer of the army, living in this city, and those having charge of the Harrison inaugural parade, culminated this afternoon in a scene in the rotunda of the Rigge House.

ALBANY, March 27.--There are two ex-Senators in the present Assembly who are ambitious to be returned to the Senate next Fall-- Frederick S. Gibbs and Thomas J. Creamer. Their past reputations have been such as to justify the closest scrutiny of their legislative conduct, but up to to-day nothing occurred to require them to show their hands or their propensities.

Mrs. Robert L. Stuart, widow of the millionaire sugar refiner, is lying very ill with pneumonia in her home at Sixty-eighth-street and Fifth-avenue. Mrs. Stuart is nearly 75 years old, and because of her advanced age her friends are alarmed at her condition.

LONDON, March 27.--Mr. John Bright died at 8:30 o'clock this morning. His end was peaceful and painless. He had lain in a comatose condition since yesterday. All of his family were present at his deathbed.

A whole family, six in number, were poisoned at Plymouth, Penn., yesterday, by eating a wild turnip, which was dug from the ground in mistake for horse radish and served at breakfast. James McBride and wife, Charles McBride, Edward Foley, Edward Mullen, and Edward Kennedy are in a critical condition, and physicians say Kennedy and Charles McBride are certain to die.

Richly decorated and crowded by a gay assemblage of invited guests, the hall and larger rooms of the Harlem Democratic Club's house, at 13 East One Hundred and Twentyfifth-street, last evening presented a more than usually brilliant appearance.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 27.--The debate on the Jesuit question was resumed in the House of Commons to-day by Mr. Dalton McCarthy, who, notwithstanding his Irish name, spoke strongly in favor of disallowing the act. He denied that the Jesuits before the suppression held their estates for educational purposes. Avarice, he said, was their sin.
There is little doubt that the fire in the barns of the Catholic Protectory in Westchester early yesterday morning was the work of an incendiary.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 27.--The first ballot for United States Senator in Grand Committee of the Legislature to-day resulted as follows: Dixon, 43; Wetmore, 31; Arnold, (Dem.,) 15; Colt and Durfee, 5 each; Goddard, 4; Taft, 2. Dixon gained 2 and Wetmore 3 over the ballot of yesterday.

Bids for lighting the streets with gas and electric lamps for the year beginning May 1 were opened by the Gas Commission yesterday. The bids of the gas companies, in the several districts now occupied by them, were, per lamp: Consolidated and Mutual, $17 50, the ...

Mr. HARRISON yesterday completed the list of nominations for the principal diplomatic posts in Europe by sending to the Senate the names of ROBERT T. LINCOLN for England, MURAT HALSTEAD for Germany, and ALLEN T. RICE for St. Petersburg.

The Hospital Book and Newspaper Society, a branch of the State Charities Aid Association, distributes reading matter among more than 50 institutions, including pauper hospitals, almshouses, insane asylums, and penal establishments, whose inmates number over 13,000 persons.
WASHINGTON, March 27.--The President sent the following nominations to the Senate to-day:

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 27.--A mass meeting was held under the auspices of the Hibernian Society to-night in memory of the late Capt. Dawson, the editor of the News and Courier, who was assassinated on the 12th inst. by Dr. McDow.

WASHINGTON, March 27.--The President to-day issued a proclamation throwing open the Oklahoma lands to settlement on and after April 22. The bulk of the proclamation, which is a long document, is devoted to a review of the proceedings by which the lands in question have been secured by the Indians and the legislation of Congress providing for their opening to settlement. The proclamation then reads as follows:

PRINCETON, N.J., March 27.--The new Board of Editors of the Princetonian has been chosen and is as follows: From the Junior Class--T.F. Chambers, managing editor; W.C. Prime and J.S. Vancleve, associate managers; G.M. Gait, Treasurer, and K.L. Ames, D.D. Casement, and A.L. Shrady. From the Sophomore Class--J.S. Black and A.P. Dennis. From the Freshman Class--C.O. Mudge.

Though the boats of the Conserva which were brought into Stapleton, Staten Island, and Cape May, N.J., by pilot boats yesterday would seem at first to be conclusive evidence that a serious accident had befallen that vessel, they are by no means conclusive proof that she is not still afloat.

Silence held its usual sway yesterday at the chess tournament that is going on at 8 Union-Square. Among the spectators was Paul von Frankenberg U. Proschlitz, President of the Breslau (Germany) Chess Club, who came over as the representative of his club to witness the tournament. Years ago he lived in this city, and was one of the organizers and President of the New-York Chess Club.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27.--Col. Fred D. Grant, the new Minister to Austria, and his wife, stopped for an hour or two in this city to-day, the guests of Mr. George W. Childs. The Colonel was in the best of health, and eager to set out on his mission.
DUBLIN, March 27.--Michael Davitt will be Chairman of the meeting to be addressed by Henry George in this city.
The big stores of A.H. King Co., clothiers of 627 and 629 Broadway, were densely crowded last night to witness one of the most novel of Spring openings.

The fourth and last lecture by W.J. Henderson on the history of music will be delivered at the New-York College of Music, 163 East Seventieth-street, to-morrow evening at 8:15. The subject of the discourse will be "Wagner and the Future of Opera."

SAN SEBASTIAN, March 27.--Queen Victoria paid her expected visit to San Sebastian to-day. Her Majesty was accompanied by Prince and Princess Henry of Battenberg and members of her suite, including Lady Churchill.
The Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday directed the Controller to issue bonds to the amount of $9,860,276 93 to pay for the land in the new parks and parkways.

CHICAGO, March 27.--The order issued by the Inter-State Commerce Commission calling upon the Grand Trunk Railway of Canada to explain charges of unlawful manipulation of rates on traffic originating in the United States has attracted much attention in Chicago local railway circles.

Republican workers of the Platt faction were wrapped in gloom last evening. Louis F. Payn, Gen. John M. Knapp, Bernard Biglin, John A. Schleicher of the Albany Journal, and others of the faithful wandered about the office of the Fifth-Avenue, looking as if their best friend had just died after making a will cutting them off without a cent.
WASHINGTON, March 27.--The Senate this afternoon confirmed the following nominations:
CITY OF MEXICO, March 27, via Galveston.--It is reported that the Government will re-form the concession for a railroad from Deming to the mines in the Sierra Madre.

A bronze bust of Victor Hugo, cast by M. Rodin from the model he made in 1883, shortly before the poet's death, had a curious adventure. It was bought by a collector in Besancon, who failed a little while afterward; his treasures were put up for sale in Lyons.

Schwartz Brothers, manufacturers of paper boxes at the corner of Centre and White streets, have dis posed of their business by bill of sale to Emanuel M. Ikelheimer, father-in-law of one of the partners. The transfer was made by David P. Schwartz in the absence of Julius Schwartz, his partner, who, it is said, is out of town sick.
A copy of the opinion of Chancellor Cobbs of Alabama upholding the rights of the minority stockholders of the Memphis and Charleston Railroad has been received in New-York.

The gossips of Parkville, one of the villages in Kings County, are deeply interested in the sudden departure for Europe on Saturday last of George McCaughlin, a son of one of the wealthy men in the place.

BOSTON, March 27.--A special meeting of the Board of Directors of the Union Pacific Railway Company was held in this city this morning. The draft of the annual report to be submitted to the stockholders was submitted, and in connection with it the question of the resumption of dividends was considered.

While the police steamer Patrol was coaling up at Weehawken yesterday afternoon, the three-masted schooner L.B. Cowperthwait of Boston, Capt. Rufus S. Wells, ran into her, carrying away the flag pole, part of the ridge pole, and part of the bulwarks. The total damage to the Patrol is about $75. The schooner was uninjured.

The final indoor parade of ceremony of the Seventh Regiment, prior to the retirement of Col. Emmons Clark, was held in the armory last night, the occasion being the public presentation to officers and members now in active service who have qualified of the Cross of Honor for long and faithful service.
An organization will be effected next week of the Brooklyn Training School and Home for Young Girls, when an act of incorporation will be drawn up and forwarded to Albany.

BRISTOL, R.I., March 27.--The work on the new torpedo boat for the navy is fast nearing completion, and the Herreshoffs expect to have it ready for trial during the coming May. Its hull is all in place, and the turtle-back shaped deck is finished except the fitting of a few more steel plates.
AUBURN, N.Y., March 27.--The amusing spectacle of three women claiming to be widows of one man entertained the lawyers and spectators in the Surrogate's Court in this city yesterday afternoon.
Amity Lodge, Independent Order Free Sons of Israel, had its annual masked ball last evening at the Lexington-Avenue Opera House.

Some time ago Thomas Connor, a beneficiary of the Naval Hospital, Philadelphia, died, leaving considerable money and property. The proceedings of the State courts as well as the grant of letters of administration in that State, purporting to escheat the property of the decedent to the State, have been declared by the Attorney-General of the United States to be irregular and void for want of jurisdiction.
Public Works Commissioner Smith has ordered the Polo Grounds fence across One Hundred and Eleventh-street taken down and kept down. He said yesterday that he would not permit it to be put up again.

Those who sympathize with the general position of the Democratic Party on national questions, especially that of reforming the national system of taxation, find themselves sorely tried by the reactionary and non-progressive conduct of the party on other matters.

Grolierites and other book collectors are much exercised over the announcement that the library of Robert Lenox Kennedy, nephew of the founder of the Lenox Library, will be sold, probably the last week in April, at the Fifth-Avenue Art Galleries.
Not much progress toward the conviction of Vincenzo Quarteraro for the murder of Antonio Flaecomio was made yesterday at his trial before Recorder Smyth.
The mounted troop heretofore known as the New-York Hussars has been accepted as an organization of the National Guard.

Chan Ah Lai, a Chinese cook who was with the British bark Victor when it was shipwrecked off the Bahamas early in March, and who was rescued and taken to Havana on the Ward Line steamer Clenfuegos, arrived here on that steamer recently and was detained by the customs authorities.

Some one put a torpedo on the car track in front of the Fifth-Avenue Hotel last night about 10 o'clock and a Broadway ear rolled over it. There was an explosion that made people think the pavement had been blown up again, and it was with difficulty that the horses attached to the car were prevented from running away. For a time there was great excitement in the neighborhood.

LANCASTER, Penn., March 27.--Ex-Congressman John A. Hiestand sold his paper, the daily and weekly Examiner, this afternoon, to exSenate Clerk Thomas B. Cochran and Harry B. Cochran, his brother. The new firm enter upon the management at once. Mr. Hiestand's name is mentioned in connection with a Federal appointment.

The assembly rooms of the Metropolitan Opera House were filled with members of the Nineteenth Century Club and their guests last evening, who came to hear a lecture by Mr. B. F. Underwood, formerly of Boston and now of Chicago, on "The Relations of Ethics and Religion."

The British warship Medusa, the first launched of the new class of cruisers building in England, has had her trial for horse power. It was extremely successful, and British naval officers are enthusiastic over the result.
The Executive Committee of the West Washington Market Association presented to Mayor Grant yesterday a request that he should move the Sinking Fund Commissioners to ...

The Committee on Appeals of the Republican County Committee did much work last night. It listened to testimony in the cases of the citizens of the Fourth and Fourteenth Assembly Districts, who assert that they are good Republicans, yet were refused the right to enroll their names on the party lists on Jan. 25.

The demand for dress materials of a high grade of texture and rich coloring has resulted this year in the production by manufacturers of siks and dress fabrics far surpassing the efforts of any previous season. At the store of B. Altman Co., Eighteenth and Nineteenth streets and Sixth-avenue, many of these exquisite novelties are displayed.

The announcement by Secretary TRACY of the vacancies that will soon exist in the naval cadetships, and also of the following series of prospective vacancies, has an additional interest from the fact that the law rearranging the course at Annapolis takes effect during the present year.
Gertrude Johnson, a young girl of 16 years, is lying in a critical condition at the house of her father, George E. Johnson, 55 Sheffield-avenue, East New-York.

WASHINGTON, March 27.--Secretary of State Blaine has received a report from the Consul of the United States at Colon, stating that work along the Panama Canal has entirely ceased, and that the West India negroes are returning to their homes. The Consul reports great depression in business.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 27.--The applications for the new 4 per cent. consolidated stock, into which the 5 per cent. loans are to be converted, have been so numerous that the lists with regard to the issues of 1870, 1872, 1873, and 1884 were closed yesterday.

PARIS, March 27.--Comptoir d'Escompte shares closed at 85f., Rio Tinto shares at 292f. 50c. and Societe des Metaux shares at 27f. 50c. Prices on the Bourse to-day were generally well supported, but the closing was dull on rumors affecting one of the principal credit houses.
The Nominating Committee of the Columbia Yacht Club will make up a list of officers this evening for the consideration of the members at the annual meeting the latter part of next month.

VIENNA, March 27.--Count Hoyos, the trusted friend of Crown Prince Rudolph, is said to have fought a duel with and shot Count Baltazzi, the uncle of Baroness Vetsera, whose death was associated with that of the Crown Prince. The duel is said to have been fought at a village in the south of France.

The trial of Frank E. Pearson, charged with the larceny of $500 from Mrs. Annie B. Wakefield, which was begun before Judge Gildersleeve, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, revives the story of the more or less remarkable romance in which these two people figured.
The mysteries of club life were revealed to the lady friends of the members of the Fellowcraft Club yesterday afternoon.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 27.--The commission appointed by ex-Secretary of the Navy Whitney to select a site for a navy yard on the South Atlantic or Gulf coast arrived this evening by the Louisville and Nashville train from Mobile.
HAVANA, March 27.--Mr. Cleveland and his party embarked to-day on the steamer Olivette for Tampa.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 27.--At a special session of the Union County courts this morning eloquent tributes were delivered by Judge McCormick. Prosecutor Wilson, Postmaster Lindsay of Rahway, exSurrogate Cerber, and others, to the memory of the late Judge Enos W. Runyon of Plainfield.

Bloom, at 287 5th-av., is taking the lead this season in showing highest novelties in the art of Dress and Cloak making. We were courteously received in the elegant reception rooms and permitted to inspect some truly artistic creations in ladies' gowns and wraps adapted for Spring and Summer wear; also some unique tailor-made garments.

TRENTON, N.J., March 27.--Mr. Farrell and his Harrison-Kearny consolidation measure have caused a dead lock. The all-night session of yesterday ran into the morning and then to noon and until 1:40 this afternoon, when adjournment was had.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27.--Mr. Keely's counsel announced to-day that the former has new in his possession the "missing link" which was needed to make the "vibratory resonator and ethereal generative evaporator" a success.

At a meeting of the Coffee Exchange yesterday afternoon Cornelius Morrison presented a recommendation of the Board of Managers to purchase the loss covered by 66, 68, and 70 Beaver-street and 113, 115, and 117 Pearlstreet and to erect on the land a suitable build ing.
ENSENADA, Lower California, March 27.--A discovery is reported here which is said to be filling the International Land Company people with dread.
The next Westchester Board of Supervisors will stand 17 Democrats and 5 Republicans, a larger Democratic majority than has ever been obtained before.

Judge Daly, in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday, simplified the trial of the suit of Clara M. Totten against Cassius H. Read by ruling that releases signed by Miss Totten Sept. 22, 1884, were in force, and that the jury need only consider what damages Miss Totten was entitled to in case it was proved that Mr. Read promised to marry her at or after the making of the releases.
ELIZABETH, N.J., March 27.--The public schools of this city will close on Friday at noon for the Spring vacation of one week.
Judge Lawrence of the Supreme Court has granted an absolute divorce in favor of Helen G. Bishop from Mind Reader Washington Irving Bishop.
An important opinion has been handed down by Judge Barrett, in Supreme Court, Special Term, in relation to the taxation of joint stock companies as corporations.

The Rev. Mr. Barker of Ocean Grove, N. J., has been conducting nightly revival meetings for two weeks as St. Mark's Methodist Episcopal Church at Pleasant Plains, Staten Island. The meetings were brought to a close last night.

David Mr. Peyser has resigned from his position on the staff of Henry E. Abbey, and is no longer connected with any of Mr. Abbey's enterprises. His place as business manager or Mrs. Patter's company has been taken by Jeff S. Leerburger. Charles H. Mathews, who represented Mr. Abbey with the Mary Anderson company, has been loaned to the Metropolitan ...

Superintendent Simpson of Castle Garden is constantly in receipt of letters from various parts of the country requesting him to select a wife from among the immigrant girls for gentlemen inclined to matrimony who are too bashful to make the selection themselves.

Policeman James Holton of the Staten Island force yesterday arrested four sailors-- Peter Beagan, Oliff Carson, Merris Steenstrum, and Arthur Gevecke--charged with stealing six bags of raw sugar, which they were about to dispose of.

Committees from the Authors' Club, the Church Club, the Princeton Club, the Association of Yale Alumni, the Society of Amateur Photographers, the Salmagundi, and the Architectural League met last night at the rooms of the Authors' Club. 19 West Twenty-fourthstreet, to consider plans which have been presented to them relative to a new building and site for a clubhouse.
An aged German woman who gave her name as Christina Myers went before Justice Duffy at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday and asked him to send her to some old ladies' home.
A scene in the noted Carter divorce case occurred in this city yesterday. Mr. Lester Carter, the Chicago lawyer, and his counsel, and Mrs. Carter and her counsel, all of ...

PHILADELPHIA, March 28.--Mayor Edwin H. Fitler's splendid mansion at Sixteenth and Walnut streets was the scene to-night of a dinner given by the Mayor to John Wanamaker in complimentary recognition of his selection as Posmaster-General of the United States.

Judge Lawrence of the Supreme Court yesterday granted an order to show cause on April 3 why the Denver, Texas and Fort Worth Railroad Company the Colorado Construction Company, and the Mercantile Trust Company ...

An inanimate Bengal tiger, with gaping jaws, crouched over the head of President Henry Van Dyke, D.D., in the main banquer hall of the Brunswick Hotel last evening. It was the annual dinner of the Princeton Alumni of New-York and vicinity.

ANTWERP, March 28.--Ferdinand Vandertaelen, a merchant prince of this city, committed suicide yesterday. The act was due to the failure of several allied firms, whose liabilities will probably reach a colossal sum. Mr. Vandertaelen was a leading member of the Liberal Party and had been dubbed the John Bright of Belgium.

VIENNA, March 28.--The report that a duel had been fought between Count Hoyos and count Baltazzi proves to be without foundation. Count Henry Baltazzi is in Madeira, and the other male members of the Baltazzi family are either in Vienna or at their residences in Moravia. Count Hoyos, who has been visiting his brother in Paris, returned to Vienna to-day.
An alarm of fire from Fifth-avenue and Forty-fourth-street and the hurrying of fire engines attracted a large crowd of excited spectators quickly together in front of the Berkeley ...

Collector Magone had another Chinese puzzle on his hands yesterday. When the steamer City of Columbia of the Ward Line arrived hare yesterday she had on board Chung Suez and Dimar Ayon, laborers, and Yan Yen Wan, Domingo Vapor, and Alvaro Adin, who called themselves merchants.

LONDON, March 28.--The Chicago and All America baseball clubs sailed in the White Star Line steamer Adriatic from Queenstown for New-York to-day. A crowd gathered to see them off and gave them an ovation. The members of the clubs are elated over their reception in Great Britain and Ireland. It is certain that baseball will become one of the features of British sport.

Vernon G. Simpson, son of A. Simpson, a produce merchant at Norfolk, Va., arrived in this city Wednesday and put up at the Northwestern Hotel on Chambers-street. He spent a portion of the day at the store of Vogel Brautigan, commission merchants, at 104 Parkpiase. and in the afternoon took a drive with Mr. Brautigan.
TOPEKA, Kan., March 28.--President Harrison's proclamation throwing open to settlement on April 22 a portion of the Indian Territory lands has caused the Oklahoma fever to break out afresh.

Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday listened to argument on the order to show cause why Judge Ingraham's warrant committing Graham McAdam for contempt should not be set aside. He reserved his decision, although he seemed to be convinced that Judge Ingraham had acted within his anthority.

Duncan B. Harrison, Who has been unable to fill his part in "The Paymaster" at the Fourteenth-Street Theatre since Tuesday night, was said to be improving by his physician last night. Mr. Harrison has suffered from a severe attack of tonsillitis, which, though painful, has not been dangerous. It is probable that he will resume his duties to-morrow night.

Mr. Kimball of St. Lawrence County is rapidly acquiring fame as a cunning member. The vicious custom has become popular this year of jumping bills to a third reading without considering them in general orders.

A matter of peculiar interest to taxpayers is under consideration by the city officers. It is as to whether it is better to increase the annual tax rates so as to pay for local improvements as they are made, meanwhile letting the sinking fund grow with the annual additions to it of the revenues from city property until it shall have wiped out the city debt, or to keep on ...

It was Generally admitted yesterday that it was impossible that the life raft upon which the two dead men were Seen by the officers of the Colorado could have belonged to the Conserva. The agent of the Conserva, H.R. Kunhardt, Jr., still refuses to believe that the vessel ...

All the evidence for the prosecution in the trial of Vincenzo Quarteraro, charged with the murder of Antonio Flaceomio, was put in yesterday before Recorder Smyth, and none of it showed that Quarteraro struck the blow that caused Flaceomio's death.

A fashionably-attired couple walked into Justice Seymour's office in Hoboken a day or two ago and asked him to marry them. When he had made them one the groom fumbled nervously in his pockets and produced a two-dollar ...

JACKSON, Miss., March 28.--The committee appointed by the State Alliance to investigate the feasibleness of establishing one or more bagging factories in the State will meet here to-morrow. Several members of the committee are already here and the full committee ...

The Post Office inspectors yesterday arrested a man whom they are very glad to have within the clutches of the law. He has made use of three names in the last, month, those of Oscar Rathrock, Samuel D. McEwen, and James ...

There is a good deal of talk among the people in the Rev. Father Corrigan's parish in Hoboken over a recent sermon in denunciation of theatres. The Hoboken Dramatic Association is recruited largely from members of his church.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 28.--By a vote of 113 to 106 the House of Representatives this afternoon ordered the commutation of John H. Swift's sentence, which was to be executed on Friday of next week, to imprisonment for life.
Mayor Grant made a visit to the new aqueduct yesterday in the company of Commissioner Scott and Chief Engineer Fteley. He went down three shafts on either side of ...
Theodore Thomas, in his Ninth Orchestral Concert, held at Chickering Hall last night, treated his large audience to a superb rendering of Brahms's Serenade No. 2 and Dvorak's ...

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 28.--Col. W.W. Dudley is in the city on professional business. A dinner was given to him to-night by 12 prominent Republicans, the affair being a most pleasant one. Col. Dudley utterly disclaims the idea that he is in Tennessee to see how Republican campaign funds were spent.

CHICAGO, March 28.--Gen. McNulta, Receiver of the Wabash Railway, has sent a telegram to Judge Cooley, Chairman of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, urging an early ruling as to the legality of paying commissions on the sale of passenger tickets. Gen. McNulta says the Western roads continue to pay commissions, and no meeting has been called with a view to stopping it.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., March 28.--The citizens of this place have decided by a vote of 136 to 3 to incorporate the village as a borough. Next Tuesday seven Commissioners are to be elected, and there promises to be a lively fight. There will be two tickets in the field, one headed by George B. Sandt; the other will be known as the fishermen's ticket.

TRENTON, N. J., March 28.--The great chloroform ease between Michaelis and others and Roessler Hasslacker has been decided in favor of the defendants by Judge Butler of the United States Circuit Court, and the decision has been filed in Trenton. The case involved damages amounting to nearly $250,000, and affected nearly every druggist in the United States.

Edward Grell's "Missa Solemnis" was sung at the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the first time in America. The work is uncommon, though not wholly unique, and was heard with a good deal of interest. It is written for four quartets of solo voices and four four-part choruses a capella.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 28.--The second trial of Ferdinand Ciprico, the ex-Inspector of Customs charged with conspiracy and an attempt to defraud the United States Government by issuing fraudulent Chinese return certificates, resulted in his acquittal by the jury in the United States Circuit Court this afternoon.

ALBANY, March 28.--For two days it has been a question whether or not the New-York State troops would parade in the centennial procession. The trouble arose over the disinclination of the Committee on Plan and Scope of the Centennial Committee to allot proper facilities to ...

The jury in Judge Gildersleeve's court added another chapter in the romance of Frank E. Pearson and Mrs. Cyrus W. Wakefield, widow of Millionaire Wakefield of Wakefield, Mass., yesterday, and it was rather unpleasant for ...

NEW-ORLEANS, March 28.--The naval commission, escorted by the citizens' committed, embarked an the lighthouse tender Pansy this afternoon, and, going down the river, inspected the Federal reservation at Jackson Barracks, below the city, and also the property on the opposite bank of the river which was purchased some years ago by the Government with a view to establishing a navy yard there.

WASHINGTON, March 28.--The only bond offering received by Secretary Windom this morning was $100,000 registered 4 s at 108. This was accepted together with an offer of $2,000 4 per cents registered at 108.

There are so many beautiful things to be seen just now in the dry goods establishment of Le Boutillier Brothers, at Broadway and Fourteenth-street, a person comes out after having gone through the various departments with a mind something like a kaleidoscope.

An immense mass of papers lie on tables and desks in the office of the Commissioners of Accounts, and a dozen accountants are at work on them making up tables from the accounts of the Market Bureau, so far as they can be gathered from the books of that bureau which have been found.

Miss Nellie Kellner, a daughter of Moritz Kellner, was married last evening to Morris Wortman at the assembly rooms of the Metropolitan Opera House. The ceremony occurred at 7 o'clock, and was performed by the Rev. ...

FREDERICK, Md., March 28.--Two mysterious shocks were felt about 8 o'clock last night in and around Buckeystown. They are supposed to have been earthquakes. Today two horses belonging to a farmer fell through the ground 10 feet and have not yet been extricated.

SPRINGVIEW, Neb., March 28.--Mrs. Gannon, the wife of a settler living near the Dakota line, was in this town yesterday asking help in rescuing her husband from the Dakota Indians. Gannon and a number of other men were captured by a vigilance committee a couple of weeks ago on suspicion of being cattle thieves. The committee finally released them on their promise to leave the country at once.

Adolph Weichelbaumer, the young German who was killed by accidentally falling off a railroad platform at New-Brunswick, N. J., Wedneaday, was on his way from Chicago to Brooklyn to keep a marriage contract with Mary Hague, the sister-in-law of Ludwig Redenberg of 23 Monteith-street.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 28.--The Benton Consolidated Company has filed a complaint in the Superior Court against the estate of Seth Cook, deceased, to recover $15,029,500. The plaintiffs allege that the deceased by combination with the Board of Directors converted 150,295 of the company's shares to his own use. The stock is valued at $100 per share.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 28.--Miss Margareta Brua Cameron, daughter of United States Senator J. Donald Cameron, and John William Clark of Newark, N.J., were married at noon to-day by the Rev. Dr. George S. Chambers, Pastor of the Pine Street Presbyterian Church, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Waters of the Dutch Reformad Church, Newark.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28.--Henry W. Ray mond, editor and proprietor of the Germantown Telegraph, has received the appointment of private secretary to Secretary of the Navy Tracy. He will assume his duties next Monday. Mr. Raymond and the Secretary have long been warm friends. The former is a son of the late Henry J. Raymond of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 28.--Four sleepers reached the city this morning with the members of the Grand Lodge of B'nai B'rith, who came from Savannah to take part in the dedication of the Hebrew Orphan Asylum.

The stonecutters' Union sent a committee consisting of J. McCarthy, Charles D. Rogers, J.B. Dyer, and P. Kelly to visit Mayor Grant yesterday. They asked him to see that all stone for the new manicipal building should be cut here, and that the contracts for the work ...

CHICAGO, March 28.--The Trunk Line Association has sent out a notice to all connecting railroads, defining that feature of the agreement recently adopted in New-York, which portains to joint rates and interchange of ...

"Le Voyage de M. Perrichon," the sparkling but somewhat diaphanous comedy of Labiche and Martin, was the play at the Star Theatre last evening, and Coquelin portrayed again his delightful conception of the ingenuous carrossier in the presence of an audience which, both as to numbers and enthusiasm, completely filled the theatre.

"If you want to find a town where lawlessness is rampant, where a crowd of loafers rule things, and where on arrest is rarer than a day in June, don't go out to the wild and woolly West for it, young man, but simply pitch your ...

Referee George Putnam Smith resumed the trial of the quarrel between the Breslin and Quinn factions of District Assembly No. 49, Knights of Labor, yesterday. E.C. Kunze, the Recording Secretary of No. 49, was the only witness. He is a member of the Quinn faction, and his testimony tended to show than they were all right and their opponents all wrong.
WILMINGTON, N.C., March 28.--At the election to-day the Democrats elected seven out of ten Aldermen, a gain of one over the last election.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 28.--A decision was filed to-day by Judge Young which has an important bearing on the rulings of the State Railroad Commission. The case was that of the appeal of the St. Louis Road from an order of the...
Several shooting matches were held yesterday afternoon on John Erb's shooting grounds at Newark, N.J., and ware watched by about 100 men.
PATERSON, N.J., March 28.--Ex-Mayor Nathan Barnert, a wealthy resident of this city, has bought and presented to the congregation of B'nai Jeshurun a fine plot of land on Broadway, ...

LONDON, March 28.--This was the first day of the Liverpool Spring meeting. The race for the prince of Wales's Plate of 700 sovereigns in specie for 3-year-olds and upward at nearly six furlongs was won by Aintree, Cataract second, and St. Hubert third.

NEW-HAVEN, March 28.--The New-England Transportation Company, devoted to the towing of coal vessels on Long Island Sound from New-York, is about to build four ocean barges of 1,000 tons each, the largest ever built here. When completed they will, with four others, be put at once on a new route to be established by the company between the New-Jersey coal docks and Providence, R.I.

The stock of the bankrupt L.M. Bates Company, dealers in dry goods at Twenty-thirdstreet and Sixth-avenue, has been awarded by Judge Lawrence's decision to the firm of James A. Hearn Son of Fourteenth-street. The matter had been the subject of a legal dispute for several days. The Messrs. Hearn will take immediate possession of the goods.

BALTIMORE, March 28.--In settlement of the long-pending dispute between the city and County about the payment by the city for public property acquired when the city limits were extended two miles further north and west and the payment of the county for taxes since June last, Mayor Latrobe gave the county authorities a check for $106,000 and the county gave their check for $41,000.

It was rumored yesterday that the Fairmount Rowing Association's eight will join the New-York Athletic Club and row under its colors in the Harlem races this year. The rumor is denied in this city, however and no news to this effect has been received from Philadelphia. Byron, the Philadelphia builder, has made a new eight-oared shell for the Fairmounts, and the Newark men expect the crew to row on the Passaic on May 30.

The seventieth annual report of the New-York Institution for the Instruction of the Deaf and Dumb has just been presented to the Legislature, and the document is quite an interesting one. It is made up of individual reports from the heads of the various departments of the institution, and all except the Treasurer's report are of an encouraging ...

BALTIMORE, March 28.--Judge Wright filed this morning an opinion is the case of Susan J. Johnson against the People's Benefit Association, deciding in favor of the plaintiff. This is a case of considerable interest to mutual insurance companies and persons holding policies in them.

The office of W.P. Clyde Co. was besieged yesterday by anxious relatives and friends of the officers and crew of the steamer George W. Clyde. There were fears in regard to the safety of the vessel, it having been suggested that she had been the unfortunate cause of the loss of the vessel supposed to be the Conserts.

ALBANY, March 28.-In the absence of anything better to do the Senate amused itself this morning with a lively discussion over the merits of Mr. Saxton's bill appropriating $20,000 to protect the owners of proporty adjacent to the canals from leakage, the money to be expended under the supervision of the Superintendent of Public Works, James Shanahan.

The appointment of the editor of the Tribune to be Minister to France has stirred up a discussion which seems to be for the most part irrelevant. Our esteemed contemporary, Harper's Weekly, for example, deprecates the appointment because "from ...

The residence of ex-Judge M.S. Isaacs, at 110 East Seventy-third-street, could not accommodate all the persons who went there yesterday morning to attend the funeral of his wife, the daughter of Barnet L. Solomon.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, March 28.--Mr. Murat Halstead is so ill that his physician forbids him seeing any one. He is suffering from a cold caught at the inauguration. Up to 10 o'clock to-night he had not been informed of the Sen- ...

The Senate will send a committee to the President to-day to ask him if he has any further communication to make to that body, and if he has not, the Senate will adjourn to-morrow, having been in session four weeks. During that time the only business it has been called upon to attend ...

As the time draws near for the meeting of the Methodist Annual Conferences in this vicinity the members of the various congregations naturally begin to get a little anxious as to whether they are to keep the Pastor to whom they have become much attached or not, or in some cases gain ...

The American Marine and Canal Propeller Company of Philadelphia yesterday have an exhibition of their model in the courtyard of the Stevens House. It was witnessed by many steamboat, railroad, and transportation men and engineers, and elicited expressions of surprise and pleasure.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 28.--The old-line Whigs mentioned in a dispatch to THE TIMES from Montgomery, Ala., as having called a meeting to be held in this city, are simply place-hunting Republican politicians who are trying to control Federal appointments in Alabama. They met here recently and called a second secret meeting at which a slate for the Alabama offices is to be agreed upon.

A fair in aid of St. Christopher's Home for Destitute Children was opened yesterday afternoon under the auspices of the associate managers of the home in the large parlors of the Cornell mansion, at Fifth-avenue and Forty-fourth-street. Mrs. Cornell, who has taken a personal interest in the home, has given her house free of charge for the fair.

Many of the yachtsmen in the city are yet in hope that there may be races for the America's Cup this season after all, and would not be surprised to learn of a challenge being found among the mail of the next Liverpool steamer.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 28.--B.M. Huey, Jr., Agent of the Southern Express Company a Blockton, a mining town, 28 miles south of this city, last night prevented the robbery of the company's office by killing the would-be robber. The safe in the office contained about $6,000, belonging to the Cohaba Coal Company, besides several smaller sums.

WASHINGTON, March 28.--"The greasy hand of boodle" was to-day laid upon Murat Halstead by the Senators whom he so vigorously and savagely denounced in July, 1886. His nomination to be Minister to Germany was rejected by the Senate this afternoon, but after this action ...

Delmonico's large dining hall has soldom resounded to more hearty and unrestrained song, applause, and laughter than it did last night when it was nearly filled with the members and guests of the New-York Association of the Cornell University. It was their ninth annual dinner, and in many respects excelled ...

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 28.--The House of Representatives passed the Ballot Reform bill in concurrence with the Senate amendments to-day, and it was sent to the Committee on Engrossed Bills. The act goes into effect June 1 next.

More rumors about "deals" in local poli ties were current yesterday than have run through the city in any month since the campaign of last Fall closed. Most of them were absolutely without foundation, but one of them had its origin in a fact. It was the rumor that Tammany Hall managers were intent, for a purpose yet ...

Several very good games were played yesterday at the American Chess Congress. Judd of St. Louis has developed into a very strong player since he appeared here several years ago, and yesterday he defeated the English champion, Blackburne.

LINCOLN, Neb., March 28.--Patrick Egan first appeared in Nebraska in the Spring of 1883 and took up his residence in Lincoln. Some months later, on the 22d of October, 1883, he appeared before A.D. Burr, the Clerk of the Districk Court for the County of Lancaster, or rather ...

One amendment of the Rapid Transit bill urged open the Railroad Committees at Albany consists simply in removing Broadway from the excepted streets and leaving the way open for the construction of an underground road in that thoroughfare. We have long been convinced that the truesolution of the rapid-transit problem must ...

The sale of the oil paintings, water colors, etehings, drawings, and autograph letters, presented to the German Hospital Fair by prominent artists and authors, was begun last evening at 240 Fifth-avenue. In all 104 pictures were disposed of, and the treasury of the German Hospital was enriched about $1,000.

The steamship Prins Frederik Hendrik from Port au Prince, which arrived here yesterday, brought a news budget containing two important facts. One fact was that the Government of Legitime had begun suing for peace with Hippolyte, and the other was that another ...

LONDON, March 28.--Everything here today is subordinated to the death of John Bright. The Radical and Irish papers vie with the Tory press in eulogizing the great tribune, and there is a loud demand that he be buried in Westminster Abbey, which will not be done all the same.

PATERSON, March 28.--Samuel G. Storm, a habitue of the Clifton race track, was arrested there to-day by Sheriff Cadmus of Paterson to answer in a suit for damages brought by Cora M. Lapham, a young resident of Paterson, whom Storms has been courting for the past ...

LAKELAND, Fla., March 28.--The Cleveland party arrived at Tampa this afternoon. All are greatly pleased with their visit to Havana. They visited the new hotel at Tampa and then drove out to Ybor City, where immense cigar facteries are situated. From there they took a special train for Sanford and Orlando, where they will stop over a short time, proceeding to Jupiter Inlet to-morrow.

DETROIT, Mich., March 28.--The English Brewery Syndicate seems to have been at work very quietly in this city for the last few days, but results are beginning is come to the surface. It is reported to-day that E.W. Voigt, the largest brewer in Detroit, who makes 40,000 barrels of beer annually, has agreed to sell for $850,000.

TRENTON, N.J., March 28.-The evident hesitancy of the Democrats in taking up the deficiency in the State Treasury at the present time has led Mr. Voorhees of Union, the Republican leader, to offer a bill providing for a State tax of three-quarters of a mill upon each dollar of real and personal property taxable, according to the last Assessors' reports. This he introduced this morning.

A lady who, with her family, occupies a flat on the east side of a new apartment house at 130 West Twelfth street, which reaches to the building line and about eight feet further than the old-fashioned residences which flank it on both sides, was surprised one day last week to find a man hanging from a rigging in front of one of her side windows.

C.P. Huntington has broken all records as an issuer of stock. His Southern Pacific Company has a share capital of $100,000,000. This was almost an unprecedented figure in railway company capitalization. But Mr. Huntington's ambitions were not yet satisfied.
The thirty-first annual report of the Brooklyn Library Association shows that the library now contains more than 100,000 volumes, an increase of several thousand over last ...

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, March 28.-- It is believed here that before long the railway lines will abandon their present policy of excessively low rates on European freights. This policy has worked serious harm to American commercial interests here, for in many cases rates from Europe have been from 33 to 50 per cent lower than those from New-York.

The ladies in charge of the needlework department of the Young Women's Christian Association, 7 East Fifteenth-street, wish to call the attention of the public to their particular department. In attractive showcases can be seen all kinds of the products of the needle for sale at moderate prices.

Another change of bill at Daly's Theatre last evening brought into view a three-act farce with the suggestive title of "Samson and Dalilah," taken from the French of Alexandre Bisson, one of the authors of "L s Surprises du Divorce," and the author of "Le Depute de Bombignas."
ST. PAUL, Minn., March 28.-There is some wheat yet in farmers' hands in the Northwest, but as to the amount of it there is a variety of opinions.

The New-York College for the Training of Teachers, which received its charter from the Board of Regents of the University of the State of New-York Jan. 12 last, has issued a circular defining the scope of the institution.

A well-dressed man about 40 years old called on Mrs. Geraldine Wennstrom at 71 McDougal-street, Brooklyn, Wednesday, and after having been shown through the house, which is for sale, handed her a letter signed "A Friend" ...

The Engineering News of this city will print in its issue for this week a colored map, showing recent railway construction east of Chicago and north of the Ohio River. It shown that 1,680 miles of railway are now under contract in that territory, not counting 3,362 miles classed as "located or under survey," of which it is probable that a large proportion will be put under construction during this year. Says the News:

SCRANTON, Penn.. March 28.--The sudden removal of Postmaster Connolly at the instance of Congressman Scranton is the sensation of the city. The indignation is intensified by the fact that Congressman Scranton announces ...

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 28.--The Dutchess County Hunt has inaugurated its first run. The meet took place at Drayton House, the residence of Archy Rogers. Mr. E.P. Rogers acted as master, Archy Rogers as first and Woodbury Kane as second whip.

HELENA, Montana, March 23.--The Daily Journal, Russell Harrison's paper, last night received the following special dispatch from Washington: "President Harrison does not desire it to be understood that any general rule or general principle will operate to keep all Democrats in office till the expiration of their present commissions.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 28.--Gov. Beaver arrived home last night at midnight, and was at his desk in the Executive Department at the usual hour this morning hard at work. The Governor smiled at the reference to yesterday's affair in Washington. "I've dismissed the whole matter from my mind. It was unfortunate that the poor crazy creature should do as he did," said Gov. Beaver.

Judge Van Hoesen, in the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday handed down an opinion in the suit of Anna Maria Doyle against the Manhattan Railway Company, awarding $30,000 for damages to the plaintiff's property, fronting 100 feet on Sixth avenue, near Fifty-thirdstreet. Peckham and Tyler were attorneys for Mrs. Doyle and Col. E.C. James for the elevated ...

The indictment charging Mrs. Lebkneschner with the murder of her son Anthony was dismissed yesterday by Judge Gildersleeve on motion of Lawyer John R. Heinzelman. She was acquitted last week on the charge of the murder of her son Charles on the ground than she was insane at the time.

The funeral services over the body of Edwin Thorne of Thorndale, Millbrook, Dutchess County, who died suddenly on Monday last, were held yesterday afternoon at the residence of Mr. Thorne's sister, Miss Phoebe Ann Thorne, 558 Madison-avenue. The great pariors in which the services were conducted were filled with friends of the dead man, and the floral offerings which were sent to the house were many and beautiful.

The employes of Leopold Simmons, manufacturer of neckwear on the second floor of 119 Spring-street, who were working overtime, noticed at about 10 o'clock last night that the building was filling with smoke. One of them ran to the box at Broadway and Spring-street and sent out an alarm.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28.--John W. Casselli, the circus acrobat, was brought to the new Court House to-day on the charge of stealing from a conductor on a Fourth and Eighth-street passenger railway car a week ago last...

BALTIMORE, March 28.--The baseball season was to open here to-day by a game between the Baltimore and Philadelphia League Club, but the game is postponed because the new grounds are muddy and the weather is unfavorable.

The charred body of Peter Greenwald, one of the workmen in Alfred E. Ower's burned factory in Kent-avenue, Brooklyn, was found in the ruins yesterday morning. The body was taken to the Bedford-avenue station house.

The trouble between the Legislature and the Centennial Celebration Committee is, apparently, in a fair way to be settled. Assemblyman Hamilton Fish has been in conference with the committee, with the result that, as may ...

The "Irish revolutionists" of this city are thirsting for blood. They have addressed a circular to their fellow-"revolutionists" throughout the country urging them to send delegates to a convention of "revolutionists" the time and place for which have not been determined upon, and the result of which, it is announced, will be the liberation of Ireland accomplished by violent means.

CHICAGO, March 28.--Chairman Blanchard has issued a circular showing the minimum percentages of the gross through rates accruing to the lines in the territory of the Central Traffic Association and authorized Pacific coast points, taking effect April 1 in accordance with an agreement with the Transcontinental Association.

The brook trout (Salmo fontinalis) is protected by the game laws of the State of New York from Sept. 1 to April 1. April, May, June, July, and August constitute the open season, and during the first three of these months the fishing is usually the best in Long Island waters.

Jay Gould is credited with making material progress yesterday in what is believed to be the greatest railroad deal he has ever attempted. Some reports insist that he has more than progressed--that he has practically accomplished the object toward which he has been bending his every energy for two years or more.

CHICAGO, March 29.--Little "Jimmy" Jordon, who was only 4 years old, was shot and instantly killed early this afternoon by some unknown person. The circumstances of his death are as mysterious as they are distressing.

ALTON, Ill., March 29.--W.H. Gear of NewYork City was arrested to-day at Decatur, Ill., on the charge of forging an accepted draft for $75 on William Mann Co. of Philadelphia, which he had cashed at Milliken's Bank, in Decatur, Ill., March 20. He formerly represented Mann Co. on the road, and he is wanted for similar crookedness at New-York and at Louisville, Ky.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March, 29.--A special train bearing ex-President Cleveland's party was side-tracked last night at Lake Alfred.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 29.--The succession of Oscar Drouet, a notary public who died a few days ago, was opened in the Civil District Court Wednesday.

A new feature of the litigation between Kate F. Monjo and Domingo Monjo came to the surface yesterday when the former's suit for $25,000 damages for false imprisonment was called for trial in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn. It went over until next week on a technicality.
