J.J. Boyle, a singer in the defunct American Opera Company, was discharged in 1887 and brought a suit against the company for $580 44 wages due and got a judgment for the amount.

Jay Gould made an assault on the Board of Electrical Control yesterday with the purpose of preventing it from compelling the Western Union Telegraph Company to put its wires under ground. His weapon was a suit in equity brought in the United States Circuit Court.
John Travis, who was arrested in Brooklyn last Wednesday for carrying concealed weapons, was turned over to detectives from this city yesterday.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 29.--The firms of L.R. Bergen and C.M. Woolley Co. closed their store doors to-day and announced that they would close out at public sale. The firms are the oldest established in this place. Three others hare closed up their business during the year. The stocks of both stores are appraised at $20,000. The reason for the dissolution is supposed to be the extremely dull trade.

The copper market gave no sign of recovery from its season of dullness yesterday. No sales were made and no change of price occurred worthy of mention. In London prices fell off a trifle and 375 tons of spot and 75 tons of future were sold at slightly lower prices.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 29.--The appointment of Lewis R. Williams as Postmaster at this place yesterday set the town astir. The appointee is about 23 years of age and very popular among his friends.

PARIS, March 29.--The Cabinet to-day unanimously resolved to prosecute Gen. Boulanger. The Presse states that MM. Cl menceau and Bovier-Lapiorre, both of whom are members of the Chamber of Deputies, have requested M. Constans, Minister of the Interior, to arrest Gen. Boulanger.

President George W. Lyon of the commission in elevated railway condemnation proceedings has been frequently absent from recent sittings of the commission.

HEMPSTEAD, Long Island, March 29.--The Improvement Company owning the hotels, cottages, c., at Long Beach has withdrawn its offer of $30,000 to the town of Hempstead for the beach. Some of the conditions attached to the sale were obnoxious to the company. The town was to have voted on the proposed sale on Tuesday.

PORTLAND, Me., March 29.--In Maine, as in the rest of New-England, it is not difficult to find men who believe in the wisdom of the closest trade relations between this country and Canada. The question was very thoroughly discussed to-night at a dinner of the Portland Board of Trade.

On the grounds of the New-Jersey Athletic Club, at Bergen Point, teams of nine men from that organization and the Elizabeth Gun Club shot a clay pigeon match yesterday afternoon.

Stannard, sld. from Leith for New-York to-day. The steamship Albany, (Br.,) Capt. Porter, from China and Japan for New-York, arr. at Suez to-day.

DETROIT, March 29.--Ex-Senator Palmer arrived home this morning with his commission as Minister to Spain in his pocket. In a conversation relating to his future movements, he said: "I will stay here two weeks; then I sojourn in Washington 10 days to get posted on Spanish affairs.

Persons who have used the bridge cars or the trains of the Kings County Elevated Railway recently have noticed that the arms which serve to divide the seats have been removed, and that the seating accommodations now consist of long, undivided benches, like those of street cars.
WASHINGTON, March 29.--Inter-State Commerce Commissioner Aldace F. Walker to-day placed his resignation in the hands of the President, to take effect April 1.

The bears had another jubilee in yesterday's stock market, but their liveliness was largely centred in the transactions of the morning. Atchison was knocked down to 40 , a drop of four points in two days. Union Pacific lost three points and Missouri Pacific gave up a couple of points more.

WASHINGTON, March 29.--The only bond offer received by Secretary Windom to-day was $50,000 registered 4 per cents at 108. It was accepted.

The wealthy and charitable ladies connected with the Brooklyn Woman's Homeopathic Hospital and Dispensary for Women and Children, at 1,318 Fulton-street, have become involved in a serious dispute over money matters.

A party of electrical engineering students of Cornell University, under the guidance of Prof. E.P. Roberts, have been visiting the principal points of interest to them in this vicinity during the past week.
On the coffee market yesterday disquieting news from Europe caused a drop of from 35 to 40 points, which is equal to about cent a pound.

CASSELTON, Dakota, March 29.--The Farmers' Alliance was in session until midnight last night. President Louck's address dealt at length on the distribution of the political patronage of North Dakota. He wants farmers to hold nine-tenths of the offices. He is willing to concede the Federal patronage to politicians.

A judgment of $2,171,395 84 was entered yesterday in the Superior Court in favor of the Executors of Commodore Cornelius K. Garrison in the suit of Clark Robinson Griggs, which was brought against Commodore Garrison in 1879.

While the Colored Methodist Conference of the Lexington district was in session at Paris, Ky., on Wednesday night John Page shot and mortally wounded Ben Kellis, from whose pew he had been elected. Bishop Andrews was in the pulpit at the time, and the shooting caused a panic among the 1,200 persons who were present.

READING, Penn., March 29.--The assignment of the Reading Iron Works to the Reading Trust Company to-day, it is believed here, will result in the early resumption of the works and the re-employment of the 2,500 men thrown out by the suspension. If the iron works resume, half a dozen other establishments will also be able to resume. One hundred of the employes were paid in full to-day.

Several brilliant games were played yesterday at the American Chess Congress. Mr. Bird is still ill, but he bears his sufferings with great patience and fortitude. He was pitted yesterday against the Irish champion, Pollock, opening with the "centre counter gambit."

CHICAGO, March 29.--E.W. Blatchford's sixstory building, 58 to 62 North Clinton-street, was the scene of a three-hundred-thousand-dollar fire to-night. The conflagration started in the middle of the third floor from some unknown cause. Damage was confined chiefly to the three upper stories.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 29.--Miss Jennie Freeman and Mr. E.B. Pyatt of Metuchen were married last evening, in the presence of a large assemblage of friends, including several New-York families. Miss Freeman is a niece of Judge Manning Freeman of the Middlesex courts and of Sheriff C.C. Campbell. The marriage was celebrated at the residence of the latter by the Rev. J. Mason, Pastor of the Presbyterian church.

The proprietors of New-York's concert halls have clubbed together and resolved up find out whether or not the municipal authorities have any power to compel them to close their places of amusement on Sunday.

As was announced some days ago in THE TIMES, the controlling majority of the stock of the Tennessee Coal and Iron Company has been secured by people who will take the management of the property into their own hands, electing an entirely new Board of Directors.

SAN JUAN DEL SUR, March 29, vis Galveston Texas.--The American longitudinal expedition, in charge of Lieut. Norris, has arrived here. The work will be finished and the party will leave for the United States probably by April 9. All are well.

The railroads of Iowa have begun their war for the repeal of the inter-State commerce law, which, the railroads claim, has entailed upon them heavy loss. They have decided to materially reduce the number of passenger trains, taking off all express and making every train carry freight, and even stock, as well as passengers.

The British bark Daisy Reed, Capt. Mitchell, which arrived yesterday from Cuban ports, in common with most of the arriving fleet of merchantmen, reported that terrible weather had been experienced in the neighborhood of stormy Cape Hatteras.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 29.--The opinion of the Court of Appeals relative to the collateral inheritance tax is at hand, and there is a general demand for it by lawyers, capitalists, societies, and corporations. It was written by Judge Andrews.

ALBANY, March 29.--The squall between the Legislature and the Centennial Committee has blown over and there is an apparent air of peace. This morning Mr. Clarence W. Bowen, the Secretary of the committee, appeared as envoy extraordinary and minister plenipotentiary from the committee.

DENVER, Col., March 29.--A startlingly-bold bank robbery occurred in Denver at 1 o'olock to-day. David H. Moffat, President of the First National Bank and also President of the Denver and Rio Grande Railway, was the victim, though the loss, $21,000, will fall upon the bank.

The prospects for a 'Varsity race between Columbia and Harvard at New-London this Spring are not very promising. Harvard has sent Columbia word that she will not row this year.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 29.--Thomas G. Shearman of New-York visited Yale University to-day and sat among the students under Prof. Sumner and Prof. Hadley.
ELIZABETH, N.J., March 29.--Pennsylvania Railroad detectives raided a party of tramps on the line of the road, at Rahway, last night and brought them captives in a box car to Elizabeth.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 29.--The stockholders of the Mississippi and Tennesse Road met here to-day and confirmed the lease of the Mississippi and Tennessee to the Chicago, St. Louis and New-Orleans Road, which is in effect the Illinois Central. The lease is for 400 years, and is dated from 1882.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 29.--It was learned to-night that the Standard Oil Company had purchased the entire Crafton oil field in this county. The field is quite extensive, and a number of wells are now producing from 100 to 150 barrels a day. The price paid for the territory is not known.

Morse of New-York and Edward Dudley of Philadelphia, have been in conference here for several days at the Central Hotel, discussing the project to build up a new watering place at Deal Lake, about four miles from this place. ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 1.--Prof. Swift of Warner Observatory has received a telegram from the Lick Observatory announcing the discovery last evening by Prof. Barnard of a new comet. Its position was, right assension 5 hours 20 minutes 50 seconds; declination north, 16 degrees 7 minutes. It is pretty faint and has a slow motion southwest. This find will entitle Prof. Barnard to still another Warner comet prize of $100.

BOSTON, April 1.--The Finance Committee of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad met to-day and thoroughly discussed the road's financial condition. It is understood that they practically fixed a plan by which the money needed until this year's crops are assured will be forthcoming. The full Board of Directors will meet to-morrow.

Assistant Treasurer Alexander McCue, who was stricken with apoplexy about 10 days ago, had a relapse yesterday, and for some time was thought to be sinking rapidly. Dr. Skene, the attending physician, said last night that Mr. McCue had had a set back, but that it was not sufficiently serious to warrant any fear of immediate dissolution.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 1.--A message from ex-President Cleveland at Jupiter says the party will reach Jacksonville Thursday morning, and leave there for the North at noon the same day. The ex-President requests that the reception be strictly informal, and that there shall be no speeches. It will probably include a drive about the city and a visit to the Subtropical Exhibition.
PHILADELPHIA, April 1.--Mary Anderson, the actress, left this city this afternoon for NewYork, and she will, it is said, sail from the city to-morrow or the next day for Europe.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 1.--At the election for town and city officers, held to-day, the Democrats made a clean sweep, electing their ticket by about 1,000 majority. They also gain one Alderman and two Councilmen. A fair vote was polled.

COPENHAGEN, April 1.--The Rigsdag closed today without either the Landsthing or the Folkething (the upper and lower houses) having agreed to the budget. In consequence the King will empower the Government to levy existing taxes and to authorize all expenditures necessary for the administration of public affairs.

Preparations for a complete reorganization of the Finance Department were begun by Controller Myers yesterday. The system of bookkeeping in each bureau will be revised, and, if improvements cannot easily be made in it, it will be abolished and a radical change effected.

LONDON, April 1.--An exciting contest is expected in the Central Division of Birmingham. The Liberals have selected a candidate. The Conservatives will try to induce Lord Randolph Churchill to stand for the seat.

Inspectors of the Health Department have made a visit to the annex of District School No. 54, One Hundred and Fourth-street and Tenth-avenue, where it is declared that Miss Rebecca Gibbs, a teacher, contracted the typhoid-malarial fever which resulted in her death March 22.

WHEELING, West Va., April 1.--As freight train No. 88 on the Baltimore and Ohio main line reached the bridge over Hart's Creek, 80 miles east of this city, this, morning Engineer Kusach noticed that the bridge was burning. It was too late to check the train, and he and his fireman with one brakeman saved themselves by jumping.

Minnie Palmer, the young girl who was shot in the breast in her apartments at 230 West Thirty-ninth-street, on Sunday night, was in an improved condition at the Roosevelt Hospital yesterday, and it is thought that she may recover.

KEOKUK, Iowa., April 1.--Mayor John N. Irwin, Republican, who closed the saloons one year ago, was defeated in the city election for Mayor by 155 majority. The contest was an enforcement of the prohibitory law.

PORTLAND, Oregon, April 1.--Last night a little after 9 o'clock the most brilliant meteor ever seen in this city crossed the heavens in a northwesterly direction. Electric lights were paled by its brilliancy. It was visible 15 seconds. It was also seen at Tacoma, Washington Territory, and north of there.

He surrendered himself and claims to have acted in self-defense.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 2.--The banking company organized at Elizabethport is negotiating for the purchase of the property of Joseph Beck at the corner of East Jersey and First streets for a site for the bank building.

The Grand Jury will be called upon to investigate charges of embezzlement against Lawyer Silas Grimstead, ex-Recorder H.D.B. Lefferts, and A.L. Curtis. BERLIN, April 2.--Prince Bismarck, in replying to the birthday congratulations offered him by the Central Manufacturers' Association, said that he looked forward to a continued maintenance of peace.

Miss Mary Anderson passed a quiet day at the Victoria Hotel yesterday, in company with her mother and brother. Nobody except these and Mr. Henry E. Abbey, her manager, was allowed to see her, absolute quiet being considered as still necessary to her complete recovery.

WICHITA, Kan., April 2.--At the municipal election to day about 800 women voted, the number being composed mostly of the temperance and sporting classes. Two women were on tickets for the School Board. Both were defeatad by a large vote. George E. Harris, a wholesale liquor dealer, is probably elected Mayor. Two wards elect liquor men to the Council. A heavy vote was polled.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 2.--The Custom House officers this morning seized 2,224 five-tael boxes of opium, valued at $15,568, which had been smuggled. The drug was found concealed under a pile of fat in a soap and candle factory conducted by Richard Ahlf and H. Gaehdez. It is thought the opium was lowered from a China steamer into the water and taken to the candle factory.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 2.--The whale recently killed on the beach here was to-day shipped to the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, where it will be dissected. Prof, True of that institution came here and superintended the shipment.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 2.--The annual session of the New-York East Conference of the Methodist-Episcopal Church begins at the Fairfield-Avenue Church to-morrow morning. Ministerial delegates representing 300 churches will be present.
The Polo Ground question was before the Board of Aldermen in Committee of the Whole yesterday. It was the first time most of the Aldermen had been in such a session, and they did not know what to do.

The St. David, a full rigged ship. reached Philadelphia Monday from Havre, with the steward J.S, Hughes in irons, a hopeless religious maniac. The first mate, E.J. Lewis of New-Orleans was suffering form acute bronchitis, and the second mate, John Hammond, of Boston was dangerously ill with rheumatic fever. The sick men were removed to the German Hospital.

RAHWAY, N.J., April 2.--The Democratic City Convention meets to-morrow night for the nomination of a Mayor, Freeholders, and Water and Tax Commissioners. The renomination of Mayor Hyer is conceded. There will be a lively contest over the Freeholders, as the chances of electing the Democratic candidates are better this year than for some time.

LONDON, April 2.--Mr. William Phipson Beale, a barrister, will contest the seat in the House of Commons for the Central Division of Birmingham, made vacant by the death of Mr. John Bright. Mr. Beale is a home ruler. Lord Randolph Churchill has declined to become a candidate.

MERIDEN, Conn., April 2.--The large ferryboat which plies between Middletown and Portland was burned to the water's edge this afternoon and is almost a total loss. The fire was discovered when the boat was in mid stream and she was run in to the Middletown slip. The boat was valued at about $20,000.

PAIRS, April 2.--The Cocarde says that Gen. Boulanger, being warned yesterday that the Government was preparing for a coup, arranged so that he should not fall into the Government trap, and left the city.

Mayor Grant said yesterday that he was sorry to see that some of the legislators in Albany were disposed to defeat the Rapid Transit bill directly, or to load it with amendments which would change its character and so compel him to aid in its defeat.

A snowstorm was beating down on Buffalo yesterday morning when the big locomotive A.G. Darwin, which had made the remarkable run from Jersey City Monday, started at 9:15 A.M. to eclipse that performance.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 2.--The Democrats elected the Hon. Henry S. Deforest their candidate for Mayor, to-day, by over 300 majority. They also elected three of the five city candidates for Supervisore and Aldermen.

NEGAUNEE, Mich., April 2.--The Korton Gold and Silver Mining Company has been organized to develop the mine on section 25, town 48, range 27, two miles north of Negaunee. George Korten and local capitalists compose the company. The assays show $35 a ton in gold and silver. The place is about three miles east of the Ropes mine in the Ishpeming gold range.

LONDON, April 2.--Mr. Stanley, in the letter received by his friend here, after stating the orders given by him to Major Barttelot, describes the advance of the column. The expedition, which consisted of 389 officers and men, started from Yambunga June 28, 1887.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 2.--This afternoon a bull, which was being led to a slaughter house, broke loose from the men who were leading him, rushed into the Catholic cemetery in Church-street, and stampeded a funeral procession just marching into the cemetery. The bull scatttered the horses and the walking mourners, but no one was hurt.

There will be a very lively contest for the control of the Republican organization in the Twenty-first Assembly District next Friday, unless all signs fail. At present the Chairman of the District Committee is William Leary, who succeeded Jacob Hess a year ago, when that gentleman moved out of the district.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 2.--Richard Hoy, a deck hand on the tugboat Mirage, had just fastened the vessel's hawser to the wharf last night when he thoughtlessly placed his foot in a coil of the rope. The boat moved out from the wharf and the hawser tightened around Hoy's leg, crushing it badly. He threw himself down to avoid being dragged overboard and the fall dislocated his shoulder. The leg was amputated at the city hospital.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 2.--The examination of the accounts of Deputy Postmaster E.B. Deshier was finished to-day. The total amount of the defalcation is $1,230,37.

The famous trotting stallion Kirkwood, belonging to R. Carman Combes of Carmansville, N.Y., died in his stable there yesterday from old age. The horse was fealed in 1860. PENSACOLA, Fla., April, 2.--The startling information that the United States man-of-war Brooklyn was found at sea in distress and out of provisions was brought to this city on the arrival of the British steamer Falshaw, Capt. Bennett, from Cabe Verde, this morning.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 2.--The Milk Producers' Union, comprising 411 farmers in the seven western counties of this State, was formed here to-day, and after next Monday all the milk from these producers will be handled by one man instead of through the milk dealers. The trust includes all the milk producers in Western Pennsylvania. It is proposed to charge 13 cents per gallon during the Summer and 18 cents in the Winter.

The Brighton Athletic Club of Brooklyn gave a boxing tournament last night at Schiellein's Hall, Atlantic-avenue and Vermont-street. The preliminaries were held last week. Gold medals were awarded the winners. About 300 men were present.

LONDON, April 2.--This was the first day of the Northampton and Pytckley Hunt Spring meeting. The race for Earl Spencer's plate of 500 sovereigns, a handicap for 3-year-olds and upward, at five furlongs, was won by Poem, Galloping Queen second, and Nimeusis third. The race for the Althorp Park Stakes of 10 sovereigns each, with 300 sovereigns added, for 2-year-olds, distance five furlongs, was won by Wayland, by Fetterlock, Loup second, and Try Again third.

LONDON, April 3.--This was the second day of the Northampton and Pytchley Hunt Spring meeting. The race for the Ascott Plate of 450 sovereigns, for 2-year-olds, at five furlongs, was won by Ulva, by Master Kildare.

Miss Sophie Eyre, formerly one of the leading ladies of Wallack's, who has been visiting this country for the past few months, is to return to England soon. Before sailing, however, she is desirous of producing at a matinee in this city a new English play, which is the property of Fred Sydney, an English actor, who is now here.
No apprehension is felt at the Navy Department on account of the Brooklyn, which a British steamer reported with broken shaft sailing for New-York.

As Park Commissioner Waldo Hutchins cannot give all his time to the performance of his official duties, he announced at the meeting of the Park Board yesterday that he would not vote affirmatively on any matter which he has not personally investigated.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 3.--Thirty towns out of 36, including all the cities except Providence, give for Governor: Davis, (Dem.,) 10,094; Ladd, (Rep.,) 9,174; Richardson, (Proh.,) 803; Chace, (Law Enforcement,) 1,952. Davis lacks 1,835 of a majority.

Nothing quite so unique in the way of a religious entertainment has ever been held in this city as that at the hall of the Young Men's Christian Association Building last evening. It was the first appearance in this city of the "Household Troops' Brass Band" in a Salvation Army concert.

CHICAGO, April 3.--The condition of the Republican machine in this city, as a result of the great Democratic victory at yesterday's election, is pitiable. It is a wreck, and its engineers are sitting in the ruins trying to find out what struck them. Boss George Swift was asked to-day: "As a local Republican manager what is your opinion of the prospects of the party in Chicago?"

The representatives of the anthracite coal companies held a meeting yesterday, at which it was voted to reduce prices to the basis of last Spring's schedule, an average of about 10 cents a ton under recently prevailing prices.

Henrietta Frances and Emma T. Day, sisters, are in the lock-up at Summit, N.J., to answer a charge of arson. The older of the girls is but 18 years of age. They had been employed as maids in Plainfield families.

CHAMBERLAIN, Dakota, April 3.--John Duck, Chasing Crane, Ponca, and Buck Antelope, Sioux from White River on the reservation, are in the city on their way to attend the United States court at Yankton.

BRUSSELS, April 3.--Gen. Boulanger and M. Arene, a member of the French Chamber of Deputies, arrived at Mons, Belgium, this morning. They were met at the railway station by M. Rochefort. The party then repaired to the Hotel Monarque, where they held a conference.
The baseball game between the Acmes of NewYork and Newarks at Newark yesterday resulted as follows: Newark, 18; Acme, 4.

BRIDGETON, N.J., April 3.--A storm moving from the southeast struck the southern portion of this city about 6 o'clock this evening, doing considerable damage. A new house just finished at Riverside was leveled to the ground.

ST. PAUL, April 3.--The stocks of wheat in Minnesota and Dakota country elevators April 1 amounted to 5,210,000 bushels, against 6,456,000 bushels March 1, showing a decrease of 1,246,000 bushels for the month of March. April 1 a year ago the stocks in the same country elevators were 16,742,000 bushels, April 1 two years ago 13,275,000, and three years ago 11,440,000, bushels.
ELIZABETH, N.J., April 3.--John Pfifer was convicted to-day in the Union County Court of cutting the halyards from the flagstaff owned by State Senator Miller of Westfield and then selling the ropes.
PITTSBURG, April. 3.--The leading officials of the Pennsylvania Railroad system are in the city to-day.

The third annual tournament for the amateur billiard championship of the United States, under the auspices of the Racquet Club, will begin on May 13. The entries will close on April 13. Orville Oddie, Jr., is the present holder of the championship cup.

AUCKLAND, New-Zealand, April 3.--The recent hurricane in the South Pacific Ocean caused great damage on the island of Tahiti. Parts of the island were submerged, and many persons were drowned. On the island of Tonga the hurricane created great havoc. Thirty persons perished there in the storm.
OSKALOOSA, Kan., April 3.--The Oskaloosa idea is still extant. After a vigorons fight the female candidates for the city offices won the day by sweeping majorities.
FINDLAY, Ohio, April 3.--By direction of Senator Sherman a special election was held here to-day by the Republicans to choose a Postmaster whom the Senator could recommend for appointment.

LONDON, April 3.--Gen. Boulanger's flight to Brussels is regarded as evidence that a good deal has been discovered in the seizure of the Patriotic League's papers which has not been divulged to the public. The news of his flight creates considerable sensation here, but as he has no friends in England it is impossible to learn aught beyond what is generally known of his movements.

The bears had the advantage throughout yesterday's stock market till the very close, when there came a spurt which carried the most conspicuous shares on the list upward easily. The hand of Jay Gould was pretty plainly discernible in this move. His stocks were the ones that went up most. The leader was his Missouri Pacific.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 3.--A relief association is being organized in the Consolidated Fruit Jar Works, in this city, which at least 300 of the employes will join.

ST. PAUL, April 3.--Wheat seeding began earnestly Monday, and some farmers were at work even Sunday. Beginning at the south of the Spring wheat area the wheat is mostly in the ground south of the Iowa and Minnesota boundary line, or, say, 75 per cent. of it.

Yesterday was ladies' day at the American Chess Congress, and preparations had been made to make the visitors as comfortable as possible. Notices were put up asking visitors to abstain from smoking, but the injunction was not extended to the players, and several of them took a few puffs at their cigars.

Judge Wallace of the United States Circuit Court spent six hours yesterday in listening to arguments upon the motion of the Western Union Telegraph Company asking that the Board of Electrical Control be restrained from interfering with the wires of the company.
The Loyal Legion met at Delmonico's last evening and decided to accept the invitation of the Centennial Committee to participate in the celebration.

AITKEN, Minn., April 3.--A peculiar phenomenon occurred here yesterday. At 4:45 o'clock it became so dark that lights were necessary in business houses and the air was filed with snow that was as black and dirty as though it had been trampled into the earth.

The stockholders of Lufford's Sons' Lithographic Company, 65 Franklin-street, Boston, met yesterday, and it was decided that the corporation should make an assignment to Francis H. Raymond, Charles Pfaff, and Melvin M. Weston.
The New-York Freeman's Journal publishes a cut of O'Donovan's statue of Archbishop Hughes to stand at the Catholic College in Fordham.

About one hundred Republicans of the Fourth Assembly District met at 68 East Broadway last night; and cut out the programme of a funeral service for to-morrow at which John Collins, Chairman of the District Committee, is expected to fill the leading role, ...
The mass meeting of workingmen in Cooper Union last evening, held under the auspices of the Building Trades Section of the Central Labor Union for the purpose of giving...

The most interesting news to yachtsmen nowadays comes in the shape of information re garding the preparations for defending the America's Cup. A special meeting of the NewYork Yacht Club has been called for to-morrow evening to consider the communication received...
Clarence Reese, the prisoner who escaped from Raymond-Street Jail, Brooklyn, on Sunday, was captured yesterday morning on Manhattan...

ALBANY, April 3.--The Crosby High License bill passed the House this morning and was sent to the Senate in the shape approved by the Republican caucus two weeks ago. Republican votes passed it, and Democratic votes, as usual, opposed it. Word was passed by the Republican leaders that under no circumstances...
About 9:30 yesterday morning, while lower Broadway was crowded with men hastening to their offices in the tall buildings below Wall-street, there was a rush of steam from 49 Broadway.
CHICAGO, April 3.--An interesting suit, in which the Illinois Central Railroad Company is the plaintiff and the Baltimore and Ohio the defendant...

At yesterday's meeting of the Board of Education a report from the Committee on Course of Study arranging for the participation of the public schools in the Centennial celebration was unanimously adopted.

The account given by HENRY M. STANLEY of his recent adventures in the Dark Continent, just made public, is a worthy continuation of that record of intrepidity and skill which has made his name famous. In picturesque impressiveness it leaves nothing to be desired.

About 300 ministers of the Methodist Episcopal Church are gathered in this city to attend the annual New-York Conference of that denomination. The ninety-ninth conference was the numerical distinction given the present gathering on all the official printed matter, and such it was really supposed to be, until at...

CAPE HAYTIEN, Hayti, March 27.--In a proclamation issued March 9 President Legitime declared the insurgent ports of St. Mare, Port de Paix, Gonaives, and Capa Haytien to be in a state of blockade and in effect from that date. There is a semblance of a blockade at St. Mare and Genaives, but at this port it exists only on paper, no armed vessel of the opposition having appeared off the harbor since Jan. 17.

ROME, Apri1 3.--Advices have been received from Massowah to the effect that King John of Abyssinia was defeated and slain in a recent battle with the Dervish Mettema and that the whole country is in a state of anarchy.

Jacob H. Dimmick, who succeeded Major Fassett as Postage Stamp Agent for the Government, with an office in the building of the American Bank Note Company, came down from his home in Port Jervis yesterday morning, and in his mail found the order of removal from his position from the Post Office Department in Washington.

The Rev. Dr. Edward Beecher, the aged brother of the late Henry Ward Beecher, was alighting from a train on the Culver Railroad at Ninth-avenue and Twentieth-street, Brooklyn, at 8:50 o'clock last night, when he fell between...

ATLATIC CITY, N.J., April 3.--This resort is becoming the rendezvous of many New-Yorkers who have been driven out of town by the rigors of Lent. Of course it is too early to have a wildly exciting round of amusements, but enough are originated to make it an oasis in the fasting desert.

The Excise bill reported by the Crosby commission, as amended by the Excise Committee of the Assembly, passed the Assembly yesterday by a vote of 69 to 53. Every affirmative vote was cast by a Republican, and four Republicans voted in the negative with the Democrats.

It is to be hoped that some arrangement may be arrived at by which the Ball players will not be forced to leave the limits of the city for their daily expositions of the national game during the coming Summer. Last year the average attendance upon the championship games would have sufficed to fill three theatres, while upon specially...

The parlors of the New-York Hospital were filled by a company of about 200 ladies and gentlemen last evening, gathered to congratulate the twelfth graduating class of the Training School for Nurses. There were 14 young ladies in the class.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 3.--Many of the people of Spotswood joined Constable Phineas Bowne yesterday in an exciting search for an absconding debtor there.

Having received a hint that it would be better for them not to complicate it, the members of the Executive Committee of the Business Men's Republican Association did not meddle with the Postmastership question at their meeting in the rooms of the Ohio Society last night.

WASHINGTON, April 3.--The New-York men at the capital who expected that the President would to-day exhibit part at least of the muchtalked of "slate" of Federal nominations for New-York, are confident to-night that something will be done to-morrow. They do not look for appointments to all the offices, however. It is expected that Joel B. Erhardt will be made Collector...

TRENTON, N.J., April 3.--Little was done in the sessions held to-day but routine work. The Jersey City charter measure was amended so that the people will be given two days' notice of the election submitting the question to the people, and providing that there will be an Alderman at Large, and it was then ordered to third reading.

The Yonkers Sons of Veterans have mustered in 13 new recruits and elected the following officers for the ensuing year: James Bowes, Senior Vice-Commander; John J. Murphy, Junior Vice-Commander; John E. Logue, Adjutant; ...

PRINCETON, N.J., April 3.--Dr. McCosh's condition is greatly improved to-day. He rested very well last night and has gained enough strength to enable him to sit in an easy chair for a short time. His relatives summoned from New-York have returned to their homes, and his physician thinks that he will soon recover.
There is every probability that the old extension of West Washington Market will have to be vacated.

A burglary was committed early yesterday morning at the house of William Stillwaggon, 341 South Fourth-street, Brooklyn. Mrs. Stillwaggon awoke shortly after midnight and found a man, wearing a mask, bending over her.

The second annual address before the Society of the Alumni of Bellevue Hospital was delivered last evening at the Academy of Medicine, 12 West Thirty-first-street, by Dr. William Osler, Professor of Medicine in Johns Hopkins University.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 3.--Intelligence reached here at a late hour to-night from Rutledge, Tenn., to the effect that Sheriff S. P. Greenlee of Granger County was shot and instantly killed last night while attempting to arrest John Wolfenbarger, an escaped convict from the penitentiary.
Complete returns from the towns in Queens County, Long Island, show that in North Hempstead John Powell (Dem.) was defeated by John Wooley (Rep.) for Supervisor.

The new Supervisor of the City Record on Monday dismissed two bookbinders, one of whom, Peter Leathen, was employed in the Finance Department. Controller Myers objected to his removal and wrote to the Mayor requesting his reinstatement, on the ground that to teach a new man his duties would much inconvenience the Finance Department.

The third of Mr. Steddard's series of Lenten lectures at Daly's Theatre will be delivered at 11 o'clock this morning. This will be the only historical lecture iin the course, and will be devoted to describing and illustrating the career of Cardinal Richelieu, the maker and unmaker of Kings.
The Red Star Line steamship Westernland arrived yesterday from Antwerp with over 1,400 steerage passengers, who were landed at Castle Garden. Among them were nearly 400 German street musicians.

The Sing Sing Board of Trustees, at their meeting on Tuesday night, authorized President Joshua G. Many to execute a contract with the Sing Sing Gas Manufacturing Company to light the streets of the village from sunset to sunrise at $25 per lamp per year for one year.

PARIS, April 3.--At the trial of the leaders of the League of Patriots to-day the Assistant Procureur accused the league of converting itself into an army for the new party, denounced the issue by the league of its manifesto condemning...

Edmund Russell, the celebrated art critic and lecturer, who has gained renown for his expositions of the Delsarte system of art teaching and criticism, is again in this country after an absence of three years.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 3.--The Lyceum Theatre was crowded to-night with people gathered to see Booth and Barrett in "Othello." They experienced a sensation and bitter disappointment. Booth went on in the first act as Iago and spoke his lines without apparent difficulty.

Attractive as was the display of Spring hats and costumes in the great show window of Lord Taylor's establishment at Broadway and Twentieth-street, it was nothing in comparison to that on the second floor, where the annual Spring millinery opening began yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., April 3.--The Democrats of Trenton, at their city convention held to-day, made a strong effort to recapture the city from the Republicans. Last year, by caucus action in the Legislature, the present Republican Mayor, Frank A. Magowan, had a bill passed consolidating Trenton and Chambersburg,...
The White Star steamship Germanic, which sailed at 8 o'clock yesterday morning, carried among its passengers Miss Mary Anderson, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Anderson, and maid.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., April 3.--This Christian seaside resort is to-day worked up over the problem as to whether Jews shall be permitted to settle here. Thomas J. Emery, a real estate agent, has written a circular denouncing the Jews as objectionable residents of the town.

An attempt was made to wreck the Pennsylvania limited vestibule passenger train No. 5 at Louisville, near Canton, Ohio. Tuesday night, by placing pieces of iron in the switch near the little town. The obstructions were discovered and removed in time to prevent a bad accident taking place.

The Dureal pictures and their reception by New-York afford a curious study of provincialism. The public regards them with an indifference that verges on contempt, and the press, for the most part, considers them a fine chance either to show smartness by "going for" them, or to air an ignorance that would not be tolerated...

Several financial institutions in which the late ex-Judge McCue was interested adopted resolutions of regret yesterday touching his death. The Kings County Bar will meet to-day to take suitable action.
Mr. John E. Heller, a commission merchant at 164 Front-street, took his wife to Daly's Theatre last Friday night and had seats in the balcony.

LONDON, April 3.--When the Parnell Commission met this morning Sir Charles Russell resumed his argument in behalf of the Parnellites. He contended that the objects of the Irish National League were justifiable before God and man.

PORTLAND, Oregon, April 3.--In building the branch of the railroad from Willows to Heppner the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company were unable to agree with a settler named Larsen for right of way, and he has been hostile to the company ever since.
Frank H. Damrosch will begin a course of lectures on "The Musical Training of Children in Schools" at Association Hall at 4 P.M. today. These lectures have especial value for teachers.

The new bridge which spans the Harlem River at One Hundred and Eighty-fifth-street has been completed for about two months, but has not been turned over to the custody of the Park Commissioners, in whose care it will ultimately be.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 3.--The forty-first annual session of the New-York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church began this morning, Bishop Randolph S. Foster of Boston presiding.

Manager J.M. Hill threw open the doors of his beautiful new Union-Square Theatre yesterday afternoon and entertained as his guests a large number of actors and actresses, for whom he gave a special professional matinee.

A tempest of no small proportions is raging in the official atmosphere of the Twentysecond Regiment of this city, and whether it will blow itself out into a peaceful calm depends upon the action taken by the Board of Officers at its meeting on April 12.

The Sing Sing Prison officials have not yet succeeded in finding Louis Napoleen, the convict who escaped on Tuesday night. He has managed thus far to keep himself out of sight of those who are looking for him and the $50 reward.

Something over a hundred years ago, when the people of the then British colonies were still linked with the mothercountry and suffered considerable inconvenience and some injury from that connection with no very marked degree of patience, the royal Governors, in their reports to the home Government, had much to say as to the "spread of independency."

The effort made by certain business men to get the railroads to extend the time for excursion tickets to the centennial celebration has not met with much success. J.M. Pierson of the Trunk Line Association, to whom the petition sent to the railroad Presidents was referred for answer, has refused...

The Bard, the most famous son of Longfellow and the chief among Mr. A.J. Cassatt's string of racers, may not be seen on the turf again this year, owing to the trouble with his leg, which caused him to stop racing suddenly last year.

The Brooklyns won an easy victory from the Mets yesterday, doing some heavy batting and fine fielding, while exactly the reverse was true of the Mets. Hughes, Terry, and Lovett pitches a few innings each, and all did very effective work.
BERLIN, April 3.--The Emperor, as a mark of renewed confidence, has summoned to the Herrenhaus Dr. von Puttkamer, the Minister who was dismissed by the late Emperor Frederick.
SEABRIGHT, N.J., April 3.--The borough election here yesterday was a very exciting one. Two tickets were in the field, one known as the fishermen's ticket and the other known as the citizens' ticket.
Grand Master Frank R. Lawrence yeterday transferred to the Trustees of Masonic Hall the last building bond, amounting to $23,000, for cancellation, thus accomplishing the discharge...
NEWBURG, N.Y., April 3.--The Rev. F.B. Savage, D.D., assisted by the Rev. J.W.F. Carlisle, this evening joined in wedlock, at the home of the bride's parents, 36 South Miller-street, Miss ...

LOCKPORT, N.Y., April 3.--There is a prospect of a revival of the foolhardy exhibitions at Niagara Falls this Summer. Carlisle D. Graham, once a Boston policeman, who is rnnning a saloon at the Falls, is the man who swam the...

There was more amusement than information in the proceedings in the Stewart will case yesterday. James Grant Wilson was the first witness. He was on an intimate footing with both Mr. and Mrs. Stewart, and continued to call at the Fifth-avenue mansion frequently after Mr. Stewart's death. In all the years covering his calls he never knew Mrs. Stewart to engage in reading.
George Le Boutillier was married in Brooklyn on Tuesday to Miss Isabella Gourlie Groshon, daughter of the late William F. Groshon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John G. Bacchus.

Mrs. Annie Lawrence of 146 West Fortysixth-street was thrown from her carriage on the corner of Fifth-avenue and Seventy-seventhstreet last night. The horse became frightened and upset the vehicle. Mrs. Lawrence was slightly injured, and was removed to the Presbyterian Hospital, but subsequently taken to her home.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 3.--In the Senate today the Hon. Mr. MacDonald of British Columbia inquired whether the attention of the Government has been directed to the proclamation issued on the 2d of March by the President of...

Major B.G. Thomas, proprietor of the famous Dixiana Stock Farm, near Lexington, Ky., sold his string of racers in training, consisting of eight 3-year-olds and three 2-year-olds, at auction yesterday.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 3.--An interview with Mr. M. Frank in the Constitution, which will appear to-morrow, will be of interest to those who are now perfecting the Jute Trust. The pine-bagging patents are owned by five men--three in Wilmington, N.C., one in Atlanta, and one in Columbus, Miss.

SCOTLAND, Dakota, April 3.--This region seems to be fated to become periodically the victim of the prairie fires which have already caused so much loss of life and property. Yesterday afternoon one of these fires swept over the country south of here and left it a blackened desert.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 3.--The cruiser Charleston is now on the dry dock at the Union Iron Works, and is almost ready for sea. The boilers are being tested, the propeller blades are in position, all large machinery is in place, and only minor details are to be attended to.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 4.--Fashionable New-Brunswick was present at Christ Church this morning to attend the wedding of Miss Caroline Hall, granddaughter of Mrs. Latham of this city, to Mr. Russell C. Sturgis, a son of Russell Sturgis of Boston. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. E.B. Joyce, rector of the church, assisted by the Rev. E. Smith and the Rev. Duncan McCullah.

Young William Krulisch, on trial before Judge Gildersleeve for the murder of Drug Clerk Wechsung, does not abate one jot of his coolness as the effort to fix the crime upon him progresses. He keeps his eyes fixed on the witnesses, and seems to note carefully every particle of testimony as it is given. At this stage of the investigation the case is still one of much mystery.

There is a heap of trouble in the Republican Party. The evidences of it will appear to-day at the primaries for the election of officers of the district associations and delegates to the new County Committee. The Chairman of these delegates is the district leader.

Ninety-eight city lots in the north western part of Manhattan Island--comprising part of the Bloomindale Asylum property--were sold at auction in the Real Estate Exchange yesterday, and brought in the aggregate more than half a million dollars. These lots comprised part of the unimproved tract owned by the Society of ...

It may not have occurred to many military men of this country that the coming centennial celebration will afford an opportunity which foreign War Dapartments intend to eagarly seize. From well-informed circles it has been learned that officers of the army and navy of England, Germany, France, Russia, Austria, ...
The Dock Board, at its meeting yesterday, passed a set of resolutions compelling the marketmen still occupying stalls on old Pier 23 North River to vacate them within twenty days.
Detective Edward Gilgar of the Fifteenth Precinct was very roughly handled last night while he was looking for a negress, who, it is believed, had been complained of for robbery, ...

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 4.--The Washington Light Infantry of this city will take part in the centennial pageant at New-York and will march under the original crimson battle flag of Col. William Washington's cavalry. This flag was actually in the battles of the Cowpens and Eutaw Springs, and is the only Revolutionary standard extant in a condition for use in a parade.

The Aldermen who want a special legal adviser instead of the Corporation Counsel and who desire to handle $15,000 to purchase fireworks and decorations for the public buildings as a means of celebrating the Washington ...
TOPEKA, Kan., April 4.--Congressman Ryan's resignation was received by Gov. Humphrey to-day, and he telegraped his acceptance at once.

AUGUSTA, Me., April 4.--The State of Maine refunding bonds have been awarded to Simon Borg Co. of New-York. The bonds have been declared valid by the Supreme Court and certified by the Attorney-General of New-York as a legal investment for savings banks. The entire loan has been sold on terms favorable to the State.

The Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital never had a more active and earnest friend than Dr. C.R. Agnaw, to whose skill and earnest endeavors very much of the success it has achieved in its field of charitable work is due. It is most fitting, therefore, that the friends of this institution should erect in his memory a suitable monument.

In response to invitations sent out by a representative committee, about 250 property owners and residents of the district between Central Park and the East River and Fortyninth and Ninety-second streets, met at the Arion Clubhouse, Fifty-ninth-street and Park-avenue, ...

Senator John W. Daniel of Virginia is at the Astor House. T. Jefferson Coolidge of Massachusetts is at the Albemarle Hotel.

"A Gould market." So everybody on Wall-street described yesterday's Stock Exchange operations. All the Gould stocks went up, Missouri Pacific leading again as it did on the day before. Atchison was in the same cement; closing on Wednesday at 42 3/8, it rose easily yesterday to 44.
Central Office detective doings at the Mercer-street station house last night suggested an important arrest in an important case.

The 11 families who live in the flat house at 559 Ninth-avenue, which was bought by Mrs. John Jacob Astor, are nervous because of two mischievous fires which broke out, one on Sunday and the other yesterday afternoon.

Mayor Grant presided at one of the most important meetings yesterday of the Committee on Plan and Scope of the Washington Centennial Celebration that has thus far been held. Reports were received from various standing committees and conclusions reached with respect to several important matters.

Senator Hearst is in the city looking after his stable of racers at the Sheepshead Bay track. He very much regrets the loss of his two-year-old Mistral, by Hock Hooking-Maid of the Mist, a California-bred youngster who was very highly thought of and very largely engaged in all the principal stakes in this vicinity.

CHICAGO, April 4.--The West Chicago Street Railroad Company has taken out a permit for building a tunnel below the river to connect the west and south sides. It is proposed eventually to run all its cars through tunnels, abandoning the bridges and avoiding the delays caused by opening them to allow vessels to pass.
DENVER, Col., April 4.--On receipt of telegraphic instructions from Superintendent Hubbard of the Chicago police to-day, "Barney" McKinney and "Andy" Larkins, two well-known horsemen, were ...

The residents of Westville, a hamlet in the town of Hempstead, L.I., are greatly troubled by the doings of an unknown man. Several women, while on their way home after dark, have been badly frightened by having a man suddenly spirng from behind a tree and seize them by the arm.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 4.--The New-York East Conference reassembled this morning, Bishop Foster occupying the chair. M.L. Scudder, D.D., of Washington, conducted the opening devotional exercises, after which Arthur B. Sanford, Charles H. Buck, and Samuel L. Beiler were elected Assistant Secretaries.

There is much discord among Hoboken Republicans, and it is doubtful if they will have a ticket for city offices in the field on election day. They held a convention on Tuesday night and nominated John R. Wiggins for Mayor and E.V.S. Besson for Water Registrar.

Dr. Edward Pick, the lecturer on Memory, will, previous to beginning his course of lectures at Harvard University, give instruction to private classes at his office, 27 Union-square, beginning next Monday.
CHICAGO, April 4.--Police Lieutenant John M. Haines was held to the Grand Jury in bonds of $3,000 by Judge Altgeld to-day on charges preferred by Lawyer Frank H. Collier, ...

The Directors of the Southern Pacific elected general officers yesterday at San Francisco. The only change from 1888 is that C.F. Crocker takes the place of his father as Second Vice-President and A.N. Towne becomes Third Vice-President.

Mrs. Mary McHaney died yesterday at the Home of the Aged, Herkimer-street and Albany-avenue, Brooklyn, at the great age of 102 years. She was born in Ireland in 1786, but had lived in Brooklyn for 75 years. She had smoked a pipe for 50 years. The doctors say that she suffered from heart disease.
The famous Burgess yacht Mayflower, the successful defender of the America's Cup against the Scotch steel cutter Galatea in 1886, ...

Mr. A.E. Colfax, Secretary of the Harlem Regatta Association, has hit upon a new idea for a two-mile race of eight-oared shells for the Harlem Cup. It is to lay a course through High Bridge to a point above Morris Dock on the Harlem, and thus enable an observation train to follow the boats on the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, conveying a party to see the race who perhaps would not go otherwise.
CHARLESTON, S.C., April 4.--The steam yacht Reva from Savannah, for New-York, arrived here to-day. The steam yacht Oneida salled hence to-day for the West Indies.

"The Attitude of the Secular Press in America Toward Religion" was the subject considered at a meeting of the American Institute of Christian Philosophy last evening in the vestry of the Church of the Strangers. Mr. A.H. Siegfried, the eastern manager of the Chicago Daily News, presented the question from the standpoint of a newspaper man.

Men in the employ of Jay Gould were stationed at several of the stations of the elevated railroads yesterday distributing petitions to be signed in favor of permitting the construction of a new "loop" in Battery Park.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., April 4.--It is thought that this place will soon have another railroad. The Freehold and New-York Railroad, extension to Lorillard's brick yard is almost completed, and it is very probable that before long the work of building the road on to Atlantic ...

SHOSHONE, Idaho, April 4.--Gov. Stevenson's call for a Constitutional Convention at Boise City July 4 on assurances from Delegate Dubois in Washington that Idaho will be made a State next Winter causes much rejoicing throughout the Territory.

MITCHELL, Dakota, April 4.--Nobody but a man who has stood before a prairie fire and tried to stay its awful rush and roar when it is fanned, by a fresh wind can appreciate its almost resistless force.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 4.--Dr. McCosh's condition continues to improve, and his friends hope soon to see him on his feet again. His progress is necessarily slow, but he has the advantage of a vigorous constitution to fall back upon.

Coquelin will be breakfasted by mine host Breslin of the Gllsey House to-day. The hour is 11:30 A.M., and the breakfast will be served in one of the hotel parlors, after that style which has made Chef Gaspard famous.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., April 4.--To-night the Opera House was crowded at a citizens' meeting, and after an exciting discussion the Common Council was by vote requested to close a contract with the Jamestown Electric Light Company for an unspecified number of street are lamps, at $6 per lamp per month. Mayor Price is now in Albany to get a bill enacted enabling the city to issue bonds for a municipal plant.

SYDNEY, N.S.W., April 4.--The British manof-war Calliope, which escaped possible destruction in Apia Bay during the ravages of the cyclone there on March 15 and 16 by being able to put to sea, has arrived here.

RED BANK, N.J., April 4.--The township of Shrewsbury has given the sum of $100 of the township money to Arrowsmith Post, No. 61, G.A.R., of Red Bank, for the observance of Memorial Day. A law passed last Winter permits the appropriation of this amount every year.
ST. PAUL, Minn., April 4.--The lumber dealers who have been cutting timber from Government lands, principally on the Fond du Lac Indian reservation, have become alarmed by ...

CHICAGO, April 4.--There was another sensational feature in the wheat deal on 'Change today. The crowd has been kept on the ragged edge for weeks waiting for the final stroke of the great bull clique which was to put the selling price for May contracts up to $1 50.
Recently useful and ornamental articles belonging to patrons of the Fifth-Avenue Hotel have vanished in the most unaccountable way.
"Count von Arnim," "Baron Boringe," or plain Oscar Well, who caused Mr. William Steinway so much annoyance by masquerading as his nephew, is again in trouble.

Politicians up town last evening had their curiosity excited by a mysterious conference at the Gilsey house. It was held in the room of Russell Harrison, son of the President, and among those present were Logan H. Roots of Arkansas, R.C. Kerens of St. Louis, and W. J. Arkell. The session was prolonged until a very late hour.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 4.--Mr. John G. Thompson, Jr., son of the late leader of the Ohio Democracy, who secured a position in the Columbus Post Office three years ago on the indorsement of Judge Thursman. Congressman Outhwalte, and other prominent Democrats, has mysteriously disappeared.
The commission which is to supervise the erection of a municipal building met in the Mayor's office yesterday.
ALBANY, April 4.--At a hearing before the Attorney General to day on the report of the Insurance Department in relation to the affairs of the Mutual Benefit Association of America of ...
C.L. Darrow of 28 Spencer-place, Brooklyn, is the possessor of two relics of rather more than usual public interest.

TRENTON, N.J., April 4.--The Republicans today forced Speaker Hudspeth to retract his statement that the Democrats would do nothing toward providing ways and means to meet the State's deficit. Mr. Riker offered a substitute for Mr. Voorhees's State Tax bill, which reduces ...

PLAINFIELD, N.Y., April 4.--The Newark Methodist Episcopal Conference, in session here to-day, voted $5,000 to endow a bed in the Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr Breckenridge of the New-York Conference made an address.

WASHINGTON, April 4.--The Southern District of the Phi kappa Psi fraternity closed a three days' session in Alexandria to-night, and adjourned to meet in Columbia, S.C., in April, 1891. A banquet ended the exercises. W.A. Barber of South Carolina was chosen to represent the district on the Executive Council. The district decided that action should at once be taken by the Executive Council to extend the fraternity in the South.

Our recent tentative outreachings after foreign "dependencies" are by no means merely amusing. It would probably puzzle and American citizen, in or out of the State Department, to say what concern we have with the Samoan Islands that we should have thought it necessary to keep a naval force engaged in watching the Germans in the harbor of Apia.
M. Coquelin will make his last appearance on the stage in this country this afternoon, at a special performance to be given in the Madison-square Theatre, in aid of the Actors' Fund of America.
Mrs. Kate Leary, the widow of the notorious "Red" Leary, who was killed in this city some years ago, lives in a cottage at Coney Island.

Manager Gustav Amberg's enterprise in producing at his cosy little theatre Paul Lindarr's new comedy, "Die beide Leonoren," seemed to have aroused German society in New-York to an unusual demonstration of approval.

A pleasant musical and literary entertainment in aid of the little bureau of help and employment kept in the Rue Roussean, in Paris, by a committee of American ladies for the shop girls of that city was given last evening in the parlors of the Rutgers Female College, at 54 to 56 West Fifty-fifth-street.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 4.--In the House this morning a motion to recall the resolution passed last week commuting the sentence of Swift to life imprisonment failed to pass by a vote of 83 yeas to 102 nays. Both branches of the Legislature have adjourned and Gov. Bulkeley has not yet signed the resolution commuting Swift's sentence.

The Rapid Transit bill was yesterday reported to the Senate "for consideration" without change and made a special order for Tuesday next. In the Assembly it was reported, with two amendments, and made a special order for Wednesday.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 4.--The complete vote of the State gives Ladd 16,952, Davis 21,350, Richardson 1,511, Chace 3,435. Davis lacks 548 of election, but has a plurality of 4,398. For Attorney-General Rogers has 21,011, Slocum 21,816; scattering, 27, giving Slocum a majority of 778.

Prof. Comstock, ex-entomologist for the United States, has just returned from Germany. He has resumed his instruction in the university, and is actively at work on the second part of his "Introduction to Entomology."
DUBLIN, April 4.--A distillery syndicate has beeln formed in this city with a capital of 1,000,000. Messrs. John Jamieson, Son, the well-known distillers, have refused to join the syndicate.
One of the most extraordinary cases of smuggling and fraud on the Custom House known in this country became public through the customs authorities in this city yesterday afternoon.

Secretary of the Navy Tracy arrived at his home in Brooklyn late last night and at once retired.

Mindful of the Washington Market scandal and the discovery that two of the meat Inspectors of the Health Department were standholders, the Health Commissioners yesterday passed a resolution that "no person engaged in business as a butcher, dealer in meat, or marketman or having any interest in said business shall be a meat inspector of the Health Department." Charles F. Carlson, who had his right leg cut off by the falling of a portion of the Kings County Elevated Railroad on Fulton-street, Brooklyn, and who sued for $25,000 damages, got a verdict in the Circuit Court yesterday for the full amount. The defendant was the Phoenix Bridge Company of Pennsylvania, which constructed the road, and in whose employ Carlson was at the time of the accident.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 4.--Frank Lamotte, one of the crack wing shots of this city, will shoot a match at live pigeons against William Dackerman, one of the exports of the Elizabeth Gun Club, on April 29, at the club grounds. Never since the marriage of Miss Fox to Prince Lichtenstein several years ago, when the Prince and Princess of Wales went on from the pro-cathedral to one of the most famous garden parties ever given at Holland House, has London witnessed any Catholic function on as imposing a soale as the Nevill-Murrieta marriage, which is to take place this (Tuesday) morning at 11:30 in the Brompton Oratory.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--The meeting of the bar of the United States Supreme Court to-day to take action upon the death of Justice Stanley Matthews was interfered with by, probably, the worst storm of the season, and in consequence the attendance was small.

About a month ago was reprinted in these columns from the London Times an account of the opening of the Hawara Pyramid in the Fayum by Mr. Petrie, the well-known explorer. News now comes from the same source that Mr. Petrie has succeeded not only in cutting an entrance into the sepulchral chamber of Amenemhat III., but in searching every accessible part of the structure.
Ex-President Cleveland returned yesterday morning early from his pleasure trip to the South looking and feeling much better than for many months before he started on the excursion.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., April 6.--David Kline, an old shoemaker, lies in a dying condition here. He drank coffee which contained Rough on Rats. His wife is supposed to have administered the poison. She has fled. Detectives are now looking for her.
EASTPORT, Me., April 6.--H.F. Wilder, proprietor of the Eastport Messenger, disappeared last November.
Once more was Secretary B.F. Tracy, of the Navy Department the guest of a Brooklyn club last evening.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., April 6.--An argument, which will probably have an important bearing in the case of Henry Seibert, trustee, against the St. Louis Road and others through which the receiver was appointed, was heard to-day by Judge Young. It was on a general demurrer to the amended complaint recently filed by order of the court.
William Baber, aged 83, of New-Rochelle, met with a violent death shortly after 8 o'clock yesterday morning.
The statement of gross earnings for the NewYork Central and its leased lines for March gives a total of $2,861,598 72, an increase of $11,989 43 over March, 1888.

One of the oldest railroad conductors in New-England is Elbridge A. Towie of the Eastern Railroad, who has been in its employ continuously since March 28, 1847. Mr. Tewle has been in the employ of the railroad 42 years, 37 years of that time as conductor.

CHICAGO, April 6.--According to a Washington dispatch printed here this morning, the Illinois Senators are waxing indignant over the treatment they are receiving from the Administration.

New-York society during the past week of this season of Lenten fasting has been chiefly occupied in giving and attending dinners. This round of gastronomical gayety began on Monday with a banquet at the Gurnee mansion, given in honor of the Coquelins, pere et fils, whom, by the bye, it has been the fashion of the hour to honor by a series of social invitations.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 6.--Perth Amboy's defaulting Tax Collector, Amzi Marsh, was exhibited in a decidedly unpleasant light yesterday, when Joseph E. Chapman of Amboy sued Mrs. Lydia Barton, a widow of that place, for the amount of a note of hers for $500 which he held.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--The Department of State has been informed by the United States Consul at Ottawa that the licenses to fishing vessels will continue to be issued this year by the Canadian Government on the same terms as last year, Collectors of Customs have been supplied with the same terms as last year, but the licenses will be granted to expire Dec. 31, 1889.
WASHINGTON, April 6.--A heavy snow and rain storm has prevailed here since early this morning.

Admiral David D. Porter has accepted the office of Grand Marshal of the naval parade and review that is to be the distinguishing feature of the first day of the centennial celebration. His acceptance was communicated by mail yesterday to Col. Asa Bird Gardiner and Capt. Henry Erben, who personally waited on him to extend the invitation of the committee.

At the recent meeting of the Trustees in NewYork R.P. Harrington, '82, was elected Latin tutor in place of R.E. Williams, '85, who has resigned to study law, L.O. Kuhne, '85, will have charge of the French classes next year and Prof. Prentice will have German and Hebrew.

Not content with winning first honors of the League and the world's championship, the New-York Giants yesterday paved the way to adding new laurels to their list by defeating the Brooklyn Club in the opening game for the local championship.

There is considerable interest manifested in naval circles regarding the awarding of the contract for the new coast-defense vessels. No news of the award had been received at the Quintard Iron Works up to yesterday noon. The fact of the Quintards being the highest bidders does not, in the opinion of naval engineers, necessarily imply a rejection of their bid.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 6.--William Suydam and his wife were buried to-day at George's Road. The husband died one day after his wife. One was 89 years old and the other 87. They had been married 70 years.

A short time ago a New-York firm sent an agent to Scorthsburg, Ind., to purchase a large white oak tree, which measured 27 feet in circumference. They bought the tree for $75, and set to work to get out as large a board as possible.

A glance at the yachting programmes for this season already announced shows the many interesting events to take place. The season will be formally opened on May 30 with the match race between the Shamrock and Titania, two of the seventy-foot sloops which are attracting so much attention nowadays.

At this writing there are five American war ships on their way home from foreign stations, and a sixth will shortly follow from the South Atlantic. The last of the cruisers enroute should arrive in the States by June 1, and there ought to be plenty of work at the Brooklyn and Norfolk Navy Yards during the coming Summer.
FORT DODGE, Iowa, April 6.--Sheriff Adams and a single deputy yesterday arrested 17 river land settlers charged with conspiracy.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., April 5.--In this part of the State the season for making maple sugar is well advanced, and owners of maple orchards have gathered the saccharine product in large quantities. A month or more ago there could no doubt be found on the city stands plenty of sugar which was called new and fresh from Northern New-York.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 6.--Mrs. Wilson, widely known by her malden name, Ida Lewis, yesterday added another to a long list of lives saved by her in Newport Harbor.

The absence of the Rev. Morgan Dix from the morning service in Trinity Church yesterday occasioned considerable comment among the uncommonly large congregation which had assembled in anticipation of a continuance of the rector's series of Lenten discourses.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 7.--Fully fifty years ago P.T. Barnum of this city edited and published at Bethel the Herald of Freedom. His unqualified utterances ultimately resulted in his incarceration in the Danbury Jail.

ST. PAUL, April 7.--It is reported that J.C. Easton of Lacrosse recently tendered his resignation as a Director of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul, and it has yet to be accepted.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 7.--The love feast today was led by the Rev. Dr. J.S. Porter. Bishop Merrill preached the morning sermon. The ordination of Deacons followed.

More or less accurate descriptions of the new building of THE TIMES appeared last Winter in difference publications. As the descriptions were obtained, generally, from the plans rather than from the building, perhaps none of them did the building justice.

TOPEKA, Kan., April 7.--Thousans of women participated in the municipal elections held throughout Kansas last week. In Topeka alone over 2,300 voted, and in Leavenworth, Wichita, Atchison, Fort Scott, and smaller cities the numbers far exceeded those of 1887.

Chief Inspector Byrnes has in custody in the cells at Police Headquarters yesterday three men who are indicted for conspiracy in attempting to blow up with dynamite David Stevenson's ale brewery on Tenth-avenue, between Thirty-ninth and Fortieth streets, some weeks ago.
Dr. Burdette Craig and his brother rode to the Jersey-avenue crossing of the Erie Railway in Jersey City yesterday, and the gateman signaled them to cross.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., April 7.--The United States ship Pensacola sank in dry dock last night, where she was being repaired for sea. Her sea valves had been opened for inspection, and another one was being out.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 7.--The local optionists of the county are indignant over the fact that they have been called upon to pay all the expenses of the proceedings for an election under the local option law that has just been repealed by the Democratic Legislature.
With a certain decorous satisfaction Prime Minister CRISPI has informed the Chamber of Deputies that the death of King JOHN of Abyssinia would enable Italy to extend her possessions in that country.

The Balfe Musical Club promises to become a public benefactor. Its members have decided to petition the Board of Aldermen and citizens generally to abolish the gutter bands who torture the ears of the long-suffering public at all hours of the day.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 7.--Yesterday afternoon, while Miss Anna Newbrandt of Sayreville and her sister were on their way home on the South Amboy Road, three men assaulted Miss Newbrandt and tried to steal her money.

The Games Committee of the New-Jersey Athletic Club has decided upon the events to be contested on May 30 at the club's grounds at Bergen Point. They are: 100-yard dash, 220-yard hurdle, 300-yard flat race, half-mile run, one-and-a-half-mile run, three-quarter-mile walk, one-and-a-half-mile walk, one-and-a-half-mile bicycle race, three-mile bicycle race, putting sixteen-pound hammer, running high jump, and running broad jump.

ALBANY, April 7.--The combination existing between Gov. Hill, Edward Murphy, Jr., of Troy, and Tammany Hall is reaching out. This "combine" is in the field for business, and proposes to make a stubborn fight for the control of the Government four years hence.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 7.--All signs point to a grand and successful French opera season here next Winter. Yesterday the two best loges left were sold by the Secretary of the opera association to Mrs. Oxlesby and Mr. E.J. Hart.

He says the Eastern Club really owns the cup now, and that in case the Valkyrie outsails a boat of her own class in the race for the cup the Eastern Yacht Club will challenge for it and win it next year.

LONDON, April 7.--The Inman Line steamship City of Richmond, Capt. Redford, from Liverpool, sld. from Queenstown to-day for New-York. The Cunard Line steamship Servia, Capt. McKay, from Liverpool, sld. from Queenstown to-day for New-York.

Private advices from Norway are to the effect that this year's catch of cod is an almost total failure, and that the supply of oil will in consequence be very small and entirely inadequate to the demand. A prominent expert gives it as his opinion that oil will go up to $35 a barrel, which is a big jump in the price, considering that it was as low as $19.

NORFOLK, Va., April 7.--The storm of thunder, lightning, and hail which broke over this city yesterday morning, changed at 10 o'clock last night, turning into a cyclone, the wind blowing at the rate of 54 miles an hour until 5 o'clock this morning.

Mr. P.S. Gilmore and his band are preparing to celebrate the twentieth anniversary of the great Boston jubilee by a series of jubilee concerts to extend over the months of May and June and to cover an extensive territory in this country and Canada.

NEW-HAVEN, April 7.--The Hartford and Connecticut Western has purchased 400 acres of land at Grantville, five miles west of Winsted, and will locate its repair shops and roundhouse there. One hundred acres of the land will be devoted to side tracks and turnouts. A small lake on the premises will be raised three feet and will then furnish sufficient water power to run the machinery in the shops.

WASHINGTON, April 7.--Copies of the official report to the British Admiralty of the committee on the recent English naval manoeuvres have just been received at the Navy Department, and are being read with a great deal of interest, as they have a very practical bearing on some of the vessels in the new United States Navy.

Tammany Hall has now been in possession of most of the important offices of this city for more than three months. At the last elec tion its representatives were chosen to fill the offices of Mayor, Sheriff, and County Clerk.

ALBANY, April 7.--Superintendent of Insurance Maxwell expects to present Part II, of his report for 1888 to the Legislature to-morrow evening or Tuesday morning.

Since the Senate refused to confirm the nomination of Mr. HALSTEAD to be Minister to Germany the Cincinnati CommercialGazette has become deeply interested in the life histories of the Senators who were unwilling that its editor should enter the public service.

The Rev. R. Heber Newton delivered the last of his series of sermons on the Incarnation at All Souls' Church yesterday morning. The church was crowded, and the interest in the sermon was keen. The minister said that the original doctrine of the incarnation was a doctrine which Christians should welcome as the key to the problems of this nineteenth century.
There was a wedding last evening in the saloon of John Schwartz, at 265 Broome-street. Samuel Hoffman and Jennie Knopf were the groom and bride.

Minnie Dunbar made an unsuccessful attempt to commit suicide in Spokane Falls. Washington Ter ritory, Saturday night. She was dissatisfied with the way she was living. She tried to kill herself a year ago, in Marysville, Cal.

BOSTON, April 7.--The South Boston Iron Works is pushing the work on the six-inch rifles for the Government. The first gun will by ready for shipment to the proving grounds by the middle of next month, and from that date on one gun will be completed each succeeding month.
PANAMA, April 7, via Galveston, Texas.-- Since the suspension of work on the canal over eight thousand laborers have been sent home from the isthmus.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., April 7.--Threescore Winnebago Indians, on a Spring excursion from the region of Black River Falls, where they make their home, are encamped three miles east of the city limits, on Otter Creek.

LONDON, April 7.--The British schooner Carrie Dingle has sunk after being in collision off Beachy Head with the Red Star Line steamer Noordland, Capt. Nickels, which sailed from Antwerp April 6 for New-York. The Noordland's bow was stove. She is at Southampton, where she will discharge her cargo for repairs. No lives were lost.
The Central Labor Union met yesterday to reorganize in accordance with a resolution passed several weeks ago calling upon all the constituent unions to elect new delegates to the central body.

Voters are expected, on the cue ballot, to vote a set of officials in under the present charter, and to vote them out again by accepting the new charter.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., April 7.--The steamship Old Dominion, Capt. Couch, from New-York, arrived here seven hours late. The trip was a very rough one, the wind blowing a gale all the time.

CHICAGO, April 7.--Election week was felt at the Chicago playhouses, and the books of none of them will show the big business which has generally prevailed of late. There were novelties at three of the houses, though most of the occupants of their stages have been seen or heard here.

There seems to be but little prospect that New-Yorkers will be able to witness ball games on Manhattan Island this season. The Board of Aldermen have not yet rendered their final verdict on the division of the Polo Grounds by One Hundred and Eleventh-street.
LONDON, April 8.--Henry M. Stanley's letter to the Royal Geographical Society was read at the meeting of that body this evening. It consists mainly of a repetition of what has already been published.
