ELIZABETH, N.J., April 8.--Chief of Police Jenkins of this city had a narrow escape from being killed this evening. He was superintending the tearing down of an old rockery on Morris-avenue when he tripped and fell headlong into the deep cellar. He was picked up unconscious, bleeding from an ugly wound in the head, and at first it was supposed his skull was fractured.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 8.--Judge Pugh rendered his decision in the famous Church divorce case this morning, granting Mrs. Church a decree of divorce on the ground of cruelty, giving her custody of three children and $400 per annum alimony.
Mr. Edward Harrigan changed his bill again last night and revived "The Grip," a local piece of his own, which was successfully produced at the Park Theatre a few seasons ago.

TRENTON, N.J., April 8.--The sensation of the night in the House was the speech of Speaker Hudspeth, explaining his action regarding the passage of the Railroad Corporation act. He said that Mr. Goble called his attention to the bill, asking if it were on the calendar. His secretary said it was.

The report of the Committee on Uniforms occupied the attention of the Brooklyn Bridge trustees yesterday, and although the meeting was brief, it abounded in remarks that were far from soothing to Trustees Higgins and Barnes, the members of that committee.

The big skysail-yard American ship Governor Goodwin has just made the run home to New-York from Hong-Kong in 129 days.

TRENTON, N.J., April 8.--Vice-Chancellor John T. Bird, who has held than office for seven years, was to-day reappointed for a second term by Chancellor McGill. Owing to some opposition from South Jersey lawyers, there was some doubt about his reappointment, but the North Jersey lawyers and his friends, irrespective of party, made a successful effort in his behalf. In politics he is a Democrat.

SALISBURY, Md., April 9.--Gov. Jackson, who was brought home from Philadelphia yesterday very ill, is somewhat better to-day. His attending physician says the cause of his illness is erysipelas, and that no serious results are anticipated at this time.

Frank B. Stearns of this city bought 8,500 acres of land in Missouri of the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad Company in 1874 for $127,000, of which he paid $92,000 down. The Atlantic and Pacific Road was swallowed up by the St. Louis and San Francisco Road, which sued Mr. Stearns in Missouri and is defendant in litigation brought here by Mr. Stearns.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 8.--Gen. Rosenbach, Governor of Turkestan, has left Kerki, near the frontier of Afghanistan, and is returning to Tashkand. He reports that tranquility prevails along the Afghan frontier. The Ameer of Afghanistan is returning to Cabul.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 8.--Burrillville elected a Republican Representative to-day by 67 majority, and Bristol failed to elect a Representative, there being five tickets in the field. The Legislature now stands: Senate, 24 Republicans, 10 Democrats, 2 to be chosen; House, 28 Republicans, 37 Democrats, 7 to be chosen. On the joint ballot, 52 Republicans, 47 Democrats. Elections are to be held to-morrow in Newport, Bristol, and Cranston.

Ward McAllister's venture into the ranks of the great public to take a hand in the management of the centennial ball is likely to be attended with disastrous results to him as a social leader. When Mr. McAllister awoke to the fact that he was not the entire committee-- merely a member of it--it astonished him.

Willis Hoffman, a young man belonging to Emerson, N.Y., shot himself in Fort Hill Cemetery, Auburn, yesterday, sending a bullet into his head and another into his left breast. His recovery is doubtful. In a letter addressed to Florence Emerson, Emerson, N.Y., he stated that he was suffering from a disease in the head. Hoffman attempted suicide about a month ago by cutting his throat.

Shepard for $50,000, the guide, philosopher, and friend of the institution.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 8.--Dr. McCosh is gaining very steadily now and sits up for several hours each day. His daughter, Mrs. Maitland, and her husband are still here. There is nothing alarming in his condition at present.

A new bell for Trinity Church chimes arrived here yesterday from Baltimore and will be hanged to-day, increasing the number of bells to 10 and enhancing greatly the value and efficiency of the chimes. It is an E flat, weighs 450 pounds, and has a beautiful tone, harmonizing thoroughly with its nine predecessors, whose sweet voices have for years been known to New-Yorkers.
Young William Krulisch went on the witness stand in Judge Gildersleeve's court yesterday to defend himself against the charge of having killed Gnenther Wechsung, clerk for Druggist Otto Doepfner.

RALEIGH, N.C., April 8.--Almost the entire town of Smithfield, in Johnston County, was consumed by fire yesterday afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8.--For some time the Pennsylvania Railroad has been endeavoring to find some means to handle the great freight traffic received at the West Philadelphia yards without the delay which cannot be helped at present because of the lack of space and facilities.

ERIE, Penn., April 8.--The Journeyman Tailors' Union of this city struck to-day in a body, and to-night turned bank all their unfinished work. The journeymen demand a uniform price to all tailors and the employment of only union tailors. The merchant tailors positively refuse to sign the agreement. The labor union will back up the tailors.

LONDON, April 8.--In the House of Commons to-night the Lord Advocate introduced a bill providing for local government in Scotland.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 8.--William Simpson, colored, the murderer of Isham Kelly, a white planter, is now in Newton County Jail. The murder was committed in 1886, when Simpson escaped and was not arrested until Saturday. The strange feature of the case is that he has been living all this time within five miles of the scene of the murder, having assumed the name of Phinzy.

Wiley, the retiring Democratic Postmaster of this city. Mr. Wiley is a personal friend of Gov. Green, who has the appointing power.

The All America team administered another defeat to the Chicago Club yesterday, and now leads Anson's men by seven games. Only 2,000 persons saw the contest, which was due, perhaps, to the lack of local interest. For six innings John Healy pitched a great game, but toward the close he eased up somewhat, and allowed Chicago to make a spurt.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 8.--Controller Carlton has effected a settlement of $10,000 of the outstanding bonds of the city which were held by a New-York creditor. This makes $30,000 negotiated by the city within the past week with its few remaining creditors.

JAFFA, April 8.--The party of American Catholic pilgrims reached here yesterday from Ismallia. The sea was fortunately smooth, and the landing was made without delay. The pilgrims proceeded at once toward Jerusalem. They will reach there to-night, and will remain until April 23, when they will return to this port on their way home.
ST. PAUL, April 8.--When the House went into Committee of the Whole to day the first bill considered was Mr. Willrich's, providing for the employment of convict labor.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 8.--A fire was discovered in the centre of the business portion of this place this morning about 2 o'clock in the barn of Bagley Burns. By hard work on the part of the firemen the flames were kept from spreading. Christopher Murray of West End was knocked from the top of a ladder and hurled to the ground, breaking two ribs.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., April 8.--It has been found that the coffee which caused the sudden sickness of David Kline contained a large amount of poison. Kline is still under the doctor's care. His wife is locked up awaiting trial for poisoning him, and to-day Robert Rusher, an engineer, was arrested on a charge of being her accomplice.

PARIS, April 8.--The Mot d'Crdre says that the Belgian authorities have given notice to Gen. Boulanger to leave Belgium, and that he will go to Brighton, England, to-morrow. Gen. Boulanger, however, has telegraphed from Brussels that this report is untrue.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 8.--It is not probable that the courts will grant another extension of time for filing claims against the Continental Life Insurance Company, which has been in the hands of receivers for 18 months.

He held a little conversation with Mr. Pearson as to the transfer of the office, which will take place probably next Monday. Senator Van Cott has received his commission, and will send his bond to Washington to-day for approval.

CHICAGO, April 8.--The statement of eastbound shipments of flour, grain, and provisions by the lines in the Central Traffic Association last week shows an aggregate of 19,856 tons, against 31,260 for the week previous, a decrease of 11,404 tons, and 36,113 for the corresponding week last year, a decrease of 16,257 tons.

Alderman Carlin is an orator who orates on every possible occasion. He made a speech before Mayor Grant yesterday and was surprised at the effect it produced. His oration was in favor of permitting Jay Gould to put an elevated railroad "loop" in Battery Park.

The Board of Finance of Jersey City yesterday indulged in vengeance on Senator Edwards and Speaker Hudspeth for the part they took in forcing the proposed city charter through the Legislature. This charter will be voted on to-day. If it is adopted, the present board is certain to go out of office.

WASHINGTON, April 8.--Harry D. Darby, a registry clerk in the Post Office in this city was arrested to-day for rifling valuable registered letters. When arrested he had $70 in his hand which he had just taken from a letter. The letter was mailed at Harper's Ferry, West Va., contained $246, and was addressed to the United States Treasury. After removing $70 Darby was about to reseal it.

ALBANY, April 9.--Even with the police in his interest Gov. Hill failed to break down the regular Democratic organization at to-day's election in this city and Cohoes, and Mr. Herrick came out on top. At the contest in this city the lightest vote in years was polled, the Republicans staying away from the polls.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 9.--The city was startled to-day by the announcement that Zebulon Rudd, cashier of the First National Bank, had resigned.

NYACK, N.Y., April 9.--The election for President of the village of Upper Nyack a few weeks ago being a tie, a special election became necessary, and was held this afternoon. Much interest was shown, as both of the former candidates were again in the field. George C. Stephens was elected President to-day by a majority of 14, and his friends are happy to-night.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 9.--Lawrence Gorman of South Amboy has for some time kept a watch on his wife, and found that she was receiving visits from a man named Roderer. Yesterday, becoming wildly jealous, he tried to kill his wife and child. He was locked up to-day.

One of the best games played at the chess tournament yesterday was that between Taubenhaus and Gunsberg. The opening was the "Ruy Lopez," and the play proceeded very carefully on both sides. On the twelfth move Toubenhaus captured a pawn, which gave him an advantage from that stage of the game, But Gunsberg kept up the fight in a masterly manner, althongh forced to exchange queens.

ALBANY, April 9.--A false notion seems to prevail that Arbor Day is a legal holiday. By the provisions of chapter 196, Laws of 1888 of the State of New-York, the Friday following the first day of May is made Arbor Day, and on that day school authorities are required to conduct exercises which shall tend to encourage the planting, care, and preservation of trees and shrubs.

Yee Sing, a wealthy Chinese merchant of Denver, was arrested in Chicago Saturday last, and left for Denver yesterday with the officers. The charge against him is that be eloped with Wong Toy, the wife of Chin Poo, another prominent Chinaman of Denver, and that he took with him $400 of Chin Poo'a money. Yee Sing denies the theft of the money, but admits that Won Toy loves him better than she does her husband.

The Stock Exchange had more excitement yesterday in the stock of the Atchison. Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Company. The recent rise of five points has dwindled sadly during the first two days of this week. A marriage license was issued Wednesday afternoon at Pittsburg, Penn., to Samuel R. Wesler, aged 72 years, and Edith P. Wilson, aged 15 years. The application for the license was made at the license office by Mr. Wesler, an erect and well-preserved man, looking many years younger than the age he gave. He was accompanied by James Wilson, the father of the girl, who resides at 168 Wylie-avenue.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 11.--The house of Mr. W. P. Word, house carpenter and millwright, living in Robin County, was burned to the ground last night. The entire family, consisting of a wife and five small children, perished in the flames. The house was a small one, with the chimney and door in one end, and escape was barred for this reason.
A petition was received this morning from the New-York Chamber of Commerce protesting against the passage of the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge bill introduced by Judge Greene.
There were 19 paintings belonging to the Duque de Durcal sold at Chickering Hall by the American Art Association last night out of a total of 51 offered for bids.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 11.--The last hours of the Newark Methodist Episcopal Conference were very busy ones. Eleven standing and special committees made reports. The Committee on Temperance and Prohibition presented a report that represented the latter rather than the former.

New-York's ball team is the proud possessor of three championships. Last season the Giants won first honors in the League, outplayed the St. Louis Browns in the world's series, and yesterday they carried off the deciding game for the local championship by defeating the Brooklyn team.

The annual report of the Norfolk and Western Railroad Company for 1888 has just been issued. The gross earnings for the year were $4,899,598.89; operating expenses, including taxes, $3,001,927.13, making the net earnings $1,897,671.76, an increase of 7 per cent over the previous year.

ALBANY, April 11.--There is considerable dispute as to whether April 30 is a legal holiday. Throughout banking circles the fact that it is a legal holiday is known, but other commercial interests seem to be divided on the subject.
NEW-ORLEANS, April 11.--Fire broke out early this evening on board the British steamship Chilian, lying off First-street, in her forward compartment.

"A Wild Idea" is a farce written by Mrs. Charles A. Doremus and Miss Bessie Marbury, which, it is understood, has been purchased by Miss Rosina Vokes. Mrs. Chauncey-Smith, an American Anglomaniac, reconstructs her entire household after improved British patterns in view of the forthcoming visit of an English young lady connected with the nobility.

NYACK, N.Y., April 11.--A war of races appears to be imminent in Haverstraw. A number of negroes are employed in the brickyards during the Summer months, and the foreigners who claim a right to the monopoly of work there object to the colored people's presence in the yards.

The Columbia College Dramatic Club will present a new burlesque, by the author of "Captain Kidd," called "William Penn; or. The Quaker and the Romany Rye," at the Berkeley Lyceum for the benefit of the university crew on the evenings of April 24, 25, 26, and 27 and the afternoon of April 27. The performance will be under the stage management of Mr. Frederick Bond of Mr. Daly's company.
ELIZABETH, N.J., April 11.--The Police Committee of this city is dealing severely with offending officers.
Two big British ships, the Ester Roy and Lansdowne, cleared from this port Wednesday for Calcutta. The former is under the command of Capt. McDougall, and the latter is under Capt. Newcomb.
Lawyer Howe asked Judge Martine in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday that Mrs. Olive E. Friend, who is under indictment for the electric sugar frauds be given an immediate trial.
FREEHOLD, N.J., April 11.--Mabel, the fiveyear-old daughter of Gilbert W. Hulsbart, who lives on South-street, while playing near a stove yesterday, had her clothing set on fire.
Julius Schwartz, ex-editor of Hungaria, and who ran against "Tim" Campbell and exJudge McCarthy for Congress at the last election, was arraigned before Judge Martine yesterday, charged with forgery.

Henry Holden Huss, a young American composer, gave a concert of his own works at Steinway Hall Wednesday evening in the presence of a large and friendly audience. Mr. Huss is not unknown here, and specimens of his work have been heard before on the concert stage.

John Von Henzel, 31 years old, of 746 Bedford-avenue, Brooklyn, committed suicide in Busch's Hotel, Hoboken, last night by shooting himself through the right temple. In his pockets were found eight sealed letters, a gold watch and chain, and a pocketbook containing $2.91.
Judge Truax, in the Superior Court, Special Term, yesterday reserved his decision on a motion argued for the city by Messrs. Dean and...
Miss Lillie Berg gave a concert at the residence of Mrs. M.P. Grace, Madison-avenue and Seventieth-street, yesterday afternoon.
Frederick Waldman, a waiter, applied to Justice Naeher, in Brooklyn, yesterday for a warrant for the arrest of Civil Justice John Petterson on a charge of assault.

RED BANK, N.J., April 11.--Red Bank is enjoying a building boom, and no town in the State is increasing more rapidly in population. About a score of new houses are being erected, and contractors agree that there is more building in progress than there has been for several years past.

The Citizens' Committee of Brooklyn, composed largely of independent Republicans, which prepared the amendments to Mayor Chapin's Local Improvement bills, is to be enlarged and to be made a permanent body.
When Mrs. Lillie Langtry returned from a walk yesterday to her home at 361 West Twenty-third-street she found firemen at work on the house.
The price of the stock of the Sugar Trust was raised six points on the Stock Exchange yesterday, making an advance of ten points this week.
BUFFALO, N.Y., April 11.--Grain shortages have been the curse of vessel owners and dealers ever since elevators were invented.

The Spring opening at Lord Taylor's Grand-street establishment this year clearly surpasses any former display.

Fire broke out about 12:30 o'clock this morning in the large carpet manufactory of Buchanan Lyall, at President and Hoyt streets, in Brooklyn. The flames burned fiercely, and so threatening was the aspect of the fire that a second and then a third alarm were sent out by 1 o'clock.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 11.--The Board of Health to-night called on the Governor to issue his proclamation, declaring from May 1 the quarantine rules of the Mississippi station in force.

Some more interesting testimony was given before the Commissioners of Accounts yesterday. The special feature of it was the revelation that some of the predecessors of the present Commissioners of Accounts knew that the accounts of the Market Bureau were kept in a loose fashion, yet took no steps to introduce a proper system.

Secretary Tracy's appointment yesterday of Pierie Parsell to be master iron plater in the Brooklyn Navy Yard in place of Owen Magowen; of James Hare, to be master patternmaker in place of D. McAllister; of James P. Howatt, to be master machinist in the Steam Engineering...

The veteran showman's performance of the Phoenix over the ashes of successive museums and shows has become proverbial, and after the successive ashes of the shows he means to have a successor to himself.
Special Policeman George Hoyt of Orange, N.J., came upon two suspicious characters near Brighton-avenue on Wednesday evening and tried to arrest them.

RED BANK, N.J., April 11.--Poker playing is becoming popular with the young men of Red Bank, and it is said that there are eight games in the town. Some of them are situated in the business part of the place.

Promoters of the Linden Park Blood Horse Association, which has in view the establishment of a track near Elizabeth, N.J., met at the St. James Hotel last night and elected these officers: President--Lloyd Aspinwall; Vice President--Richard Stockton; Treasurer-- William M. Connor; Secretary--John H. Coster.

SCRANTON, Penn., April 11.--The German Methodist Episcopal Conference, embracing the States of New-York, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Connecticut, Massachusetts, and Indiana, began its session in this city this morning. The conference will be continued five days.

ALBANY, April 11.--The Gilbert A. Robertson Home has been incorporated. The object is to establish a Summer home for poor families in New-York City, and enable them to have, free of expense to them, a short period of rest in the country during the Summer months.

The strength of the hurricane which prevailed off Cape Hatteras for three days, Saturday, Sunday, and Monday, was attested yesterday by the storm-beaten hulls of arriving vessels.

BUCHAREST, April 11.--It is rumored here that an attempt was made upon the life of the Czar on Sunday last and that his Majesty was wounded by an exploding shell. The affair is said to have been hushed up by the Russian authorities.

Justine Genez, the twenty-three-year-old daughter of August Genez, proprietor of the Schuetzen Park at One Hundred and Sevetiethstreet and Boston-avenue, committed suicide yesterday morning by shooting herself in the head with a large revolver.

The Blue Anchor Society, the State auxiliary to the Women's National Relief Association for the Aid of the Shipwrecked, has just issued its eighth annual report.

At the meeting of General Passenger Agents at Commissioner Fink's office yesterday the New-England and Canadian Railroads agreed to co-operate with the other railroads in abolishing commissions to agents.

WASHINGTON, April 11.--Sergeant at Arms Canaday appears to be in the way of getting into trouble with the Senate before that body meets again in the Fall or Winter. An effort was made some time ago to get rid of him, even at the expense of an entire reorganization of the Senate force.

Mayor Grant presided at yesterday's meeting of the Committee on Plan and Scope of the Centennial Celebration of Washington's Inanguration, which was finally to pass upon the programme which has been submitted to and approved by Mayor Grant and Gov. Hill...

UTICA, N.Y., April 11.--The Northern NewYork Methodist Episcopal Conference is now in session at Lowville, Lewis County, Bishop W. X. Ninde presiding.
Robert Kell, doing business as Kell Co., importer of woolens and plushes at 480 Broome-street and at Bradford, England, has failed.

ALBANY, April 11.--Having passed the Crosby Excise and Saxton Ballot Reform bills and ordered the Mayor's Rapid Transit bill to a third reading, the House to-day took hold of the convict labor question, and, it must be confessed, gave an exhibition of neither enlightened statesmanship nor common humanity.
Dr. von Bulow had another large and delighted audience at the Broadway Theatre yesterday afternoon, when he gave the second of his extra piano recitals.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 11.--A boy residing at Seabright, but attending school at the place, was arrested last night by Constable Clay Woolley on complaint of his parents for playing truant.

Wall-street was treated to something of a sensation yesterday. The plans of some more or less eminent financiers went wrong and their sorrows were retailed all over the Stock Exchange district. Statesmen like Deacon S.V. White and "Steve" Dorsey of 1880 "soap" fame, and Col. Bob Ingersoll are among the sorrowing.

The Republican Senators held a caucus this afternoon, not for the purpose of considering proposed legislation, but because Senator Fassett felt that he had a grievance against some fellow-Senator who had divulged the secrets of yesterday's caucus.
RAHWAY, N.J., April 11.--It has been decided by the Republican leaders to demand a recount of the votes cast for Mayor at the recent election.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., April 12.--The present crop year, Col. Rogers of the Market Record said to-day, will go into history as one of the most important speculative seasons the wheat trade has ever witnessed. General prices of wheat and its products all over the world had declined for several years and had become so depressed ...

BALTIMORE, April 12.--Rain prevented the Boston and Baltimore exhibition game here to-day. The Baltimore Club is now complete. Cunningham, the pitcher who has been holding off, arrived in the city to-day and signed a contract to play.

Mayor Grant's secretary, T.C.T. Crain, is beginning to rival Mayor Hewitt as a letter writer. His latest production is a communication to Street-Cleaning Commissioner Coleman, reciting grievances complained of to the Mayor yesterday by a committee of east side property owners.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 12.--John Guy Vassar's will provided $100,000 for the establishment of the John Guy Vassar Orphan Asylum and $100,000 more for the maintenance of the asylum and care of the property.

In the presence of a large and attentive auditory, chiefly of English people, Signor Laneiani gave yesterday, in the newly excavated portion of the Forum of Augustus, a most interesting description of the origin, progress, and scope of the excavations.

During 1888 the Pope's income amounted to 504,000, of which 372,000 came from the obolus of St. Peter, and 132,000 from the interest of moneys which are invested out of Italy.

Capt. Shaw of the steamship Delta, which arrived yesterday from Port de Paix, reported that the situation in Hayti was unchanged. The Delta was the British vessel which was seized by one of Legitime's gunboats under the suspicion of having contraband of war on board.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 12.--Drafts--Sight, 10; telegraphic, 15.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 12.--Mrs. Mary McNierny, while suffering last night from dementia, attempted to kill Mrs. Mary Petit and her daughter, who live in the same house on Broadway. She attacked them with a big mallet and chased them to their apartments.

The police of Capt. Westervelt's precinct are investigating a case of mysterious fires at the Chenango flat house in Lenox-avenue, between One Hundred and Twenty-seventh and One Hundred and Twenty-eighth streets, belonging to the Aiken estate.

Thirty picked men of the United States Marine Corps will sail to-day for France on the steamer La Gascogne. They are under the command of Capt. Williams, United States Marine Corps, who has with him Lieut. Paul St. C. Murphy, also of the Marine Corps.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES has moved into its new, large, and elegant building. It will be an admirable building for the home of a great newspaper.

The reports concerning the low rate of speed of the revenue cutter McLane on her trial trip appear to be unfounded. From the latest accounts it is learned that she ran 41.2 miles in 3 hours and 58 minutes.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., April 12.--In the case of Hope Co. of Amsterdam against the State Board of Liquidation to compel the funding of $4,000,000 of the old Citizens' Bank bonds into State consols Judge Ellis handed down his decision to-day, maintaining the exception of the State and dismissing the plaintiffs' demand.

The ninth annual drill and review of the Berkeley School Corps at the Seventh Regiment Armory last evening was witnessed by between three and four thousand of the relatives and friends of the manly young soldiers.

One life is believed to have been lost in the fierce fire which consumed the Planet Mills in Brooklyn yesterday morning. ALBANY, April 12.--Ex-Judge Countryman held a brief adjourned hearing to-day in the case of Controller Myers against the State Assessors, alleging discrimination against New-York in making up their equalization tables.

The Fellowcraft Club has prepared a unique exhibit for the centennial celebration. It consists of numbers of the newspapers and magazines published in the United States during the Administration of Washington, as well as certain American journals that antedate his term as President of the United States.
The Brooklyn Aldermen are very indignant because they have received no invitations to the inaugural centennial celebration.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, April 12.--Some time ago Annie and Carrie Hally, aged 15 and 17, left their home in Newark and ran away to Vineland to get work. They found nothing to do, however, and last week started for home.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 12.--The sale of the Memphis Water Works to the Artesian Water Works Company has been consummated, with the approval of the City Council.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 12.--The Duluth and Winnipeg Railroad stirred up a regular tempest in the House to-day.

ST. IGNACE, Mich., April 12.--Merles Brothers, the Detour lumbermen who astonished the world a few days ago by stealthily removing a sawmill having a capacity for an annual cut of 6,000,000 feet, got safely into Canadian waters this morning.

The sale of the Sans Souci villa on Halidon Hill, with nine acres of ornamental grounds, was consummated Saturday, 6th inst., by the execution of the deed conveying the property from Mr. Clement Ferguson to Mr. Lorillard Spencer.

A squall, accompanied by heavy rain, struck this city at 7:12 o'clock last night. For 10 minutes the wind blew at the velocity of 25 miles an hour, and then apparently died out altogether, while the rain continued to fall for 10 minutes longer.
RONDOUT, N.Y., April 12.--About a week ago the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company began the work of dredging the edge of the flats on the south side of Rondout Creek, near the lighthouse.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 12.--Secretary John C. Sheehan of the New-York Aqueduct Commission has given birth to a scheme that he hopes will give Buffalo a new harbor and himself many shekels. A number of New-York capitalists stand godfathers to Mr. Sheehan's child, which is yet not very full of vigor.

NORWALK, Conn., April 12.--Early Wednesday evening the long, dry grass on Cockenoes Island, four miles east of this harbor, was set on fire by some unknown persons and when the flames had finally burned themselves out, the whole place was but a stretch of low, barren land with only a few smoldering trunks of trees and clumps of bushes remaining.
RED BANK, N.J., April 12.--By a recent act of the Legislature the town of Red Bank has been greatly enlarged, and therefore the present water supply is considered inadequate.

PITTSBURG, April 12.--A heavy thunder, wind, and hailstorm visited portions of Western Pennsylvania, Eastern Ohio, and Maryland to-day, doing considerable damage. At Elk Garden, Md., a flash of lightning instantly killed John Wetzell, a farmer, and two horses.

DETROIT, Mich., April 12.--An important decision was rendered in the United States District Court yesterday by Judge Brown.

NEWARK, N.J., April 12.--The congregation of the Eighth-Avenue Baptist Church held a meeting to-night to protest against the appointment of the Rev. Dr. Van Horne as their pastor, recently made by the Methodist Conference at Plainfield.
"Citizen" writes to THE TIMES suggesting that an arch should be built on Broadway at about Canal-street.

Tschigorin and Bird played one of the best games at the chess tournament yesterday. The Russian champion, who played black, adopted the two "knight's defense." After the game was well developed he managed to win a pawn from Bird, and immediately gained an advantage.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 12.--Dispatches from Findlay and Tiffin, in the natural gas belt of Ohio, report phenomenal strikes of gas at Findlay.

The meeting of the Manhattan Club Thursday night, so far as the forgeries of the ballots at the last election are concerned, amounted to little more than the organization of the Board of Managers, which will continue its investigations, and eventually try the accused person.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 12.--Serious charges were made in court this morning against Silas D. Grimstoad, a lawyer, and exJustice of the Peace H.D.B. Lefferts. The latter is now in jail for swindling.

As the Albany night boat Drew of the People's Line was coming down the Hudson about 2 o'clock yesterday morning she collided just below Kingston with the sloop Revenue, Capt. James M. Collyer, of Athens. The sloop filled and sank almost immediately, only the top of the mast remaining above water.

MOBILE, Ala., April 12.--Lumberton, Ala., 55 miles north of Mobile, on the Mobile and Ohio Road, was totally destroyed by fire yesterday afternoon. A strong wind prevailing communicated the fire from a slab pit to the lumber mill owned by Turner Oates of Mobile, from which it spread to the store owned by the same firm.

LONDON, April 13.--A dispatch from Sydney, N.S.W., says: "The Captain of the German man-of-war Adler, which was wrecked in the recent hurricane at Apia, states that Mataafa at first assisted only the Americans, but afterward repented and succored the Germans. The United States steamer Nipsic, although floated, is useless."

The painting of the steel cruiser Boston white is looked upon by some naval officers as aping the English custom; but aping or no aping, the new cruiser presents a very handsome appearance.

LONDON, April 12.--The Derby Spring meeting opened to-day. The race for the Sudbury Stakes of 750 sovereigns, for two-year-olds, about five furlongs, straight, was won by Mr. J. H. Houldsworth's b.c. Carrick, with Lord Calthorpe's b.f. Heresy second, and Lord Hastings's b. or br.f. Pink Pearl third.
NORWALK, Conn., April 12.--The oil well at Southbury has been closed for some time so that the company might be reorganized and the work pursued under more favorable conditions.

LUXEMBURG, April 12.--The ex-Duke of Nassau has received a number of telegrams congratulating him upon his assumption of the Regeney of Luxemburg.

MONTREAL, April 12.--The Crown, in the case "Jack" Kehoe, who was sentenced for life imprisonment for the murder of Thomas Donnelly, has liquidated Kehoe's estate, he being dead civilly, any has given the surplus of $800 to Donnelly's widow as a slight compensation for her loss.

PARIS, April 12.--When the Senate met to-day the President read the decree constituting that body a tribunal for the trial of Gen. Boulanger, Count Dillon, and M. Rochefort. The Procureur General, Quesnay de Beaurepaire, then read a statement setting forth the grounds upon which the prosecution of the accused is based.

Capt. Barber of the steamship Tropic had an interesting tale of the sea to relate yesterday on his arrival from Progreso. The Sheriff has taken possession of the printing establishment of Horatio J. Hewitt, at 27 Rosestreet, on executions in favor of his wife and daughter aggregating $5,564 for money leaned. Mr. Hewitt succeeded John Ross Co. in 1876, and had an extensive plant which he nominally valued at $60,000, against which there is a chattel mortgage for $10,000 in favor of W.P. Garrison.

Dr. von Bulow's series of piano recitals at the Broadway Theatre was closed yesterday, but an additional recital is now announced for Thursday afternoon, April 25, in the same theatre, as well as an orchestral concert at the Metropolitan Opera House May 2.

PHILADELPHLA, April 12.--Some startling changes are taking place in the navy yard at League Island. Democrats have been pretty effectually weeded out, and the process is still going on. Of a total of more than 200 employes the weeding-out process, which was started last month, has left about 30.

The body of Dr. Charles Wagner, whose sudden death in Hanover, Germany, on March 7 was announced in THE TIMES of March 9, arrived at Hoboken on board the North German Lloyd steamer Elbe Wednesday, and will be taken to Wilkesbarre, Penn., for interment. He wanted to be buried in the land of his adoption.

The Kings County Republican Campaign Committee gave a dinner at the Clarendon Hotel last night and presented Treasurer James W. Birkett with a handsome gold badge studded with diamonds. ALBANY, April 14.--The Mount McGregor Railroad Company has bean incorporated with $500,000 capital. W.J. Arkell is President and Frank Jones Secretary and Treasurer. The principal office will be at Ballston. Of the stock, $325,000 is preferred, and on this 6 per cent. must be paid from the net earnings first. This company purchased the Saratoga, Mount McGregor and Lake George Railroad property.
When Mr. Froude was writing his "English in Ireland in the Eighteenth Century" he staid in Ireland for a long while. To all appearance he has since returned to his old haunts.

There probably is no place on this continent where a menagerie exists that the sanitary rules are so rigidly enforced as in MadisonSquare Garden. The building is disinfected, cleaned, and dusted twice daily.
ELIZABETH, N.J., April 14.--John Quinn, a prisoner in the Union County Jail charged with assault, cut through the iron bars of the cook house to-night and escaped.
Amid the mass of details about the dreadful scene of death and wreck at Apia two dramatic incidents shine out like gems. One was the escape of the Calliope.

A correspondent of the Baltimore News, writing from Chattanooga, Tenn., describes a plan that is believed to be on foot and to have grown out of the recent visit of Mr. W.W. DUDLEY to that and other points in the South.

Miss Virginia Potter and her cousin, Miss Clara Potter, the latter a daughter of the Bishop of New-York, have been visiting Southold. The object of their visit was to secure suitable property for a retreat for young working girls of New-York during the Summer. They inspected several houses, but as yet have not rented one.

ALBANY, April 14.--Gov. Hill has already began to manoeuvre for the control of the State Convention next Fall, which will nominate the successors of the following State officers whose terms will expire on Dec. 31:
LONDON, April 15--Gen. Boulanger has taken a house in the Avenue Louise, Brussels. He has seven horses in the stables, and it is expected that his black charger will be taken thither from Paris.

ALBANY, April 14.--To aid friendless young girls to help themselves by providing for them a temporary home where they may be guided and trained to be self-supporting, the Brooklyn Training School and Home for Young Girls is incorporated. The trustees include P. Francena Maine, Helen J. Conrow. Jennie A. Jordan, Abbie T. Boody, Cora E. Woodruff, Henrietta Manney, and others.
ST. PAUL, April 14.--The Dressed-Meat bill only awaits the signature of Gov. Merriam to become a law. It passed the House Friday night with nearly a score of votes to spare.

Dr. George R. Gyles, for 40 years a physician in this city, died at his home, 417 West Twenty-third-street, yesterday from the effects of strychnine. Dr. Gyles had been very despondent for some time and his mind is believed to have been affected.

A syndicate of Northern and Southern capitalists has just purchased 63,000 acres of land adjoining the city of South Pittsburg, Tenn., for $540,000. The property, which consists of coal, iron, and timber land, is to be developed on a grand scale.
The duck shooting season on Long Island waters ends on May 1. From Oct. 1 until that date constitutes the open season.

At City Island yesterday, where some fifteen hundred New-Yorkers pursued the festive flounder with choice bait sand worm and clam, the general feeling was that Fish Commissioner Eugene G. Blackford has taken altogether too narrow a view of the work of pisciculture.
Last Winter Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE'S firm in Pennsylvania was constrained to surrender to the North Chicago Rolling Mill a contract for making 17,000 tons of steel rails for the Union Pacific Road.

In the light of the statutes conferring power upon him, the statement by StreetCleaning Commissioner Coleman of the reasons for the change from the contract system of cleaning the streets below Fourteenth-street to the old day's-work system, seems to be misleading.

PITTSBURG, April 14.--Twenty-five foreign glass blowers who sailed from Liverpool to Boston and departed thence on Friday for Jeannette, Penn., arrived in Pittsburg yesterday morning via the roundabout Pittsburg and Lake Erie route through Ohio.

WASHINGTON, April 14.--Mrs. Febiger, wife of Admiral Febiger of the navy, was thrown from her carriage this evening and badly, and perhaps fatally, injured. Mrs. Febiger and her son had been riding about the city, and the carriage ...
B. Johnson Sons' shoe factory, in Raynbam, Mass., was burned Saturday night together with 700 sides of leather and 75 cases of shoes ready for shipment. Total loss, $30,000; insurance, $17,000.

ELMIRA, N.Y., April 14.--Clarence Haley is a dashing, handsome young man of this city who several years ago changed his name to Parker. During the past year he has been employed as an agent on the road for Meagley Co., cracker manufacturers of Binghamton.
The Bar Association of this city, at its meeting to-morrow evening, will consider the form of an amendment to the State Constitution providing for a reorganization of the higher courts in this city.
The young Duke de Durcal has met with a very Bull's Run in his attempt to sell that portion of his father's great gallery of old masters which fell by lot to him in the partition of the estate.

Rehearsals of "Uncle Joe," the new play in which J.K. Emmet will be seen at the Fourteenth-Street Theatre next week, are well under way. The cast of the piece includes the names of Edmund Lyon, C. D. Burnett, Harold Hartsell, M.J. Cody, R.V. Hickman, Frank H. Dayton.

CHICAGO, April 14.--Two of the notable engagements of the Chicago theatrical season came to an end last night, one, the fortnight's engagement of the American Opera Company at the Columbia, and the other the Robson and Crane engagement at the Chicago Opera House.
Mr. Henry F. Spaulding writes with regard to the statement that there is a stone in Bellevue Hospital on which Gen. Washington stood when he delivered his inaugural address:
ST. PAUL, April 14.--General Passenger Agent Fee of the Northern Pacific was a little excited to-day over the action of the Union Pacific on Puget Sound passenger business.
The Hamburg steamship Suevia arrived at Quarantine last night at about 8 o'clock, and though she brought no news of the missing people from the Danmark she still was the bearer of sad tidings.

Gen. George A. Sheridan lectured last night at the Union-Square Theatre on "The Modern Pagan." The lecture was alleged to be an answer to the well-known arguments of Col. Robert G. Ingersoll, but savored strongly of a personal attack on that orator. An audience of fair size seemed to enjoy Gen. Sheridan's anecdotes.

It begins to look very much as though somebody was engaged in a big scheme of speculation with the tickets which are to admit spectators to the grand stands during the parade of the centennial processions.

The "Mets" played a strong game with the Cuban Giants yesterday afternoon at Weehawken. A new pitcher named Baker was put in for the Mets and he virtually won the game, as the colored athletes were unable to hit him. More than 3,000 people went out to see the game and they greatly enjoyed the unique contest.

It was made evident yesterday that in certain parts of this city a live appreciation of the sacredness of music is absolutely impossible unless there is more or less beer in the immediate neighborhood.
The Jersey City Board of Finance met Saturday morning and reorganized for the year by the election of Commissioner Emil E. Datz as President. They also adopted these warlike resolutions:

The receipt of the news giving in full the account of the loss of the American and German war ships in Samoa was the all-absorbing topic with naval officers in the city yesterday.
The Hon. SIMEON B. CHITTENDEN, who died in Brooklyn yesterday, was an excellent example of the best type of American citizen.

BOSTON, April 14.--The biggest meeting the followers of constitutional prohibition have held since the campaign on the pending, amendment began took place in Music Hall this afternoon. United States Senator George F. Hoar, who made the principal address, got a cordial welcome from the large audience.
NEWARK, N.J., April 14.--Bernard Schroe der, confidential clerk and bookkeeper for R.G. Salomon, leather manufacturer, is under arrest on a charge of grand larceny.

CHICAGO, April 15.--It is charged that the threatened strike against the insurance system of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company by its employes is being fomented by agents of life insurance companies.
A meeting of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association was held last night at St. Lake's Hospital, the President, George Macculloch Miller, in the chair and the following members present:

GREENFIELD, Mass., April 15.--The breaking of a drawbar on a freight car of a wild Easternbound freight train, occurring at the moment that another freight train was passing on the west track, made a wreck this morning which blocked all travel on the Fitchburg Railroad.

Albert G. Underhill, good-looking and about 35 years of age, took a "flier" in the stock market in a curious way a few months ago and it has landed him in the penitentiary. He says that he is a physician and that he lives at the Everett House.

Two of the early trains on the New-York and Harlem Railroad yesterday met with accidents at a point between Bronxville and Tuckahoe, in Westchester County. These stations are only about one mile apart.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 15.--In Committee of the Whole to-day the lower house of the State Legislature recommended that the C.R. Davis Civil Service Reform bill be indefinitely postponed. The debate was on party lines, the Democrats supporting the bill and the Republicans opposing it.

Princeton's baseball players fell easy victims to the New-Yorks yesterday. They couldn't gauge the curves of little George, and their field work was anything but good.

Brooklyn Republicans had another row last night over the vexed question of patronage. The fight this time occurred among the members of the Executive Committee of the General Committee, who met at the headquarters in Montague-street.

The statement that seats for the stands erected by the Army Committee for the convenience of the general public in witnessing the military and industrial parades connected with the centennial celebration have been allowed to be absorbed by speculators is vigorously denied by Col. Cruger and his associates.

MOBILE, April 15.--James Cunningham Co., wholesale hardware dealers, failed to-day, making an assignment for the benefit of all their creditors.

The Execute Committee of the Hotel Men's Association of the City of New-York met at the Continental Hotel yesterday noon to consider ways and means for the accommodation of the overflow from the hotels during the centennial week.

DANVILLE, Va., Apri1 15.--A dispatch to the Daily Register from Critz's station, on the Danville and New River Railroad, in Patrick County, gives a graphic account of a devastating forest fire, extending from Patrick Springs to Critz's, covering an area ten miles long and three to six wide.

Mrs. William Hanson on Sunday afternoon sat beside the body of her husband, who was killed on Saturday while attempting to stop a runaway team, which he feared would injure some children, and she wondered where money was to come from to bury him and provide for the four little children. The family were in destitute circumstances.
BELLEVILLE, Ill., April 15.--A remarkable freight wreck occurred on the Cairo Short Line, two miles from this place, yesterday morning. A freight train was running toward Belleville.

NEWBURG, N.Y., April 15.--High and dry in the shipyard of Marvel Co., at the south and of this city, stands the famous cutter yacht Bedouin, owned by ex-Commodore Archie Rogers of the New-York Yacht Club.

Commodore Elbridge T. Gerry, Chairman of the Executive Committee, made a call on Mayor Grant yesterday. What the object was was not made public by either gentleman. It probably had to do, however, with Mr. McAllister's reputed assertion that Mr. Gerry had said that Mayor Grant ought not to preside at the centennial banquet, "because he hadn't brains enough."

Rosenstiel Rosenfeld, wholesale dealers in white goods at 35 Walker-street, have failed, and the Sheriff has taken charge of their store. Judgments for about $4,828 were entered against them in favor of four creditors.

The Rapid-Transit bill comes up for final action in the Senate to-day and in the Assembly to-morrow.
PHILADELPHIA, April 15.--The Conshohocken Worsted Company made an assignment at Norristown for the benefit of its creditors today.

KINGSTON, N.Y , April 15.--Judge Mayham has just decided an interesting law point in Circuit Court here. DeWitt H. Newkirk, a former resident of Kingston, committed suicide in Rochester in July, 1887.
The stock market had to stand some hard pounding yesterday, but, all things considered, it stood the experience well. Quotations went off all along the list, put only fractionally.

WASHINGTON, April 15.--When the new Collector of the Port of New-York paid his last visit to Washington he was registered at Wilckers as "J.B. Erhtung of Cincinnati," and afterward explained that it was all a mistake.

The entries to the light-weight tug-of-war tournament of the Berkeley Athletic Club to be held Thursday evening in the clubhouse, 19 West Fortyfourth-street, closed last evening. Entries have been made by 12 teams, as follows: Acorn Athletic Club, B. Niblo, F. Olsen, T. Richard, and G.H. ...
An incident which may be deemed worthy of notice occurred in the East Fifty-firststreet police station a few nights ago.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, April 15.--The Hon. E. W. Everest and Count De Sainville, two adventurous noblemen who have resided here for some time, started to-day to make the trip which Earl Lonsdale attempted but failed to accomplish.

ST. PAUL, April 15.--The State Treasurer a few days ago served notice on the Manitoba corporation that taxes at the rate of 3 per cent. on its gross earnings were due the State. Judge Campbell for the road was surprised. He had never heard of such a thing.

PALESTINE, Texas, April 15.--In the injunction suit brought against the International and Great Northern Railway, receivers appointed by the District Court of Smith County, District Judge Williams to-day ruled that the appointment of the Smith County receivers was null and void, and that the District Court of Anderson County had rightful jurisdiction. Judge Williams appointed John R. Hearne receiver of the road, fixing his bond at $200,000.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 15.--A valuable horse belonging to Joseph Polaschek, a newsdealer of this city, broke loose to-day and tried to jump a high picket fence. The horse stumbled and was impaled on the the pickets, the points of which passed nearly through the animal's body.

On the second floor of R.J. Horner Co's West Twenty-third-street establishment there is probably the most magnificently-furnished suite of three rooms in New-York City, if not in the country. It consists of a hall, parlor, dining room, and bedroom.
Thomas Hope came over from Philadelphia yesterdey in obedience to a call from Judge Hilton's counsel in the Stewart will case, reinforced by an order from the Surrogate.
The Congregational Club of New-York and vicinity held its April meeting last evening at Clark's on West Twenty-third-street. The meeting was presided over by Roswell Smith, President of the club.

BOSTON, April 15.--The transfer of the Bay state Brewery in South Boston by Henry Souther to a syndicate composed of the Hon. Frank Jones of New-Hampshire, James P. Cook, and Charles A. Sinclair was effected today, ...
ST. PAUL, April 15.--The House fell in very gracefully to-day with Senator Sherffer's proposition to make drunkenness a crime.
The pressure upon the hotels for abiding places for the centennial guests of New-York during the approaching celebration is tremendous.
COLUMBIA, S.C., April 15.--Gov. Richardson today granted a full and free pardon to William C. Williams and Harrison Heyward, the two negroes who were convicted of murder in the Pickens ...

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 15.--There is a bill pending before the Legislature in this State which is frightening the ice companies, and there have already been one or two hearings before the Committee on Commerce and Navigation, a number of leading officers and agents ...
That unique educational charity, the Hampton Institute, is still expanding, and asks those who sympathize in good work cheaply done to help its growth.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 15.--About a week ago the Constitution, commenting on the paucity of replies to the appeals of Major Stewart in NewYork, called upon that gentleman to return home and not to be hawking the poverty of exConfederate veterans before the North.
PHILADELPHIA, April 15.--It seems to be quite doubtful whether or not the 8,000 militiamen of Pennsylvania will participate in the centennial parade in New-York.

Louis Michael tried to prove yesterday in the City Court, before Judge Nehrbas and a jury, that he was employed by Adolph Sonbein in his plate-glass store at 82 Centre-street to run a rickety elevator, which fell one day and resulted in the loss of the boy's legs.

Within the last few weeks the Sugar Trust has raised the price of the leading grades of refined sugar 1 cents a pound. This is an advance of about 18 per cent. in the case of granulated sugar.

The platform of Annex Hall was filled last evening with a number of earnest gentlemen who have spent much time and $325 in enabling a certain soap manufacturer to bestow $21,000 in charity. The cost of distribution of his charitable fund is borne by the beneficiaries of his businesslike benevolence.

One of the most curious episodes in recent politics is the very energetic, but somewhat limited, effort now being made to build up the fortunes of Mr. DAVID B. HILL, as a national leader for the Democratic Party.
So far only three of the owners of land taken by the city for the Pelham Bay Park insist that their water rights were not condemned and appraised.

TROY, April 15.--A mixed train was in collision this afternoon with a with a wild-cat freight train at Putnam, Lake Champlain, on the Delaware and Hudson Railroad. The engines were wrecked and one car was thrown into the lake. Sidney Sherman, an engineer, was killed. No passenger was injured.

The simple fact that a play written by a Western man was condemned by the newspaper critics of New-York is made the excuse for the revival of that tiresome, decrepit allegation that products of the Western mind are damned in the East because of their origin, without reference to their merits.

Abel de Graaf, with his wife and three children, who arrived Sunday on the Amsterdam from Holland, will have to go back again. It was discovered that he had some to this country under contract to work for the New-York Belting and Packing Company at Passaic, N.J., and consequently by law prohibited from landing.

The topic of interest to Colombia College students yesterday was the appearance of the Miner, the annual publication of the Junior Class in the School of Mines. Full of illustrations representative of the various societies, ...

PITTSBURG, April 15.--The largest natural gas well over struck was brought in today by the Philadelphia company near Belle Vernon, 26 miles from Pittsburg. It is running off 40,000,000 feet a day, the pressure being 800 pounds to the inch. It is one of the most significant wells ever struck, as it shows there are millions of new fields and that the supply is good for many years to come.

TRENTON, N.J., April 15.--Although this is expected to be the last week of the session, the Democrats to-night started three measures which they will have to pass by a party vote, although not caring to own them as party measures.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., April 15.--Surgeon General Brown of the United States Navy visited the navy yard during the past week and selected a site for a new naval hospital, which will be built this Summer on Leary's Island. The building will front the inner harbor. It will be a brick structure three stories high, with accommodations for twenty or twenty-five patients.

Since Nov. 11, 1888, the choir of St. James's Church, Seventy-first-street and Madison-avenue, under the direction of Mr. G. Edward Stubbs, the organist, has been using as anthems in the evening service parts of or the entire oratorios of the most celebrated writers.
The Driving Club will hold their Spring exhibition at the grounds on Satarday afternoon next, and will throw the gates open to all who care to see the two trotting races they have provided.

John H. Crook, one of the best-known restaurant proprietors in this country and member of the firm of Nash Crook, who for thirty years conducted their business in the old TIMES Building, died yesterday morning at his home, 86 West Sixty-eighth street.

RAHWAY, N.J., April 15.--A special meeting of the Common Council, acting as a board of on vassers, to-day officially announced the vote polled at last week's charter election, and passed a resolution fixing May 7 as the date for a special election for Mayor to end the existing tie.

Assistant Treasurer Ellis H. Roberts yesterday morning began to count the $178,000,000 in the New-York Sub-Treasury. He was assisted in his work by Major J.F. Meline, Assistant Cashier of the United States Treasury;

A stroll along upper Broadway nowadays will convince one of the great amount of moving to be done May 1. Numbers of stores which have been occupied by the same tenants for years, have notices posted in the windows that the occupants intend to remove a block or so above or below "the first of May."

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 15.--The Sons of Temperance of New-Jersey began their State Division meeting in this city to-night with a reception and dinner to the grand officers and some of the national officers of the order. The business session will be held to-morrow, 200 delegates attending.

BALTIMORE, April 15.--The steam trial trip of the new gunboat Petrel, which was recently announced to take place to-day, has again been postponed. At the Columbian Iron Works, where the vessel is being built, it was stated that necessary work on the gunboat had not yet been completed, making it impossible for a trail to take place.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 15.--Marshal H.B. Clare and two Deputies went on board the shanty boat of D.W. Jones at Warsaw, Ky., yesterday, and attempted to search it for stolen goods.
An ingenious gentleman named Charles P. Hyman has adopted a scheme to make money out of the centennial, which seems likely to succeed if he doesn't grasp for too much.

Little Elsie Leslie, in Lord Fauntleroy regalia, stood behind the candy booth at the Hahnemann Hospital fair last evening and dispensed choice sweetmeats. Her price list wan extremely radical, but in no case was it disputed. If she said $1, then $1 it was. If $5, the five were given her and she thanked each purchaser so prettily that the reward was ample.
How well New-York theatregoers remember old favorites was demonstrated last night by the number and character of the people who attended the performance of "The Henrietta" at the Star Theatre.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 15.--The pigeon-shooting match to-day, for $50 a side, between Frank Lamotte and William Duckerman was won by the former by four birds. The conditions were 15 birds each, 21 yards rise, 80 yards boundary, one barrel only to be used. The birds proved a difficult lot to kill. Lamotte killed 12 to Dusckerman's 8.

The funeral of ex-Congressman S.B. Chittenden will take place at 3 o'clock to-morrow afternoon from the Church of the Pilgrims, at Henry and Remsen streets, Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. Rachard S. Storrs will officiate.
Steamship Santiago, (Br.,) Potter, Hull, 14 ds., with mdse. and passengers to Sanderson Son. Arrived at the Bar at 9:30 P.M.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 15.--A cyclone swept over the eastern portion of Montgomery County, Ala., yesterday evening, accompanied by a heavy rain and thunder storm. Two negroes were instantly killed by lightning in a eabin, and several others were shocked and seriously injured. Several houses were blown down, and some damage was done to young corn and cotton crops.
The New-York Indian Association met yesterday afternoon at 21 West Thirty-secondstreet, the residence of the President of the association, Mrs. I. Irving.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 15.--The State Board of Health to-day published rules and regulations adopted for the guidance of county, town, and other officers, as well as for the instruction of individuals.

Lieut. James B. Manahan of Company E, Sixty-ninth Regiment, died suddenly Friday at his home, 309 East Twenty-ninth-street. Lieut. Manahan has recently suffered several bereavements, which have had a serious effect on his general health.

WESTON, West Va., April 15.--Richard Dowell, the supposed murderer who was arrested about two weeks ago in Grand Forks, Dakota, for a crime committed 13 years ago, arived here this evening in the custody of T.G. Dawson and W.T. Casey, the special officers sent for him. He is not the man wanted, and his arrest is a blunder. He was taken to jail, but will likely be released to-morrow.

PESTH, April 15.--Emperor Francis Joseph and Empress Elizabeth, accompanied by Archduehess Valerie, started for Ischl at 9 o'clock last night. It is semi-officially denied that the condition of the Empress is as bad as is reported.

ALBANY, April 15.--Gov. Hill distinguished himself to-night by sending nine vetoes to the Legislature. The most prominent were of Mr. Deane's bill allowing Vassar College to hold additional property and Mr. Pierce's Flatbush Fire Company bill.

Fire was discovered shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday morning in the basement of the bachelor apartment house 28 West Twentyfirst-street, which is occupied by Hermann Oelrichs, Travis Van Buren, and other wellknown club men. The fire originated in the janitor's apartments, and the house was filled with smoke when a policeman made the discovery.

Chairman Walker of the Inter-State Railway Association has called a special meeting of the Board of Managers in Chicago for April 23. The subject to be considered is the request of the Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis and Omaha Road for the authorization of rates to Duluth on the same basis as those to Chicago from Northern Nebraska points.

ST. PAUL, April 15.--The suicide of Charles F. Hatch in Minneapolis to-day was a great surprise to his many friends in this city. Mr. Hatch was quite well known to a large majority of the old railroad men in the Northwest.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 15.--The first round in the chess tourney between the bachelors and benedicts of the Elizabeth Chess Club has resulted in a tie. Each side won four games. The next round will be played next Saturday evening.

CHICAGO, April 15.--According to the stories of the big Chicago wheat manipulators the causes which led to the suicide of President John Jackson of the St. Louis Elevator Company on Saturday are not attributable wholly to that gentleman's dealings in May wheat, but rather to the losses of the Elevator Company. John. B. Lyon, who is accredited with representing the Chicago syndicate interested in the deal, says:

People in search of interesting sights may find them to-day when the Commissioner of Public Works, under the guidance of the Commissioners of the Board of Electrical Control, begins to cut down telegraph poles and reel up wires which Mayor Grant has declared must go under ground.
SCRANTON, Penn., April 15.--Bishop O'Hara of this city has issued a circular to the Catholic clergy of the diocese directing them to hold special services in their respective churches ...

Lawyer John Jerolomon appeared before Judge Beach, in Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday, to ask that the complaint of William Best against his client, ex-Supervisor of the City Record Thomas Costigan, for $25,000 damages for slander be made more specific.
LOS ANGELES, April 15.--There is an authenticated report of a scheme to capture Lower California. A reporter yesterday found two gentlemen who had been asked to join in the undertaking.
Ignatz Reinitz wound up the European trip he began in January in Judge Martine's court yesterday. He arrived home on the Servia in the morning.

TROY, N.Y., April 15.--The Troy Steel and Iron Company has completed an experiment in making soft steel under a procees invented by C.W. Bildt, chief chemist for Washburn Moen of Worcester, Mass.

NEWBURG, N.Y., April 15.--Lieut. Towne of Lowell, Mass., in charge of the Salvation Army in this city, while selling the War Cry to-day entered the grocery store of M. McCormick on Broadway. A trap door leading to the cellar was open and Miss Towne stepped into it, falling to the floor below. She was picked up unconscious and but little hope is felt of her recovery.
ELIZABETH, N.J., April 15.--The annual firemen's election for Chief Engineer and Assistant Chiefs of the Elizabeth Department was held tonight and was hotly contested.

DETROIT, April 15.--Gen. Drum, Adjutant General of the United States Army, will retire May 28 and a series of promotions will be made, leaving a vacancy in the office of Assistant Adjutant General, which will be filled from among the Captains of the line. There are, of course, a host of candidates and some active hustling is going on.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 15.--In the House of Commons today the Hon. Mr. Tupper's bill respecting the safety of ships was read the third time and passed.
PHILADELPHIA, April 15.--Mrs. Hannah Battersby, said to be the largest woman, in the world, died to-night at her home in Frankford, a suburb of this city.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 15.--Edwin Booth arrived here Sunday, the picture of health, and opened to-night as Iago to Barrett's Othello before the largest and most enthusiastic audience ever assembled in the Opera House, his reception on his appearance amounting to a perfect ovation. The entire house for the balance of the Booth-Barrett engagement is sold. Mr. Booth says he will fill all his engagements this season.

A dispatch was recived by the Coney Island Jockey Club yesterday declaring Egmont out of the Suburban. The horse has a bad leg, and has shown a lameness in his work at Nashville, where the Chicago Stable's horses are being trained. The probabilities are that the horse has broken down, and so Mr. Hankins scratched him rather than permit people to bank him when there was no chance of his starting.
PATERSON, N.J., April 15.--The Paterson Board of Aldermen organized this afternoon, electing Alderman John Curtis, a Republican, President.

CHICAGO, April 15.--Henry E. Abbey and Marcus R. Mayer are in the city completing arrangements for the appearance of Patti at the Auditorium next December. "My understanding with the managers of the Auditorium," said Mr. Abbey, "is that our season of Italian opera will begin Dec. 9, but I believe we will be ready by the 5th. We will remain in Chicago a month."

The New-Rochelle Yacht Club held a meeting last evening in the Grand Union Hotel. Several amendments were made to the club's constitution and racing rules.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 15.--The coal handlers on the docks fronting the river are on the warpath to-day. Last season they were paid 14 cents for loading coal into vessels. Early this season they came to the conclusion that they should have 16 cents. At the same time their employers decided to reduce the price to 12 cents. The old men laid down their shovels and new men were put to work.

PARIS, April 15.--The liquidators of the Panama Canal Company have informed the shareholders of that concern that they believe that a reissue of the unsold lottery bonds of the company under par would realize 12,500,000f, and save the canal, but that the Government as reluctant to propose such a measure, fearing that Parliament would not consent to its adoption.

A shrewd Chinaman, calling himself Nan Po Ki, has been swindling his countrymen in New-Haven by selling them for $1 apiece a card which he claimed was a passport which could be sent to China, and would entitle any Chinamen to enter this country at San Francisco. The card was an advertisement for a Chinese Directory, and he disposed of about 700 of them before leaving the city.

The committee appointed to examine the books of ex-Assistant City Clerk Manseli of Hoboken, who is under indictment for forging improvement bonds, have discovered that the tax-sale books have been "doctored." NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 17.--A man claiming to be Detective O'Harra of Cincinnati arrested John Fielder at the Cartaret Works, near Woodbridge, last night, accusing him of having committed a murder in Suwanee County, Fla., several years Ago. Fielder claimed that he was in jail at Bangor, Me., at the time, and as the detective had no corroboration of his story the prisoner will probably be released to-morrow.

Yesterday's stock market was enlivened somewhat by the activity of one or two bear pools, whose brokers made brave onslaughts on every point that seemed unprotected. The fact that they accomplished little was no reflection upon the energy of them; they tried hard enough.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 17.--Mrs. Jane A. Ten, Eyck, for half a century the trusted housekeeper for Col. Kean, father of Congressman John Kean, Jr., died suddenly last night on the steamer Pilgrim of the Fall River Line while on her way to Boston to visit a relative. She left Elizabeth Monday accompanied by her daughter. The body will be brought here for interment.

Freese Son, dealers in musical merchandise, at Dallas, Texas, have failed. Their liabilities are nearly $500,000. The cause of the failure is said to have been the recent failure of Thomas B. Scanlan, the music dealer of Boston and New-York, to whom Freese was largely indebted. An attachment against the firm for $20,000 in favor of the First National Bank of Galveston has been issued.

Gen. Franz Sigel, United States Pension Agent in this city, said yesterday that the Washington report that he had resigned his office was true. He had not been asked to resign, but he did not wish to embarrass the Administration or stand in the way of the appointment of an agent of like political faith with the powers that be.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 17.--President Adams of Cornell received to-day a letter from Mrs. A.S. Barnes announcing the gift of a fine portrait of the late A.S. Barnes of New-York for Barnes Hall, the house he built for the Cornell Christian Association at a cost or $60,000. The portrait was done by a German artist in Berlin four years ago.

LIMA, Ohio, April 17.--The Standard Oil Company to-day closed the deal whereby they become the possessors of a majority of the stock of the Ohio Oil Company. This gives them control of the Lima field.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 18.--The Spanish steamer Navarro, Capt. Aldecocea, from Cuban ports with a carge of sugar, now at Quarantine, came in through the jetties Tuesday morning without detention, drawing 24 feet 5 inches forward and 28 feet 6 inches aft, Which is the greatest draught of any vessel that has ever passed through the jetties. The next largest draught was that of the British steamship Rochester, which went to sea in 1883 drawing 26 feet.

WASHINGTON, April 18.--At the business session of the National Academy of Sciences this morning several reports of committees were read. A Home Secretary and Council, consisting of six members, were elected.

Watson, M.D., shows that during that period there were 6,910 births, 3,490 marriages, and 6,479 deaths. The record of marriages was the largest made.

PURCELL Indian Territory, April 22.--A great change has come over this town. Yesterday it was a metropolis, to-night it is a hamlet in point of population. The metamorphosis was effected at 12 o'clock to-day, when several thousand men, women, and children crossed the Canadian River and entered upon a wild struggle for homes in the promised land.

The east-bound shipments of flour, grain, and provisions from Chicago by the lines in the Central Traffic Association last week aggregated 18,573 tons, against 19,738 tons the preceding week, a decrease of 1,165 tons, and against 32,568 tons for the corresponding week last year, a decrease of 13,995 tons. The Vanderbilt lines carried 52.2 per cent. of the business, the Pennsylvania 23.8, the Chicago and Grand Trunk 17.1, and the Baltimore and Ohio 7.4.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 22.--The attaches of the Elizabeth Post Office to-night presented a handsome silver ice pitcher to James T. Wiley, the retiring Postmaster, who has been given the Lay Judgeship of Union County.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 22.--Lewis R. Williams, the newly-appointed Postmaster at this place, entered upon his new charge for the first time this morning. Mr. Williams has appointed George B. Van Brunt Assistant Postmaster. The appointment caused a ripple of excitement when the announcement was made. Van Brunt is a stanch Democrat and was Assistant Postmaster under the administrations of ex-Postmasters Bennett and Newing.

It would be simply enormous were all who have asked to be given a place in line allotted the space they ask for.

Don Stolling, a Norwegian artist, long a resident of Mexico, came to New-York a few days ago to see all that there was to be seen at the centenary before taking passage for Europe. Henry Corneith of 62 Bleecker-street, this city, began suit in Justice Engle's court, in Brooklyn, yesterday to recover $250 from his father-in-law, Henry Zeh, a farmer on the outskirts of Brooklyn, for a year's board of Mr. Zeh's wife, Anna.

LONDON, April 23.--This was the first day of the Epsom Spring meeting. The race for the great Metropolitan Stakes (handicap) of 20 sovereigns each, with 500 added, for three-yearolds and upward, about two miles and a quarter, was won by a length by Tissaphernes, Cotillon second, and Fallow Chat a bad third.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 23.--A decision or extraordinary interest and importance has just been handed down by the Second Division of the Court of Appeals. WASHINGTON, April 23.--The President and his family and the other guests from Washington of the New-York Centennial Committee are to be taken from this city to Elizabethport in the most comfortable style of which the Pennsylvania Railroad Company is capable.

The American, Midland Railroad, of which William Thorpe of New-York is President and Theodore Frothingham of New-York Secretary, with principal offices in Findlay, Ohio yesterday issued a notice for a meeting of the stockholders at the Joy House, in Findlay, on May 15, for the purpose of authorizing an issue of first mortgage bonds of the company in amount not to exceed $50,000 per mile of road built.

The Eastern Association of Wells College students held its annual luncheon at Delmonico's yesterday. It was decided to raise $5,000 to assist in erecting a new college building. Miss H.C. Porter of Philadelphia responded to the toast "The College" and Miss Swinton to "Our Fund."

NEW-HAVEN, April 23.--Dr. Thomas G. Lee lecturer on histology and bacteriology in Yale University, recently read an important paper on the etiology and treatment of typhoid fever before the annual New-Haven County meeting of the Connecticut Medical Society.

BINGHAMTON, April 23.--The grumblers early besieged the new Administration and pressed it to undo the work of its predecessor upon the new Post Office. Hitherto they have been beaten at every point and their charge of fraud has been answered and its ridiculous nature fully exposed. Nearly $100,000 has been expended upon the new Post Office.
The tenth annual special combination sale of Jersey cattle began at American Institute Hall, Third-avenue and Sixty-third-street, yesterday morning at 10 o'clock.

Reports were current at Columbia College yesterday that President F.A.P. Bernard was critically Ill. In the rumors, however, his danger was greatly exaggerated. The President has a relapse about a week ago, but his condition at present, according to his family physician, is greatly improved.

At 8:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon a special train of 10 cars filled with employes of the New-York City Post Office pulled out of the station of the Erie Railroad, on route to Englewood, N.J., to attend the funeral of Henry G. Pearson.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 23.--Checks drawn on the Grand Rapids National Bank are coming in, bearing the signature of James R. Lynn, Jr., Robert Lynn, and others, and they show that it is an easy matter for some swindlers to find victims. One check for $500 was received this morning from Savannah, Ga., and last week one for $253 turned up.
BERLIN, April 23.--The Emperor and Empress have gone to Dresden to visit the King of Saxony.

PITTSBURG, April 23.--The national conference on the Christian principles of civil government met in Old City Hall this afternoon. The meeting was largely attended by delegates from various parts of the country. The opening session was occupied in organizing.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 23.--A report was current here to-night that Sanford, 150 miles south of here, had a sudden death this morning, supposed to be from yellow fever.

Justice Michael Norton of the First District Civil Court died a few minutes before 12 o'clock last night. His death has been expected since Monday afternoon, although it was believed he had a slight chance of recovery. He had only been sick a week.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 23.--Annapolis to-day calebrated its two hundred and fortieth anniversary by giving an exhibition of its trades and industries. About forty houses were represented in a most creditable display. The Easton Guards, the Frederick Rifles, the United States marines, the Governor's Guards of Annapolis, and a detachment of United States sailors with cannon took part. In the afternoon a successful carnival took place, followed at night by a display of fireworks.

Miss Isabel Marian Ashmore, daughter of Sidney Ashmore, was wedded to her cousin, Charles Beckwith Ashmore of London, England, in Old Trinity at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon by the Rev. NEWARK, N.J., April 23.--George Hengil proves to be the name of the seventeen-yearold boy who sprang from Sayres's dock into the Passaic River last night and was drowned.

CINCINNATI, April 23.--Murat Halstead is reported considerably improved by his physicians this evening. There has been some slight irregularity of the heart during the last twentyfour hours, but if he has no bad turn, there is thought to be little danger new that the action of the heart will become seriously affected.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 23.--Four years ago Wilkinson Brothers, bankers, of this city failed for $700,000. To-day the Sheriff sold at public auction, at the Court House, the real estate belonging to the bankrupt firm.

The cornerstone of the new St. Peter's Church at Port Chester was laid yesterday. The Society of St. Paul's Parish was organized in 1824. In 1843 a regular church building, costing $8,000, was erected on Main-street. Previous to that time worship had been in halls and churches of other denominations.

Miller, wife of the hotel proprietor, who says that Mary stole a large quantity of valuable clothing.
