NEWARK, N.J., April 23.--Christ Church, East Orange, was the scene last night of an interesting church election. It grew out of the trouble which resulted in the resignation of the Rev. Walter Hughson, the assistant minister of the parish.

VIENNA, April 23.--The strike of the car men is nearly at an end. The rioting, however, continues in the Favoriten and Hernals quarters. The mob to-day stoned the cavalry, and reinforcements of infantry were required. Many rioters were wounded and a large number were arrested. The military charged the mob with sword and bayonet and cleared the streets. The rioters to-day were merely anti-Semitic enthusiasts, actual workmen generally not participating in the tumults.

A general conference of Lutherans irrespective of nationality was held last night in the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, at 45 and 47 West Twenty-first-street, the Rev. G.F. Krotel presiding.

The Fordham College Athletic Association blossomed out in the athletic world yesterday afternoon with Spring games held on the college grounds at Fordham. There is an exceedingly strong probability that the truckmen of this city who expect to reap a plentiful harvest May 1 by "moving" persons despite of the parade and the attendant difficulties of the holiday, will be somewhat disappointed. The great law of supply and demand has come to the rescue of the intended victims and unless the city ordinances interfere, out-oftown truckmen will cut down prices.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., April 23.--Desertions continue at Fort Niagara, despite the regulations. Private Howard, who was arrested as a deserter from the Eighth Infantry about a month ago and who had been tried and found guilty and was awaiting sentence, deserted yesterday.

The denefit given to Signor Italo Campanini, the noted tenor, at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening was attended by a large and enthusiastic audience. The familiar opera "Lucia" was performed, and certain features of the presentation were of more than average merit.

OVER CLAIMS--MANY GOING AWAY. GUTHRIE, Indian Territory, April 23.--Suffer ing began here in dead earnest to-day. Fifteen thousand people asked for the commonest nesessaries of life and were unable to obtain them even by offering fabulous prices for them.

WASHINGTON, April 23.--Mrs. Harrison and Mrs. McKee attended the concert given last evening by the Yale Glee and Banjo Clubs, and at the close of the concert the performers were invited to the White House, where, after a collation, the President and Mrs. Harrison were entertained with several numbers of vocal and instrumental music.

Miss Kate Maher, the ticket agent of the Long Island Railroad at Newton, L.I., is missing. A number of residents of the town have contribution money to employ a detective to try to find her.
Ex-Sergt. Thomas J. Thorpe of the Third United States Artillery has been missing since the 31st ult., and his wife is anxiously waiting in this city for his reappearance.

W.S. Baker of Philadelphia, one of the best authorities in the country on portraits of Washington, visited the Centennial Loan Exhibition, at the Assembly Rooms of the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday, and discovered among the engraved portraits of Washington two portraits which he had never seen or heard of before, though intimately acquainted with this branch of Americana.

Many of the older men of Wall-street yesterday attended the funeral of Alexander Henriques, so many years the Stock Exchange's Vice Chairman. Venerable D.C. Hays was there, and so were Joseph Marie, George Brodhead, D.O. White, President Bull of the Stock Exchange, Jacob Rubeina, C.F. Frothingham, George Cummings, Controller Myers, and L. De Bebian. The Stock Exchange, the Masonic order and the Old Guard were represented.

BALTIMORE, April 23.--A special to the American from Louisville, Ky., tells of the quiet wedding there to-day of Congressman Gibson of Maryland and Mrs. Marrietta Powell Hallyday. Bishop Dudley of Kentucky performed the ceremony.

The Empire Condensed Milk Company, at 34 Hudson-street and at St. Johnsville, N.Y., has failed. President Edward R. Coker as trustee for Effie R. Coker has entered judgment against the company for $20,747. The Sheriff made a levy at the office in Hudson-street, but found scarcely anything of value, most of the property being at St. Johnsville where the factory is situated.

ST. PAUL, April 23.--As stated last week, a meeting was called by Secretary Abbott to endeavor to adjust the difficulties between the Northern and Union Pacific Railways. This meeting was postponed to May 7.

The present attitude of the Prohibitionists recalls the attitude of the Abolitionists for thirty years before the war. "Rum" is talked about by them in very much the same terms in which slavery used to be discussed by PHILLIPS and GARRISON.

The four-year-old colt Tennyson, by Longfellow-Lucy Jackson, one of the cast-offs of J.B. Haggin's stable, has been declared out of the Suburban. This makes four declarations since the original date for declarations, Feb. 20. The horses declared are Egmont, Galore, Darlington, and Tennyson.

The fine private collection of paintings owned by Mr. Aaron Healy of 198 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, will be on exhibition at his residence to-morrow and Thursday from 9 to 12 A.M., and from 8 to 11 P.M.
NEW-BRUNSWICK N.J., April 23.--Mrs. Elizabeth Latham was taken to the State insane asylum to-day. She is a young married woman and was made insane by the disappearance of her husband.

Judge Ingraham, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, reserved decision on a motion to sent the suit of Dr. Charles E. Simmons against the executors of Samuel J. Tilden to a referee. Joseph H. Choate argued in favor of the motion, and James C. Carter against it.

The work of cutting down the number of would-be participants in the civic parade was begun yesterday by Gen. Butterfield, the Chief Marshal, and his assistants, and his orders will naturally cause much dissatisfaction from parties who have been arranging to parade for some weeks past.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 23.--Inquiry at the Union Iron Works to-day revealed the fact that no time has yet been set for the trial trip of the Charleston and no cause is ascribed for the delay.

William Kearne, a brakeman on the Danbury and Norwalk branch of the Housatonic Railroad, fell from the top of a moving train near Hawleyville and was run over and instantly killed. Charles W. Lockwood, a switchman on the same road, was crushed between two cars, at Branchville, and was removed to the Danbury Hospital in a dying condition.

The Academy of Anthropology was entertained yesterday afternoon at Cooper Union by a paper on "The Baby's Mind; Studies in Infant Psychology," prepared and read by Dr. Elizabeth Stow Brown of New-York. Dr. Brown declared that the most poetic beauty of human life is to be found in infancy, and referred to painting, soulpture, music, and religion for evidence of the claim.

The second annual ball of the Clifton Boat Club was held at St. Mary's Hall, Rosebank, S.I., last night. The hall was decorated with pennants and sporting paraphernalia, while the stage was banked with tropical plants.

BALTIMORE, April 23.--A special from Richmond, Va., says: "Mrs. Sidney Lee, mother of Gov. Lee, who had an operation performed on one of her eyes recently, is doing as well as could be expected under the circumstances.

The work of wire and pole cutting went merrily on yesterday, and last night only four poles were standing in Broadway from Twentythird to Forty-second-street. The men, under charge of Contractors Hess and Busbey, went to work early yesterday morning.

The sale of the collection of books composed principally of the library and prints of Robert Lenox Kennedy, together with a collection of miniatures, paintings, and Oriental porcelains, was begun yesterday afternoon at the art rooms of Ortgies Co., 366 Fifthavenue, Robert Somerville being the auctioneer.

Mail brought by the steamer Careline Miller from Cape Haytien yesterday confirms the report which was published on Sunday in ragard to a victory obtained over Legitime's forces at Trou, April 9. On April 7 Legitime's army, in command of Gen. Prophete, captured and entirely destroyed the town of Petite Riviere.

Sadness straggled into the New-York Stock Exchange yesterday afternoon. Five hundred brokers went home last night grieved and disappointed. They had hoped much; they had hoped in vain; happiness was afar off; life was a great big green goeseberry. The war ships now in port which will participate in the coming centennial celebration are all ready to move to their respective positions. The little Yantic lies off Twenty-sixthstreet in North River, and can drop down into the lower harbor at a moment's notice.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 23.--The Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees of Cornell University held an important meeting last night. Instructor E.E. Hale, Jr., and Mr. Edwin M. Brown, who is now studying in Germany, were appointed assistant acting professors for one year.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 23.--All the flags on public buildings in this city, on newspaper offices, and on many private buildings were hoisted to-day in honor of Washington's passage through the city 100 years ago. The church bells were tolled at 12:30 o'clock, the hour at which he arrived in the city.

Philetus F. Dorlon died at his home on Dorlon's Point, near South Norwalk, Conn., yesterday. He was the originator of the oyster business still carried on by members of the family in Fulton Market and at other places in the city. His wife and one son survive him.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 25.--Howard Bird, the young broker who was arrested by Mayor Handren at Dunellen on Tuesday night, will sue the Mayor for damages. The difficulty which led to Bird's arrest by the Mayor, who was one of his intimate friends, arose out of a political discussion.

PORTLAND, Oregon, April 26.--A collision occurred last night in the Willamette River, a few miles below Portland, between the British steamship Danube and the American steamship Alliance. The Danube was bound for this city from Victoria, and the Alliance was bound down the river.

LONDON, April 26.--In an Interview to-day Gen. Boulanger reiterated his disavowal of any intention to precipitate a war between France and Germany. Nevertheless, he did not consider that the future of France had been settled forever by the war of 1870. He declared he would never consent that France should be insuited. He was anxious, he said, to cement France's friendship with Russia and England.

The big red storm signal with the blue square in its centre reclined in an utterly faggedout, wet, and frayed condition at the door of the Signal Service Bureau in the Equitable Building last night. All day long it had been thrashed and blown about by the howling northerly wind that, accompanied by heavy squalls of rain, had beaten upon the city.

KINGSTON, N.Y., April 26.--The June graduating class of the State Normal School at NewPaltz, Ulster County, for 1889, consists of forty-four members, the largest, since the organization of the school, and being more than all the previous graduating classes combined.

ALBANY, April 26.--New-York County paid $900,000 into the State Treasury yesterday on account of its school tax. The balance is $660,000. The total the county will receive back as its quota under the apportionment is $684,094.
NEWARK, N.J., April 26.--A man was arrested in a street car at midnight to-night by Policemen Wackerman and Schmidt on suspision of his being Salzman, the assailant of Mrs. Mutter of Irvington.
The organization which flourished many years under the name of the Gotham Art Students, formerly in Bond-street and later at 697 Broadway, has fallen on evil times.
LONDON, April 27.--A dispatch from Auckland says that the United States steamer Nipsic was again disabled while being towed in Apia Harbor. Mataafa has returned to Apia.

Mrs. Flossie di Marco, wife of Celestino di Marco, a well-to-do contractor of Italian labor, at present supplying the United States Government with workmen at the Harlem Ship Canal, committed suicide by shooting herself in the right breast about 6 o'clock last evening at their home on the second floor of 2,206 Firstavenue.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 26.--Entries for the Orange County Colt Stakes closed on Saturday. The stakes are offered by Mr. J.S. Coates for two, three, and four year old trotters, bred in Orange County, contests to take place on the Goshen Driving Park on some date in October to be hereafter fixed.

For the first time since the chess tournament began Weiss, the Vienna champion, was defeated yesterday. The whipping he got was at the hands of Blackburne. Weiss had the first move and started with a vigorous attack, but Blackburne returned blow for blow.

Alfred Fallek and L.M. Barnett opened a jewelry store at 772 Fulton-street, Brooklyn, about two months ago. Yesterday Mr. Fallek reported to the Brooklyn police that his partner Barnett, had disappeared on Wednesday, taking jewelry valued at $750 with him. Late yesterday Barnett was arrested in this city by one of Detective Byrnes's men.

John H. Baker, the new Cherokee Commissioner, is a prominent lawyer of Indiana, and represented the Thirteenth District of that State in the Forty-fourth, Forty-fifth, and Fortysixth Congresses. He was a delegate at large from Indiana to the Republican National Convention ...

The Aschenbroedel Verein, composed entirely of German musicians, held their annual election for officers at their clubhouse, 74 East Fourth-street, last night.

MONTREAL, April 26.--At a meeting of gray cotton manufacturers last night it was decided in view of the great advance in the price of raw cotton to advance the price of cotton cloth from 1 to 2 cents per pound. The shipments to China are still going on. Nearly $500,000 worth was shipped thither during the past twelve months.

A dinner in honor of Grover Cleveland was given by Joseph H. Choate in the Union League Club last night. Around a circular table in the alcove room was gathered a very distinguished company of New-York lawyers.

DETROIT, Mich., April 26.--President Ashley's annual report of the Toledo, Ann Arbor and North Michigan Railway shows the gross earnings for the year to have been $687,579 01, operating expenses $433,392 11 net earnings $254,186 90.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 26.--Information from Gladstone just received states that the large force of longshoremen employed by the Soo Road to handle flour and other freight at that point went out on a strike last Monday, demanding 30 cents per hour, when the company would pay only 20 cents.

Before long will be tried in the Supreme Court the case of Mrs. Gertrude Rhinelander Waldo against Charles H. Schieffelin, both of this city, in which the plaintiff charges that the defendant defrauded her at $12,294 22. She alleges that he obtained this money from her ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 26.--Seventy-five kegs of powder exploded at Beattie's quarry, on Leete's Island, to-day. Nearly every window in the village was wrecked, and people who lived thirty miles away heard the noise. Nobody was injured.

ASHLAND, Wis., April 26.--During a terrific gale which raged on Lake Superior Wednesday the steamer Australasia and her consort, the George, which were making for this port for ore, were driven on the beach of Michigan Island, near Bayfield, one of the Apostle group.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26.--Henry A. Cramp of the William Cramp Sons Company to-day denied the report that the tests so far made with the pneumatic guns on board the dynamite cruiser Vesuvius had been other than satisfactory.

OTTAWA, April 26.--Canada will not back down in pressing the claims for compensation from the United States for the alleged unjust seizure of British vessels in Behring Sea. This was in effect the declaration of Sir John Macdonald in the House of Commons to-day. The matter was brought up by Mr. Prior, member ...
Ella Hammond and Addis Stanton, who were arrested with Edward Meredith and Henry Hermann for an assault on Phil Daly at their Fourth-avenue plane last Fall, were released yesterday.

The approach of tha centennial holiday recess has damped speculation on the Stock Exchange, and there were few transactions of any consequence yesterday. Quotations, neglected, ran off fractionally, few stocks closing as high as they opened. But the day's changes were neither important nor significant of anything consequential.
The act for the better management of the sinking funds, to the end that they shall not swell unnecessarily at the expense of the taxpayers, was put into operation yesterday.
The gay centennial decorations that delighted the eyes of New-Yorkers on Thursday presented a most and and woebegone appearance at dusk yesterday.

Henry Lembeck, one of the best-known Germans in Jersey City, have the new charter adherents a blow from the shoulder yesterday. David Kennedy, alias "Brocky Dave," who was released from Sing Sing on the 15th inst., after having served three years for stealing a diamond pin from a gentleman riding on a surface car, was brought before Justice O'Reilly at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday.

PARIS, April 26.--The Provisional Directors of the Comptori d'Escompte have signed a deed constituting a new company. The deed gives the present holders of shares 40,000 founders' shares, besides a right to 20 per cent. of the profits. A syndicate of bankers guarantees the entire amount of the capital in the event of the shares not being taken.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 26.--Fred A. Bill of Dubuque, General Passenger and Freight Agent of the Diamond Jo Line of steamers, presented to the lowa Railroad Commissioners this morning a very interesting question concerning discriminations against his company.

LONDON, April 26.--This was the second day of the Sandown Park second Spring meeting. The Walten two-year-old race of 1,000 sovereigns, selling allowances, five furlongs, straight, was won by Charlottesville, by Fitz James-Miss was second, and Queen Lily, by SpringfieldQueensland, third.
DES MOINES, Iowa, April 26.--Four-fifth of the stock of the Des Moines Street Railway Company was to-day sold to a syndicate represented by George B. Kerper, President of the ...

BUFFALO, N.Y. April 26.--Fred Ryers, the champion pool player of Buffalo and a wellknown sport, died to-day from opium poisoning. He was found unconscious outside a joint kept by two Chinamen, who were arrested pending an investigation of the case.

BOSTON, April 26.--The Artists' Festival of the Art Students' Association, for which the social world here has been preparing for two months, took place at the Museum of Fine Arts, while outside the wind howled and the rain poured ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 26.--It is now found by the will of Joseph Earl Sheffield that the homestead on Hillhouse-avenue will not go directly to the Sheffield Scientific School, but that it will be held in trust by the eldest son, George St. John Sueffield, during his life. The university will, therefore, derive no immediate aid from the estate, and there is no present prospect of a four years' Scientific course.

Not a few anglers residing in this city are preparing to celebrate the contennial holiday upon the trout streams of Pennsylvania and New-York State. The rush to the fishing tackle dealers has been continuous for the last week.
EDINBURGH, April 26.--The question whether the freedom of the city of Edinburgh shall be conferred upon Mr. Parnell is to be submitted to the vote of the ratepayers.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 26.--Frank Van Buren, son of Gen. Daniel T. Van Buren of Plainfield, while riding last Saturday was thrown from his horse, sustaining injuries from which he died to-day. He was twenty-one years old. An older brother, Edward, was severely injured in New-York by a Broadway car last Friday, and it was while the rest of the family were in attendance upon him at the Chambers-Street Hospital that the accident to Frank occurred.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 26.--Henry T. Scott of the Union Iron Works denies the truth of the statements made yesterday regarding alleged defects in the machinery of the Charleston. He declares that the Goverment engineers are more than satisfied with results thus far obtained. He also says that no date for the trial trip has yet been fixed.
Police Superintendent Murray said yesterday afternoon that he would to-day formally announce his full detail for the centennial celebration.
ALBANY, April 26.--Gov. Hill made the following proclamation to-day:
The popularity of Deputy Collector Charles Davis, of Chief Clerk and Acting Deputy Collector Thomas J. Dunn, and of Deputy Collector Searing among the Custom House ...

BALTIMORE, April 26.--The British steamship Cordonilla, Capt. Gavin, has brought 1,750 tons of Mapganese iron ore from Maeri, Turkey, the first of that article brought here from that port. It is for the Edgar Thompson Iron Works in Pennsylvania.

Banks, banking houses, trust companies, and other financial institutions down town were much exercised yesterday over the progress of the effort at Albany to make Monday and Wednesday legal holidays. Several bank Presidents sent telegraphic protests to Gov.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 26.--The Northern Pacific and Wisconsin Central deal having been regarded all along us a foregone conclusion, the matter did not excite much cemment and the railway official here had little to say about the matter.

Jouett arrived in the city from Washington yesterday morning, and met the Navy Committee and the Committee of Arrangements of the mercantile marine naval parade in consultation at the Stewart Building in the afternoon. SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 26.--The Boston and Albany Railroad's usual good management had a close call this evening.

WASHINGTON, April 26.--The Secretary of the Treasury to-day-rejected offers of $1,000,000 4 per cent. bonds at 108 and $60,500 at 108 1/8.

The United States steam corvette Juniata arrived in this port yesterday morning from the naval training school, and is now anchored in the harbor off Communipaw flats. The tide was running strong ebb when the Juniata attempted to take position, and, dragging her ...

The A.B. Cleveland Company, Limited dealers in seede at 47 Cortlandt-street, whose President, Artie B. Cleveland, fied the city last January, is arranging with the creditors to take care of the indebtedness by the issue of bonds to run three years to the amount of $425,000.

ALBANY, April 26.--The Senate this morning formally ratified the action of the House yesterday by passing the non-partisan Police bill, the non-partisan Park Board bill, and the bill to increase the police justices of New-York to fifteen.

NEWBURG, N.Y., April 26.--The pupils of the public schools to-day held Arbor Day exercises at the several school buildings. This was carried out previous to the legal date owing to the fact that the regular Spring Vacation will occur next week, and it would be difficult to secure the attendace of pupils. No trees were planted, but the literary programme prepared by the State Superintendent was carried out.
NEWPORT, R.I., April 26.--Stram yacht Ladoga and schooner yacht Norma sailed hence to-day for New-York.

PORTLAND, Me., April 26.--At a meeting of the Board of Trade to-day resolutions were adopted protesting against any legislation which will deprive citizens of facilities of transportation of merchandise over the Canadian lines between the Atlantic and the West.
By an error in the types yesterday it was stated that 106 East One Hundred and Sixth-street had been transferred by levi M. Cohen to Leopole Gusthal.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., April 26.--The universal theme of conversation in this village is the recent action of the Port JerviS, Monticello and New-York Road in canceling its engagement to carry a trainload of excursionists over its road to Ellenville on Sunday next.

The Chicago Stock Exchange has resolved to strike the bonds of the Chicago City Railroad Com pany from the list unless it was furnished with a statement of the number issued. President Holmes said yesterday that the information had not been given because the only person who possessed it, the company's Secretary had been sick. Now that he was well the information would be furnished.

A curious fact in connection with the record of the Cunard steamship Etruria is that, while the quickest average time was made on eastward passages, the highest average speed per hour was made going to the westward.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. , April 26--This was Founders' Day at Vassar College, and the parlors and reception rooms were crowded this afternoon with parents and friends of the students.
The funeral of Civil Justice Michael Norton occurred at his late residence, 42 Charltonstreet, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning.

TRENTON, N.J., April 26.--Two freight trains on the Pennsylvania Road collided at 2 o'clock this morning. Five cars and an engine were wrecked. William A. Hilton, and ironworker, of 1,709 Moravian-street. Philadelphia, was killed. Both trains were south-bound.

PATERSON, N.J., April 26.--Felix Klee, age fourteen, son of Adolph Klee, a prominent dry goods merchant, was found dead to-night from a pistol shot in his father's woodshed at 50 Fair-street. Some of the neighbors say that the boy was chastised by his parents and afterward shot himself. Others say the shooting was accidental.

About one hundred woman suffragists were courageous enough to brave yesterday's wind and rain to attend the convention of the State Woman's Suffrage League at Masonic Hall, Twenty-third-street and Sixth-avenue. Most of these were delegates from the different counties.
UTICA, N.Y., April 26.--On May 19, 1,500 boxes of opium stored at Cape Vincent will be sold under seizure by the Deputy United States Marshal.
ST. PAUL, Minn., April 26.--Miss Josephine Hauser, niece of Senator Albert Scheffer's wife, and daughter of Paul Hanser, Sr., President of the Hauser Malting Company, committed suicide last night.
ST. PAUL, Minn., April 26.--Dr. Otto Lugger, the State Entomologist, has returned from Perham, Otter Tail County, the scene of the grasshopper devastations of last year.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 26.--The Connecticut Sons of the Revolution will join the societies from other States in a conference at New-York on April 30 to consider the matter of forming a national order.
LONDON, April 27.--The steamship Leerdam, (Dutch.) Capt. Potjer, from New-York April 11 for Amsterdam, passed the Lizard yesterday.

Judge Ingraham, in Supreme Court, Chambers, was applied to yesterday on behalf of Mrs. Mary E. Roland, for an injunction restraining the owner of property on Forty-thirdstreet, running from Madison-avenue to Vanderbilt-avenue, from allowing it to be used as a meat market.
Not only those persons who smoke cigarettes, but those who do not, have now a splendid opportunity to profit by a financial scheme promulgated by W. Duke, Sons Co., manufacturers of cigarettes.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 26.--Frederick Schuitz has sued August Michel for $2,500 damages for covering him with a coat of red and black paint while he slept and afterward calling in fifty other boarders to laugh at the sight. Schultz was asleep and was awakened by their shouts of laughter.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26.--Leoni Clark, known on the variety stage as the "cat king," who, with a troop of thirty cats, has been one of the attractions here this week, met with a great misfortune this morning.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 26.--Centennial exercises were held in the public schools to-day, and were conducted by the Principals. At the High School Superintendent Dix addressed the advanced scholars. In all the schools flags, purchased by the scholars, were hoisted.

GUTHRIE, Indian Territory, April 26.--A petition has been prepared and is being extensively signed for the extension of the limits of the town site of Guthrie. It will be sent to the authorities at Washington, and its promoters profess to believe that it will be granted immediately ...

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 26.--An exhaustive review of the seeding and crop outlook in the Northwest shows that in many parts of this State and Dakota an increase is given in the acreages of all grains, due to new breaking in the newer portions, while in some sections attention ...
Coroner Levy and a jury concluded the investigation into the cause of death of little Tobias Hipper last evening.
As is now a customary thing the Forum makes it appearance laden with much of the month's best thought.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 26.--The last of the constitutional cases which have been recently brought before the Supreme Court, was disposed of to-day in an opinion reversing the decision of Judge Howland and holding that the act authorizing the temporary loan of $1,400,000 is constitutional. Under this decision it is presumed there will be no difficulty in negotiating the loan and the calling of an extra session of the Lagislature will not be necessary.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 26.--The barns and outbuildings on the fares of Dr. Worthington B. Searles, at Rocky Hill, twelve miles from New-Brunswick, were totally destroyed by fire yesterday, together with their contents, including several horses and a number of valuable prize cattle. The loss which is partially covered by insurance, is about $25,000.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 26.--The storm throughout Maryland has been the worst for years. The heavy rainfall has injured the bloom on the peach trees in many parts of the State. At Chestertown there was a hurricane, and one estimate is that if the damage to other orchards outside of Kent County is as great as in that county no less than 100,000 trees will be damaged.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 26.--There was an exciting accident on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad this morning. It occurred at the "Y" which is made by the tracks that lead by Locust Point toward Philadelphia and those that lead to Washington.
More than one hundred gentlemen of prominence will enjoy to-night's Delmonico banquet in commemoration of Gen. Grant's birthday.
Inspector Alexander S. Williams was not on duty yesterday, owing to the loss of his infant son.

ST. PAUL, April 26.--"The liberty of the press shall forever remain inviclable, and all persons may freely speak, write, or publish their sentiments on all subjects, being responsible for the abuse of such right." Such is the language of the Constitution of Minnesota in regard to the freedom of the press.

Theodore Thomas's centennial celebration at the Broadway Theatre on Sunday evening will be a fine entertainment. Ralph Joseffy will play Liszt's Hungarian fantasy and the same writer's transcription of Beethoven's "Ruins of Athens" march, and the orchestra will perform some of the most popular music of the best order.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 26.--The Senate passed the Weldon Extradition bill to-day without debate. No effort was made to revive the retreactive clause which was struck out in the Commons by the opposition of the legal gentlemen in that body. The measure will become law next week. There is no truth in the report that it will be submitted to the English Government for approval before being proclaimed in the official gazette.

SANFORD, Fla. April 26.--C. Dement and other inmates of the Dement bakery and restaurant, have been removed by Dr. Joseph Y. Porter, State Health Officer, to Suspect Camp, two miles from the city. The camp will be guarded.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 26.--St. James's Protestant Episcopal Church, at Goshen, possesses four antique and beautifully wrought cut-glass chandeliers that have a history in ...

HARTFORD, Conn., April 26.--The House this morning passed a bill providing that no person shall make, sell, or have in his possession any product made wholly or in part of any fat, oil or oleogenous substance or compound thereof not produced from milk or cream which shall be in imitation of butter or cheese. The penalty is a fine or imprisonment or both.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 26.--There is trouble brewing among the railroads, and the prospect for a lively war of rates is very good. Several weeks ago the Eastern lines fixed upon a thirtycent flour rate, St. Paul to New-York via rail ...

LITTLE FALLS, Minn., April 26.--Soon after 12 o'clock last night one of the sisters in the Belle Prairie Convent was awakened by smoke. She discovered that the convent was ablaze. The inmates of the building were immediately aroused and with difficulty all were saved.
SIOUX FALLS, Dakota, April 27.--Articles incorporating the Sioux Falls and Pacific Short Line Railroad Company have been filed.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 27.--Edward L. Stickland, lately a weaver in Roy's Mill, Port Schuyler, shot himself in the head this evening fatally. His wife recently left him and he was discharged from the mill for drunkenness.

Mrs. Schumacher of Boston delivered a course of illustrated lectures last week in Sage College on the art treasures of the Vatican. These lectures were designed for the young ladies of Sage. Mrs. Schumacher will lecture at Wells College on Cayuga Lake this week.

LONDON, April 27.--Gen. Boulanger has been with us for several days, but the aspect of external nature has not materially changed beyond a certain amount of awe created by his stopping at the Hotel Bristol, where the atmosphere alone costs money.

The fever of the centennial has reached Trenton and caused Mr. George R. Whittaker to squander $300 on a statue of George Washington of heroic size. It may be thought a myth that a heroic Washington of any degree of likeness could be bought for that sum; yet the sale occurred, and, what is more, the statue is of fine marble and was made in Italy.

The steamer Narragansett from Stonington, with a large number of passengers from Boston and the East, is due this morning. The Stonington will arrive from the East to-morrow with a full passenger list.
The work on the machinery for the new battle ship Maine is already under way. The subletting at the work to different firms is closed in nearly every instance.

HAVANA, Cuba, April 26.--Continued fine weather has enabled the larger part of our sugar estates to complete grinding, and with the exception of the large contracts, the season will be finished with the present month.

Warren C. Barry, a charcoal dealer of 245 West Nineteenth-street, is at present in a peculiar position. He has been indicted by the Grand Jury upon the complaint of Edward Halstead, who charges that he paid Barry $500 in order to get a position as recording clerk in the Surrogate's office.
WASHINGTON, April 27.--There is but little foundation for the reports which have been circulated to the effect that the diplomatic corps will not take part in the centennial ball and banquet.

BERLIN, April 27.--The members of the commission to consider the questions concerning Samoa have seen Prince Bismarck and Count Herbert Bismarck. The former briefly expressed his confidence that the conference would be harmonious. The Foreign Office appears to be assured of an early termination of the negotiations.

A deputaion of Close Communion Baptists from England, consisting of the Rev. Dr. E. Parker of Manchester, President of the Brighton Grove College, and W. Dale Shaw of Huddersfuld, arrived on the Germanic on Friday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 27.--There has been a great rush down the Hudson this afternoon and evening on both the West Shore and Hudson River Railroad, fully 6,000 people going south on both roads.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. April 27.--One day last Summer George W. Williams suddenly disappeared from his home at this place. Joseph Williams, his father, made repeated inquiries about him, but failed to receice any response until a few days ago, when a letter from Tipton, Iowa, informed him that his son was confined in an insane asylum there.
BERLIN, April 27.--The delegates to the Samoan conference are delighted with the reception accorded them by Prince Bismarck.

Manager William A. Camp of the NewYork Clearing House received a letter yesterday from a leading bank President, suggesting that a meeting of bank Presidents be called for to-morrow to reach a decision regarding action in relation to keeping open on Wednesday.
The President and the members of his family were startled last evening by the blowing down of two giant eim trees immediately in front of the Executive Mansion.
MONTICELLO, April 27.--Ex-County Treasurer C.S. Starr of Sullivan County is undergoing an examination before a special committee of the Board of Supervisors for an alleged shortage in his accounts.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 27.--Information comes from Moberly, Mo., to the effect that that city is greatly excited to-day over an attempt to assassinate City Councilman Howard Jennings.

Lizzie Farmer, sixteen years old, of Yonkers, was found yesterday morning in a bedroom at the Enoch House, at 207 East Forty-secondstreet, unconscious from the inhalation of gas, which was escaping from an open burner.

ST. LOUIS, April 27.--The Republic's Wichita correspondent telegraphs that paper as follows: Out of the many wild rumors with which the border is full to-day, is one which seems to bear the elements of probability. The report is of an attack on an old soldiers' colony in the southwestern part of Oklahoma.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., April 27.--The dwelling of James Hannish, near Hookerville, Nicholas Cuunty, West Va., was burned on Wednesday night last, and Hannish's wife and two children were burned to death in the building. Hannish was away from home at the time. The cause of the fire is unknown, but it is believed to have been incendiary.

GEORGETOWN, P.E.I., April 27.--About sixty sail of Nova Scotian and American "bankers" have arrived here. They report having been unable to reach the Magdalen Islands, to which some of them were bound for bait, on account of ice, which is packed solid from East Point to Cape Breton.

A colored fisherman in Black River, near Brunswick, caught last week a half bushel of lobsters. It was just after that northeast gale, and the presumption is that they were driven south by the bad weather, as they are rarely ever seen in these waters. Some of the old citizens tell of seeing them years ago.

CHICAGO, April 27.--After firing four shots, Charlie Howard, the thirteen-year-old son of J.C. Howard, chief clerk of the Wabash Railroad, captured a burglar on State street near Twelfth last night, who had just plundered the residence of the lad's father.

One of the most beautiful arches erected in the city is the Washington triumphal arch, which spans Fifth-avenue from curb to curb about 100 feet north of Washington-square, and between the residence of ex-Mayor Cooper and that of the Misses Rhinelander.

A colored man made a spring for a Desbrosses-Street Ferry boat of the Pennsylvania Railroad ferry just after she had left her slip at the foot of Exchange-place, Jersey City, yesterday morning. He fell into the water and was drowned.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 27.--The owners of the American bark J.D. Peters, Capt. Lane, 114 days out from Newcastle, N.S.W., are anxious regarding the safety of their vessel. The British ship Buteshire, which left Newcastle after the Peters departed, arrived here last Monday. The J.D. Peters has a cargo of coal consigned to Parrott Co. Insurance companies have refused to accept any further risks upon her.

ALBION, N.Y., April 27.--This village is wild with excitement over the murderous assault on his wife by William H. Whaling. Last night Whaling went home, and during a quarrel with his wife he attacked her and cut her throat. He then dragged her into the yard, where she was found this morning. She will die. whaling was arrested.

PARIS, April 27.--Politically speaking, Paris is very quiet. Occasionally a vague rumor comes from the mystery of the High Court, and a more and more defined presentiment gains strength that there has been found too little fire to produce any great amount of smoke. This idea, however, is merely venture. No one feels interest enough to ferret out the real facts of the case.

President Barnard of Columbia College died at 4:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon. His death had been expected for some days, and the end was peaceful and painless. He had been sleeping in his chair, and just before death he awoke and nodded his head in answer to the nurse, who asked if he wanted some nourishment. Before this passed his lips the venerably scholar's sands of life had run out.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 27.--News of a tragedy, with children as the principals, comes from Malvern, Carroll County, Ohio. LAWRENCE, Mass., April 27.--Timothy Reardon, a laborer residing in South Lawrence, has received word from Washington that his claim for an original pension had been allowed. CANTON, Ohio, April 28.--While a number of children were playing at Malvern, Ohio, yesterday, two of them, Charlie Dickman, aged five, and Johnny Hexawer, aged eight, cousins, got into a childish quarrel. The murder caused the wildest excitement, and the parents of both children are nearly crazed over the terrible tragedy.

LONDON, April 28.--The Marquis of Londonderry, in an address at a banquet at the College of Physicians, Dublin, Saturday, announced his resignation of the office of Lord Lieutenant of Ireland. He denied that his resignation was due to anything that Mr. Balfour had said. He accepted the office, he said, for two years, and he agreed to remain a third year at the request of the Govornment.
Logan Uriah Reavis, long a conspicuous and well-known citizen, died at the City Hospital yesterday from the effects of a surgical operation performed a few days ago.

GUTHRIE, Oklohama, April 28.--The Western Union extra wire from the North reached Guthrie late lastnight and to-day press messages can be wired direct from here for the first time since the opening of Oklohama. LONDON, April 28.--Gen. Boulanger passed a quiet day. He took a drive this afternoon and afterward dined at has hotel with a few intimate friends. He has taken a house in Portland-place.

NEW-HAVEN, April 28.--An important book is now coming from the State Printer. It is a catalogue, with names and records, of Connecticut soldiers and sailors engaged in the war of the Revolution, the war of 1812, the Mexican war, and the civil war.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 28.--Dan McCarty, horseman, left to-day over the Central Pacific Railroad with three cars containing fifty-two horses for Eastern races. One car will go to Louisville, where a number of his horses will enter the Derby and various handicap races. The other two cars will go to New-York, and the horses will appear there and on other tracks.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 29.--The first sale of properties for taxes under the Martin act was held to-day. Among the properties sold was the Pitman Methodist Church, with its grounds, in George-street. It was sold for arrearages of assessments for street improvements, which the Trustees have failed to pay. Money will be borrowed and the church will be redeemed. The sale was a success, only $3,000 worth of property being taken by the city.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 29.--The Joint Committee of both houses of Parliament appointed to inquire into the expenditure of the country in respect to legislation and the practicability of reducing the same, has recommended that on the expiration of the tenure of the present incumbent of the Chaplaincy of the Senate that office be abolished and that in the future there be no barroom.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 29.--The Pusey Jones Company at noon today launched a new revenue cutter for the United States Government. She will be 145 feet in length over all, 136 feet on the line, and will be finished by July. She was not christened.

Belle Wehuke, a two-year-old child, was shot and instantly killed in West New-York on Sunday afternoon while her aunt was carrying her up the Boulevand in her arms. Charles Pfeiffer, who was shooting at a target, made a bad shot, and the bullet crashed through the child's skull. Pfeiffer was arrested.

FOUNTAIN, Col., April 29.--The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe station house at this point was broken into this morning at 2 o'clock by two tramps, who murdered the night operator, A.C. Hastings, and robbed the body of $65 and escaped. A posse of officers are in pursuit of the men, who, if captured, will be lynched.

NEW-HAVEN, April 29.--Seven Yale students while sailing in the harbor this afternoon were capsized by a sudden squall. All of the men succeeded in climbing upon the upturned boat, and were rescued half an hour later by a boat from the Breakwater. The men were thoroughly chilled and badly exhausted.
RED BANK, N.J., April 29.--The Rev. Nelson A. Macnichol, pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church, preached a centennial sermon last evening.

HALIFAX, N.S., April 29.--The Gloucester schooner Pendragon, at Port Hawkesbury, wanted to get a new sail from Gloucester duty free. The customs authorities at Ottawa have telegraphed to Collector Bourinot that the Pendragon must pay the duty on her sail, as the United States refused free entry for Canadian vessels under similar circumstances.

THREE RIVERS, Province of Quebec, April 29. --Yesterday, while twelve men and a little girl were crossing the Nicolet River at Ste. Clothilde in a skiff the boat upset and three of the men were drowned. All were residents of Ste. Clothlide. Their names have not been ascertained.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 29.--The Lookout Rolling Mill Company of this city Saturday night discharged all of their white workmen and to-day they employed 150 negroes. Trouble is apprehended between the new workmen and the old men.

HARTFORD, April 30.--The new passenger station of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Road in this city will be occupied by the company on Sunday, May 5. It is the largest and most costly structure on the Consolidated lines outside of New-York City and is built of Long Meadow brownstone.

PALESTINE, Texas, April 30.--In the suit of John R. Hearne, receiver of the International and Great Northern Railroad, for possession of the road and property, Judge Williams to-day rendered his decision in favor of the plaintiff. The defendant, Receiver Bonner of Tyler, will take the case up on appeal to the Supreme Court at Austin.

CHICAGO, April 30.--A panic took place during the exhibition of fireworks in the big Lake Front Park to-night. Half a hundred people are known to have been seriously hurt, a number perhaps fatally. Scores of others suffered painful injuries.
