N.W. BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 1.--The Janeway memorial collection was opened at Rutgers college this evening. It is a very valuable colection of carios recently brought from Europe and placed in the college in memory of Dr. Thomas L. Janeway.
BERLIN, May 1.--It is stated that the liberation of Malietoa, the deposed King of Samoa, has been voluntarily announced to the Samoan Conference.

Yesterday brought under the review of a peace-loving people the triumphs of peace. Uncle Sam let down the bars of the field of industry and the numerous herd filed out for the multitude to judge them.
Since the mobilization of the United States war vessels in New-York Harbor on Monday there has been no wide scattering of the different ships.

Col. S.V.R. Cruger was greatly instrumental in directing the movements of the military and civic parades on Tuesday and yesterday by means of his special telegraph wire that he leased from the Western Union and equipped with an efficient corps of telegraph operators.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1.--George Klotz died at his residence, 1,727 Mervine-street, to-day, the result, it is said, of injuries inflicted by Anton Bruf. The two men were employed at Charles Class's brewery, Klotz as engineer and Bruf as his helper.

Edward P. Fox, once a member of the widely-known restaurant firm of Crook, Fox Nash, died on Monday at his home, 114 East One Hundred and Twentieth-street, after a long sickness resulting from kidney disease.
WASHINGTON, May 1.--Bond offerings to-day aggregated $20,100 as follows: Registered 4s--$8,750 ...

The Guion steamship Nevada, which has now been overdue from Liverpool for two days, is being anxiously awaited. She was sighted in a partially disabled condition by a vessel which arrived in Queenstown on Monday. One of her engines had been rendered useless, and she was running slowly under the other alone. There is little cause for apprehension as to the Nevada's safety, though the delay will necessarily be considerable.

Mr. Iselin will put the Titania in commission this afternoon. She is at Piepgras's yard at City Island and will begin the season in first-rate trim. Capt. Haff of Volunteer fame will sail her and her owner thinks she will outsail anything in the seventy-foot class.
That a political deal has been made in which THOMAS C. PLATT and Gov. HILL are the high contracting parties does not admit of doubt.

LONDON, May 1.--The House of Commons today rejected the bill introduced by Sir Wilfrid Lawson, proposing to give urban leaseholders power to purchase their leases. The vote stood 186 against the measure to 157 in its favor.
Charles Danhard and Charles Fisher of Pamrapo-avenue, Greenville, went sailing on Newark Bay last evening in a boat owned by Danhard.
A full list of events to be contested on the Berkeley Oval on May 18, in the eleventh annual field meeting of the Interscholastic Athletic Association, includes the following:

It's an ill wind that blows nobody good. "I'm glad I kept open to-day," said an un patriotic but sharp druggist yesterday, "al though it is a holiday. I am making more money selling vaseline, cold cream, camphorated cream, and preparations of that kind than on any day since I began business."

CITY OF MEXICO, May 1, via Galveston.--The Government makes official announcement that the Berlin banker, Herr Bleichroeder, has made a demand for the remainder of the loan of 2,900,000, upon which he held an option.
As Gen. Butterfield and his staff passed Fiftieth-street at 9 o'clock the Star Division, comprising the various educational institutions of the city, wheeled into line.

First Sergt. Robert Walsh, Company B. Eleventh Infantry, has been retired. First Lieut. John V. White, First Artillery, has been detailed as Professor of Military Tactics at the Agricultural and Mechanical College in Oktibbeha County, Miss., relieving Second Lieut. H.C. Davis, Jr., Third Artillery, who is ordered to join his battery.
HAMILTON, Ontario, May 1.--While workmen were engaged last night in removing debris at the scene of the recent railroad wreck another body was found, swelling the number of the killed to twenty.

BOSTON, May 1.--Mayor Hart to-day informed the representatives of the united labor bodies of Boston who recently asked him for an appropriation from the contingent fund at his disposal to defray the expenses of a delegation of workingmen to the Paris Exposition that in the opinion of the Corporation Counsel such appropriation cannot be made.
Alonzo A. Ostrander of 266 Bergen-street, Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday on a charge of bigamy. He has a wife whom he married on Aug. 17, 1875, living at the above address, but...

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn, May 1.--The North Western Miller to-day says: "There was a slight gain in the flour output last week. Fifteen mills were operated, but only eight ran full time, the rest getting in two to four days.

Some hundreds of thousands of people went to their homes last night and spent the evening trying to make up their minds which of the two great centennial street parades--the millitary or the civic--pleased them best.

At a meeting yesterday of the creditors of Thomas F. Scanian, doing business in Boston as the NewEngland Piano Company, a statement was presented by Mr. Scaulan showing direct liabilities of $233,401, and contingent liabilities of $259,168;...

CHICAGO, May 1.--There was a meeting of the Irish Catholic Colonization Association of the United States at the Grand Pacific Hotel today. Bishop Spalding of Peoria, Bishop O'Con J.J. Riordan, W.P. Rend, Michael Cudahy, and W.J. Onahan of Chicago were selected as directors. A dividend of 6 per cent. was declared on the stock of the association.
CHICAGO, May 1.--A Director of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul said to-day that Director John Plankinton had sent to the board his resignation as Director, with a peremptory...

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 1.--Jacob Fisher, a Polish Jew, was committed to jail here to-day charges with bigamy. Fisher, it is said, fled to America from Germany two years ago, deserting his wife and children.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 1.--White Caps demolished the saloon of John Messmore, at Rawson, Hancock County, Ohio, last night. This is the second time Messmore has been visited, his saloon having been wrecked about two months ago. He had been warned not to resume business at Rawson, but paid no attention to the warning. He has now decided to leave the place.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 1.--A dispatch from Union City states that two distinct shocks of earthquake were felt there last night. The undulatory motion seemed to be from southwest to northwest.

Postmaster Cornelius Van Cott yesterday took charge of affairs at the Post Office. He came down in the morning, accompanied by his legal advisor, ex-Judge Bankson T. Morgan, who will for a time assist Mr. Van Cott in mastering the details of the department.
The Jersey City railway stations found out last night what it was to be jammed with travelers.
A number of centennial stand ticket speculators and doorkeepers met in the Thirtyninth-street temporary annex to the Metropolitan Opera House last night to settle "business matters" ...

LONDON, May 1.--Lloyd's agent at Berlin reports that the Weser has yellow fever on board, several officers and twenty-eight men being ill and three having died. The North German Lloyd steamer Weser, Capt. von Schuckman, sailed from Baltimore April 17 for Bremen.
ELIZABETH, N.J., May 1.--Gen. J. Madison Drake of the Veteran Zouaves, accompanied by Chief of Police Austin of this city, went to New-York...
CHICAGO, May 1.--Some weeks ago Samuel Lazarus, T.S. Bugbee, A.B. Gregory, and N.T. Eaton, Western stockmen, issued an invitation from Kansas City to several well-known stockmen ...

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 1.--In the House today Mr. Mulock asked what action the Government proposed to take on the application of Ontario millers for an increase in the duty on flour. The Speaker ruled the question out of order.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 1.--To-day the first annual joint sale of the Kingston, Fleetwood, Balgowen, Loudoun, Larchmont, and Beaumont Studs took place at Treacy Wilson's stable, with Phil C. Kidd as auctioneer.
NEW-HAVEN, May 1.--Capt. Woodruff of the Yale crew says to-night that the Yale-Harvard University race at New-London will be rowed on Friday, June 28.

The Board of Education met yesterday afternoon, with President J. Edward Simmons in the chair. Mr. Thaddeds Moriarty, who was appointed a Commissioner to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Mr. William A. Cole, took his seat in the board.

ALBANY, May 2.--In the Court of Appeals to-day the following causes were argued: No. 298--Augustus S. Gorham, appellant, vs. Anron Innis, assignee, respondent--Argued by Henry S. Bennett for appellant, Henry M. Taylor for respondent No. 247--John H. Riker, surviving executor, respondent, vs. Sampson S. Leo, appellant--Argued by John E. Parsons for appellant, Adolph L. Sanger for respondent No. 273--Charles W. Wales, an infant, ...

LONDON, May 2.--The banquet to Consul General Waller to-night was in many respects the most notable Anglo-American affair that London has ever seen. It is true there were not so many familiar names in the list of guests as at the Phelps dinner at the Mansion House, but this is only because it, unlike the other, was a matter of individual...

UTICA, N.Y., May 2.--Horace Silliman of Cohoes to-day formally presented the twentythousand-dollar Young Men's Christian Association building which he has erected on the Hamilton Campus to that institution.

The students of Columbia College assembled in their various departments at 9:30 o'clock yesterday morning in readiness to escort the body of their late President, Dr. F.A.P. Barnard, from his residence, 63 East Forty-ninthstreet, to St. Thomas's Church.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, May 2.--The dispatches sent out from Texas purporting to give details of the rioting at Silao and Guanajuato are gross exaggerations. The Prefect of Silao was assassinated yesterday, and his was the only life lost in the entire affair. The authorities have restored order, and to-day everything is quiet.

As soon as Thomas F. Gilroy received from Mayor Grant yesterday morning his certificate of appointment as Commissioner of Public Works for a term supposed to begin on May 1, 1889, and continue until May 1, 1893, ...
Wall-street had a good time yesterday. Something like an old-fashioned boom struck the stock market. Nearly every stock on the Stock Exchange list went up. Many stocks gained over a full point each.
Almost any other city in the country would have looked woebegone yesterday had it passed through such an experience as a centennial celebration.

The Chamber of Commerce held its one hundred and twenty-first annual meeting yesterday. There was a large attendance of members, a fine lunch was served, and a pleasant, social time was enjoyed. The following officers were chosen, most of them being re-elected:
NEW-ORLEANS, La., May 2.--O.B. Sansum, Master of Chancery of the United States Circuit Court, filed to-day a report in the celebrated drainage case of J.W. Peak against the city of New-Orleans.

Within the next month some one of the art museums or churches in New-York City will be made richer by the addition of Lord Ronald Gower's masterpiece, the head of the Saviour entitled "It Is Finished."

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 2.--The row which was raised at New-York over the reported presentation of a Grand Army badge to Gov. Gordon of Georgia by Gen. J. Madison Drake turns out to be a tempest in a teapot. No Grand Army badge was given. It was a veteran zouave brouze badge, made from captured rebel cannon. Gen. Drake laughed to-day when he read about the New-York discussion.

The professions with which Mayor GRANT came into office have led some people to believe that, for the sake of his own reputation and for the purpose of convincing the public that the Tammany organization could be safely trusted to control the municipal administration, he would make his...

CUMBERLAND, Md., May 2.--During the trial yesterday of Melvin C. Garlitz for the murder of his wife a very dramatic and exciting scene occurred. While a witness was describing how Garlitz stood over his wife while she was lying down and fired three shots into her body. Mr. Joseph White, the father of the dead woman, ...

BUFFALO, May 2.--As a special reservation officer was closing the Goat Island Bridge gate at Niagara Falls to-night he heard a scream. It came from a woman who had seen a man leap from the lower side of the bridge. A moment later the body appeared, was swept swiftly down the stream, and disappeared over the brink of the American Falls.

BALTIMORE, May 2.--A very pretty wedding in the English style at noon to-day at St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church was that of Commander Henry F. Picking of the United States Navy and Miss Laura Sherwood, daughter of...

CINCINNATI, May 2.--The grain merchants of this city pronounce the inter-State commerce law a failure, at least so far as providing protection for the merchants of Cincinnati is concerned, for this city has almost lost its grain trade because of the outrageous discrimination against it in the matter of freights. Where this time last year the merchants here were handling 150 to 200 carloads a day, they now handle but 15 or 20.

Mr. Seth Low made an address in memory of Simeon B. Chittenden. He said: MR. PRESIDENT: Since the Chamber last met another of the noted merchants who in our day passed away. On the morning of the 14th of April the Hon. Simeon B. Chittenden died at his...

Franklin Woodruff, who was recently selected as boss of Brooklyn Republican politics, has become very weary of the task and announced yesterday that he would retire on Monday night, when the Executive Committee again meets.

Last Sunday two young men named Clarence P. Page, aged twenty, and Fred Hines, aged twentyfour, left Lynn, Mass., in a new canoe they had purchased, intending to paddle to Somerville. Since then nothing has been heard from them nor has the canoe been seen.

The annual meeting of the Civil Service Reform Association was held Wednesday evening at the New-York Academy of Medicine, Dorman B. Eaton presiding in the absence of Mr. Curtis, who is still detained at Staten Island by lameness.

HARTFORD, May 2.--The week's adjournment of the Legislature on account of the centennial in New-York has furnished the railroad corporations an opportunity for massing their forces for the great encounter which is to take place on the floor of the House next week over the Housatonic Road.
On Monday night a committee of County Democrats called on Gov. David B. Hill and gave him a great many reasons why he should veto the bills which are the result of the Tammany-Republican "deal."
LONDON, May 2.--The cross-examination of Mr. Parnell was continued before the Parnell Commission to-day. Mr. Parnell admitted that Condon was connected with the Manchester murders.

It was the duty of Mr. CURTIS, as President of the Civil Service Reform Association of New-York, at its annual meeting, to review the situation, and it was inevitable that he should examine the question of "the condition and prospect of civil service reform under the party change of administration which occurred on the 4th of March."
ALBANY, May 2.--The first boat of the season to reach this city from the West over the Erie Canal was the W.L. Monty of Thompson Mills, which reached the district this afternoon, laden with lumber.
MR. FERGUSON, WHO WAS SEEN AT THE Gilsey House on Thursday evening, April 25, with Paymaster Smith, is earnestly requested to send his address at once to 346 Broadway, Room 18.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 2.--Justice Davy of the Supreme Court has decided a novel will case. Several years ago Joseph Ebner lived in Michigan and his brother, Edward Ebner, lived in Rochester. They were both unmarried men and upward of seventy years of age.

BERLIN, May 2.--An official denial is published to-day of the report printed in the Berliner Tageblatt of Tuesday that at Monday's sitting of the Samoan Conference Mr. Kasson, one of the American Commissioners, had asked whether a secret treaty existed between England and Germany for a partition of the Ponga...

ALBANY, May 2.--However much inclined the Legislature may be to adjourn on the 16th inst. as the original final adjournment resolution specifies, it is hardly possible that that programme will be carried out.

Under the auspices of the State Department of Public Instruction Prof. Albert S. Bickmore, in charge of the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park, will lecture to-morrow at the museum to the teachers of the city and State of New-York on "The Forests of America."

Grover Cleveland and Col. Lamont strolled down Broad-street yesterday afternoon and attracted as much attention as though Mr. Cleveland was still President. Little knots of brokers and others gathered on the sidewalk and remarked that Mr. Cleveland was looking remarkably well.

Dr. Hans von Bulow made his farewell appearance before the New-York public at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening. There are various rumors afloat as to the probability of his returning next season, but in the absense of any definite or authoritative announcement the statement of last evening's programme must be accepted as correct.

HARTFORD, May 2.--The health of Mrs. Harriet Beecher Stowe has improved so much during the past few months that a very comfort able Summer is expected for her. It would not be strange, in view of her continued recuperation, if another season might be spent by her at her favorite resort on Long Island, from which she was conveyed home last Fall in so helpless a condition both of mind and body.

An interesting feature of the Titan Athletic Club's games to be held on the Manhattan Athletic Club's grounds, at Eighty-sixth-street and Eighthavenue, to-morrow afternoon, will be the performance of T.P. Conneff in the mile run. Mr. Conneff says that he will attempt to beat his record of 4:24 for the distance.
CHICAGO, May 2.--Judge Tuley rendered a decision yesterday in the case of the J.W. Butler Paper Company against the Jeffery Printing Company, which is a substantial victory for the complainants.

CHICAGO, May 2.--The late J.D. Jennings left his estate by will to a trust company to be managed for his heirs. To-day an attorney for the company came into court and, on its behalf, declined to accept the trust, which covers about $3,000,000 worth of property. The heirs ask for a trustee to settle up the estate, as no successor in trust is named in the will.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 2.--Quite a commotion has been stirred up among the grain commission men by the alleged tightening up of wheat grades on the part of Inspector Clausen and his men. The commission men say that within the last week grades have been tightened up materially, so that what formerly passed for No. 1 hard now passes for No. 1 Northern, and so on. It is said the raise is really a whole grade.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 2.--B.G. Bruce and P C. Kidd held their combination sale of thorough breds here to-day. The crowd was large and the bidding was fairly brisk. The weather was cool. Fifty-eight head sold for $23,040, an average of $397. Following is a list of those sold:

Judge O'Brien of the Supreme Court yesterday handed dawn a decision in favor of Mrs. Sara Jane Collins, widow of Commodore Edward K. Collins, the founder of the famous Collins Line of steamships. Mrs. Collins was sued by Edward K. Collins, one of Commodore Collins's sons, and his executor.
SING SING, N.Y., May 2.--A dynamite manufactory about three miles from the Yonkers railroad station and close by Shaft 16 of the new Croton Aqueduct blew up for the third time about noon to-day.

A contest has been begun in the Surrogate's Court, over the will of Miss M. Louise Comstock, who kept a fashionable private school on West Forty-fourth-street. Miss Comstock's will was drawn so as to provide against any of her property being received by her next of kin after the death of her mother, who was given a life interest in the estate.

The centennial celebration having been disposed of, people who were unfortunate enough to be compelled to do so, yesterday gave their undivided attention to that annual Ameri can pastime called "moving."
ELIZABETH, N.J., May 2.--Several weddings were celebrated here last night. Mr. Edward Payson Baker and Miss Mary Hamilton Campbell were married at Westminster Church by the Rev. Dr. Leale.

There was laid before President HARRISON a few days ago by a committee representing the American Forestry Congress a memorial in which he was urged to recommend the enactment of laws designed to preserve the timber on the public lands.

Ward McAllister was not an altogether disinterested reader of the published reports of the centennial ball at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday night, having had considerable to do in planning the affair.
The Marquis de Mores is at the Hotel Brunswick. Commander Henry F. Picking, United States Navy, is at the Brevoort House.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 2.--The Orange County Stock Farm, not unknown through the skyrocket career of Latimer E. Jones, has again changed hands. The property consists of 850 acres of choice farming lands in the town of Warwick, with a fine mansion, capacious barns, and breeding stables and race track, and other accessories of a first-class stock farm.

William White, a well-to-do man of fifty years, who for a long time kept a restaurant at 15 Wall-street, this city, and lived at 501 First street, Brooklyn, went to Greenwood Cemetery yesterday afternoon and committed suicide. He went to his family plot near the Twentiethstreet entrance and shot himself in the head.

WASHINGTON, May 2.--While the President was reviewing the naval parade in New-York Bay, listening to Bishop Potter's vigorous remarks about "practical politics," looking at the soldiers of many States, dining at the Metropolitan Opera House, and otherwise participating...

Filled with the perfume of fragrant flowers and brilliant with the light from hundreds of electric jets, the new home of the NewYork Southern Society, at 18 West Twenty-fifthstreet, was last night formally but joyously opened for the purposes to which it will henceforth be devoted.

A valuable addition will be made to this city's list of hotels the coming Fall, when the thus far unfortunate Plaza Hotel will be opened for the accommodation of the public. Since it passes from the control of its original proprietors the building has gone through various vicissitudes.
VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., May 2.--The yacht Winona Gaskell, from Beverly for New-York, arrived here yesterday.

BOSTON, May 2.--Capt. Merriman, Equipment Officer at the Charlestown Navy Yard for three years, has been suspended by Commodore McCann for being absent without leave. It is thought, however, that Capt. Merriman will be reinstated, or that some satisfactory settlement will be brought about, as his previous record as a naval officer has been a good one.
It is announced that the centennial fair now in progress to enable the Hahnemann Hospital to carry on adequately its noble work for the sick and poor will be closed to-morrow evening.

Washington's League team proved its inability to cope favorably with the Giants yesterday. The latter hit the ball at will and scored runs until they were tired. They made singles, doubles, and triples, to the intense delight of the spectators, and Connor and Gore...

The old Marble Cemetery, in Second-street, near Second-avenue, was surrounded by troops and filled with a number of noted foreign offi cials yesterday morning at the disinterment of the body of Don Sebastian Lerdo de Tejada, ex-President...

Some of the appointments Mayor Grant has been preparing to make ever since he went into office were made by him yesterday. A little more or a little less preparation might have produced satisfactory results.

THE HAGUE, May 2.--Owing to the improvement in the health of the King of Holland the Dutch Parliament to-day by a unanimous vote passed a resolution restoring his power. The announcement was received with cheers. Par liament sent a telegram to the King congratulating him upon the favorable turn in his disease.

The lacrosse team of the College of the City of New-York suffered its second defeat in the Metropolitan League's series yesterday afternoon at the hands of a team from Stevens Institute on the grounds of the old St. George Cricket Club at Hoboken, N. J. The score was 2 to 0.

The promenaders who were passing the Hoffman House yesterday afternoon, shortly after 3 o'clock, had their pleasure spoiled by witnessing a shocking accident. Thomas Daley, an employe of a Broadway firm, was engaged in putting up awnings on the front of the Hoffman House.

Charles F. Chatterton, the private secretary of Henry E. Abbey, is now the sole representative of the firm of Abbey, Schoeffel Grau in this city, and he will manage the home office for some time to come.

Secretary of State Frederick Cook is very ill at the Gilsey House. His condition is extremely critical, and his wife and daughter are at his bedside. He took cold while on one of the boats in the naval parade on Monday, and returned to the hotel with a chill.

The annual report of the Executive Committee reviewed the work accomplished by the association during the previous year, and made special reference to the solicitude which had been felt in looking forward to the change in the Administration, and expressed regret at...
LONDON, May 2.--The report that the North German Lloyd steamer Weser, which left Baltimore April 17 for Bremen, had yellow fever on board proves to have been entirely without foundation.

The ship Bridgewater, which put into this port in a sinking condition while on a voyage from Darien,. Ga., for Liverpool, has been towed into shoal water off Cliften, S.L. where two powerful tugs are alongside pumping her out. A diver will be sent down to find the leaks and, if possible, to make temporary repairs, that the vessel may be towed up to this city.

DUBLIN, May 2.--The Tipperary court has affirmed the sentences of four months each imposed on Mr. John O'Connor, member of Parliament for South Tipperary, and Mr. Thomas Condon, member of Parliament for East Tipperary; three months on Dr. Charles Tanner, member of Parliament for the Middle Division of Cork, and two months on Mr. Manning for violations of the Crimes act.

Thirty laborers at the Brooklyn Navy Yard were discharged on Wednesday, and yesterday William Leaycraft, one of the local Republican patronage dispensers, spent several hours looking over the places so vacated. The men were told that there was no work for them. Secretary Tracy was in town and saw a score of politicians, but would have nothing to say to the public. He will return to Washington to-day or to-morrow.

Yesterday was by-day at the American Chess Congress, and the players looked refreshed by their two days' rest. Blackburne, however, seems to be considerably annoyed over some difficulties that he has had with the Managing Committee.

LONDON, May 2.--A dispatch from Melbourne says that a monster meeting of Irish sympathizers was held in that city on Tuesday. Mr. John Dillon made an address which created great enthusiasm among his listeners. One thousand pounds was subscribed to aid the Irish cause.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 2.--The Freshman oratorical contest held by the Cliosophie Literary Society last night resulted in the awarding of the following prizes: First, John Van Ness, New-Jersey; second, U.F. Smiley, Pennsylvania; honorable mention, Irvine McColl, NewYork.

Mrs. Alice O'Keefe, who lives at 136 Madison-avenue, was preparing to go out to see the civic parade on Wednesday when she accidentally dropped her pocketbook from a secondstory window into the street below. The book contained private papers, $500 in bills, and two rings set with diamonds.
SANTA ELENA, Ecuador, May 2, via Galveston.--The United States steamer Mchican, which has been surveying the bay here for the last three days, sailed hence this morning for Payta, Peru

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 3.--A runaway engine on the West Shore Railroad caused much excitement last night. Engine No. 22 was standing at the roundhouse here, when in some unaccountable was the throttle blew open and the locomotive started north on the south-bound ...

There were many anxious inquiries at the Gilsey House yesterday about the condition of Frederick Cook, Secretary of State, who is dangerously ill with pleuro-pneumonia, the result of a cold contracted by exposure during the centennial naval parade.

The boat at the civic parade of the centennial celebration representing the art of shoemaking by hand as practiced in the seventeenth century in the time of Hans Sachs, the celebrated German poet and shoemaker, was furnished by Beneke Brothers of 199 and 201 ...

Thirty more laborers were discharged from the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday. They were told that there was no work for them. The clerks in the various departments who are Democrats expect to be dismissed at any time.
Some time ago Moses Hunter of 190 Montgomery-street, Jersey City, was induced to take out a policy in the Union Benefit League of New-York.

The Americal Female Guardian Society will celebrate its fifty-fifth anniversary at its home for the friendless, 32 East Thirtiethstreet, on Wednesday next. A business meeting is to be held at 10:30 in the morning, followed at 2:30 in the afternoon with an exhibition in the chapel of the work of the children in the several classes of the industrial schools.

Judge Edward F. Browne of the City Court, whose term of office will expire next December, sent his resignation to Gov. Hill on Thursday. The Governor accepted it yesterday, and appointed Leicester Holme to succeed Judge Browne.

CHICAGO, May 3.--The Pullman Company today assumed control of the second-class sleeping and tourist car service of the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad. The transfer took place at Denver and practically completes the absorption by the Pullman Company of this branch of the service throughout the West.

Mrs. Benjamin Harrison, her daughter, Mrs. McKee, Mr. and Mrs. Russell Harrison, Mrs. Tracy, and her daughter, Mrs. Wilmerding, were the guests of Mrs. J.J. Van Nostrand at dinner last evening, at the home of Mrs. Van Nostrand's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William B. Leonard of 192 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn. Covers were laid for twenty-two. Among the other guests were Dr. S. Fleet Speir, Gen. Rodney C. Ward, and Dr. Charles H. Hall.

A movement is well under way to perpetuate in imperishable granite the imposing arch designed by Stanford White and erected at the head of Fifth-avenue fronting Washingtonsquare as a decorative feature in the centennial celebration of Washington's inauguration.

The competing "ticker" systems used on the Stock Exchange got some of Wall-street's brokers into a lively row yesterday. The Commercial ticker came out with its "official time" a minute and a half ahead of that of the Gold and Stock Company.

PORT MONMOUTH, N.J., May 3.--The Port Monmouth clammers have discovered a new hard-clam bed near the Southwest Spit Buoy. The claims are very plentiful, and some of the sloop owners gather thirty bushels a day.

LONDON, May 3.--Mr. Henry White, the American Charge d'Affaires, to-day presented at the Queen's drawing room Fred D. Grant, United States Minister to Austria, and Lieut. Henry D. Borup, United States Army, military attache to the American Legation at Paris, while ...

With the conclusion of our own centennial ceremonies popular attention will be more closely directed to the fact that those of the French Republic have been mean while drawing nearer, and indeed are now at hand.

An enthusiastic mass meeting of residents of the Fourth, seventh, and Thirteenth Wards was held under the auspices of the East Side Water Front Protective Association as Botanic Hall, 68 East Broadway, last evening.

PENSACOLA, Fla., May 3.--The Supreme Court of Florida has rendered a decision of importance to the public and to railroad corporations. The Board of Railroad Commissioners created by the Legislature of Florida in 1887 fixed the rates for the Pensacola and Atlantic Railroad Company.

LONDON, May 3.--This was the last day of the Newmarket first Spring meeting. The race for the One-Thousand-Guinea Stakes, a subscription of 100 sovereigns each, half forfeit, 200 sovereigns to the second, and the third to save its stake, for three-year-old fillies, one mile, fortyeight subscribers, was won by Minthe, Wrinkle second, and Polka third.

Commenting upon a dispatch to THE TIMES from San Francisco relating to the probable erection of steel-rail mills in this country by English capitalists, the Allentown (Penn.) Register makes the following curious assertion:

A few years ago the voice of the Rev. Dr. Scott, father of the President's wife, gave out and he was obliged to stop preaching. He was living then at Oxford, Ohio. It occurred to him that he might possibly get a Government position in Washington, and he applied to his ...

BOSTON, Mass., May 3.--The reported disappearance of Samuel Fessenden, Treasurer of the Cape Cod Ship Canal, with a large indebtedness, created quite a stir in business circles to-day. Some weeks ago Fessenden, with his wife and daughter, went to California.

The height of athletic enthusiasm at Columbia College has been reached during the few days since the centennial celebration and will continue for the coming week. The regatta on Friday enlivened the interest in aquatics, and the annual spring games next Saturday will also add to the sport.

"The New-York police force grew from 2,519 members in 1880 to 3,351 in 1888. Notwithstanding this fact the Police Commissioners, in their last annual report, declare that an increase of the force is almost indispensably necessary.
ST. PAUL, Minn., May 3.--The progress of the traffic arrangement between the Northern Pacific and Wisconsin Central starts speculation as to probable changes in the heads of departments of the roads.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 3.--The movement begun about a year ago for organizing the hop growers of the State in local associations in affiliation with the State Brewers and Maltsters' Association for the promotion of what might be deemed their mutual interests seems to have met with complete failure.

BOSTON, Mass., May 3.--The will of the late Stanton Blake, filed in the Suffolk Probate Court, gives $10,000 to the Massachusetts General Hospital and $5,000 each to the Institute of Technology, the Museum of Fine Arts, and Harvard College.

PETERSBURG, Va., May 3.--Walter Harris and Robert Williams, two colored youths, aged about nineteen years each, were hanged to-day from the same scaffold at Hicksford, the County seat of Greensville. Harris murdered Anthony Parham on the 13th of November last.

Mr. S.F. Thayer of Minneapolis, Minn., the new Minister to the Netherlands, will sail for his post this morning on the steamship Veendam. He was entertained at dinner last night at the hotel Brunswick by several members of the Holland Society.

RALEIGH, N.C., May 3.--Deputy Collector B. B. Bouldin was fatally shot this afternoon while raiding a distillery in Johnston County. He was one of the bravest men in the Revenue Service and fired upon his assilants till he had emptied two revolvers when he was shot down.

The annual games of the Columbia, Grammar School were held at the Manhattan Athletic Club Grouuds yesterday. The success of the meeting was assured by the donation of $250 by the Principals of the school for prizes, and the great interest which has been taken in athletics this year by the boys.

The lantern-slide exhibition at the Society of Amateur Photographers' rooms, 122 West Thirty-sixth-street, last evening, consisted of 125 views taken by Mr. W.T. Wintringham of the Brooklyn Academy of Photography.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 3.--This city is to have a new fire-alarm system. The cost will be $5,000. The present alarm is very faulty and causes much annoyance when fires break out. The boxes for the new alarm arrived to-day and will be placed in position immediately. There will be an entirely new circuit, and a new switchboard with more powerful batteries will be put up at the central station.

Tschigorin surprised another of his opponents yesterday at the chess tournament. He played against Gossip in a "king's knight" gambit. Gossip displayed much willingness to beat his enemy.

LEROY, N.Y., May 3.--At 7:45 o'clock to-night flames were seen issuing from the cupola of W. D. Matthews Co.'s largest malthouse, situated on Church-street. The alarm was sounded by the company's whistles, and in a short time two heavy streams were in operation.

LONDON, May 3.--Advices from Massowah give details concerning the recent death of King John of Abyssinia. He made an attack March 10 on the dervishes, in their stronghold at Netemmeh, but his forces were defeated, the King being badly wounded.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 3.--It has come at last, and, though it was expected, satistaction and dissatisfaction are neither increased nor diminished at the appointment of Col. D.S. Alexander of this city to be United States District Attorney for the Northern District of New-York.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 3.--The Court of Appeals adjourned for a month to-day, without giving a decision on the constitutionality of the McEvey elevator law. It is intimated that this decision is withheld until after the adjournment of the Legislature to prevent a new law going through.

DIXON, Ill., May 3.--Forreston about twenty miles north of this city, on the illinois Central Railroad, was swept by fire this morning. Aid was telegraphed for to surrounding towns, and was promptly afforded.

ISHPEMING, Mich., May 3.--The Ishpeming and Grand Rapids Gold Company has just organized, and will mine for gold eight miles northwest of Ishpeming, where a promising body of quartz has been found. Fred Braastad of Ishpeming, owner of the Braasted Iron Mines, is President of the company.

Womwrath and James Dungan, two of the occupants, were killed. Several others were injured. The coach was demolished and its horses were killed.

The Juniors of Columbia College were in high glee yesterday afternoon. Their representative crew main won the class races of the college contested on the Harlam River.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 3.--The entire Lakeview stud of thoroughbreds was sold by Bruce Kidd here to-day. It was the property of the late Capt. John B. Wilgus, banker and capitalist, and cost that gentleman about $40,000.

Mayor Grant remained at his home yesterday. He was sick with a cold. Nursing himself for renewed struggling with the matter of appointment to public offices, he had time to consider the effect of the appointments he made on Thursday.

Abnor Mellen, formerly wholesale dealer in bedding supplies at 142 and 144 Worth-street, made an assignment Thursday to Gordon McKay. FINDLAY, Ohio, May 5.--In excavating gravel on a farm hear Van Buren, this county, yesterday, an Indian skeleton was unearthed, with a jar and some wampum shells. The skeleton was in a good state of preservation, and was taken charge of by Dr. George of Van Buren. The jar was of earthenware, very thin and dark. It was broken in getting it out.

Stockholders representing two-thirds of the stock of the Union Bank of 747 Fifth-avenue wound up the affairs of the bank by selling their interest to the Columbia Bank of 501 Fifth-avenue yesterday.

James Wordon, the night watchman of the Ontario Paper Mills of Watertown, N.Y., is suspected of setting fire to the mills at 1 o'clock yesterday morning. The mills were fired in a number of places, but were not destroyed owing to the good work of the Fire Department.

A well-dressed man, aged about thirtyfive years, was found unconscious on the east side drive of Central Park last night about 11:30 o'clock. He was taken to Roosevelt Hospital and is not expected to live through the night. The surgeons at the hospital were unable to say whether the man had taken poison or was suffering from epilepsy.

This purchase covers about all there is left of good fishing along this famous trout stream. Trouble between the new owner of the stream and anglers who have fished there for years is looked for.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 6.--Clergymen and prominent citizens representing the churches and the local branch of the Evangelical Alliance appeared before the Excise Board here today and protested against issuing licenses indiscriminately. It was charged that the excise law is openly violated on Sundays and that scores of places called hotels should be closed. A temperance war is foreshadowed.

MALDEN, Mass., May 6.--Ira W. Hopkins of this city, whose coat containing personal documents was found in the railroad wreck at Hamilton, Ontario, is safe at home. He intended taking the ill-fated train at Chicago, but missed it. His trunk, however, went forward. The railroad authorities telegraphed here yesterday inquiring as to Mr. Hopkins's whereabouts.

Cashier Guderian says that the bank has cash enough on hand to meet all calls, and has been offered any amount of outside financial aid. Citizens came to the bank's assistance to-day, and the run is about over.

ST. PAUL, May 8.--Shortly after 4 o'clock this morning it began to rain, accompanied by heavy thunder and lightning. MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 8.--A stock company composed of a dozen wealthy citizens has purchased a lot on Main-street, paying for it $60,000 cash, and will erect on it a theatre with a seating capacity of over two thousand. The theatre itself will have all the modern improvements and will cost $100,000. It is intended to have the building ready by the 1st of January if possible.

The famous thoroughbred brood mare Nevada is dead, the effects of dropping a foal to George Kinney. She was twenty years old, was a daughter of Lexington, her dam being Lightsome, a daughter of Glencoe, and her grand-dam was the famous brood mare Levity. It is estimated that deepdraught vessels are only loading about threefourths as heavily as usual.

The will of Henry G. Pearson was filed yesterday for probate in the Surrogate's office. It was executed March 10, 1883, and witnessed by E.S. Post and Haughwout Howe. Mr. Pearson's widow, Mrs. Ellen Mason Pearson, is made executrix, and receives all the property, both real and personal.
The New-York City members of the National Hotel Men's Association will leave the Grand Central Station at 5:50 o'clock next Sun day evening for Chicago, where the annual convention is to be held.

HARTFORD, May 8.--Gov. Bulkeley's experience with the Legislature during the past four months has convinced him that a general law providing for the issue of charters by the Secretary of State similar to the joint stock law in its operations would be of great benefit to the State.
One of the greatest newspaper buildings in the world has just been completed for THE NEW-YORK TIMES, and was graphically described in last Monday's issue of our illustrious contemporary.

The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New-York has just issued its thirty-first annual report for the year ending May 1. It includes a valuable review of the commerce of the country and of the city for the last 100 years.

The final rehearsal of Gilbert and Offenbach's comic opera, "The Brigands," was held at the Casino yesterday, and the work will be presented to-night.

AUBURN, N.Y., May 8.--James D. Fish, the President of the Marine Bank of New-York City, who was convicted of misapplying the funds of the bank and causing its failure, will be released from prison Saturday next.
BALTIMORE, May 8.--The Johns Hopkins Hospital, which was formally opened yesterday, is thought to be the most richly endowed, largest, and best institution of the kind in the world.

WINNIPEG, May 8.--Lord Lonsdale arrived here last night from San Francisco, coming via the Canadian Pacific Railway, and bringing with him his guides and dogs. ALBANY, May 9.--The Mayor's Rapid-Transit bill was formally killed this morning in the Assembly, and unless a new deal is made between Mayor Grant and Mr. Platt it never will be resuscitated.

NEW-HAVEN, May 9.--The rumor which has been circulating for the past six months to the effect that ex-Minister Phelps would resume his duties as professor in the Yale Law School was verified to-day by the issuance of a prospectus of the elective studies, with a course in law by Prof. Phelps.
BALTIMORE, May 9.--Favorites captured every one of the races here to-day, contests that were in every instance without sensational features.

BOSTON, May 9.--With Welch sick, Crane injured, and George and Titcomb out of condition the Giants were without a pitcher to-day. Capt. Ewing, however, was equal to the emergency. He resolved to do some curving himself, and put big "Bill" Brown behind the bat.

The Yantic has been ordered to put to sea from New-York with a supply of torpedoes for the purpose of searching for and destroying derelicts and obstructions to navigation off the Atlantic coast in the track of ocean steamers and coasting vessels.

The report of the Health Department to the Dock Board, which was made in February last and which called attention to the bad sanitary condition of a large portion of the water front, bore its first fruit yesterday.

William Gillette returned to New-York yesterday from his home in Hartford, Conn., where he has been for some time at work on an entirely original play which is to be produced next season. The subject, like that of "Held By The Enemy," is based on incidents of the civil war.

MONTREAL, May 10.--Last night a largely-attended meeting was held in Knox Church, at which the Rev. Principal MacVier, the head and font of the movement, presided. NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., May 10.--Moreextensive improvements are being made at the Pier this season than in any previous year of its history.

RALEIGH, N.C., May 10.--Memorial Day was observed here to-day with unusual ceremonies. The stores were closed, and there was a military display. Gov. A.M. Scales, whose brigade.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 10.--The examination of the cadets of the six-year graduating class commenced to-day, It will continue ten days. The examination of candidates for admission into the Academy will take place next week, beginning Wednesday. The graduating exercises will take place on June 7, the ball occurring on the evening of the same day.

MONTREAL, May 10.--A customs seizure has been made here in which $35,000 is involved. The firm in trouble is F. Gioroux Co., and the stock consists of French notions, perfumery, curtains, drapery, and wines. The customs officers made the seizure on a charge of undervaluation, and say that the invoices place them at half cost.

An Omaha Republican paper remarks that "it is not at all probable that the President knew anything about VANDERVOORT, or had even heard of him." and insists that the Nebraska members of Congress should be held responsible for the man's appointment because they labored to put him into the public service and have succeeded in "humiliating the State before the country."

NEW-ORLEANS, May 10.--The remains of Gen. William S. Harney, who died at Orlando, Fla., Thursday, were shipped to Washington to-day for interment at Arlington.

The remains of a man, apparently about thirty years of age, were found floating in the Erie Canal at Utica, N.Y., yesterday. Both legs are badly crushed below the knees, and there is a wound in the left breast. In a pocket was found a ticket from Rochester to Glens Falls via the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad to Schenectady, and the Delaware and Hudson from there. The body has not been identified.

SANTA BARBARA, Cal., May 10.--The United States cruiser Charleston will put to sea early this morning. The naval engineers have been working with results shown by the cards taken during the downward passage from San Francisco ...

Miss Alethea M. Hunt, daughter of George W. Hunt, one of the civil engineers of the aqueduct and an old resident of Brooklyn, was married Thursday evening to William A. Caywood, son of the Hon. David Caywood of the same city.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 10.--Whooping cought has many victims here. In Long Branch City, the more aristocratic portion of the place, there are seventeen cases. No deaths have as yet been reported.

Mayor Grant, at about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, after several consultations with Bourke Cockran, William H. Clark, James J. Martin, and other leaders of Tammany Hall, appointed just one Police Justice and no more-- his personal friend, Daniel F. McMahon.

Special Tax Collector Michael J. Bourke of the old town of New-Lots, who is short $20,000 in his accounts, kept in hiding yesterday.
NEWBURG, N.Y., May 10.--Farmers along the Hudson are being victimized by a new style of lightning-rod swindle.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 10.--The funeral of Count Toistol, late Minister of the Interior, took place to-day, The Czar was present. He has presented to the widow 200,000 rubles and granted her a yearly pension of 6,000 rubles.
The Commencements of Columbia College will be held this year at the Metropolitan Opera House. The Law School will, as heretofore, have their exercises in the evening of June 12.

BERLIN, May 10.--There was an encounter near Brackel, Westphalia, to-day between the troops and strikers. A large body of the latter had gathered and were becoming disorderly, when they were ordered to disperse by the officer in command of the military. The strikers refused to obey the order.
After being practically at a standstill all day, yesterday's stock market displayed a little spirit at the close. The bears got in some fine work, knocking almost everything off fractionally.

Edward Everett Hale delivered a lecture on the public school question last night at the Berkeley Lyceum under the auspices of the Public Education Society. Prof. J.S. Newberry, President of the society, introduced Dr. Hale, who spoke extemporaneously and in a conversational style.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 10--State Auditor Braden yesterday consulted Attorney General Clapp with reference to the new law relating to the foreclosure of landf and the refunding of moneys paid at tax sales. A large number of f Eastern capitalists are interested in the matter. The case in question was the first one to come up under this law, and the points involved were of such a nature that a legal authority was necessary.

The New-York Deaconesse's Home, 241 West Fourteenth-street, was formally opened last night by a reception to about three hundred ladied and gentlemen prominent in the charitable work of the Methodist Church, Bishop Andrews presided over the formal exercises, which included addresses by Dr. Crawford. ELIZABETH, N.J., May 10.--Cashier David Snodgrass of the Sugar Manufacturing Works at Elizabethport was buried this morning from St. Patrick's Church. Solemn requiem mass was celebrated by the Rev. Father Gossner, assisted by the Rev. Fathers Carroll and Mcchan. The officials and clerks of the company attended in a body with a large number of the employes.

The school ship St. Mary's will start at 10 o'clock this morning on her annual cruise. Last evening when the order "Visitors ashore!" enforced a parting between the boys and many of their friends there were 98 of the sailor lads on board, but 12 more were expected to arrive this morning.

The Actors' Amateur Athletic Association jumped up another peg yesterday. Its baseball nine defeated the County Fair team by a score of 27 to 10. The actors' nine was made up of J. Ott, second base; J.F. Hoey, centre field; J. Carroll, short stop; Burr W. Mcfutosh, first base; Charles Mitchell, third base; M. By far the most important fact brought out by the sessions in this city of the Committee on Inter-State Commerce is that nobody concerned desires the repeal of the law creating the commission.

NASHVILLE, May 10.--After the first race at the West Side trace to-day Gen. W.H. Jackson, one of the presiding judges, announced to the people present that Jockey James McLaughlin and the horse Torra Cotta, who were ruled off the track yesterday because the horse was pulled in the Rock City Handicap, had been reinstated.

The vexed question of the tariff on worsteds and woolens was up for a hearing before Collector Erhardt yesterday. Appraiser Cooper, Naval Officer Burt, Deputy Naval Officer Comstock, Deputy Collector McClelland, and other officials were present.

Thomas Murray, who was thrown from a Myrtle-avenue car at Smith-street on Dec. 22 and had his left leg cut off, got a verdict for $18,000 against the Brooklyn City Railroad yesterday in Judge Osborne's part of the Supreme Court. This is the largest amount of damages ever found against this company.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 10.--"White Capism" has broken out in Mitchell County. A family named Nix, living a few miles from Camilla, were visited a fortnight ago by a band of marauders who took Nix and his wife and three daughters into the yard and subjected them to a most cruel beating. Two men who were visiting Nix were likewise treated, after having fought desperately.

Sixty or seventy graduates of Brown University sat down to dinner last night at Delmonico's--a dinner given to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of Prof. John L. Lincoln's service as an officer of the university.

RAHWAY, N.J., May 10.--A serious fire occurred in the suburbs of this city early this morning. Three large houses, known as the Muller property, in Scott-avenue and Luffberrystreet, were totally destroyed.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 10.--Drafts, sight, 7 ; telegraphic, 12 .

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 10.--John Cavalier, a veteran of the war of 1812, died this morning in his one hundred and second year. Cavalier died on the township poor form at Middlebush, where he had been supported for some time.

Since the Senate Committee on General Laws submitted its first report concerning Trusts and similar combinations, on March 6, 1888, the views of the majority of the committee have undergone a curious but not inexplicable change.

RED BANK, N.J., May 10.--The new Board of Town Commissioners last night elected ex-Postmaster William Applegate Town Treasurer. Four saloon licenses were granted. The license fee is $150. SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 10.--An important opium seizure was made to-day. It had been suspected for some time that the drug was being smuggled from China in trunks coming in free of duty as baggage. The Pacific Mail steamer City of New-York arrived to-day from the Orient. Three Chronicle reporters having, secured a tip, were on the lookout for suspicious looking baggage.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 10.--The Ocean Clubhouse was entered by thieves last night. They succeeded in getting away with all the keys to the bedrooms but failed to break open the safe.

BOSTON, May 10.--Keefe pitched his first League game to-day and the Giants won in handsome style. The appearance of the genial expert curver seemed to inspire the boys with confidence, and they played with rare vim and determination.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 10.--The New-England fast freigt train from Boston going west over the Erie Road met with an accident this morning near Guymard station, eleven miles west of here.

CHICAGO, May 10.--The big steamship Chemung came down the lake front early this morning with the speed of a railroad train. She was on the home stretch of the greatest long-distance run ever made on fresh water.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 10.--The body of a man was found floating in the harbor yesterday afternoon, and was subsequently identified as that of Albert Sutton, an Englishman, thirty years of age, who had until a few weeks ago been employed by Oscar Summers, a butcher of this village.
William H. Wolverton, President of the New-York Transfer Company, complained to Inspector Byrnes a week ago that several trunks and packages had been mysteriously tampered with while in transit.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., May 10.--A convention of the American Society of Civil Engineers will be held at the Octagon House on June 26. About 250 delegates and visitors will be present, and the convention will be in session for one week.

HALIFAX, N.S., May 10.--Surrogate Payzant delivered judgment to-day in the celebrated McLeod will ease. The will was disputed by the representatives of the brother of Alexander McLeod, the testator, who left the bulk of his large estate, valued at $500,000, to Dalhousie College. The decision confirms the will and codieils. The case is to the appealed to the Supreme Court.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 10.--Andrew Carnegie, in an interview here to-day, predicts that some of the evils of discriminations in freight rates, about which he recently complained in open letters and in an address to the Pennsylvania Legislature, will soon be corrected by the Pennsylvania Railroad.

The Spring run of striped bass, as the fish is called among the local anglers, struck the town last Sunday and has, maintained itself fairly well since. The warm weather of the week was a boon to the fishermen. It stirred up the bass into good biting humor and made the sport agreeable.

ST. LOUIS, May 10.--The Chicago, Burlington and Quiney has at last secured fine terminal facilities in this city. For several years agents of the Burlington have been quietly buying up such land as was needed, but the strictest secrecy has been maintained until to-day, when their movements were made public.

WASHINGTON, May 10.--The President made the following appointments to-day: United States Attorneys.--GEORGE D. REY- NOLDS of Missouri, for the Eastern District of Missouri; ELBERT E. KIMBALL of Missouri, for the Westen District of Missouri.

Mrs. Hemser, wife of the Treasurer of Hoboken Branch of Lady Lincoln Lodge, Knights and Ladies of Honor, reports the sudden disappearance of her husband from his home on Grand-street, Heboken, last Wednesday. He was to have met the lodge that evening to pay $200 on account of $1,000 due a Mrs. Schroeder, whose husband had died while a member of the lodge. His books are being examined.

Many a humble home in the down-town seat-side section is to-day adorned with a beautiful silk American flag. At Primary School No. 34, at 293 Pearl-street, yesterday afternoon centennial commemoration exercises were held.

NEW-HAVEN, May 10.--The semi-centennial observance of the founding of Odd Fellowship in Connecticut is already being arranged for and promises to be the greatest assemblage of the order ever held in the State. The event will be celebrated on Sept. 3, in this city. The first lodge created was Quinnipiae Lodge, No. 1 of this city, and the occasion will also mark this lodge's inception.

Henry G. Marquand and Richard Watson Gilder, the Chairman and Secretary of the association which proposes to erect the memorial arch at Fifth-avenue and Washingtonsquare, called upon the Mayor yesterday afternoon.

Between heat, humidity, and wind yesterday was the most uncomfortable 10th of May experienced in this city for fifteen years. Morning broke with the sunbeams struggling through a thick haze. The atmosphere became hotter and hotter as the day progressed.

The first consignment of corn this season via the Erie Canal arrived yesterday, consigned to the Produce Exchange. There were three boatloads, or 23,800 bushels, and as spot corn was short the arrival was welcome. One of the boatloads sold at 46 cents a bushel for export.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 10.--The Park public school at Perth Amboy has been closed owing to the prevalence of scarlet fever.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 10.--Patrick Murray's three-story frame dwelling house, on Lloyd-street, was Instantly demolished by a cyclone shortly before 5 o'clock to-day, and sixteen workmen that were near the top of the building went down with it, Six of the men were seriously injured, and two of them may die.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 10.--A very old man, with a flowing white beard, but still active in his movements, was picked up by the police on the street here the other night on the charge of being drunk.

Commissioner Gilroy lifted his official axe a few times yesterday, and every time it came down, except once, a County Democrat's head fell. That once was when he attempted to decapitate Martin J. Keese, who for eight years has been the janitor of the City Hall.

The Commissioners appointed a year ago by Judge Knapp to select sites for one or more parks in Hudson County have chosen four sites, and will give a hearing in the Court House on Jersey City Heights to-day to property owners.

GALVESTON, Texas, May 10.--The Board of United States Engineers which is here under Governmental appointment to make an investigation of the Texas coast for the purpose of recommending to Congress such point or points upon this coast as are most available for the location of a first-class harbor held a public session here to-day for the purpose of hearing suggestions.

The decision of Judge Young of Minneapolis in the case of the appeal of the Minneapolis and St. Louis Road from the order of the Minnesota Railroad Commission that the upper berth, when occupied, should be lowered or closed according to the wishes of the persons occupying the lower berth will be appealed from by the Railroad Commission.
LONDON, May 10.--The steamship Hindoo sld. from Hull for New-York yesterday. The steamship Persian Monarch, (Br.,) Capt. Bristow, from New-York April 28, arr. at Havre to-day.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 10.--The steamship City of New-York arrived to-day from Hong-Kong and Yokohama, bringing advices to April 24.

An important, railway deal was consummated in Wall-street yesterday. The Richmond Terminal Company bought at private sale all the outstanding minority stock of the Richmond and Danville Railroad Company.

The Reform Club of this city has begun to distribute letters among the farmers of the United States with the purpose of ascertaining whether or not they are gaining in wealth and social influence or are receding.

Steamship Britannie. (Br.,) Parsell, Liverpool and Queenstown 9 ds., with indse. and passengers to J. Bruce Ismay. Arrived at the Bar at 3:50 A.M. Steamship Olbers, (Belg.,) Gregory, Santos and Rio Janeiro 26 ds., with indse, and passengers to Busk Jevons. Arrived at the Bar at 2 A.M.
"President Harrison has aged considerably since he entered his high office," a Fifthavenue photographer said yesterday. "His beard is whiter than it was just previous to his inauguration.

A special meeting of the National Democratic Committee will be held at the FifthAvenue Hotel June 12 for the purpose of electing a Chairman of the committee in place of William H. Barnum and of adopting a suitable memorial of his life and work. The call for the meeting is issued by S.P. Sheerin of Indiana, the Secretary of the National Committee, at the request of the members of the Executive Committee.

As compared with old-time railroading, that of the present day is a marvel of perfected science. Instead of the old method of running trains haphazard, the public demands a schedule accurate in time on which trains and boats may and dorun, making their connections to the minute.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 10.--The thirty-fourth session, forty-third year, of the Southern Baptist Convention assembled in this city at the First Baptist Church this morning, vice President L.B. Ely of Missouri in the chair. Six hundred and seventy two delegates were enrolled.

PORT EWEN, N.Y., May 10.--While a workman named Van Vliet was digging at the foot of sand hill on Kline's brickyard here to-day a human skull rolled down the bank and rested at his feet. He and a number of other men scarched in the hole in the blank from which the skull had rolled. A skeleton was found.

Gossip was beaten by Burn at yesterday's chess tournament, and he attributed his defeat to the fact that his chair was too low. Several days ago, when Tschigorin beat him, Gossip complained that the coffee which he had drank was bad, but Tschigorin had partaken of the same coffee from the same restaurant.
Albert Fitzgerald, a Montreal youth of pleasing address, is under arrest at Police Headquarters for a series of thefts committed in the Grand Central Hotel in Broadway during the centennial.
FREEHOLD, N.J., May 10.--The Board of Chosen Freeholders in February ordered County Auditor JOhn P. Applegate to discover the amount of license fees due the county.
LANCASTER, Penn., May 10.--Gen. Simon Cameron was attacked with a slight hemorrhage last night, but his condition to-day was reported improved and not believed to be serious.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 10.--The approach of the annual meeting of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul, coupled with the fact that there are two vacancies in the Board of Directors, has given rise to all sorts of stories.

CHICAGO, May 10.--Following the example of Inspector Byrnes of New-York, Capt. Michael J. Schaack of the Chicago police force has written a book. This product of the Captain's brain deals with his experience as a police officer, and recounts in detail the growth of anarchy in Chicago, which culminated in the Haymarket riot and the hanging of the leaders.

It has been an interesting day in the Senate, and in spite of the almost overwhelming heat a good deal of Important work has been accomplished. The chief event was the discussion over the Rhodes Anti-Bucket-Shop bill, which took up almost the entire session. The opponents to this measure, although few in number, made up in verbosity what they lacked in soundness of argument.

While the New-Jersey Central Railroad Company's drawbridge between Bergen Point and Elizabethport was closed about noon yesterday a heavily-laden schooner ran into it, forcing a passage after her two masts had been carried away.

Brooklyn was visited by a small-sized cyclone about 5:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon that unroofed houses and uprooted trees and telegraph poles in various parts of the city. The blow lasted only about seven minutes, but during that time it was almost impossible to get about the streets. The dust was so thick that pedestriaus could not see ten feet in front of them.

BROWN'S VALLEY, Minn., May 10.--A large number of people are arriving here daily in anticipation of the opening of the Sisseton Reservation. A company of from seventy-five to one hundred men have been organized and will move on to the reservation near this place to-morrow or Sunday and squat on the lands not taken by Indians under the allotment act. There is much excitement in this and adjoining towns.

Although the Charleston is the third of the war vessels constructed by the late Administration, and the novelty of success is thus somewhat worn away, yet for several reasons her trial trip possesses a special interest and importance.

Burglars entered the dry goods store of John Bolton, at 522 Fifth-avenue. Brooklyn, on Thursday night, and stole a small safe. It was found yesterday afternoon in a lot at Secondavenue and Third-street. The thieves had been unable to break it open.

So much has been said about the separation of those capital comedians, Robson and Crane, that the public may not be inclined to look upon an account of their last joint appear ance as a matter of news.
A large number of well-known persons started on a transatlantic journey yesterday, and the passenger lists of all the outgoing steamers were very long.

VIENNA, April 28.--The most famous insane asylum in the world, at any rate as far as the rank and station of its inmates is concerned, is that of Drs. krafft-Ebing and Von Leidesdorff at Doebling, a pretty village situated about an hour's drive from this city.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 11.--C.B. Mitchell of New-Jersey, Maitland Alexander of New-York, and R.S. Life of New-York have been announced as debaters to represent Whig Hall in the Lynde prize debate at the Princeton Commencement. A.R. Gulick of New-Jersey is alternate.

PITTSBURG, May 11.--The mines of the Chartiers Block Coal Company, at Toms Run, a few miles from Chartiers, Allegheny County, were the scene of a terrific explosion of firedamp this morning, resulting in the instant killing of four Hungarian miners and great damage to the mines.

GENEVA, April 20.--Some of the political institutions of Switzerland merit the attention of American leaders in public reform. The natural rights of the citizen are here more fully recognized than in any other country.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 11.--The annual convention of the Women's Christian Temperance Union of New-Jersey will be held in Asbury Park on Oct. 15, 16, and 17. It is expected that 300 delegates, representing 213 unions, will be present. Col. George W. Bain will address them, and it is probable that Frances E. Willard, the national President of the society, will also be present.

BERLIN, May 11.--The Samoan conference held a plenary sitting to-day. The Committee on the Government of Samoa agreed upon a constitutional council, composed of native chiefs elected by the natives, the council to be dominated by a ministry in which each treaty power shall have one representative.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 11.--One of the largest seizures of opium made at this port took place after the arrival of the Pacific Mail steamer City of New-York yesterday afternoon. Deputy Surveyor Fogarty and an inspector seized five large trunks which were filled with opium and labeled "An King, Panama."

PRINCETON, N.J., May 11.--In the doorway of the Post Office this afternoon an unknown German drew a pistol and shot Jacob Tash through the left breast. Tash died within four minutes.

WASHINGTON, May 11.--To-day's bond offerings aggregated $40,000 registered four and a halfs at 108 flat. All were accepted.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 11.--Mr. Herbert W. Ladd, Republican, who will in all probability be elected to the Governorship at the May session of the Legislature, has announced that his first appointments will be his staff. For these honors he names Roscoe S. Washburn, Henry A. Du Villard, and William T. Nicholson, Jr., of Providence; the Hon. Addison Hopkins of Burrillville, Col. Henry D. Harden of Warwick, and Mr. Joseph T. Perry of Newport.

The stated shooting season of the National Guard at Creedmoor is to be opened on May 20 by the Seventh Regiment, which will occupy the range for five days, a detachment of two companies practicing each day. Twenty-eight days additional have been set apart for the use of the organizations of the First Brigade, but the dates have not yet been assigned.

The trouble which has been brewing all Winter between the jockey clubs and the Turf Alliance, the organization of bookmakers, has culminated in a refusal of the bookmakers to pay more than $60 a day for the privilege of making books on the track of the Brooklyn Jockey Club at the meeting which opens next Wednesday.

The second annual entertainment under the auspices of the Choristers' League of the Church of the Heavenly Rest will be given at the assembly rooms of the Metropolitan Opera House next Wednesday evening at 8 o'clock. The programme consists of a minstrel entertainment by members of the league, orchestral selections, vocal and instrumental soles, recitations, and exhibitions of magic and legerdemain. All the performers are amateurs. The band music will be furnished by Cappa.

NORWALK, Conn., May 11.--Mrs. Huldah Rockwell, widow of Joseph Rockwell, should she live until Monday, Aug. 19 next, will be 100 years old. "Granny," as she is familiarly called, was born at Fairfield, now Westport, Aug. 19, 1789.

The eleventh attempt of the Society of American Artists to interest the picture-viewing and picture-buying world of New-York is the first which bears on its face the possibility of success in a financial way. Hitherto their exhibitions have been handicapped by the bad light of the gallery or its indifferent position.

The wiring of the Parliament Building in Vienna has been quite ingeniously accomplished, the principal cable running through one of the many ventilating pipes, the wires being carried through the gas piping, thereby allowing the elaborate decorations on the walls to remain uninjured.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 11.--The Harvard Bicycle Club held its first race meening this afternoon. The first event, a scratch race of one mile for safety bicycles, was won by R. H. Davis of the Harvard Club, E.A. Bailey of the Hartford Club second.

LENOX, Mass., May 11.--The mercury has climbed into the nineties this week, a point higher than it has reached in May before since the records have been kept. It is seldom that the heat is as intense in midsummer as it has ...

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 11.--There is more trouble between Gen. J. Madison Drake of Elizabeth and his old antagonists among the Grand Army men of this city. Drake refuses to let his command, the Veteran Zouaves, or Grant Post take part in the Grand Army parade on Decoration Day unless they get the right of the line.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., May 11.--On the County Clerk's book for applications for citizenship in these United States is the signature "Ovid Bertold Seran Agnan Musin," which the great violinist put there this morning.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 11.--Five negroes and seven whites were whipped at Newcastle this afternoon for larceny, highway robbery, and horse stealing. Three of the whites, for burglary, were given forty lashes and one hour in the pillory each, and one of the negroes took twenty lashes and one hour in the pillory for horse stealing. About one hundred and fifty spectators were present.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 11.--Officials of the Standard Oil Company in this city have been very quiet over the move toward building a refinery at or near Chicago.

Strenuous efforts have been made by Mayor Chapin and his associates to induce the Rev. Dr. Richard S. Storrs to withdraw his resignation as a Brooklyn Park Commissioner. The board passed resolutions urging such action, but Dr. Storrs said yesterday that he had no intention of returning to the office he recently vacated.
SANTA BARBARA, Cal., May 11.--The new United States steamar Charleston left port at 7 o'clock this morning for Point Magu, below Ventura, whence she will make her four hours' run to Conception.

ST. PAUL, May 11.--Senator Scheffer was present in the Municipal Court room to-day and conferred with Judge Burr concerning the enforcement of the drunkards law. The Judge declared the law a very good one, and, beginning next Monday, any person found guilty of having been drunk will be punished with heavy fines or imprisonment. The Spring games of the Stevens Institute Athletic Association which come off on Friday afternoon next are looked forward to with great interest. Quite a number of students are in training for them, and there will probably be more entries than there have been in any previous year.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 11.--The yachting season will open in about a week, and during the next few days three new boats are to be launched. George Masters will lauch his boat, the Quaker City.

Twenty-two members of the New-York Riding Club, headed by President Howard Carroll, and eighteen members of the Kings County Riding Club, led by President H.G. Hull, had the first regular Spring outdoor horseback ride of the season yesterday afternoon.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 11.--Serious charges were filed in the Probate Court yesterday against P.J. Cadwallader, a prominent attorney. The heirs of the estate of J.A. Gordon of this city, who reside in Boston and Wercester, Mass., charge that he has illegally collected some $23,000 from the estate.

NORWALK, Conn., May 11.--Destructive fires, most of which are of an incendiary origin, have been alarmingly frequent in the Western part of Fairfield County during the past few weeks, and the number of conflagrations in Nowalk and its immediate vicinity alone are growing rapidly.

With the exception of the usual throng who follow the turf, race week brought wish it few of those social lights whose presence at former meetings of the Maryland Jockey Club gave to those events great social prominence. There was a notable absence of all those large entertainments which in former years characterized the meetings, and, with the exception of a few small dinners given at the Baltimore and Maryland Clubs, nothing of important occurred.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 11.--An awful tragedy occurred in Kansas City, Mo., this afternoon at 2 o'clock, in which Detective William Gilley had his throat cut and a noted burglar, James Smith, was instantly killed. The detective's throat was ripped open with a knife, and the burglar was filled with bullets and died ...
A servant girl in Easton, Penn., who recently died, left $500 to the German Lutheran Church, and $5,000 to a granddaughter of her employer. The money was all saved out of her wages.
HOLLY, N.Y., May 11.--A sensation was caused this morning by the fact that Mrs. Polly Smith, wife of George Smith, has been found drowned in Sandy Creek, three miles north of this village.

JAMESTOWN, May 11.--The experiment of propagating muskailonge at the Chautauqua Lake station of the fish hatchery has proved a failure this year and the station will be tenantless until another Spring, when the seines will be drawn earlier.

The National Academy of Design closes its doors on the sixty-fourth Spring exhibition with $23,060 to its credit from the sale of sixtysix pictures. The attendance during the centennial week was not particularly large, and the sales for the whole term of the exhibition are very much the same as last year.

The glee and banjo clubs of Columbia College had slight occasion to cavil at the warmth of appreciation accorded their efforts at Chickering Hall last evening. The enthusiasm of the audience equaled its extent, and a neat sum must have been added to the treasury of the boat club and athletic and baseball associations of the college, for whose benefit the concert was given.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11.--At the meeting of the International Convention of the Young Men's Christian Association to-day the Secretary read the list of subscriptions since yesterday for the prosecution of the work of the International Committee.

RED BANK, N.J., May 11.--The Board of Water Commissioners organized last night by electing John H. Cook President, W.T. Corliss Secretary, and John S. Applegate Treasurer. It is the intention of the board to have two three-inch artesian wells driven soon, which will more than double the present water supply. The mains are to be extended and will be laid in nearly every street in the town.

Collector Erhardt gave his decision yesterday on the question as to whether worsteds should be classed as wollens and be burdened with as much tariff as there is on woolens. The decision was in favor of the woolen men, who demanded that the tariff on worsteds be put up.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11.--To-morrow will be George W. Childs's birthday, and as the event falls on the Sabbath a great many printers throughout the country, or rather east of the Mississippi River, to-day set up their "thousand ems."
