BELVIDERE, N.J., May 11.--At Mountain Home, Monroe County, Penn., yesterday, Jeffrey Harrison, aged eleven years, shot and killed Sophia Everett, aged ten. While the two were playing together at Harrison's home they quarreled, and the boy ran up stairs and got a loaded shotgun. The little girl became frightened and ran into another room. The boy forced his way in and, aiming the gun, fired. The youthful murderer is in custody.

The unseasonable heat, combined with the threatening clouds which intermittently blackened the skies yesterday afternoon, had a naturally depressing effect on the matinee business of the theatres, and all the houses suffered more or less. Considering the weather, however, the business was remarkably good, and every manager offering an attraction worthy of patronage figured up a reasonable profit as the result of his afternoon venture.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., May 11.--Lovers of the huckleberry can congratulate themselves on the prospect of a big crop of that favorite wild fruit during the coming season. The Shawangunk Mountains, from Lake Mohonk to the Delaware River, show every evidence that the largest crop for many years will be gathered ...

COLUMBIA, Tenn., May 11.--The last day of the Scotch-Irish congress was opened by a stirring extemporaneous speech by the Hon. Benton McMillin, who said that not a single member of the Scotch-Irish race so far as he knew had ever been an Anarchist or a Socialist.

BALTIMORE, May 11.--The stockholders of the Canton Company have addressed a petition to the President and Directors asking for the consideration of some plan looking to the final closing up of the affairs of the company.

AUBURN, N.Y., May 11.--James D. Fish, exPresident of the Marine Bank of New-York City, was discharged from the Auburn Prison this morning after serving three years ten months and fifteen days of a ten years' sentence for wrecking the bank. On Jan. 28 last his sentence was commuted by President Cleveland so that it expired to-day.

There were reported at the Sanitary Bureau during the past week 782 deaths, 692 births, and 350 marriages. The deaths numbered 51 more than the preceding week. There were 8 deaths from measles, 48 from Scarlet fever, 43 from diphtheria, 24 from whooping cough, 4 from typhoid fever.
ST. PAUL, May 11.--The wholesale grocers in Minnesota have entered into a compact to refuse to give any prices on goods at the time of selling or before the goods are shipped.

Patrolman William White of the Fifth Precinct ended a brief and inglorious career in the Police Department yesterday by tendering his resignation, which was promptly accepted.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 11.--Henry M. Frisble, convicted of embezzlement, was to-day sentenced to the penitentiary for one year. He is a member of the bar, and was once convicted in the United States Court of pension frauds. Frisbie was Lieutenant Colonel of an Indiana Regiment. Colonel of the Ninety-second Corps D'Afrique, and a Brigadier General by brevet.

BOSTON, May 11.--Two damaging errors in the eighth inning to-day by the Giants changed a victory to a defeat. The misplays gave the local team 3 runs--just enough to carry off the contest, Crane and Welch are still on the sick list, and Hatfield was put in to pitch. Gore is lame and his position was taken by little George.

PORTLAND, Me., May 12.--George S. Rowell and Walter C. Emerson have purchased the entire stock in the Portland Advertiser, owned by the late Hobart W. The residence of Mr. T.W. Bourne, in New-York-avenue, Clifton, S.I., was visited by one or more burglars Saturday afternoon during the absence of the family. An easy entrance was made by raising a rear window, left unfastened. Silverware valued at $500, comprising part of the wedding presents of the family received two years ago, was stolen. The police were notified promptly, but thus far have not discovered much to encourage them.

ALBANY, May 12.--The Boston and Albany Railroad makes the following report for the last quarter: Gross earnings, $1,998,996 21; operating expenses, $1,414,808 63; net earnings, $584,187 58; fixed charges, $223,828 43; net incomes, $350,359 15; cash on hand, $407,493 22; profit and loss, deficiency, $537,977 91.

OKLAHOMA, Indian Territory, May 12.--Three weeks ago Oklahoma, which has sprung into national fame, was barren of settlers. To-day there is scarcely a quarter section in all its 2,800 miles that has not been located or filed on, and its population is estimated at 20,000.

LONDON, May 13.--A conspiracy has been discovered among the military officers stationed in St. Petersburg. A large number of the conspirators have been arrested. CHICAGO, May 13.--The Cattle market was very liberally supplied to-day, and at the opening of business the prospects appeared rather gloomy. BINGHAMTON, N.Y., May 14.--D. Gannah, engineer of Erie Train No. 8, was killed this morning near Dalton, on the Buffalo division. He was leaning out of the cab window and was struck by a mail pouch catcher. The accident was not discovered until the train had gone some distance. Gannah's home was in Buffalo. He leaves a widow and one child.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 14.--Along portions of the Hudson River and in the Catskill Mountains this evening there was a severe electric storm. The court of inquiry recently appointed to investigate the recent disappearance of Paymaster Henry Smith of the Essex convened yesterday at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The board consists of Commodore Erbein, Capt. Reid, Paymaster Putnam, and Lieut. Nickels. The only witness examined was Dr. Chichester, who attended Paymaster Smith during his absence, and who told of the injuries to Mr. Smith's thumb, which the witness doctored. The investigation will go on to-day.

LANCASTER, Penn., May 14.--A storm of unusual violence visited this section last night, and lightning struck a large barn, part frame and part stone, belonging to the Rev. John Newcomer, about a mile east of Mountville, and all efforts to save it proved unavailing The barn, with all its contents, save the live stock, was destroyed. Three pigs were burned, but the horses and cattle were saved.

The village of Jamaica, L.I., is suffering from the depredations of sneak thieves and burglars. During the last two weeks a dozen chicken roosts have been robbed and two houses entered. Early yesterday morning an attempt was made to enter the hotel of James Charlick, at East Jamaica. Mr. Charlick fired two shots at the thieves, but without effect. The citizens will hold a meeting to devise some way to secure police protection.

Early in the season bait fishing for trout on Long Island is more successful than the more scientific work of the fly caster. From this time forward until July the fly caster's sport will be grand and the most enjoyable season is perhaps right now when the scent of the apple blossoms pervades the air, and when all nature is smiling.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., May 14--Connecticut people are not forgetting that here in their own State lie the ashes of one of Washington's dearest friends and trusted counselors, a man who, next to Washington, stood in the front rank in the service for his country during the long Revolutionary period--"Brother Jonathan" Trumbull.

A misplaced switch on the Brooklyn, Bath Beach and West End Railroad was the cause of a serious and almost fatal railroad accident at the Unionville yards a little after 10 o'clock on Monday night. Three passengers were severely injured, several others were slightly hurt, and three of the company's locomotives were damaged but not badly enough to prevent their use yesterday.

Some years ago catfish were taken from the Erie Canal and placed in Chautauqua Lake. The experiment proved gratifying, as the improvement in the species has been marked. Now Chautauqua catfish are in great demand. When cooked the flavor of the meal is so near that of brook trout that some persons are deceived.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 14.--The pending litigation in the celebrated Sharon divorce case was practically ended yesterday by a decision of the United States Supreme Court affirming the decision of the Circuit Court declaring the alleged marriage contract between ex-Senator William Sharon and Sarah Althea Hill a forgery.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 14.--A local paper explains the ability of Bishop to perform the cabinet feats as follows: He was a contortionist and had the power of dislocating his joints at will.
To-day the Eastern racing season of 1889 opens with the meeting of the Brooklyn Jockey Club at the Gravesend track.

An anniversary meeting of the Woman's Boards of Foreign and Domestic Missions of the Reformed Church of America was held in the Collegiate Reformed Church, at Fortyeighth-street and Fifth-avenue, yesterday. The morning session was given up to the reading of reports and addresses on foreign missions.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 14.--The count of the votes at the School Board election was not completed till 2 o'clock this morning, occupying nearly as long a time as the balloting itself. Two thousand four hundred and fortyseven votes were east, and the citizens' ticket was found to be in the majority by nearly two to one, having 756 more votes than the regular ticket. Three hundred and sixty-three women voted.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 14.--The jury selected to decide how Jacob Tash, Jr., was killed brought in a verdict to-day charging that he came to his death by a pistol shot fired by Charles Acker of New-York.

PORTLAND, Me., May 14.--The marriage of Theodore Butterfield of Utica, N.Y., to Miss Clara Louise Deake, eldest daughter of Mr. Charles Standish Deake of this city, which took place this afternoon in St.Luke's Cathedral, was the principal society event of the season.

The tomato was decided to be a vegetable in the United States Circuit Court yesterday. John Nix Co. recently imported a large quantity of Bermuda tomatoes and were charged 10 per cent. duty under the tariff on vegetables in a natural state. The importers held that the tomato is a fruit and should come in free.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES publishes a very full and animated account of certain transactions in Baltimore of Mr. Charles George Wislon, and if our contemporary presents the facts correctly, Mr. Wilson ought not be retained for a day in the office of President of the Board of Health, to which he has been appointed by Mayor Grant.

MAY'S LANDING, N.J., May 14.--The jury in the case of Andrew Grimes, the colored sailor charged with the murder of Mate John Martin on board the schooner Annie S. Carl, while she was lying at anchor in Absecom Inlet last Christmas Day, returned a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree this afternoon. Judge Reed immediately sentenced him to be hanged on Thursday, June 20.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 14.--The new Rutgers College laboratory has been considerably damaged by unknown persons. The men are supposed to be enemies of the janitor. To get him into trouble they broke into the laboratory and opended the water fancets. The water soaked through the walls and ceilings, damaged a number of valuable books, and did other damage. The police are hunting for the offenders.

Morris Wilkins, the giant auctioneer, undertook yesterday at the Real Estate Exchange to sell to the highest bidder Story's beautiful piece of sculpture, "Medea Meditating the Murder of her Children," which has been on exhibition for some time in the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 14.--The establishment of a State Weather Bureau and Signal Service at Cornell University, though it may prove to be, perhaps, the wisest act of the present Legislature, has so far practically been unnoticed by the press of the State. But this service is not an experiment.

Miss Mabel Channing Wright, daughter of Mr. Frank Wright of Boston, and Mr. James Duane Livingstone were married yesterday afternoon at Calvary Church, Fourth-avenue and Twenty-first-street. The Rev. Dr.Henry Y. Satterlee performed the ceremony.

ALBANY, May 14.--A circular from the office of the State Superintendent of Education calls attention to the new law providing that school meetings be held on the first Tuesday of August at 7:30 o'clock, instead of the last Tuesday at 7 o'clock.

MADISON, Wis., May 14--Jeannette Flower, wife of Frank A. Flower, a prominent journalist of this State and ex-State Labor Statistician, sued to-day for divorce, alleging cruel and inhuman treatment. There will be no defense offered. The defendant was born in Cattaraugus County, N.Y., and before coming to Wisconsin was employed on the Fredonia (N.Y.) Advertiser as traveling correspondent.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 14.--A borough election was held here to-day. There was a very light vote polled. G. Fred Kroehl, John D. Beegle, and William H. Smith were re-elected Borough Commissioners, and Milan H. Ross was re-elected Collector and Treasurer. H. Marriott was elected Assessor by a small majority.

The semi-annual convention of the New-York and New-England district of the Missouri Synod of the Lutheran Church began a three days' session at Rockville, Conn., yesterday, with forty delegates present, representing churches in New-York, Albany, Paterson, New-Haven, Boston, and other cities.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 14--At a joint meeting of the miners and operators of this district yesterday the existing differences were satisfatorily adjusted by the adoption of the following scale: From May 11 to Oct. 1, 1889, 55 cents per ton; from Oct. 1, 1889, to May 1, 1890, 60 cents per ton. In addition to this all the mines are to have a check weighman paid through the office and a seven-eighths screen.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 14.--The Roman Catholic Cathedral in this city, which was begun by Bishop Galberry during 1876, will cost $500,000. The first subscription for it in the diocese was taken early in 1876 and amounted to less tahn $20,000.

A fatal accident occurred at the Michigan Car Works at Detroit Tuesday. Four laborers were unloading a carload of iron when some part of the brace holding the load broke and several tons of iron fell on the men, completely burying them. When the victims were liberated Joe Benscotte was dead and his three companions mortally injured.

There was a healthy tone in yesterday's stock market, and few stocks moved and other way than upward. The coal stocks, the Grangers, all showed new strength and scored advances. Lackawanna jumped over a point; Reading's friends displayed more courage than in a long while; every one of the conspicuous North western properties scored advances.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.Y., May 15.--Mrs. Maria Boisuat, who was accused of killing her child several months ago, and escaped indictment only because the doctors said she was temporarily insane, was married at Franklin Park tonight to James Higgins, a prosperous farmer.
PHILADELPHIA, May 15.--Gen. Adna Anderson, the well-known railroad engineer, committed suicide last night in his room in the Lafayette Hotel in this city.

BERLIN, May 15.--The sub-committee of the Samoan conference has decided than the municipal Council of Apia shall comprise six members, Germany, England, and the United States each to appoint one. The other three shall be elected by the residents of Apia. This decision displeases the British Commissioners, who call it the Phelps compromise. Mr. Phelps, although not a member of the sub-committee, was asked to attend its last meeting.
NEWARK, N.J., May 15.--Otto Brethouer, a jeweler, fifty-three years old and unmarried, dropped dead in front of his boarding house, 43 William-street, to-night. Cause not known.

BERLIN, May 15.--Distress is beginning to be felt in the coal districts in consequence of the strike of the miners. A committee has appealed for funds, and a number of Westphalia newspapers have opened subscription lists. The number of strikers and their dependents is estimated at 160,000.
PARIS, May 15.--Mr. Whitelaw Reid, the new American Minister, was received by M. Spuller, Minister of Foreign Affairs, to-day. President Carnot will receive Mr. Reid at the end of the week.

Atterbury, the Rev. Wilton M. Smith, the Rev. J. Balkon Shaw, and the Rev. Arthur Mitchell took part in the service. Singing by the young people's societies of the church and by the Sunday school formed a part of the programme.

AMHERST, Mass., May 15.--The Amherst light gymnasium exhibition occurred this afternoon. Three classes, the Juniors, Sophomores, and Freshmen, competed for the Gilbert prize of $100 awarded to the class excelling in light drilling and marching.

A flashlight picture of the audience was taken Tuesday night at the meeting of the Society of Amateur Photographers, at 122 West Thirtysixth-street, with a Kodak camera by Mr. G.D. Milburn, who also demonstrated the operation of stripping paper film negatives. The paper films greatly interested the members of the society, who crowded around Mr. Milburn as he developed the picture and explained the stripping of the plate.

WASHINGTON, May 15.--Under the Tariff act of 1883 silver ore was admitted into the United States free of duty, while lead ore is taxed 1 cents a pound, a practically prohibitory tariff. When the law was passed small quantities of an ore containing both silver and lead were being imported from Mexico for use as a fluxing ore by American smelting companies.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 15.--The time for holding the Republican State Convention is June 25 and 26 and the place is Columbus. There was a very strong rivalry between Cincinnati, Toledo, Cleveland, and Columbus, but the last named won after a hard fight.

The attendance at the amateur championship billiard tournament given under the aus pices of the Racquet Court Club was larger last evening than at any of the preceding games of the week. The fires game, between Miller and Townsend, was won by Townsend, 800 to 198. The second game, between Oddie and Jennings was won by the formers, 300 to 91.

At Creedmoor the regular rifle practice of the troops of the National Guard was begun yesterday under conditions which promise to result in a large saving in expense to the State. ERIE, Penn., May 15.--The attendance at the meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers was largely increased to-day. The council has received an invitation to hold a meeting in London from the scientific societies of that city.

The National Temperance Society and Publication House celebrated its twenty-fourth anniversary Tuesday. In the afternoon it met at 58 Reade-street and adopted the annual report presented by the Corresponding Secretary, J.N. Stearns.

CHICAGO, May 15.--The lines of the Wabash Railway east of the Mississippi River were sold before Judges Gresham and Jackson to-day to Messrs. Ashely and Joy, representing 90 per cent. of the bonds and acting in the interests of the Wabash Western Purchasing Committee, for $15,550,000.

The Training School for Nurses of Charity, Maternity, and Infants' Hospitals held its thir teenth annual Commencement yesterday afternoon in the Charity Hospital Building on Blackwell's Island. NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 15.--James Kelly, who arrived at McCormack's Hotel last night and registered as coming from Kentucky, was found unconscious in his bedroom to-day with the gas turned on. He died this afternoon. Kelly arrived on a late train last night, and in jumping off had nearly fallen under the train. Among his letters was one evidently from a "green-goods" man who had promised to meet him at New-Brunswick.

HARTFORD, May 16.--The debate on the great railroad fight between the Consolidated and the Housatonic Railroads began in the House of Representatives to-day. At 11 o'clock the Question came up as the order of the day. A good deal of preliminary skirmishing took place for position.
The Berkeley nine will play the Olympics of St. John's School, Sing Sing, at Berkeley Oval, Morris Dock, this afternoon at 3 o'clock.

The bark Jose D. Bueno, bound for Cuba, was seen Tuesday afternoon proceeding quietly down the bay in tow of the tugboat Adelaide. FREEHOLD, N.Y. May.--A maiden lady living between this place and Englishtown, who is nearly eighty years old, has traveled but once on the cars. She has never seen a steamboat, and never was more than twenty miles from her home.

FREEHOLD, N.J., May 15.--The Monmouth County tax rate will be higher this year than it was last year. The rate last year was the highest ever known in the county. Last year there was raised for county purposes the sum of $159,774 60. The amount to be raised this year is $168,591 06.

Mayor Grant had as few visitors of importance yesterday as on any day in which he has been at the City Hall this year. He was evidently waiting for news of the fate of his Rapid-Transit bill in the Legislature. He early announced that he should make no appointments during the day.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 15.--The Commencement appointments announced to-day are: Valedictorian--Robert E. Speer, Huntingdon, Penn.; Latin Salutatorian--Lewis S. Mudge, Princeton, N.J. The English salutatory is the third honor of the Senior Class.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J. May 15.--Application was made to-day to have bail fixed for John C. Raymond, the New-York architect who is accused of arson in burning down the Adrian Institute at Iselin. The insurance companies claim that he has burned nine houses.

Ex-Commissioner of Schools William Lummis yesterday presented the Board of Education library with a large number of educational works, recently purchased by him at the sale of the library of John M. Buckley, and received therefor the thanks of the board.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 15.--Agents have been working here for several days in the interests of a gigantic combination, and in spite of the greatest efforts at secrecy the truth has gradually leaked out.

Ex-Judge R.B. Seymour, Corporation Counsel of Jersey City, has filed in Trenton the answer of the old boards to Mayor Cleveland's bill in quo warranto on behalf of the new boards. Both the old and new Police Boards met yes terday, but the situation of affairs remains un changed. The old boards control all the offices except the Police and Fire Departments.
CHICAGO, May 15.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad Company was held at its general offices this morning at 11 o'clock.

Father Francis Dent, at one time a professor of theology in the College of Francisean Fathers at Allegany, N.Y., has begun a suit to recover $25,000 damages from Vlcar General Keegan of Brooklyn for slander. A similar action has been instituted against Bishop Ryan of Buffalo.

RED BANK, N.J., May 15.--The marriage of Miss Hannah May Carrick, daughter of William Carrick of this place, and Robert E. Craig of Richmond, Va., took place to-day at the pride's home on Branch-avenue. Only a few relatives and intimate friends of the couple witnessed the ceremony, which was performed by the Rev. F.R. Harbaugh, pastor of the Presbyterian Church.

Tobin, the unfortunate young woman whose body was washed ashore on the rocks at Clifton, S.L, on Sunday, to make it of more than ordinary interest. The appeal of George H. Tilden from the decision of Judge Lawrence of the Supreme Court, holding the will of Samuel J. Tilden to be valid, was argued yesterday in the Supreme Court, General Term, before Presiding Justice Van Brunt and Justices Brady and Daniels.

CHICAGO, May 15.--A scheme rivaling in some respects the electric sugar refining swindle was exposed here to-day. The perpetrator is a smooth-mannered young fellow named John Archibald Comp, whose papers indicate that he has been operating not only in Chicago but also at Kansas City, St. Louis, and Cincinnati.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., May 15.--The Taber contested will case, which was marked for trial for this term of the Supreme Court, was settled this morning by agreement of counsel, and the decision of the Probate Court was affirmed. Elizabeth Taber of Marion left $400,000 to various Congregational churches and missions, and the will was contested by the heirs at law on the ground that the lostatrix was of unsound mind.

The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor held its annual meeting Tuesday. There were present Samuel Gompers, President; Senator Daniel McLaughlin of Illinois, William Martin of Pittsburg, Penn.; Henry Emerich of New-York, and P.J. McGuire of Philadelphia.

POUGHKEEPSIE, May 15.--Col. Parks, Superintendent of the West Point Military Academy, issued an order to-day announcing the beginning of the annual examinations on Saturday, June 1. The Academic Board will be divided into two committees.

Widener, W.L. Elkins, and Mr. Kemble, have succeeded in passing three bills through both houses, which will bestow additional power upon the corporations controlled by them in the city of New-York, and which will greatly improve facilities for passenger transit in the metroplis.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 15.--The Shah of Persia, who is now journeying from Teheran to St. Petersburg, is meeting with a grand reception in Russia. At Erwan the streets through which he passed were lined with troops, and at several points there were triumphal arches bearing the inscription, "To the Shah's Sacred Person." The entire town was brilliantly illuminated upon the evening of the day on which the Shah arrived.

It was ascertained yesterday that exState Senator George W. Plunkitt, who has been mentioned as a probable member of the Board of Dock Commissioners, has contracts with that body. Having trouble in disposing of the material taken from cellars he excavates, he is dumping it as filling for the bulkheads at Seventy-fifth and Seventy-sixth streets on the North River.

CLEVELAND, May 15.--By agreement of attorneys the courts permitted the stockholders of the Cleveland, Columbus, Cincinnati and Indianapolis Railway Company to meet to-day and vote upon the proposition to consolidate with the "Big Four" system. The meeting was held in President Layng's office this morning at 8 o'clock.

At the annual meeting of the stock and bondholders of the Pittsburg. Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad Company held at Pittsburg yesterday. Messrs, L.H. Myers, E.P. Williams, and Charles E. Speer, whose terms as directors had expired, were reelected. Nearly three hundred and twenty thousand votes, representing $31,870,800 were cast, the largest vote ever polled.

ST. PAUL, May 15.--A cold, raw, penetrating rain made matters in the city both last night and to-day about as disagreeable as they could be. For about twenty-four hours the wind has been in the northeast, but the returns show the storm centre to be moving northwesterly from Kansas to Chicago and the lakes, so that a change in the wind to westerly and southwesterly may soon be expected.

The contest of the will of Congressman Peter Paul Mahoney, in which his sisters, Mrs. Prendergast and Mrs. Cahill are trying to have his bequest of all his property to his widow declared invalid, was begun yesterday before Surrogate Abbott in Brooklyn. Patrick Keady represented the contestants, while Recorder Smyth appeared for Mrs. Mahoney.

CHICAGO, May 15.--The police are inclined to believe that the arrest of Lewis B. Mann, the lithograph agent, in this city Tuesday night, on a charge of larceny, was the result of mere anxiety on the part of the New-York firm. Mann says he can soon convince the firm of his innocence. He goes back to New-York to-night.

BOSTON, May 15.--The time when Boston shall have elevated railroads has again been postponed by the action of the Massachusetts Senate, which defeated the bill to-day by the decisive vote of 20 to 15, with 4 Senators paired. This shows 22 Senators, a clear majority, as opposed to elevated roads, and settles the question for a year at least.

Yesterday was the eighth working day of the Washington Memorial Arch Finance Committee, and the fund was increased by over $2,000 in additional subscriptions. The committee felt greatly encouraged by the receipts of yesterday, and now report a total of nearly $25,000.

The veteran actor, James E. Murdoch, will have a benefit in Philadelphia next Wednesday night, May 22. The spacious auditorium of the Academy of Music, one of the handsomest and most comfortable theatres in this country, and one of which Philadelphians are justly proud, ought to be crowded to do him honor.

At a meeting of the New-York Yacht Club held last evening in the clubhouse, 67 Madisonavenue, two letters from the Earl of Dunraven in relation to the proposed race for the America's Cup were read and a report of the Cup Committee was heard. The letters are very interesting, as they touch upon the points being freely discussed by American yachtsmen.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 16.--A third suit was to-day decided against the Baltimore and NewYork Railroad Company in the Union County courts.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., May 16.--The Borough Commissioners have decided that the trains must not run through the village at a greater rate of speed than sixteen miles an hour. Gates will be put up at all the railroad crossings.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 16.--An English syndicate is negotiating for the purchase of seven breweries in this city and one in Muskegon, and have an agent here arranging details. The prices will aggregate $700,000. Those now in the business will, if the deal is perfected, retain an interest in the combination to the extent of one-third of their selling price.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16.--The American Fisheries Association held its second day's session at the rooms of the Anglers' Association of Eastern Pennsylvania to-day. Frederick Mather, Superintendent of the New-York Fishery Commission, read a paper on "Salmon in the Hudson." Prof. Goode of the Smithsonian Institution at Washington then read a paper on "Colors of Fishes."

The association decided to build a Thornley memorial chapel at the corner of Mount Tabor Way and Pilgrim Pathway.

NEWARK, N.J., May 16.--John D. Higgins, who left this city some time ago for Canada, is back again, although he has not yet seen his family. He was involved in financial difficulties with the Cartaret Chemical Works, in which he was a clerk for six years.

NEWARK, N.J., May 16.--Gov. Green to-night appointed Bernard J. Ford, the Deputy Revenue Collector of Newark, Superintendent of State Buildings at Trenton.

The transfer books of the company close this afternoon for annual election purposes, only stock that is of record before they close being of value to its holder for use in voting.

YORK, Penn., May 16.--Bishop J. Dicksom presided over the United Brethren Conference to-day. At the morning session a brief message of greeting was adopted and referred to the Committee on Correspondence to be forwarded to President Harrison.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16.--A syndicate of Philadelphia capitalists, headed by Thomas Cochran, has purchased the graphaphone rights for the world outside of the United States and Canada. The price paid was $500,000.
WASHINGTON, May 16.--The Secretary of the Treasury to-day purchased $43,000 4 per cent. bonds at 108 flat; an offer of $75,000 at 107 exinterest was rejected.

NEW-HAVEN, May 16.--A lead-colored carrier pigeon, apparently tired out, flew into the old lighthouse tower at Southeast Point yesterday. It was secured without difficulty by Capt. E. Thompson, the weather observer stationed there, who fed it and put it in a cage. A closer examination revealed the presence of a small ring around the bird's leg bearing the number 3,952. The pigeon seems well content with its new quarters.

DUBLIN, May 16.--Referring to the report concerning the abolition of the Viceroyship of Ireland, United Ireland says: "The Viceroyship, although degraded, must be maintained, as it is a sign of Ireland's separate nationality."

For the third day of the Brooklyn Jockey Club's meeting the card is a very attractive one, the Brookdale Handicap, for horses of all ages, and the Seaside Stakes, for two-year-olds, being the principal features. These, with the four purse and sweepstakes races, should furnish excellent sport.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 16.--Five bills of indictment against Assessor Thomas I. Quill of this township and Deputy Charles Tyler were returned by the Marion County Grand Jury this evening.

BALTIMORE, May 16.--Charles George Wilson has not said much since last Monday when THE TIMES began to enlighten the public on his history. PORTLAND, Oregon, May 16.--The steamship Columbia, which has just arrived at Astoria bound from San Francisco to Portland, brings a report of the loss of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company's magnificent side-wheel iron steamer Alaskan. This vessel is reported to have foundered at sea off Cape Blanco Monday, May 13, while on her way from Portland to San Francisco. Only meagre particulars have been received yet.

The amateur billiard contest at the Racquet Club was continued last evening with a single game between R. Townsend of NewYork and R.I. McGinnis of Boston. Richard Young acted as referee. When the score stood 254 for Townsend to 171 for McGinnis. Townsend made a run of 46 and won the game. His average was 8 4-37. McGinnis's average was 4 11-12. The winner's best run was 77, and the loser's was 47.

The annual meeting of the National Board of Fire Underwriters was held yesterday in the office of the local Board of Underwriters in the Mutual Life Building. D.A. Heald of this city, President of the National Board, presided, and there were present about forty representatives from various States.

The Charter Oak Park Guaranteed Stakes for trotters have closed with 105 entries for the 10 stakes. The 2:28 trotting class has 19 entries, and will be divided, with $600 added by the association for each class. The hores will be named June 13.
Mr. Zapher of Inwood died Wednesday from measles. He was seventy-five years of age.
CHICAGO, May 16.--W.S. Millen, General Manager of the Wisconsin Central Railroad, has been appointed General Manager of the Northern Pacific, and will enter upon the duties of the position on July 1.

PITTSBURG, May 16.--A cablegram from Rome, published to-day, conveyed the first intelligence of the consolidation of the Pittsburg and Allegheny dioceses of the Roman Catholic Church. The diocese of Pittsburg was erected in 1843, and the Right Rev. Michael O'Connor was consecrated Bishop of the new see. He remained in charge until his death, when he was succeeded by Bishop Domenece, a Spaniard.

QUEBEC, May 16.--A disastrous fire broke out early this morning in St. Sauveur, a suburb of this city, in the house of Mrs. McCann on Valier-street, and spread with great rapidity through the wooden district which surrounds it.

John O'Brien, of the firm of Clark O'Brien, appeared before the Aqueduct Commissioners yesterday and answered the charges which Chief Engineer Fteley had made against him and his partner, that they had persisted in employing upon Section 9 of the new aqueduct David R. Page a assistant engineer and a man named McGowan as foreman, after Mr. Fteley had told them that these two men were unfaithful, incompetent, and disorderly.

BERLIN, May 16.--A compromise is being arranged between the miners and their employers and it is expected the men will resume work everywhere on Tuesday.

Joseph Phelps Williams, an assistant bookkeeper in the transfer department of the Central Trust Company, 54, Wall-street, and a resident of 62 Livingston-street, Brooklyn, came to this city with his mother and sister on May 1 to see the civic parade.
The General Executive Board of the Knights of Labor has issued a circular to the members of the order on the eight-hour question.

LONDON, May 16.--In the House of Commons this afternoon Mr. Balfour, Chief Secretary for Ireland, stated that ten Irish members of the House are now in prison for offenses under the Crimes act. He said they are all enjoying good health.

ST. PAUL, May 16.--A circular has just been sent out by Charles D. Barney Co., the Philadelphia bankers, to stockholders, which is intended to revolutionize the management of the St. Paul and Duluth Road. It favors the return of W.H. Fisher to the Presidency.

Allen Thorndike Rice, recently appointed United States Minister to Russia, died suddenly yesterday morning in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel, this city. Mr. Rice had not been in good health for several months, but nothing serious was apprehended until last Sunday. He had been complaining of a sore throat for several days, and last Saturday went out to Sands Point, L.I., on a visit to Mr. Lloyd S. Bryce, who has a country seat near that place.

The match race between the eight-oared crew of the New-York Athletic Club and the Atalanta Boat Club will be rowed on the Harlem to-morrow afternoon. The course will be one ane one-half miles straightaway. No event in local rowing circles has attracted such general attention for some time, and an exciting contest is expected.

Coroner Hughes last evening began an inquest into the mysterious death of Miss Mary E. Tobin, whose body was found in the water off Clifton, S.I., on Sunday. The Coroner is also an undertaker and has a small combination office and wareroom, about 15 feet square, opposite the Roman Catholic Church at Rosebank. In this the inquest was held.

NORFOLK, Va., May 16.--Chief Justice Fuller of the United States Supreme Court and Judge Hugh L. Bond of the United States Circuit Court are here on their way to Charleston, S.C., to hold court. The Bar of Norfolk gave a banquet this evening in honor of the Chief Justice.

Miss Tillie Frelinghuysen, daughter of Frederick T. Frelinghuysen, ex-Secretary of State, was married yesterday afternoon to Mr. H.W. Gray of New-York. The wedding took place in the old Frelinghuysen homestead, one of the most beautiful residences in Park-place, in Newark, N.J.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 16.--The Worcester Theatre took fire this morning soon after 3 o'clock, and was totally destroyed. the fire started in the rear of the building, near the stage. Explosions followed each other in rapid succession, and in a short time the roof fell in.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 16.--The Board of Education last night presented to Joseph Battin, the aged philanthropist who presented to the city the two-hundred-and-fifty-thousand-dollar building now to be used as a high school, a beautifully-engrossed set of resolutions accepting the gift. The speech of the Mayor on the occasion was also engrossed and presented with the resolutions.

ALBANY, May 16.--Contractor Snaith has returned to Albany. He regrets that his counsel should have advised him to leave the city. He says he is sorry that he could not have done a better job in the Capitol, but this was impossible, because of the haste employed.

HELENA, Montana, May 16.--Tuesday's election for delegates to the Constitutional Convention shows that the embryo State is safely Democratic. The returns show that the Democrats will have a majority. A conservative estimate gives them 39 and the Republicans 34 members of the convention. Two of the Democrats are Independents, giving a working majority of three.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 16.--Capt. Morris of the British schooner Galena, which arrived at Charleston from New-York to-day, reports that when off Frying Pan Shoal a carrier pigeon flew on board. On one leg was a rubber band with "83" stamped on it. No vessel was in sight at the time. The pigeon was brought to Charleston.

There were rumors at the chess tournament last evening that at least ten of the players would be left out in the cold and would not even get back their entrance fees. However, Mr. Frere, Vice President of the American Chess Congress, said that the money would certainly be paid by the committee and there was no doubt that it would be forthcoming when due.

ALBANY, May 16.--Old Father Time executed the Legislature at noon to-day in excellent shape and in conformity with previous arrangements. There was no bungling about it and very little delay. No Sheriff was on hand, however, to oversee the execution, although it might, perhaps, have been better for the State had a number of these officers been on hand at numerous stages of the session.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 16.--Philip Daly's condition is improving. He has been ill, but now seems to be rapidly recovering. He is seen daily upon the streets, either on foot or in his carriage.
The sixth annual drill of the Columbia Institute cadets last evening filled the Seventh Regiment Armory with an interested audience, made up in large part of the fond parents of the small soldiers.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 16.--The Rev.P.E. Smyth, pastor of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, to-day celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of his ordination to the priesthood.

White announced that Burlington was going straightway to 60 and nothing could save.

PAUL, May 16.--The rains of the last two or three days have been of immense benefit to crops, and crop reports received at the various railway offices yesterday were almost without exception of a most favorable character. LONDON, May 18.--The Post's Berlin correspondent, referring to the Samoan conference, says: "The committee reports on the land and government questions were presented to the conference to-day. The report on government was approved, with the exception of a few details, which were left for the next meeting. The next meeting will probably be held Tuesday, when, judging from the unanimity shown today, a final decision will be arrived at."

Three Polish immigrants, who landed at Castle Garden from the Hamburg steamer Amalti on April 8, reappeared at the Garden yesterday and told a long story of hardship and ill treatment which they had undergone since their arrival in America.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 17.--Yale University has purchased the Munson place, near York and Elm streets, for the new-Yale gymnasium. It will be given to the Gymnasium Committee at once. The price has not been made public. The lot has 200 feet front on York-street and runs back about 400 feet. It is only two blocks away from the Yale campus. It is believed the building will be erected immediately.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 17.--The Rutgers College lacrosse team defeated the College of the City of New-York in the game here to-day by five goals to one. The game was one of the Metropolitan League series.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 17.--Three large hives of bees took possession of R.O. Howell's grocery store yesterday afternoon, swarming upon a quantity of comb honey in one of the show windows. There were thousands of the little insects, and their presence destroyed trade for the remainder of the day. When night came Mr. Howell and his clerks smoked the store with sulphur, thereby killing the honey makers. No one in Plainfield was willing to hive them.

Some of the best of the three-yearolds in the East will meet this afternoon in the race for the Brooklyn Derby over a distance of a mile and a quarter, which is a quarter of a mile less than the Western Derbys are run at. The seven starters announced are all of them good ones, and the race should be a hard one from start to finish.

The Spring games of the Stevens Institute Athletic Association, which were to have been held on May 17, have been postponed a week. The postponement was to allow of a change in the constitution of the athletic association admitting any member of the institute to participate in the games. This will probably largely increase the number of entries and make the games of much more interest to the college in general.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 18.--Consequent upon the developments of yesterday showing preparations for unnecessary and unlawful civil service examinations here the local board has crawfished, and the examinations proposed have been indefinitely postponed.

LONG BRANCH, May 18.--The case of Leon Cottentin, the chef of the Hollywood Hotels at West End, who recently brought suit for $100,000 damages against William G. Hall and Dr. H.H. Pemberton, has been decided by the Monmouth County courts. Mr. Cottentin is awarded $270 damages.

BERLIN, May 18.--As far as can be learned, the American Commissioners to the Samoan conference have succeeded in carrying every important point they set out to obtain. OCEAN BEACH, N.J., May 18.--The second special election to decide on a new name for this summer resort has been held. The name of Belmar was agreed upon, only three votes being cast against it. The first name decided on was Elko, but the Summer residents objected so forcibly to the name that another election was held. The new name was suggested by H. Allaire, the wealthy architect of Monmouth County.

NIOBRARA, Neb., May 18.--William McLaughlin, a private in the Fourteenth Infantry, stationad at Fort Randall, shot and instantly killed his sweetheart, Maggie Lowene, Thursday night, with a rifle because she had been talking with another soldier of whom he was jealous. He was arrested, but yesterday escaped from the guardhouse. A detachment of cavalry is in search of him.

WESTERLY, R.I., May 18.--The General Assembly has passed an act authorizing the Providence and Stonington Steamship Company to increase the number of its Directors from seven to nine. The corporation has voted to accept this amendment to its charter. President W. M. Miller presided at the meeting and 10,483 shares were voted upon.

For the benefit of "E.B.R." and all others who are interested in knowing how Mr. Harrison's Administration has made appointments, it can be stated that approximately, from March 4 ro May 17, 9,500 appointments have been made under Harrison's Administration, including 600 Presidential Postmasters, 7,000 fourth-class Postmasters, 1,500 Railway Mail Service employes, 150 miscellaneous appointments, and 200 department changes. For the same period under Cleveland there were about 2,000 appointments all told.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 18.--Judge Scudder to-day fixed bail at $10,000 each in the cases of General Freight and Passenger Agent Hendrickson and Construction Superintendent Russey of the Raritan River Railroad, who were arrested for the murder of George KesSinger, killed in the fight to prevent the railroad from laying its tracks over the Furman brickyard at Sayreville. Charles and John Whitehead, rival brickyard proprietors, went bail for the men.
The arrival of the Umbria off Brow's Head at midnight Friday made her time of passage eastward six days and three hours. This is the best trip but one on record from New-York to the eastward.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., May 18.--Lovers of piscatorial sport are beginning to come here again in goodly numbers. Pickerel are biting well on live bait, and on pleasant days the bosom of the lake is specked with boats all burdened with sportsmen angling for pickerel. There are fishermen from New-York, Newark, the Oranges, Morristown, Dover, Boonton, and where not, and everybody has luck.

In a recent paper on the hygiene of Japanese houses the common idea that dwelling houses in that country are very unhealthy was distinctly disproved. The remarkably small infant mortality among the Japanese shows that their houses are healthy and suited to their modes of life.

A very interesting afternoon's trotting was had yesterday over the fine track of Sire Brothers at Morristown, N.J. It was the formal opening day and the proprietors arranged two races and offered for prizes as fine set of harness and a handsome suit of horse clothes.

RED BANK, N.J., May 18.--A number of deaths have occurred among the old residents of Monmouth County during the last few days. On Thursday, May 9, Japhia Clayton died at his home in Leedsville, aged eighty-one years. The direct cause of his death, was rheumatism of the heart. He had been a resident of Leedsville for fifty years, and was one of the wealthiest farmers in Eastern New-Jersey.

NEWBURG, May 18.--A letter has been received here from the Judson T. Kilpatrick Post of the Grand Army notifying Fullerton Post that after decorating Gen. Kilpatrick's grave at West Point the organization will come to this city and take part in the parade on May 30.

PORT HURON, Mich., May 18.--The steam barge R.P. Ranney arrived here to-day and reported running into and sinking the schooner Merrick off Presque Isle yesterday morning. ATLANTA, Ga., May 19.--The report of State Commissioner of Agriculture Henderson for May, just out, is gratifying. There is a manifest improvement in the general condition of farming interests. There is a spirit of independence aroused, a revival of hope in the future, and a determined and co-operative purpose among farmers that is everywhere observable.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 19.--Telegrams from Middle California report an earthquake about 3:15 o'clock this morning. At some points, especially in the San Joaquin Valley, the shocks were quite severe, and in a few cases the tops of chimneys were thrown down. The shock was sufficiently heavy in this city to awaken nearly all slumberers.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 19.--The colored Republicans are a large and essential portion of the party in this city and county. They are made much use of during campaign times, and until recently have been ignored with impunity in the distribution of patronage. However, for a year or two they have been gaining courage, and many have bolted.

TRENTON, N.J., May 19.--The Trenton horse-car stables were partially destroyed by fire at an early hour this morning. John L. Hanly, a driver, who was sleeping in the stables, was so badly burned that his life is despaired of. The horses were all saved, but twenty-seven cars were burned. The loss will reach about $25,000; covered by insurance.

ROME, May 19.--King Humbert started for Beriln to-day, accompanied by the Prince of Naples and Premier Crispi. A large number of societies, with bands and banners, and a large and enthusiastic concourse of citizens gathered outside the railway station to witness the departure. Inside the station were assembled the Cabinet Ministers, members of the Chamber of Deputies, the Syndic of Rome, and others.

Mrs. Louisa Wilson, nineteen years old, who lived with her father, Anton Rausch, a baker, on the Boulevard, between Eighty-first and Eighty-second streets, was shot by her husband, Charles Wilson, last night at Eighty-firststreet and Tenth-avenue and instantly killed.

Mayor Grant did not repeat his long horseback trip Saturday and yesterday. BALTIMORE, May 19.--George Ward, seventyfive years of age, lives with his son near Carrollton, in this State. Close to the house is a rivulet, which flows from a spring and which is only a few inches deep. Mr. Ward built a dam across this stream. When the water became deep enough he threw himself into it and kept his head beneath the surface.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 19.--Assesser Quill's bondsmen have surrendered him to the Sheriff and he has been sued on an old note for $500. When Quill was arrested on the various indictments his bond was fixed at $5,000, and it was not until he had viewed the inside of the county bastile for one hour and twenty minutes that bondsmen, in the persons of Jacob Bos and Phil Reichwein, were secured.

Cooper, a wealthy real estate agent, living at 34 Seventh-avenue, Brooklyn, returned from the races about 6:30 Saturday evening and boarded a Seventh-avenue car at the Culver Railroad station. The Larchmont Yacht Club has issued circulars announcing the match race of the sloops Shamrock and Titania to be sailed over its course May 30 and the Spring regatta of the club to be sailed June 1. The course of the match race will be twenty-seven nautical miles and the start will be made at 10:30 A.M.

The conferences between the American Meat Company and the American Cattle Trust terminated Saturday in a traffic agreement by which the former company will handle the product of the latter from the slaughter house to market. To-day representatives of the conference will sign the contract. Officers of both companies say nothing further was ever contemplated at the conference, neither company caring to sell out or to consolidate.

SALEM, Va., May 19.--One of the features of the Commencement exercises of Roanoke College, which will begin June 9, will be an address by the Rev. John P. Turnbull June 12.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 19.--It has been discovered that the city has been systematically cheated for several years past by the two men employed during that time to take the annual school census.

The Clover Stakes for two-year-old fillies will be the feature at the Brooklyn track this afternoon, twenty-two young ladies being in the list of probable starters. The Parkway Handicap, with the horses named as probable starters in a race at a mile and a sixteenth, will also furnish good sport. Besides these there are four purse races on the card, with the following horses as contestants in the several events:

LONDON, May 20.--M. Henri Rochefort, who was arrested Saturday on the charge of assaulting M. Pilotel, was arraigned in the Vine-Street Police Court this morning. He was bound over in one surety of 100 and two of 50 each to keep the peace for six months.
A tired, invalid, and efficient public servant, Charles Oscar Shay, Chief of the Fire Department, was retired yesterday by the Board of Fire Commissioners on a pension of $2,500 a year.

Lillian Russell resumed her place in the cast of "The Brigands" at the Casino last night. She was in perfect voice, and was cheered to the echo by the crowded audience which packed the theatre. Albert Aronson says that the Casino never presented an opera which gave such promise of a long and successful run as "The Brigands."

The wheels of justice never spun around so quickly as they did yesterday in the case of John McCarthy and John Cunningham, who robbed a countryman in Doyers-street at 5:30 o'clock in the morning, and were on their way to Sing Sing at 2:15 o'clock in the afternoon.

The subscriptions for the Washington Memorial Arch fund still continue to roll in, increasing in volume day by day. Over $1,500 was received yesterday, besides a large number of letters offering suggestions and the announcement that the American Water-Color Society had started a subscription list among its members to help the project along.
GETTYSBURG, Penn., May 20.--The dedicatory season was opened here to-day by Wiedrichs's Battery I, First New-York Artillery.
Charles H. Manning, the well-known pool expert, is anxious to gain championship laurels, and for that purpose he yesterday challenged Alfred de Oro, the Cuban player...

Massachusetts's Creedmoor rifle team will sail for Europe on June 19 to compete with the crack team of British volunteers. The victories of the Bay State men last year at Creedmoor and other shoots gave Boston such confidence in the men that a popular subscription was...
Russell B. Harrison called at the Custom House yesterday. He was asked how many places he wanted, and said that he didn't want...
MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 20.--Samuel R. Ainslie, the present General Superintendent of the Northern Pacific Railroad, will become General Manager of the Wisconsin Central Railroad on July 1.

The contest over the vacancy that will be created in the army next week by the retirement of Adjt. Gen. Drum on account of age, is waxing hot and forms the main topic of gossip at present. It is generally conceded that the chances for the Adjutant Generalship lie between Cols. Kelton and Whipple.

Judge Daly, in the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday listened to the reading of affidavits which affirmed and denied a peculiar story. Mrs. Harriet Hubbard Ayer, President of the Recamier Manufacturing Company, took the affirmative and James M. Seymour, who was head of the stock-broking firm of Seymour...
The French papers announce the arrival in Paris of two lions and two lionesses tamed by the "celebrated American Colonel, Daniel Boone."

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 20.--William Miller of 1,015 Magnolia-avenue, and a conductor on the Central Railroad drill engine at the Elizabethport docks, had both legs cut off this evening by the engine. He died at the hospital soon after.

The Corinthian Mosquito Fleet, organized last December to unite owners of single-handed cruisers for their mutual benefit and enjoyment and to foster by racing and cruising an interest in designing, rigging, and handling of all small craft, met last evening in the Sturtevant House...

FREEHOLD, N.J., May 20.--The Grand Jury of Monmouth County closed its labors at noon today, returning forty-seven indictments. Among the bills found three were for illegal liquor selling, three were for libel, five were for embezzlement, and one for being a common scold. There were no indictments found against the Long Branch gamblers.

The suit brought by Cora Knapp to recover $250,000 from the estate of Demas Barnes is in the hands of George F. Elliott and William J. Gaynor, two Brooklyn lawyers. The case is expected to come to trial within a few weeks.

ROCHESTER, May 20.--The examination of James Faulkner, the brother of Lester B. Faulk-- ner, was begun in the United States Court this afternoon and continued up to the adjournment of court at 11 o'clock to-night. He is the most important of the Government's witnesses, as by him the statements in reference to false reports sent in to the United States Controller were corroborated.
James F. Bishop was appointed by the Excise Commissioners yesterday to be Secretary and chief clerk to the board at a salary of $3,000 a year in place of George H. Gale, removed.

FORT DODGE, Iowa, May 20.--After two weeks' investigation the Webster County Grand Jury failed to indict the seventeen river-land settlers charged with conspiracy by the land owners. The settlers are jubilant and aver that this is their first legal victory, as it is a partial recognition of their rights to work the land from which the evictions have been made.
SARATOGA, N.Y., May 20.--The Circuit Court convened at Ballston this morning, with Justice Frothingham Fish on the bench.

The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church devoted much of its session yesterday to the consideration of the educational and missionary work of the Church among the negroes in the South--a matter considered by many the most important before the General Assembly.

Baptist Sunday schools will have their May anniversary exercises to-day. At the Madison-Avenue Baptist Church, the MadisonAvenue Baptist Sunday school, the First Baptist Sunday school, the Madison-Avenue Mission Sunday school, the Children of the Home...

The Linden Blood Horse Association is having trouble in securing land adjoining their track on which to build barns. It secured fifty-three acres from McCandless at $300 per acre, but Farmer Palmer, who owns land adjoining, refuses to sell his property for less than $600 per acre. Other farmers are holding off for stiff prices, which the association refuses to pay.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20.--The local politicians were a good deal shaken up this afternoon when they heard that Senator M.S. Quay had been here on a secret mission to Boss McManes, and had slipped out of town again before anybody but McManes and one or two newspaper...
FORT WORTH, Texas, May 20.--The committee to invite President Harrison to visit Texas and the Spring Palace in June left here last night for Washington.

In preparation for the recent centennial parade it was ordered, through the Adjutant General's office, by the Commander in Chief of the National Guard that the State service uniform, heretofore permitted to be embellished by the addition of brass shoulder scales, white cross belts, and decorative trimmings of various...
CINCINNATI, May 20.--The Latonia races opened today, the feature of the day's racing being the Latonia Derby at a mile and a half. It was won in the easiest sort of fashion by Hindoocraft.

The Yonkers police made a strong effort to enforce the liquor law on Sunday, and, in order to do it effectually, had the full force out all day, and every one of the 250 saloons was kept under surveillance.

The heavy sea fog that has for the last three days wrapped the Sandy Hook observer in an almost impenetrable cloak of moist mist gave some signs yesterday of lifting. Later on the wind blew in strong from the southeast, and after a few heavy showers of rain the weather became comparatively clear.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 20.--The Democratic State Central Committee will meet in this city to-morrow for the purpose of arranging for the State Convention. Cleveland, Toledo, and Columbus are at work with energy to secure it. The convention will probably he held early in July. Quite a large number of leading Democrats are here to-night, most of whom regard ex-Congressman J.D. Campbell of Butler County as the most available candidate for the Gubernatorial nomination.

The remains of Washington Irving Bishop, the mind reader, who died in the Lambs' Club on Monday afternoon of last week, were interred in Greenwood Cemetery yesterday afternoon. Previous to the interment funeral services were held in Grace Church, the Rev. Dr. Huntington...
The following communication was received yesterday through the mails: CAPE HAYTIEN, Hayti, May 6.--The rumor of a Franco-Haytian alliance has taken substance...

The account which was published last Sunday in THE TIMES of the efforts of M. Theodore Ferrary, the musician, to obtain employment to secure the most ordinary necessaries of life, have occasioned many offers of help. By an error of the types M. Ferrary's address was given wrongly in Sunday's newspaper. It is 438 Sixth-avenue instead of 423, as was given.

DETROIT, May 20.--The will of the late Alexander Folsom of Bay City, Mich., was filed for probate to-day. He leaves various personal bequests; $60,000 to different missionary societies of the Presbyterian Church, $30,000 to Alma College, and $30,000 to the Young Men's Christian Association of Bay City.

LICK OBSERVATORY, Cal., May 20.--The earthquake was felt here at 3:09 yesterday morning. The shock was not heavy, but an extraordinary feature of it was the great duration which is registered on the instruments. For two minutes and twelve seconds the vibrations were felt. They were from north and south.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 20.--A number of NewYork Princeton Alumni have presented to the college a fine portrait of Dr. McCosh by John W. Alexander.

OTTAWA, May 20.--It is said that there are over fifty applications for the American Consulship in the Dominion capital The fight promises to prove very exciting, as the Harrison Adminiatration has decided to create Ottawa a Consulate General for the Province of Ontario.

The American Ticket Brokers' Association will begin its annual convention at the Grand Central Hotel to-morrow morning. The Executive Committee began its work yesterday and settled many claims pending between members and between patrons of members and members with whom they had disputes.
ALBANY, May 20.--The Trustees of the Capitol, Gov. Hill, Lieut. Gov. Jones, and Speaker Cole, will meet on Wednesday to dispose once and for all time of the much-vexed Andrews case.
OTTAWA, Ontario, May 20.--The Canadian Government has received a cablegram from the imperial authoritios stating that work on the Pacific coast defenses will be begun this Summer.

The New-York Indian Association met at President Irving's residence, in West Twentysecond-street, yesterday afternoon. A special committee reported a plan for Summer work. It was adopted and the committee continued with power.

SARANAC LAKE, May 20.--The Spring season is now at its height. Fine weather prevails, and a more delightful Spring could not be desired. The foliage has come out, and the country looks beautiful in its new dress.
Alexander W. Hume, surviving partner in the firm of A.W. T. Hume, merchant tailors at 499 Fifth-avenue, made an assignment yesterday to Asa A. Spear, giving eight preferences aggregating $8,424.
George Whipple, a stock broker, doing business at 74 Broadway, lives with his wife and daughters in a fashionable boarding house kept by the Misses Fisher at 148 Pierrepontstreet, Brooklyn.

SCRANTON, Penn., May 20.--The prohibition war is hotter than the weather in this section of Pennsylvania, and from this time on until the close of the polls on June 18, when the people of the Keystone State will decide for or against the liquor traffic, we may expect to revel in a torrid temperature. The Women's Christian Temperance Union is up and active...

Since Franklin Woodruff was forced from his office as dispenser of Federal patronage in Kings County two weeks ago the local politicians have been discussing the possibility of his resigning his position as President of the Republican General Committee. WINNIPEG, May 20.--Word has just been received here of a ferocious fight which took place near Fort MacLeod last week between Blood Indians on one side and a force composed of soldiers, cowboys, and Gros Ventres on the other. It seems that the bloods have lately been stealing horses from the Gros Ventres, and the latter, assisted by soldiers and cowboys, made an effort to recover the stolen animals.
The Congregational Club of New-York and vicinity held its decennial meeting yesterday afternoon at 5 o'clock in the Assembly Rooms of the Metropolitan Opera House.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 20.--A Times Monroe dispatch says: "The United States mail hack running between Bastrop and Monroe was stopped and robbed a short distance beyond Fouche this evening. The robbers, two white men, stopped the hack, called the driver aside, and carried off all the mail."

JACKSON, Mich., May 20.--Mrs. Oscar Folsom, mother of Mrs. Grover Cleveland, was married here this evening to Mr. Henry E. Perrine, a wealthy gentleman from Buffalo. PITTSBURG, May 20.--Presidents Newell and Oliver of the Pittsburg and Lake Erie Railroads and Vice President McCullough of the Pennsylvania Company's lines west of Pittsburg held a conference to-day with results important to Pittsburg and its chief interest, the iron and steel industry.
WASHINGTON, May 20.--The Secretary of the Treasury to-day purchased $12,850 4 per cent. bonds at 108 flat. Offers of $100,000 fours at 130 flat were rejected

BERLIN, May 20.--The miners who are on strike in Westphalia will resume work to-met-- row, The committee will remain permanently to watch over the interests of the miners, and the strikes will be resumed if the owners fall to keep their promises.
The Special Quarantine Commission, at its meeting in the Mayor's office yesterday, authorized the Treasurer to draw $15,000 from the Controller to apply to the improvements on Hoffman Island.
WASHINGTON, May 20.--The President made the following appointments to-day: Receivers of Public Moneys.--THOMAS B. BUM- GARNER of Arkansas, at Dardanelle, Ark.; HENRY...

The Jewish Ministers' Association of America began its semi-annual conference yesterday in the rooms of the Young Men's Hebrew Association, Lexington-avenue and Fiftyeighth-street.

Secretary of the Navy Tracy appeared in the City Court, Brooklyn, yesterday as counsel for the Atlantic-Avenue Railroad Company in the suit brought by Thomas Holmes for $30,000 for injuries received in an accident. Secretary Tracy will sum up up for the defense.

Mayor Grant has not yet decided to satisfy the anxious politicians and put an end to their predictions by appointing any one to the vacant offices within his disposal. Yesterday was regarded as almost certain to bring forth the chicken from the egg, but it didn't, and so City Hall loungers continue their speculations and exchange them with politicians as sure "tips."

LONG BRANCH, N. J., May 20.--The new Board of Commissioners has organized and re-elected all the old officers with the exception of Street Commissioner and Captain of Police. The strife for the latter office was between J. W. Banford, the presant Captain, and James Layton. After seven ballots the election went over until the next meeting.

At the meeting of the American Baptist Publication Society in Boston yesterday the Hon. Horatio G. Jones, President of the Trustees of the George Nugent Home for Baptists at Germantown, Philadelphia, announced that the home had a foundation or endowment of $300,000 or $400,000, and was ready to receive all Baptist ministers and their wives over sixty years of age. The inmates are supported for life.
BALTIMORE, May 20.--Five men heavily handcuffed arrived here to-day in charge of several Deputy Sheriffs.

FLINT, Mich., May 20.--The stock stables of the Hon. William Hamilton, two miles southeast of this city, were struck by lightning yesterday afternoon, and in a few seconds half a dozen adjoining buildings were in flames. The shock prostrated Mrs. John Nogett, wife of the tenant. She is in a precarious condition.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 20.--While Louis E. Waite and H.A. Howard were riding in a carriage this afternoon from Indian River into the Adirondacks, the team ran away, throwing both gentlemen out. Mr. Waite was killed. Mr. Howard was not seriously injured. Mr. Waite was 50 years old and was one of the most prominent lumber dealers and real estate owners in Glens Falls.

A meeting of the Young Men's Democratic Club was held at the Hoffman House last evening. John H.V. Arnold presided. Among those present were E. Ellery Anderson, David McClure, Judge Leicester Holme, John D. Crimmins, Gen. Egbert L. Viole, Robert Grier Monroe...

The Committee on Arrangements of the Chess congress decided yesterday that Weiss and Mason should play off their last game today, and this will decide whether Weiss or Tschigorin is to have first prize.

The contest between the towns of Frankfort and Marion, Ind., for the general car shops of the Toledo, St. Louis and Kansas City Railroad is extremely spirited. At both points elections were held on Tuesday of last week to vote subsidies to the company as inducements for the location of the shops.
The steamship Ems, from Bremen, reports, May 17, latitude 46 54', longitude 42 , passing an iceberg about 40 feet in height and 150 feet long.

A pleasing dramatic performance was given by amateurs in the art of acting at the Lyceum Theatre last evening for the benefit of the Burnham Industrial Farm, a charitable institution the province of which is the reclamation of truant and vagrant boys. The farm is situated up in Columbia County, near the Connecticut State line.

ANNAPOLIS, May 20.--A Russian man-of-war is expected here Friday afternoon and the naval cadets will tender the officers a hop Friday night. The man-of-war has a number of naval cadets on board training for the Russian Navy.

PATERSON, N.J., May 20.--"Steve" Brodie jumped off the rocks into the basin below the Passaic Falls at 5 o'clock this morning. The distance is about ninety feet. He was clad in red flannel.

Mrs. Annie Keltner reported to the Hoboken police yesterday that her four-year-old child had been abducted. She believed her husband stole the child. They have separated, and she is at her parents' home. While the child was playing in the street, a cab stopped and a man seized the child, entered the vehicle, and was driven rapidly away.

The season of 1889 seems destined to be memorable for the breaking of records by ocean steamships. It was but the other day that the City of Paris broke two in one trip, that of the best day's performance and that of the shortest passage between Queenstown and New-York.

SCRANTON, Penn., May 20.--A destructive storm cloud swooped down on the mountain west of Scranton this afternoon with tremendous force and burst upon the farming settlement of Clark's Summit with great fury.

APIA, Samoa, May 1.--The shipwrecked officers and crews of the Trenton and Vandalia left here on the steamer Rockton to-day for Mare Island Navy Yard. Lieut. Wilson, who arrived on the Rockton April 29, reported that he had found the greatest difficulty in chartering a vessel.

The wedding of Dr. Nestor Ponce de Leon to Miss Pilar Bolet-Monagas was celebrated on Sunday afternoon at the church of St. Francis Xavier. The bridegroom is a son of the editor and lawyer, Nestor Ponce de Leon, and a descendant of the discoverer of Florida.

Three burglars attempted a few minutes before 1 o'clock yesterday morning to rob the Queens County Savings Bank at Flushing, L. I., but were frightened away by the janitor and his wife, who had been awakened by a burglar alarm.

Charles George Wilson, President of the Board of Health from Baltimore, was in the Hoffman House cafe last night, being introduced by Edward S. Stokes to Tammany politicians who have been wondering who he was and what he looked like.

NEW-HAVEN, May 21.--The Hon. E.D. Bassett a resident of this city and until recently Haytian Consul at New-York, is a candidate for the position of United States Minister at Hayti, and his friends in New-England are confident of his appointment.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 21.--Miss Kate Bogart, a teacher in a South Amboy public school, was arrested to-day and placed under bonds by Judge Ford for whipping one of her little pupils, Ruth Grace. The girl's father is a Trustee of the school.

Denominational interest in the Presbyterian General Assembly continues to be exhibited in large audiences at the Fourth-Avenue Church. RED BANK, N.J., May 21.--The last performance of the season in the opera house was given last night. While returning home from the performance the wife of Andrew Naser, a baker, was run over by a carriage and seriously injured. The horse attached to the vehicle knocked her down and the wheels passed over her head.

Frank Templeman, who was arrested last night and is now in a cell at Police Headquarters on a charge of subornation of perjury, is, in the opinion of Inspector Byrnes, the worst rascal that has ever been in his clutches. The belief is natural, for Templeman undertook to induce persons to swear that the Inspector and District Attorney Fellows were joined in a conspiracy with Private Detective James E. Wilkinson to defraud the city.
Members of the New-York Telegraph Club gathered last evening at their new quarters at 48 and 50 Church-street, which they expect to open formally June 1 for their quarterly meeting.

A meeting of the Amateur Athletic Union was held yesterday, when the Brighton Athletic Club was elected to membership, and most of its members, together with the Columbia College tug-ofwar team and several Western athletes, were reinstated.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 21.--A cablegram from London tells of the marriage of Miss Hope Glenn, formerly of Iowa City. The husband is Mr. Richard Hurd of Boston. Sir Arthur Sullivan gave the bride away.

LONDON, May 21.--Mr. William O'Brien testified before the Parnell Commission to-day. He remained seated while giving his evidence and spoke in a weak voice. ALBANY, May 21.--The New-York Rowing Club has filed a certificate at Albany in effect that the Trustees have been reduced from nine to five. These are the present Trustees: R.R. De Florez, H.S. Rokenbaugh, John A. McKim, F.L. Leland.
Many well-known citizens attended the funeral of George J. Forrest, which took place at his residence, 26 West Twenty-first-street, yesterday forenoon.

BISMARCK, Dakota, May 21.--Possible candidates for Governor of North Dakota are beginning to appear. It is whispered about quietly that ex-Speaker Smith Stimmel of Fargo is being put forward by his friends for that high position.

BERLIN, May 21.--Three thousand masons in this city have gone on strike. They demand that their hours of labor be nine per day, and that they be allowed half an hour for breakfast, an hour for dinner, and an hour for supper.
The Pilot Commissioners, at their meeting yesterday, received the reports of Pilots Scott and Hammer two of the suvivors of the pilotboat Charlotte Webb.

Warden John Green of the Kings County Penitentiary will resign in a few days, his resignation to take effect on July 1. The only reason he would give yesterday for his action was that the Charities Board would be Democratic after that date, and then his resignation would be asked for.

BOSTON, May 21.--The remains of Allen Thorndike Rice, late Minister to Russia, were removed from the receiving tomb at Mount Auburn Cemetery at 5 o'clock this evening and placed in their final resting place in the Bourne family tomb.
Collector Erhardt yesterday nominated L.M. Gano of Watkins, N.Y, to be a Deputy Collector, to fill the place of John A. Mason, Secretary of the Civil Service Board at the Custom House.

The trotting races which were to have inaugurated the Spring meeting of the Driving Club of New-York yesterday afternoon were postponed until to-day on account of the threatening condition of the weather.
CHARLESTON, West Va., May 21.--The FlemingGoff Gubernatorial Contest Committee has finished reading deposition from four counties, and thus far Goff has a clear gain of 2.
The celebrated Oaklands herd of Jersey cattle from Valancey E. Fuller's farms at Hamilton, Ontario, were sold at auction in the American Institute Building yesterday.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 21.--Lucius W. Pond, who died in this city to-day, had an eventful life. He was born in Hubbardston April 20, 1826, and came to this city twenty years later.

WASHINGTON, May 21.--Bishop Keane, the rector of the new Catholic University in this city, arrived here this aftertenoon. He was met at the station by delegation of Catholic clergy of the city, who gave a banquet in his honor in the evening at Welsker's Hotel.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 21.--Ambrose Van Tassell, aged forty, dropped dead of heart disease in the hallway of his residence, 1,156 Elizabeth-avenue, this afternoon, while the neighbors were preparing for burial the body of his wife, who died two days ago.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., May 21.--A warrant was issued to-day at the instance of the temperance people of this place for the arrest of twelve citizens who have signed the license application of James C. Parker to keep a hotel. The complaint was drawn under the Inn and Tavern act, and charges that the certificate is false. The temperance people will push the case.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 21.--It is learned on good authority that there is every prospect of negotiations being opened at an early date for a settlemant of the fishery question. This intelligence has created much satisfaction here.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 21.--The Rev. Walter Scott, pastor of the First Baptist Church at Harlem, New-York City, has been offered the Principalship of the Connecticut Literary Institute at Suffield. The institute is the oldest Baptist educational centre in the State.
ALBANY, May 21.--No performance of the Silver Age" was given at Jacobs Proctor's Theatre last night. It was announced that Edwin F. Mayo, the star, was ill, and the tickets were redeemed.

The British steamship James Turpie, which sailed yesterday for Beaufort, N.C., to load cotton for English ports, had an interesting experience on her way to New-York, whither she came from Messina with a cargo of fruit the other day.

The contract between James C. Duff and Henry E. Dixey, under which Mr. Dixey will monopolize most of the time at the Standard Theatre next season, was signed on Monday. Mendel Marks, manufacturer of children's clothing at 431 Broome-street, made an assignment yesterday to Samuel M. Mark's, giving a preference to Johanna Marks for $2,000. The assignor has been in business about a year, claiming a capital of about $5,000.

There was little consolation in yesterday's stock market for the bear contingent. Quotations perversely went upward. And, though doleful prophesies were plenty, there seemed nowhere any prospect of bear relief through disaster.
