BALTIMORE, May 21.--George Appold, President of the Merchants and Miners' Transportation Company, said this morning that the Johns Hopkins, which was burned last night, was worth $200,000 and was insured for $145,000.

The old Board of Police Commissioners of Jersey City yesterday afternoon held the first meeting they have held since the new Police Commissioners succeeded in stealing a march on them. It is said that they propose forming a new police force, and intimations are heard that the board members will make themselves personally responsible for the equipment of the men.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 21.--Prof. Wiggins after nearly a year's investigation announces that the Middle States, espcially Pennsylvania, will be visited by a serious earthquake on Aug. 17, 1904. Planitary conjunctions will prove the cause.

The pupils of the New-York Institution for the Instruction of the Deaf and Dumb gave an exhibition at the Home at Washington Heights yesterday afternoon to the life members, about one hundred in number, who had met for the purpose of electing officers and Directors of the institution.

BERLIN, May 21.--King Humbert, the Crown Prince of Italy, and Signor Crispi, the Italian Prime Minister, arrived in Berlin this morning. They were met at the railway station by Emperor William, the royal Princes, Prince Bismarck, and a number of Generals. After embraces the party drove to the royal castle.

Barnes, the clevar colored light weight, rode three winners and was second in one race at Latonia yesterday. A Brooklyn Anderson, another calored lad, won two races and was second in a third, Reagon also winning two and Taylor and Hayward, Jr., one each.

The big double-turreted monitor Puritan reached the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday afternoon, in tow of the steel cruiser Boston, The Puritan is the largest monitor in the navy, and her tonnage displacement is almost double that of the Boston.

The secret ballot bill now pending in the Connecticut Legislature has been subject to much adverse criticism, some of which seems to us not justified. Franklin Woodruff was very angry yesterday because THE TIMES stated that his own assertion that he was disgusted with the Brooklyn patronage question and thought seriously of resigning had caused surprise among the Republican leaders in Brooklyn.

Mr. Adolph Sutro of San Francisco, a brother of Mr. Otto Sutro of Baltimore, has been visiting this city for the past week. Mr. Sutro is one of the most public-spirited citizens, not only in California, but in this country.

Early trains to Garden City yesterday carried about 200 clergymen and laymen to attend the twenty-third annual convention of the Long Island Diocese of the Protestant Episcopal Church. At the roll call representatives of seventy-two churches out of about one hundred in the diocese, responded, a representation larger than at any former convention in the history of the diocese.

Mr. Jay Gould's fight for the control of the International and Great Northern Railroad goes merrily on. Mr. Gould has had recorded in various counties of Texas the judgment he lately got through a Northern court for $500, 000, representing his claims for "moneys advanced" the road.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 22.--It was little thought when Simeon Coy was prosecuted and convicted of conspiracy to manipulate the tally papers in a Congressional election in this district that Republicans, who were chiefly instrumental in sending him to prison, would aid in setting him free.

ALBANY, May 22.--Superintendent Maxwell had to have a law enacted to get access to the books of the Home Provident Safety Fund Association of the city of New-York. The examination into its affairs, which was subsequently...

The Episcopal service for the dead was conducted yesterday morning at St. Bartholomew's Church, Madison-avenue and Fortyfourth-street, over the body of Peter Carpenter Baker, one of the originators of the Typothetae Union, who died last Sunday.
ELIZABETH, N.J., May 22.--Mrs. Emily Vivar, who brought a suit against the Supreme Lodge, Knights of Pythias, for her dead husband's insurance policy of $3,000, to-day obtained a...
MINNEAPOLIS, May 22.--The Market Record says the most critical period in the Winter wheat crop has been passed.
Perfect weather, an excellent track, and a good attendance were the propitious characteristics of the opening day of the Spring meeting of the Driving Club of New-York yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 22.--Kings County is here to-night in force. It came, appropriately enough, in a storm, for it proposes to take the President by storm to-morrow, and not to stop storming until there is no loner any doubt of securing the appointment of Mr. Theodore B. Willis as Surveyor of the Port of New-York.

ELIZABETH, May 22.--The event of the day here has been the arrangement in the Union County Court of Gen. J. Madison Drake against whom three indictments for criminal libel have been found by the Grand Jury.

The Park Commissioners had one of the longest sessions of the year yesterday and disposed of many matters. They omitted to elect a President, however, and J. Hampden Robb is sure of at least another week's salary in that office.

A bad effect on the health of jurors in the Court of General Sessions seems to be produced by the trial of the Electric Sugar Refining case. When the court adjourned on Tuesday afternoon twelve jurors had been secured by two days' hard work, but yesterday morning J. Wilson Gordon, who had been sworn in as the ninth juror, came into court armed...

The Catholic News has received a cablegram announcing that the Pope has fixed Friday as the date of the secret consistory at which the new Cardinals will be named. Bishop Wigger of Newark is in Rome with his health restored. He leaves there to-morrow to join Bishop Rademacher at Lucerne.

MADISON, Wis., May 22.--Confirmation of what has been said regarding the condition of the State Treasury comes from the management of the Wisconsin Veterans' Home at Waupaca. Though the Legislature appropriated $50,000 for permanent improvements at the home, and though the warrant has been drawn for the same and signed by the Secretary of...

ALBANY, May 22.--The report of the Supervising Commission--Lieut. Gov. Jones, Senator Fassett, Speaker Cole, and Capitol Commissioner Perry--of the Capitol appointed under Chapter 578, Laws of 1888, has been made. The work, the report says, has proceeded with as large a force of men and as rapidly as consitent with strict economy.
BERLIN, May 22.--Contrary to expectations, there was no difficulty encountered during the deliberations of the Samoan Conference to-day.

Yesterday Mayor GRANT made seven appointments to office, including those of three additional Police Justices. Taken as a whole, they are neither very bad nor very good, but with the exception of that of Mr. TAINTOR they are strictly Tammany appointments. To succeed Police Commissioner STEPHEN B. FRENCH the Mayor...
Shortly after 5 o'clock yesterday morning the home of A. Belamont Purdy, about a mile east of Hempstead, L.I., was discovered to be on fire.

PITTSBURG, May 22.--In the Edison-Westinghouse electric light case to-day the presence of Mr. Edison added to the interest. He sat with his attorneys and watched the proceedings very closely. Mr. Westinghouse was also in the court room during a greater portion of the day. Attorney Lowry opened the case for the defense.

The pile of railway ties and sleepers which the Fourth-Avenue Railway Company has placed at the lower end of the Fourth-avenue tunnel as its contribution to the poor of the city was still a big one yesterday, notwithstanding...

The love of a lively row is not a new trait of the followers of Calvin, and it was therefore only natural that the Fourth Presbyterian Church was filled to its utmost capacity with commissioners and spectators yesterday afternoon when the debate over the attack on the Board of Missions among the freedmen came on for hearing.

ALBANY, May 22.--Dr. Henry E. Allison, first assistant at Willard Asylum since 1878, was appointed Medical Superintendent of the NewYork State Asylum for Insane Criminals at Auburn by Superintendent of Prisons Lathrop today. Dr. Allison succeeds Dr. Carlos F. Macdonald, who has been appointed on the new...
ST. PAUL, May 22.--The English brewing syndicate passed through St. Paul about two weeks ago, and it leaked out to-day that they made overtures to the brewers here for their property.

BERLIN, May 22.--In consequence of the nonacceptance by the owners of the strikers' Germs, the Gelsenkirchen miners met to-day and resolved to continue the strike. The majority of the strikers at Dortmund have resumed work. Deputy Hammacher is trying to arrange a settlement with the men still out. Fielscher's spinners at Reichenbach are on strike.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 22.--A special election was held yesterday in the Fourth Congressional District to elect a successor to the Hon. Thomas Ryan, who was recently appointed Minister to Mexico. Gen. Harrison Kelly, the Republican nominee, who is a farmer, was elected without opposition.
HARTFORD, May 22.--The Connecticut Senate to-day refused by a vote of 20 to 4 to grant the petition of the Housatonic Railroad for leave to build a parallel road from New-Haven to New-York.

Changes have been made in the arrangements for the professional regatta to take place at Garfield Reach, Salt Lake City, Utah, June 8 and 9. June 8 the double scull race will be rowed for prizes as follows: First prize, $1,800; second prize, $900; third prize, $500; fourth prize, $300.

LONDON, May 22.--Mr. William O'Brien continued his testimony before the Parnell Commission to-day. He denied that he had ever published in United Ireland articles inciting to outrage. The League, he said, was founded chiefly to oppose secret landlord combinations.
Application was made to Judge Moore, in the Sessions Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, for the removal of George W. Devlin, the assignee of John E. Murray, a furniture dealer, who failed...
The fund for the Washington memorial arch was increased yesterday by contributions amounting to $2,299.45.

Capt. Le Fagan, Marine Corps, has been detached from the League Island Navy Yark, to take effect June 1, and ordered to duty at the Marine Barracks, Boston, relieving First Lieut. W.F. Spicer, detached and ordered to the Marine Barracks, Norfolk.
The price of coal went up yesterday. The big sales agents met in the office of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company, and decided upon the advance without much dispute.

LONDON, May 22.--The remarkable enthusiasm shown in Berlin in the reception of King Humbert, which transcends anything ever seen there before, is taken to indicate how thoroughly the German people realize the importance of an Italian alliance. As I said a fortnight ago, this alliance has of late been distinctly shaky.

NEW-HAVEN, May 22.--The agitation caused by the departure of Prof. Russell from the Yale Divinity School has not yet diminished, and on the authority of members of the graduating class it is stated that many of the advanced students will not return to college unless he be reinstated.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 22.--Capt. James W. Banford was elected Captain of Police by the Board of Commissioners here last night. Only one ballot was taken, the vote standing 4 to 3.

BERLIN, May 22.--There was a parade of the Berlin and Spandau garrisons to-day in honor of King Humbert. The troops were reviewed by Emperor William and the King. At luncheon in the palace, the Emperor proposed a teast to King Humbert.

In the inquiry as to the state of affairs at the Chicago Insane Asylum yesterday Dr. Clevenger, formely a member of the medical staff there, testified that it was impossible for a reputable practitioner or attendant to stay there. The most disreputable ones were the ones to stay, because they devoted more time to intrigue. Boodleism controlled the management of the institution.
WASHINGTON, May 22.--The Secretary of the Treasury to-day purchased $241,000 four and a half pet cents. at 108 flat.

Big, robust Capt. Anson and his aroundthe-world combination made their appearance at St. George yesterday bent on taking a ball from the Giants. They felt confident of success until they saw genial Timothy Keefe, the king of curvers, walk into the box. His presence sent a chill through the big Captain, for he knew from experience that the New-Yorkers,...
There is a little dissatisfaction in the General Executive Committee of the Germans who took part in the centennial industrial parade over a deficiency of about $3,500 in the accounts.
LANSING, Mich., May 22.--Based upon resolutions adopted by the Live Stock Sanitary Committee, the Governor has issued a proclamation...
The Hamburg-American American Packet Company's new twin-screw steamship Augusta Victoria will sail from this port at 1. P.M. to-day on her first eastward trip across the Atlantic.

A bitter cold wind blew across the grounds of the Brooklyn Jockey Club track yesterday afternoon. The track was heavy and rather holding, as a result of the rainy weather of the past few days, and the time in the six races run was decidedly slow in consequence.

Frank Templeman, who got himself into trouble by making charges against Inspector Byrnes and District Attorney Fellows in connection with Detective Wilkinson's bill against the city for services, was arraigned before Recorder Smyth in the Court of General Sessions yesterday morning.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 22.--The names of the honor men were announced at Rutgers College to-day. They are as follows:

HALIFAX, N.S., May 22.--Advices from St. Pierre, Miquelon, state that two fishing vessels, the Ella and Quartre Freres, which left France some time ago for the Newfoundland fisheries, with 175 men on board, have been lost and that all hands have doubtless been drowned.

CHICAGO, May 22.--The dead body of Dr. P. H. Cronin, the Irish-American who strangely disappeared from his home in Chicago two weeks ago, was found this evening some distance north of the city in a sewer on Evanston-avenue. A bloody towel was wrapped about the head.

Staten Islanders are becoming outspoken in their opinion of the bungling methods pursued by the officials who are investigating the mysterious death of Miss Mary E. Tobin. Coroner Hughes and his jury have held four sessions at Rosebank and are apparently no nearer a solution of the case than they ever were.

ST. PAUL, May 22.--The trouble among transcontinental roads is likely to develop into a serious outbreak should the persistency of the Union Pacific in invading the territory of the northern routes compel the Northern Pacific to withdraw from the association.

At the meeeting of the Newark Episcopal Diocesan Convention in Newark yesterday the Rev. Robert N. Merritt of Morristown, W.W. Holly of Hackensack, W.R. Jenvy of Hoboken, and N. Barrows of Short Hills, and Messrs. E. A. Stevens of Hoboken, F.W. Stevens of Newark, Henry Hayes of Newark, and E.A. Walton...
LONDON, May 23.--Lord Dunraven's yacht Valkyrie sailed her maiden match to-day. She was first home, but was beaten on time allowance.

The Inman Steamship Company can now congratulate itself that it has in the steamship City of Paris a real ocean greyhound. Cablegrams were received at the company's office in this city yesterday announcing that she had crossed the Atlantic, from Sandy Hook to Queenstown, in 6 days and 29 minutes, reckoning time from Sandy Hook to Roche's...

NEWARK, N.J., May 23.--The brewery of George W. Wiedenmayer has been sold to the syndicate which purchased the other Newark breweries. The price said to have been paid is $250,000. Other important purchases will be announced in a few days.
The village of New-Rochelle is stirred up over a row which took place on Wednesday afternoon between two prominent citizens and members of the Baptist Church.
The convention of the American Ticket Brokers' Association finished its business yesterday afternoon and adjourned to meet next year at Indianapolis.
Treasurer William B. Stewart acknowledges the receipt yesterday of additional subscriptions to the memorial arch fund, amounting to $1,083 25.

Senator FARWELL of Illinois is reported as saying that the President will call no extra session of Congress. Senator PLUMB of Kansas, on the other hand, is reported to have declared that an extra session would surely be called for October. Although Mr. FARWELL'S relations with the President ...

The testimony of Mr. O'BRIEN is by far the frankest statement of the Irish cause that has been made to the Parnell Commission. With the exception of the self-exposure of PIGOTT, it is the most interesting of the proceedings had before that body, and without exception it is the most valuable testimony taken.

The northward and westerly wind of yesterday made it so unsafe for the numerous small craft anchored along the main anchorages that before noon one and all ran for shelter. Outside on the Communipaw flats and in the neighborhood of the Staten Island anchorages some of the brick and wood schooners were putting their noses under with every sea and threatening to drag at any moment.
Corporation Counsel William H. Clark said yesterday that he knew of no reason why he should make any changes in the present staff of assistants.

Every wholesale dry goods house of consequence in the country was represented by a buyer yesterday at the trade sale of domestic colored cotton goods made by order of Bliss, Fabyan Co. of this city, selling agents for the Otis Company, Columbian Manufacturing Company, Thorndike Company, Warren Cotton Mills, Boston Duck Company, and Cordis Mills.

J.H. Mayo, a homeopathic physician at Randolph, Vt., was arrested yesterday for forging a note for $100 on Joseph Gould, a manufacturer of Gouldsville, Vt., and obtaining $30 thereon from the Randolph Savings Bank.

Fraternal co-operation in Christian work was the uppermost subject with the Presbyterian General Assembly yesterday. The galleries of the Fourth-Avenue Church, the only part open to visitors, were thronged most of the day, but principally during the afternoon, when the debate upon the report from the Committee of Conference on Fraternal Co-operation in Christian Work, was in progress.
CHICAGO, May 23.--Before Judge Tuley to-day Kennedy R. Owen secured an injunction against the Board of Trade and the Western Union and Gold and Stock Telegraph Companies.

On the 30th of November, 1887, an expedition sailed from this port aboard the steamship Hondo to survey and locate the route of an interoceanic canal across the territory of the Republic of Nicaragua. The Hon. William McKinley of Ohio will deliver the oration at the Metropolitan Opera House on the evening of Decoration Day. Rose Coghlan, Henry E. Dixey, Thomas W. Keene, and Miss Gertie Boswell will read, and the Bank Clerks' Glee Club of sixty voices and Miss Dora Wiley and Signor Battastime will sing. Mayor Grant will preside and the Rev. Dr. Paxton will officiate as Chaplain.
The incorporation of the Pittsburg, Beech Creek and Eastern Railroad completes plans which have long been under consideration by a syndicate of Eastern financiers for another line from Pittsburg ...
DENVER, Col., May 23.--S.J. Ranney, an attache of the imperial household of Russia, has been in the city the past few days.
An interesting outcome of the new charter conflict in Jersey City will probably be the organization of a new Democratic County Committee.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 23.--The third annual meeting of the New-England Intercollegiate Athletic Association took place at the fair grounds in this city this afternoon in the presence of about a thousand people.

Delmonico's banquet hall was full of railroad men and enthusiasm last night. It was the occasion of the dinner of the New York Railroad Club, and over one hundred gentlemen availed themselves of the opportunity to attend.
ST. PAUL, May 23.--The country reports show considerable wheat moving. Elevator companies that were getting only 100 to 500 bushels a day are getting 1,000 to 10,000 bushels.
Judge Truax, in the Superior Court, yesterday vacated, as to the city, a judgment entered in 1876 against it and the City Central Underground Railway Company.

Henry Tydeman, who took passage on the steamship City of New-York at Queenstown for this city on her last trip, committed suicide by jumping overboard on the morning of Friday, May 17. Tydeman had no friends or relatives on board. He had entered as a second cabin passenger, and had been noticed from the first as of a melancholy and unsociable disposition. An unsuccessful attempt was made to recover his body.

BERLIN, May 23.--Emperor William, King Humbert, the Crown Prince of Italy, and Signor Crispi, the Italian Prime Minister, attended a gala performance at the Opera House last night. The opera produced was Meyerbeer's "Camp in Silesia." It was followed by a new ballet by Italian dancers.

If there is anything a fly-casting angler detests it is a gusty wind, which plays havoc with the flies and leaders and whirls them anywhere but the right place. Just such a wind blew over the usually placid waters of Harlem Mere yesterday, stirring up little waves and waiting quantities of green leaves over the lake.

William H. Cotterill, the President of the Electric Sugar Refining Company, was upon the witness stand in the trial of the Rev. William E. Howard when Part I of the Court of General Sessions was adjourned yesterday afternoon. AUBURN, N.Y., May 23.--Charles F. Durston, Agent and Warden of Auburn Prison, who has been attending a meeting of prison officials at Albany, said to-day that he thought Gov. Hill would sign the Fassett Prison bill.

The gray-coated park police had their annual parade and review on the Mall in Central Park yesterday morning under the eyes of President of the Park Board J. Hampden Robb, Commissioner Towie, a hundred invited guests, and an unlimited number of nurse girls and children.

NEWARK, N.J., May 23.--Robert Lyon, a fifteen-year-old boy, committed suicide at his home in Lafayette-street this afternoon. He had some words last evening with William Freeman, his stepfather. This afternoon he went to his room. A minute later his sister heard a pistol report, and dashing up stairs found the little fellow lying dead on the floor.
The Coaching Club will hold their annual parade to-morrow afternoon at 5 o'clook. The meet will be in Central Park in the crossroad ...
A general court-martial has been ordered to meet at West Point to-day for the trial of such persons as may be brought before it.

All the members of the North New-York Congregational Church and a number of their friends met last evening in their place of worship, 2,661 Third-avenue, to act on the expected resignation of their pastor, the Rev. John F. Hooper.
BALTIMORE, May 23.--A week ago the gambling houses of this city, of which there are many, received intimations that the Grand Jury would investigate them.
ITHACA, May 23.--It is the habit of Henry W. Sage, one of Ithaca's millionaires, who has given more to Cornell University than any other man, to keep his princely deeds secret.

Superintendent Murray and Inspector Steers made an investigation yesterday of the disgraceful affray which occurred Wednesday in the Prince-street police station between Sergts. Myron Allen and Cornelius Weston of the Eighth Precinct.
AUBURN, N.Y., May 23.--The Rev. A. Walker, colored, pastor of Zion African Methodist Episcopal Church, went to the York (Penn.) Conference by order of the Bishop a week ago Monday.

AUBURN, N.Y., May 23.--Dr. Carlos T. Macdonald, Superintendent of the State Asylum for Insane Criminals, has accepted the appointment of President of the new State Commission in Lunacy, and yesterday subscribed to the oath of office at Albany.

Weather that could not have been more delightful and a track that could not have been nearer perfection were two of the prime conditions that resulted in the success of the second day of the Spring trotting meeting of the Driving Club of New-York.

George B. Plumer, ex-chief engineer of the Haytian man-of-war Dessalines, returned from Port au Prince, Hayti, a day or two ago, by the way of Charleston, S.C. with him were Engineers Graham, Hughes, and Carroll, the four being part of the contingent of eighteen officers who were sent by Minister Preston to Hayti on the Atlas Line steamer Andes on March 9.

Yesterday was another day of bear distresses. Stocks were in a mood for going up, and they went. The Grangers led, St. Paul common and St. Paul preferred carrying the bull banner, closely pressed by the rest of the list.

Surrogate Rastus S. Ransom recently procured the passage by the Legislature, and the approval by his old crony, David B. Hill, of a bill increasing the salary of the Surrogate from $12,000 to $15,000.

New-York's aggregation of Giants bowed to the superiority of Anson's around-the-world combination at St. George yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, May 23.--Lord Durham and Sir George Chetwynd informed the Jockey Club at a meeting held yesterday that they had effected a settlement of the suit for libel brought by the latter against the former in connection with turf scandals. The club objected to the settlement and postponed consideration of the subject until a special meeting to be held next ...

The Kings County Supervisors yesterday took hold of the case of Michael J. Bourke, the Tax Collector of New-Lots, who confessed that he was $26,000 short in his accounts, and took action that may make it warm for Bourke.

The annual meeting of the associate members of the Brooklyn Institute was held last evening in the institute building in Washington-street, Brooklyn. Gen. John B. Woodward presided and congratulated the association that the bill for a new site for the institute on the east side lands had passed and was now in the hands of the Governor.

The Fourteenth Regiment celebrated the twenty-eighth anniversary of its mustering into service last evening in the armory, at Portlandavenue and Auburn-place, Brooklyn, by holding a dress parade and passing in review before Brig. Gen. McLeer.

The Shakespeare Society of New-York has been in existence for four years or so without making, until lately, any particular impression, good or bad, on the social or literary life of the metropolis. Recently, however, the society has come prominently into notice.

The Senior class of Smith College, at Northampton, Mass., is going to do a Greek play. The "Electra" of Sophocles, recently done here in English by Mr. Sargent's pupils, has been chosen as the play best adapted for representation by young women alone. The special study of the play has been going on for a year. Two performances will be given, June 11 and June 15.

The World's Exposition at Paris is attracting widespread attention all over the globe. The stream of travelers to the brilliant French capital is enormous and seems to be on the increase, to the delight of the Paris hotel keepers and tradesmen.
ST. PAUL, May 23.--The position taken by the Central Traffic Association with regard to lake and rail rates is expected to result in granting the Duluth lines a differential rate.

The Tidewater Oil Company's paraffine wax factory at Constable Hook, N.J., was destroyed by the yesterday afternoon, entailing heavy loss. About 3:30 o'clock three explosions were heard in rapid succession.

City Superintendent of Schools Jasper has been approached by a philanthropic gentleman, who is averse to the publication of his name, but who desires to assist poor boys of the public schools of this city to obtain a collegiate education. TACOMA, Washington, May 23.--Twenty or thirty years ago Robert Shields, then a comparatively young man, acquired a homestead on the banks of the Missouri River, on the site where the city of Omaha now stands.

WASHINGTON, May 23.--The delegation of Brooklyn Republicans who think it is high time that the Federal offices which are to go to Kings County should be distributed, and who came down to Washington last night to say so to the President, have spent a pretty busy day at the capital. Since breakfast this morning they have seen and talked with Boss Thomas ...
The second game of chess between Tschigorin and Weiss for first prize and the championship was played off yesterday, and again resulted in a draw.

Gustave Amberg's Summer season at Terrace Garden, Third-avenue and Fifty-eighthstreet, began last night with a performance of the operetta "Farinelli," libretto by W. Wolff and Charles Cassmann, music by H. Zumpe.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23.--The Norwegian bark Patriot was struck by a squall early this morning. While anchored just outside the Delaware Breakwater her cables parted and she was dashed with terrific force against the stone wall of the breakwater, crushing in her side, and she sank almost instantly. Fortunately her crew were able to scramble upon the stonework, and all hands were saved.

Yachtsmen were absorbed yesterday with the news of the maiden race of the Valkyrie, the Earl of Dunraven's new cutter, which was sailed Wednesday on the Thames, in the race of the New Thames Yacht Club of London. The result of the race confirmed the general opinion among yachting men here that the Valkyrie is not only a good sized boat, but a powerful one, ...

The leading members of the Bar of NewYork and Brooklyn will sit down to a notable banquet to-night at Delmonico's to do honor to the Hon. Benjamin D. Silliman in commemorating the sixtieth anniversary of his admission to the bar at the May Term of the year 1829.

There are two city lots in the Twelfth Ward with something of a history. They are between One Hundred and Twenty-ninth and One Hundred and Thirtieth streets and Sixth and Seventh avenues. They were in 1827 part of the Charles Henry Hall estate. In 1835 the lots were owned by Joel L. Evans.

A spectacular entertainment, arranged by Carl Marwig and under the management of Mr. A.B. De Frece, was given last evening at the Metropolitan Opera House in aid of the Teachers' Mutual Benefit Association of the City of New-York.

Stone Cliff, the country residence of Frederick J. Stone, a nephew of Cyrus W. Field, about a mile and a half back of Dobbs Ferry, was entered by burglars early yesterday morning. It is surmised from their character that they were inflicted while he was bending over the bed of a person feigning sickness, who had been used to lure him ...

A strong and evidently combined effort is being made to create the impression that there is plenty of money in the State Treasury. This will be an extra day at the Brooklyn track, there being six races as usual, with entries that bid fair to furnish good sport. The entries are as follows:
The croquet grounds at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, were bedecked and encircled with flags yesterday to celebrate the opening of the spring games of the Brooklyn Croquet Association.

Judge Beach, in the Supreme Court, yesterday dismissed the complaint in the suit of Edward H. O'Brien and D.J. Murphy against the Live Stock Association of New-York and New-Jersey, (Limited,) thus allowing the case to be taken on exceptions, in the first instance, to the General Term.

PITTSBURG, May 23.--Arguments in the Edison-Westinghouse electric light suit was concluded to-day. Mr. Amos Broadnax began this morning on the Westinghouse side, and contended that the one new thing in all the lamps was the fibrous conductor, and that was theirs.

STANDING ROCK, Dakota, May 23.--As to the Indians signing the treaty under the new terms there seems to be a wide difference of opinion.

LONDON, May 23.--Before the Parnell Commission to-day the cross-examination of Mr. William O'Brien was continued by Attorney General Webster. Mr. O'Brien declared that United Ireland, his paper, worked according to constitutional methods, and advocated nothing but peaceful means to attain the end sought by the Irish Parliamentary Party.
The progress of the movement for opening to settlement a half of the great Sioux Reservation in Dakota indicates that we shall soon see a rush in that quarter like the one of a month ago in Oklahoma.
Congressman James Kerr of Pennsylvania was at Castle Garden yesterday watching the tide of immigrants which was coming in with unusual rapidity.

Miss Rosina Vokes will change her bill at Daly's next Monday night, so that those persons who have not yet heard Florence Marigold sing the song of the whale, or witnessed the tabulations of Spiggott the butler and his young mistress in "My Lord in Livery," will have to make haste.

William Quackenbush, said to be at the time of his death the oldest resident of this city, died at his home, 153 Perry-street, yesterday, in the ninety-third year of his age. Mr. Quackenbush came from an old Holland Dutch family, and was born at Hempstead, in what is now Rockland County, this State, in the year 1797.

WHITINGS, N.J., May 23.--Edward Rowe, a farmer living at Shamong, was found dead this morning on the road that leads from Paisley to the former place. He went to Paisley yesterday, and on his return was kicked to death by his horse. He was about fifty-five years of age.

A man who is chosen to be Mayor of the city of New-York cannot serve two masters, and he may as well choose at once which he will serve. He cannot serve the cause of good municipal government and that of a political machine at the same time.

Mrs. Mary I. Neilson, the sister of Frederick Gebhard, who is being sued in the Supreme Court, before Judge Andrews and a jury, for $25,000 damages by Mrs. Martha Ferguson of Newport, R.I., was on the stand in her own behalf yesterday.

ROCHESTER, May 23.--The witnesses examined in the Faulkner trial to-day seem to have been called with special reference to the mysterious disappearance of the books of the bank, which the Government seeks to show were burned in an alleged "coon hunt" when a certain barn appears to have been set on fire and destroyed.

FARMINGDALE, N.J, May 23.--A few weeks ago Benjamin Hulick, a farmer living near this place, set out a peach and apple orchard. Mr. Hulick went out into the orchard a few mornings afterward and discovered that all of his trees had disappeared during the night. He made an investigation, which resulted in his finding the trees on the land of a person livivg some distance away. The trees have all been returned.

The suit of Mrs. Emma L. Eames for absolute divorce from Frank M. Eames, which has occupied the attention of Justice Culien and a jury, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, since Monday, ended yesterday in a verdict for the plaintiff. The jury was out about an hour. It was the second trial of the case, the first resulting in a disagreement.
LONDON, May 24.--The White Star Line steamship Britannic, Capt. Parseli, from New-York May 15, arr. here at 5:30 P.M. yesterday.

The Legislature authorized the Brooklyn Aldermen to spend $25,000 on the recent centennial celebration, and the money was placed in the hands of Aldermen McKee, McCarty, Board, Schlusser, and Murphy. They spent it lavishly, and yesterday it leaked out that they had gone in debt to the extent of something like $4,428.

A.E. Ayer Co., stockbrokers, at Worcester, Mass., have made an assignment to C.C. Potter. The liabilities are $50,000 and the assets $65,000. The company had branch offices in Boston, Fitchburg, Clinton, and South Norwalk, Conn. The cause is said to be the failure of the Public Grain and Stock Exchange in New-York last year, followed by dull business.

LONDON, May 23.--Mr. Robert T. Lincoln, the new American Minister, has taken up his residence at 5 Cadogan-square. Mr. Henry White of the American Legation presented Mr. Lincoln to Lord Salisbury at the Foreign Office today.

Grand Marshal Henry W. Knight, who will have charge of the Decoration Day parade in Brooklyn, announced his official programme yesterday, and stated positively that President Harrison would review the line from a grand stand to be erected at Washington Park.

It is doubtful whether the Thirteenth Regiment of Brooklyn will make its contemplated trip to Minneapolis in August. All endeavors to secure a reasonable rate from the railroads running from Chicago to Minnesota have proved futile.

LONDON, May 24.--The yachts Valkyrie, Yarana, and Irex sailed another race to-day. The finish was made with a good southeast breeze, after a splendid race. The Valkyrie again proved the winner, her time being 5:06:20. The Yarana was second, in 5:13:22, and the Irez third, in 5:14:10.

GRAND FORKS, Dakota, May 24.--There was a heavy white frost here last night. In this immediate vicinity it did no harm to garden vegetables, but information from points west say that the farmers fear the frost will prove a set-back to the crops now so well advanced.
